fields.headline: Ferguson welcomes foundation stone
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy is the latest star striker to kick-start a Manchester United rebuilding process.
fields.body:
It was a special day, as Sir Alex Ferguson observed, for Manchester United and for Ruud van Nistelrooy. "Particularly for Ruud," he added, turning his eyes towards the dark-haired young man sitting at his right hand, the blandness of his tone failing to disguise the meaning of his qualification.

In all his 24 years, Van Nistelrooy has certainly never known such an occasion as yesterday's Old Trafford press conference to announce his arrival, on July 1, as the club's latest star striker. His £19m transfer from PSV Eindhoven, the most expensive in the history of English football, will tie him to Manchester United for the next five years, representing the prime of a career that he must have feared had reached a premature conclusion a year ago, when he collapsed during a training session with a serious knee injury.

For Manchester United, on the other hand, such days are nothing new. In August 1958, rebuilding his team after the Munich disaster, Matt Busby paid Sheffield Wednesday a British-record fee of £45,000 for Albert Quixall, a dashing goalscorer. Four years later he set another record by bringing Denis Law back from Torino for £115,000. Since then the story of Manchester United has been studded with the arrivals of expensive strikers.

Some of the glittering acquisitions, such as Joe Jordan and Andy Cole, have been unqualified successes in the red shirt. Others, including Ted McDougall and Garry Birtles, have endured prolonged public humiliations. But a period of adjustment is always necessary, particularly when, like Van Nistelrooy, the player comes from a different football culture.

"The initial few weeks will be frenetic for him," Sir Alex predicted. "He'll take a while to get used to the speed of the game from one end of the pitch to the other in the Premier League. But he'll adjust. They always do."

Although Van Nistelrooy will see out the remainder of the season at PSV, with whom he hopes to complete the Dutch league and cup double, he provided a preface to his United career yesterday with a self-assured performance in front of the British media. "The expectations will be high, from everybody around me," he acknowledged. "But my personal expectations are even higher, so that's no problem."

As a boy, he continued, the great Old Trafford sides of the past had not figured among the posters on his bedroom wall, where pride of place went to Marco van Basten and Diego Maradona - "Remember, in 1986 I was 10 years old." But he was certainly an admirer. "Lots of players dream of playing for this club,"' he said, "and for me it's the same. In the last few years they have won so many trophies, and always with good football. In every position they have players who are special, and for me it's nice to be able to play and train with them."

Invited to estimate the number of goals he will score in his first season, bearing in mind the size of his transfer fee, he declined with a smile. "You mean how many pounds per goal? No, I have my own thoughts about how many goals and at the end of the season I will tell you if they came true."

But confidence, he believes, will not be a problem. "When a big club like this one pays so much money, it means they have confidence in you. So that gives me confidence, too. I don't feel it's a pressure. It lifts me up."

He had never doubted that he would end up at Manchester United, even during the darkest hours of his rehabilitation, and repeated his gratitude to Sir Alex for staying in touch during a long year. "That was very special for me. We talked a lot about people who had the same injury. When you have support like that, it gives you a good feeling."

For Ferguson, the player's country of origin provided a reassurance. "I think the Dutch football mentality is one of quality," he said. "That's what they concentrate on, so anyone who comes from there to a club like ours has had a very good preparation. Ruud has a very good understanding of the game, and he has a presence on field, which is important at a club like ours."

Although Old Trafford is accustomed to such events, there is a sense that this week's signing has a special significance in terms of the club's evolution. Van Nistelrooy's arrival was planned long before Roy Keane voiced his criticisms of the squad this week, but such an investment in talent signals the club's intention to mark the last of Ferguson's 16 seasons in charge by recapturing the European Cup, nowadays the true focus of their efforts.

Invited to comment yesterday on the need to "'freshen things up"' within the club, Sir Alex gave a characteristically testy reply: "I'm not going into that." But it would be no surprise if the coming weeks saw an additional capture to parallel that almost 40 years ago of Pat Crerand, who arrived from Celtic in the same summer as Denis Law, costing less than half the money but going on to exert just as profound an effect on the glittering team of the mid-60s. A midfield passer of the Crerand type, in partnership with the aggressive instincts of Roy Keane, would give United's play a dimension it has lacked since Eric Cantona's departure.

Kieron Dyer and Rivaldo have been among the names aired in this connection, along with the suggestion that their arrival might involve the departure of David Beckham. But given Van Nistelrooy's strength in the air, and the manager's belief that his strengths include the ability to score goals in a variety of ways, it seems unlikely that Ferguson would consider parting with the best crosser of the ball in the English game.

"I think Ruud will develop into something we haven't had before," Ferguson concluded. He was not worried about the "missing" year - "It could even be a good thing," he said, "because they're usually better at 24 than 23" - but he revealed that Van Nistelrooy could have been a United player even earlier.

Darren Ferguson, his son and a former United player, was a team-mate of Van Nistelrooy's at Heerenveen in 1998. "He rang me and said, 'This boy's fantastic. Come and get him right away.' We sent someone over, but PSV signed him the very next day. We were too slow. But he's here now, and that's the point."

fields.headline: Twelve steps to another thumping headache
fields.trailText: Ron's on the wagon Twelve steps to another thumping headache.
fields.body:
"Look ... look Ron! ... He's put his foot in the cat tray! ... Ooh! ... hee hee! ... he's pulled the radiator off the wall!" ... bloomin' heck ... Mrs Manager's watching Lee Evans ... marvellous hmm ... isn't it? ... "he's set his trousers on fire! ... hee hee hee!" ... a far cry from the reaction I got on my return from er ... Ron's lost weekend ... the seat of my best slacks scorched from my ill-advised demonstration of the combustible properties of methane ...

So out to the potting shed with Tony Adams's hard-hitting autobiography ... "Addicted"... ho ho! ... every day's his cup final! what a read! couldn't put it down! ... hooked! ... that very night, I resolved to confront my demons head-on! ... Ho ho! ... Ron's off the pop! marvellous isn't it? ... and decided to keep a diary detailing my long journey back from the abyss ... maybe there's a book in it! and the minute I put pen to paper it was as if I'd thrown off my ball and chain! or as Californian "rockers" the Eagles would say ... "loosened my load" ... look out for it in your stocking at Christmas! ...

Tuesday Fired with enthusiasm after my first AA meeting ... and with Tony's proposed "sanctuary" in mind ... I've converted the potting shed into Ron's Pop-In! ... and blow me! ... just as I'm banging up the sign ... my first visitor! ... Harvey! ... from my AA group! ... cordial greetings ... hmm? ... "Hello, I'm Ron ... er I'm an alcoholic er ... marvellous ..." and immediately we're engaged in fierce intellectual debate ... there's more to life than football you know! ... er ... "Acknowledge the higher power!'"hmm? "Bacchus!" ... isn't it? ... and blow me! ... from out of nowhere ... there's two bottles of "Concorde" on the trestle table ... and we've settled down for a dip into my bumper postbag! ...

So ... a reader's letter! ... a Mr W Hague writes: "Ron, if it wasn't for all the foreigners in the Premiership, bringing down the level of competition, Manchester Utd would have won the Champions League! - I can drink 14 pints you know."

Well ... nothing clever about that ... but are the mighty Reds a club in crisis? ... do they need fresh blood at Old Trafford? ... Roy Keane seems to think so ... bit of niggle with Haaland there? ... hmm? ... Sir Alex hasn't seen a thing! ... Well any manager worth his salt puts up the defensive shield ... ho ho! ... down at Yeovil they still know me as "the Buffer"!

But crisis? ... what crisis! so Fergie forked out a fat fee for fi er fum? where was I? Yes the boy Van Nistelrooy! but mention "panic-buying" hmm? Sir Alex would do his pieces! ... so would Mrs Manager! still hasn't forgotten coming home to a freezer-full of brisket on the day the foot and-mouth crisis broke! can't give the stuff away!

Ho ho ... I could rabbit on all night! ... just opening a third bottle ... I've turned to Harvey he's gone! polished it off anyway! cheeky little thing ... slight aroma of liniment and athlete's foot ... er the wine not Harvey! well both of them actually marvellous!

Wednesday Blow me ... now Ferenc's got the hump ... because I've commissioned that Damien Hirst for this week's "top-tip" ... maybe I was a bit harsh with him "Ferenc you're bloomin' rubbish." Off to Ron's Pop-in ... and Harvey's back! ... ho ho ! that little button nose er bottle of Concorde and more frank discussion! Belief! That's what its all about hmm? ... the magic in your mind! hearing Teddy Sheringham say: "We can't switch it on and off at will"' ... bringing back memories of my ill-advised introduction of "positive thinking" at Fulham in the 60s ... all of us sitting glumly in a darkened dressing-room ... resulting in a powerful headache for myself ... and two defenders carried off with brain-fever marvellous!

Bottoms Up! and straight into the postbag ... Another reader's letter! Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes: "Ron, George Best reckons that when he was on fire he could win games single-handedly, Ron, was you ever on fire?

Ho ho, very funny Mark, but I'll never forget Calum MacFhearghais ... the archetypal fiery Scot! ... a wee dram and a fish supper! ... but when the chips were down .... he "wis the wee boy!" ... three down on aggregate in the quarter-final, second-leg ... reduced to ten men ... his reaction was spontaneous! cometh the hour ... er ... combusteth the man ... leaving nothing but a small patch of scorched earth and a pair of smouldering boots ... down to nine men we took a terrible hammering ... er marvellous! ... and Mark ... every day's my quarter-final er ... second-leg these days! ho ho the 12 steps isn't it? ... counted 13 before stoving my head off the back door ... Don't think Mrs Manager noticed ...

Thursday ... ho ho ... er I've lost my diary ...

Friday another reader's letter! "Dad, I've found your diary," your son, Ferenc. ... And another reader's letter! Damien Hirst writes: "Cancellation fee: to the cost of 200 litres of formaldehyde ... £60"

Ron Manager was talking to the curator of the Cleopatra exhibition about the soaring cost of embalming fluid.

webTitle: Among big money singings there will always be failures

fields.headline: Among big money singings there will always be failures
fields.trailText: With the transfer system facing extinction, transfer fees continue to imitate the diplodocus, a creature of vast size but little sense.
fields.body:
The transfer system, it is said, will soon be as extinct as the dinosaur. In the meantime transfer fees continue to imitate the diplodocus, a creature of vast size but little sense. Yesterday Ruud van Nistelrooy, the Dutch striker who at £19m is the latest player to break the British transfer record, was formally unveiled at Manchester United. Last November Rio Ferdinand moved from West Ham United to Leeds United for £18m and last June Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, whom Leeds had previously sold to Atletico Madrid for £12m, joined Chelsea for £15m.

No wonder the season has a few rings around the eyes. Far from stifling the transfer market, the European Commission's attempt to end the trade in bootlegged kickers appears to have stimulated it. The bigger the fees the greater the doubts about their wisdom. When Alf Common joined Middlesbrough from Sunderland for £1,000 in 1905 the amount was widely considered obscene.

The first worry, which applies to all transactions, is that a serious injury will end whatever hopes a manager had of improving his team with a big buy. Neither Pierluigi Casiraghi nor Luc Nilis was a seven-figure signing but the sudden termination of their playing careers, at Chelsea and Aston Villa, was still a reminder of how precarious the professional footballer's trade is.

Then there is the matter of the buyer's judgement in assessing first a player's ability and then the effect he is likely to have on the team. Since most managers and coaches are former league professionals who have been in the game since their teens it might be thought that such experience would minimise the chance of error, yet this is not always the case.

A glance through the lengthening list of players for whom English clubs have spent £10m or more suggests that little has changed since October 1980, when Manchester United paid Nottingham Forest £1.25m for Garry Birtles, a striker who then did not score a league goal for nearly a year. Though many big transfers work, there will always be spectacular failures.

Quite often it is a case of incompatibility, the square-peg syndrome. In recent seasons few pegs have come squarer, or more expensive, than Chris Sutton, whose £10m move from Blackburn Rovers to Chelsea two years ago was doomed from the start. As a striker with Norwich and Blackburn, Sutton successfully combined strength and accuracy in the air with skilful feet and a sharp eye for scoring opportunities. He was at his best when partnering Alan Shearer at Ewood Park.

The pair were perfect in a Rovers team that complemented wing play and good crosses with tight passing where it mattered. At Stamford Bridge, however, Sutton suffered because, in addition to fitness problems, the strongest aspects of his game were alien to a style that demanded the ball played to feet, obviating the need for a target figure. Even the lofty Tore Andre Flo never quite became that.

Sutton, like Flo, is now plying his trade in the slightly less demanding, though highly competitive, Scottish League. Rangers paid Chelsea £12m for Flo last November, an amount that may yet be justified if, despite the margin of Celtic's championship triumph, they make a decent showing in Europe next season. None of the English game's other seven-figure buys have flopped in the manner of Sutton, although Sylvain Wiltord is still some way short of justifying the £13m that Arsenal paid Bordeaux for his services last August.

Then again, some players will take longer to acclimatise than others. The potential of Thierry Henry, who cost Arsenal £10.5m from Juventus, has been realised only since ArsÁene Wenger persuaded him he could be a better central striker than a winger.

The bigger the fee the greater the tendency to doubt the wisdom of the purchase. The £18m David O'Leary spent on Ferdinand was accompanied by much critical tut-tutting but since then the former West Ham defender has become a better player and if his efforts help to get Leeds into next season's Champions League, one way or the other, then the outlay will have been justified.

So it will be for Manchester United if Van Nistelrooy's goals take Sir Alex Ferguson nearer to another European Cup triumph next season than his team did this time and for Liverpool, whose £11m investment in Emile Heskey has already seen the team reach both domestic cup finals and the Uefa Cup final.

It is the clubs who are less likely to win things or get into the Champions League that need to think twice about joining the really big spenders. For example, did Tottenham pay Dynamo Kiev £11m for Sergei Rebrov simply to prove how innately ordinary was the rest of the team by comparison?

And was Juan Pablo Angel, the Colombian striker who had caught many a European eye at River Plate, fully aware of what he was letting himself in for at Aston Villa when he signed for Ë9.5m?

Angel is not so much a square peg as a lonely little petunia in an onion patch. Surely one good reason for ending the transfer system is to save some clubs and their managers from themselves.

webTitle: Opening credits for the wonderful wizard of Oss

fields.headline: Opening credits for the wonderful wizard of Oss
fields.trailText: Since Manchester United resurrected their record move for Ruud van Nistelrooy, the placid everyday life of Oss - an affluent industrial town near Nijmegen and birthplace of Britain's most expensive footballer - has been thrust into the public eye. It is not used to all the attention.
fields.body:
The groundsman at RKSV Margriet glances up wearily. Since Manchester United resurrected their record move for Ruud van Nistelrooy, the placid everyday life of Oss - an affluent industrial town near Nijmegen and birthplace of Britain's most expensive footballer - has been thrust into the public eye. It is not used to all the attention.

"Are you looking for Ruud? He doesn't play here any more," he jokes, while a duck, waddling into the goalmouth, hampers his attempts to mark up the six-yard box.

Van Nistelrooy joined Margriet at the age of 14. For a non-league side the surroundings are relatively grandiose; there is a seated area under a small stand and even an electronic scoreboard. "This is where he started but Ruud has come such a long way since then. This is a small town - everybody knows one another - and we remember him; it makes us proud to see him doing so well."

Oss was once unfairly branded "the dullest town in the Netherlands" by a Dutch magazine, but it does have more favourable claims to fame. Locals pride themselves that margarine and insulin were both "invented" here and the population of 55,000 includes the Vitesse Arnhem defender Marc van Hintum, another former Margriet player, who boasts eight international caps.

The local professional team, Top Oss, are on the verge of earning a play-off place for promotion to the Dutch top flight. Van Nistelrooy, who left Margriet for nearby Den Bosch at the age of 17, represents the biggest fish that got away.

Five miles away lies Geffen, the village in which Van Nistelrooy grew up. If Oss is sleepy, Geffen is comatose. Jo Spierings owns the sports shop that supplies the kit to the village's part-time team Nooit Gedacht, where the forward played until moving to the brighter lights of Margriet in 1987. Spierings sold the young Van Nistelrooy his first pair of football boots.

"They were for him to play in the school team before he joined Nooit Gedacht but that is a claim to fame, no?" he says, smiling. "He was a lovely player, whether the ball was on the ground or in the air. Manchester has got a prima footballer."

But not, it seems, a prima donna. "He wasn't arrogant at all but people around here do not treat him as a big star anyway," he adds. "We just see him as one of us. So he's famous. It doesn't matter."

The small time may seem £19m away but Nooit Gedacht is still an integral part of the Van Nistelrooy family - Ruud's uncle Hans is in the first team, his father Tinie coaches at the club and his mother used to play for the women's side. As the former junior team manager, Gens Grinsven coached the side's most famous graduate then watched his career flourish through the higher age groups.

"Ruud was under my charge from about the age of six to eight and would come in once a week for training," he says. "He and the other boys played football all the time in the street - night and day, rain or snow.

"He was tall and thin for his age but very quiet. He listened to what we told him. He had a free role up front but at that time we had two wingers who showed a lot of promise: Erwin Romme on the right and Mark Beekmans on the left."

From Beekmans on the left supply will switch to Beckham on the right from July 1, the Dutchman's 25th birthday. "English football will suit his style of play," says Grinsven. "It was better he move to England than Italy, where everything is to feet. Ruud is more direct. I am sure he will be a huge success."

fields.headline: Mellor's musings make amusing reading
fields.trailText: Reflections on pre-season predictions for the First Division this week, with a special mention for David Mellor, who tipped QPR to go up and his former favourites Fulham to miss out. Such foresight!
fields.body:
This week we look back on the experts' pre-season predictions for the First Division. "I have a hunch QPR are in for a good season," said Chris Wright, wrongly as it turned out. "Whether we are good enough to fill one of the top two places I don't know, but I would settle for that nerve-racking day at the end of May." David Mellor also picked Rangers as "dark horses", while writing off his former love, Fulham. "I have a hunch the kind of pressure that's around at Craven Cottage is more likely to be destructive than constructive," he mused. Got to go with those hunches.

Crystal Palace were another club attracting insider support. Bullish owner Simon Jordan said in August: "The club has huge potential. People who say I'm throwing good money after bad will have to eat their words."Not us, guv. Not when he's canny enough to employ a manager with Alan Smith's forecasting nous. He prophesied: "I think we can make a play-off place - and then who knows what can happen?"

Comforting news for Lou Macari. Huddersfield have announced a £500,000 three-year sponsorship deal with Prime Time - a management recruitment company.

Hard to know where to start with Chelsea Village, a new magazine for corporate clients of the former football club, also sent to "hand-picked households in the prestigious parts of Chelsea and Fulham". Which is more nauseating, the article on "the fight against retail ennui" or the one on a new local nightclub where the clients are "so good-looking, it quickly becomes scary"? Suffice to say that if any team visiting SW6 is looking for a motivational tool, they should order a few thousand copies and give them to their players and fans on entry to the ground.

Cowdenbeath could be Third Division champions tonight, with worrying implications for us all. Andrew Miles calls to let us know he hopes they don't make it, and not just because he supports second-placed Brechin. It's also a matter of international geopolitics - two of Cowden's three previous divisional titles came in 1914 and 1939.

The impact of the 2002 World Cup mascots Ato, Nik and Kaz, launched this week, may not be quite what the organisers had in mind, if Korea's previous efforts are any guide. The mascot craze that has swept the nation recently included the debut of Podori, "a smiling ape-like creature in police uniform" intended to soften the image of Seoul's fearsome riot squads. An ape dressed as a cop - what could be more reassuring?

M25 weather update: "I suppose driving through two feet of flood water on the local roads gave us a clue," sighs the Canvey Island website, reporting the postponement of Thursday's Ryman League game at Enfield. The previous night's match at Hampton was abandoned after half an hour due to another freak downpour. So, nine days until the season ends (including last night) and still eight games to go, plagues of boils permitting.

mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Ferdinand flowers away from his roots

fields.headline: Ferdinand flowers away from his roots
fields.trailText:
Leeds' £18m defender is maturing fast in the Yorkshire countryside and the big cities of Europe.

Leeds' £18m defender is maturing fast in rural Yorkshire and Europe, reports Daniel Taylor
fields.body:
It is five months since Rio Ferdinand left West Ham and the East End but, judging by his current choice of literature, it is fair to say he still has a passing interest in his old manor. He is midway through Hard Bastards which is not, as might be assumed, a tribute to Stuart Pearce and Julian Dicks but a Who's Who of the London underworld by Kate Kray, widow of Ronnie. "It's a good book," he says with a smile. "Just a little bit of light reading."

Ferdinand, who lines up for Leeds against Chelsea today, has had time to indulge his passion for reading recently - bags of time, in fact. His move to Leeds may have taken him away from his roots but, as he points out, it has also taken him away from temptation. He is settling into a picture-book village near Wetherby and the tranquillity of rural Yorkshire - living in the sticks, as he puts it - suits him to the ground. He is fast becoming an advertisement for the benefits of a quiet life.

He did worry. After spending all his life in London, the vast majority of it growing up on the Friary estate in Peckham, it was only natural to be consumed by a few what-ifs. Yet it seems a long time ago now since he was asking his parents, Julian and Janine, whether he was making the right decision to head north. "It surprises me to say it but I don't miss London at all," he says. "I thought I would be homesick, miss all the attractions of big-city life and all that, but I actually feel a lot more comfortable out here.

"There are a lot more distractions down there, not just the nightlife but everything that goes with being in the capital. There was always something going on after training. Looking back, it was good to get out when I did. Now I just come home and watch television or read. It's a lot slower pace of life and it gives me a lot more time to think about football and focus on my game."

The first thing that is noticeable about Ferdinand is how relaxed he is in unfamiliar company. The second is how unpretentious he is, totally unassuming, level-headed. David O'Leary, his manager, eulogises not only about an outstanding young player but also an outstanding young man, eager to learn and smouldering with a desire to better himself. Probe deeper and it emerges that Ferdinand has quietly gone about involving himself in the local community, making regular trips to the most deprived areas of Leeds. The £18m man may be big-time but this is no big-time Charlie.

To the media he is courtesy personified. Like every Premiership club, Leeds have their fair share of players who would rather chew a cockroach than chew the fat with a journalist. Ferdinand, however, is cute enough to understand the benefits of a good press. It says a lot about him that eight days ago, 24 hours before his first match back at Upton Park, he sacrificed his lunch so as not to disappoint the assembled corps. To many people that may not seem much but write a list of which other members of football's Millionaires' Row would do the same: it would not cover the back of a half-time raffle ticket.

"It's the way my family brought me up. My parents always drummed it into me to be grateful for everything I've got because there is always someone out there who needs more than you," he says.

"I'm not money-mad, never have been, and I can see the bigger picture. When you look at the news there are a lot of bad things happening all over the world. Sometimes it's easy for us as footballers to moan about little things and forget there are people out there who would love to be in our shoes. We should never overlook how fortunate we are to be where we are. I come from a poor area and I'm not going to forget that."

When we met at Leeds' Thorp Arch training ground on Thursday Ferdinand was slightly late because, according to Dominic Matteo, he was "playing his music in the gymnasium and dancing all over the place". Integrating into new surroundings is never easy but the 22-year-old seems to have eased into Leeds as into a comfortable old slipper.

It was a difficult start. After losing four of his first six games, including shipping three goals in the opening 30 minutes of a bilious debut at Leicester, Ferdinand can remember looking at West Ham's results and thinking: "Bloody hell, what have I let myself in for here?"

Deep down, though, he knew he had made a sound career move. It would be wrong to say he had begun to drift at West Ham but the time was right to leave and, home and abroad, Leeds have elevated him to a new plateau. In London his only experience of the Champions League was his Gameboy version. Even then, he says, the theme music made the hairs stand up on the back of his neck. On Wednesday, when he hears the real thing at Elland Road, Ferdinand will be lining up against Valencia for a place in the final.

It is threatening to become one of the great stories of European football. "I think we've surprised everyone and, if I'm being totally honest, ourselves as well," he says. "Maybe there are people out there who are regretting not paying us too much respect. Because we're not a massive name in Europe I think some people have come up against us thinking: 'Ah, it's just Leeds, they don't really matter.' Then they've got the surprise of their lives.

"We've got some great players here and our style is different to most European teams. We play a pressing game, very hard and very fast, and that has shocked some of the teams we've faced. But whichever way you look at it, what we have achieved this season has been tremendous."

Captaining the side in Lucas Radebe's absence, Ferdinand would not be human if he had not pictured himself lifting the European Cup. But first things first. "Valencia are a great team," he says. "I watch a lot of European football and they have got some outstanding players, particularly Gaizka Mendieta. They've got the best defensive record in La Liga and they have already knocked out Arsenal, so it's going to be really tough."

Tough, but it is not impossible. Judging by the Spanish press, it is clear there will be no under-estimating Leeds now. The club's stock has risen more than they could have dared anticipate and, with it, Ferdinand has become established as one of the most graceful defenders in Europe. Marca has already described him as the English equivalent of Franco Baresi.

It is fulsome praise but fast becoming the norm. When Ferdinand's transfer was completed in November the consensus was that Leeds had encroached the boundaries of acceptability. Now it is looking like shrewd business.

"There were some great experts out there saying it was far too much money and now, funnily enough, the same people who were throwing things in his face are saying: 'I told you he was a great player,'" says O'Leary. "I do know we could get a lot more for him now, at least Ë25m.

"He wants to be remembered as a truly great player and, for me, he's going to be a great defender for England for years to come. To be honest, I just wish I could have played alongside him." TV: Leeds United v Chelsea Sky Sports 1, ko 12noon today

Marca has already described him as the English equivalent of Franco Baresi. It is fulsome praise but fast becoming the norm. TV: Leeds United v Chelsea Sky Sports 1, ko 12noon today It is five months since Rio Ferdinand left West Ham and the East End but, judging by his current choice of literature, it is fair to say he still has a passing interest in his old manor. Ferdinand, who lines up for Leeds against Chelsea today, has had time to indulge his passion for reading recently - bags of time, in fact. He is settling into a picture-book village near Wetherby and the tranquillity of rural Yorkshire - living in the sticks, as he puts it - suits him to the ground. "It's the way my family brought me up. My parents always drummed it into me to be grateful for everything I've got because there is always someone out there who needs more than you," he says. "I'm not money-mad, never have been, and I can see the bigger picture. When you look at the news there are a lot of bad things happening all over the world. fields.headline: European run an accountant's dream
fields.trailText:
A Champions League place can transform a club, says John Cassy.

A Champions League place can transform a club, says John Cassy.
fields.body:
It may be the continent's premier competition but the race for the Champions League is not just fuelled by a desire for glory. Cash is king when it comes to playing in Europe and qualification for the Champions League can provide an unparalleled financial boost.

Last season Manchester United were knocked out of the Champions League at the quarter-final stage, a relative disappointment, but still made £26m from the competition - more than eight Premiership clubs made in their entire season.

"Europe is becoming the main course, not the dessert it once was," said Gerry Boon, author of an annual report into football finances by the financial experts Deloitte & Touche. "When players win the FA or Worthington cups now, they are quoted as saying 'we're glad that we have qualified for Europe'. This demonstrates how domestic Cup competitions have become a means to an end, rather than an end in itself."

Few clubs realise that more than Liverpool and Ipswich, two teams already sure of European football next season but still scrapping for promotion to the Champions League. Neither will now be happy with anything less. Liverpool said as much last season but Gerard Houllier's side missed out to Leeds United by a whisker. The Anfield accounts department must be praying that it does not happen again.

Their large squad has left them with a wage bill of £40m, one of the highest in the country. Last year 70% of all the money it turned over during the season went straight into players' pockets - the biggest proportional spend of the top five clubs in the Premiership and more than Deloitte & Touche say is healthy for any club looking to sustain a long-term business.

"The Champions League is a necessity for a club with a wage bill like Liverpool's but for Ipswich it would be like Christmas coming twice," said Nick Batram, an analyst at the City stockbrokers Granville Baird. At Ipswich's Portman Road ground one can feel the excitement the prospect of the club's first European action since 1982-83 is generating. One year after promotion from the First Division the club are on the verge of lining up against sides like Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and AC Milan.

Earlier this week Ipswich were granted conditional planning consent for a new North Stand, which will raise the capacity to more than 30,000. But European football could have a more immediate impact, adding huge sums to annual turnover and transforming their manager George Burley's ability in the transfer market.

Leeds have bought big this season off the back of their European run, paying £18m for Rio Ferdinand, £7.2m for Olivier Dacourt and £6m for Mark Viduka. Next year, unbelievably, Ipswich could compete. In smaller leagues like Holland, Scotland, Portugal and Belgium the impact of European competition is even more stark. At Rosenborg in Norway domestic competition has become a financial afterthought with the Champions League making up more than 50% of annual income.

Clubs in those smaller leagues want to combine to create a 'sixth force' in European football - a TV market to match the five big leagues of England, France, Germany, Italy and Spain. They may be too late. "The harsh reality is that there already is a sixth force in European football, and that is the Champions League," said Boon. Increasingly those outside that market are finding they are no longer in the game.

Leeds' share of the Euro cash-cow

1st group stage: £1.83m for qualifying plus £203,500 for each win and £100,000 per draw Total (two wins, three draws): £2.543m 2nd group stage: £1.83m, performance-related bonuses as before Total (three wins, one draw): £2.541m Quarter-finals: £1.63m Semi-finals: £2.04m Total so far: £8.754m

TV money: Leeds' share £4.4m (England's share £22m) Other income: Ticket sales, merchandise, corporate hospitality, other matchday income £10m Total so far: £23.154m Runners-up bonus: £2.44m Winners' bonus: £4.07m Additional revenue from final: £2.8m

Possible total: £30.024m

fields.headline: Pulis case ends in settlement
fields.trailText: Gillingham are to ask Bristol City and Stoke to cover the £150,000 costs they incurred after the wrongful-dismissal action brought against the Kent club by Tony Pulis ended yesterday at the high court when the former manager accepted an out-of-court settlement of £75,000.
fields.body:
Gillingham are to ask Bristol City and Stoke to cover the £150,000 costs they incurred after the wrongful-dismissal action brought against the Kent club by Tony Pulis ended yesterday at the high court when the former manager accepted an out-of-court settlement of £75,000.

The Gillingham chairman Paul Scally said last night that he was "very disappointed" with the two Second Division clubs, who denied making illegal approaches for Pulis until the eve of his suit. Had the admission come earlier Scally believes the action may never have been brought.

"They denied having any contact with my manager and quite clearly they had," Scally said. "They'd had clandestine interviews with him without my knowledge or consent from early May to the end of June [1999]. That was admitted in court. The day before it went to court, or perhaps the first day of the trial, we eventually got them to admit the truth. Had they admitted the truth three, four or five months ago this matter might not have ended up in the high court.

"Gillingham have incurred costs which they wouldn't otherwise have incurred, so at the very least we'll be looking for the recovery of our costs from these clubs. If they fail to do so I will take action through the Football League and the courts."

Pulis joined Bristol City as manager within days of being sacked by Gillingham in June 1999. The Football League promised last night to open an investigation into the alleged illegal approaches for Pulis if instructed to do so by Gillingham.

Scally, meanwhile, will discuss with his lawyers on Monday whether to press blackmail charges against Pulis after it was alleged in court on Thursday that the 43-year-old tried to blackmail the chairman out of £200,000 using documents stolen from the club. But Pulis strongly denied the claim. After giving evidence for a third day yesterday morning, Pulis accepted a £75,000 settlement in respect of money he was owed as a bonus for the £1.2m sale of Ade Akinbiyi to Bristol City in May 1998.

Gillingham said last night that they always accepted they owed Pulis £50,000 for the Akinbiyi sale. Pulis, however, had been looking for around a further £120,000 in bonuses he claimed he was due after the sales of James Corbett and Iffy Onuora and Akinbiyi's subsequent transfers to Wolves and Leicester.

Pulis had also been suing for at least £168,000 in salary, plus bonuses and expenses, paid car and telephone benefits after he was sacked by Gillingham. Pulis's solicitors said they were pleased to have reached an "amicable agreement". Scally's solicitor Trevor Watkins described the outcome as "a complete vindication" for his client.

The case exposed an interesting network of people on both sides. A briefcase of Gillingham documents, allegedly showing financial irregularities, which were given to Pulis by Maurice Saffery, an accounts clerk at Gillingham, were handed on to Norman Hayward, a family friend who was chairman of AFC Bournemouth when Pulis was manager there, and thence to Roy Pack, who acted as a consultant to Pulis in this case.

Pack, a self-styled investigator of alleged corruption in football who played for Arsenal and Portsmouth, and Hayward had worked together at Bournemouth after the club went into administration in January 1997.

A winding-up order on Chesterfield will be heard at Leeds crown court on May 10. The order is being served on behalf of the Inland Revenue and Glory Years, Chesterfield's shirt manufacturers. The debt represented by the order is £500,000.

webTitle: Hasselbaink prepares to hit the boos

fields.headline: Hasselbaink prepares to hit the boos
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has been called a lot of things in West Yorkshire. A banner at his last appearance for Leeds, a pre-season friendly at Birmingham in July 1999, branded him: "Greedy, selfish, Judas". He can expect worse today.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has been called a lot of things in West Yorkshire. A banner at his last appearance for Leeds, a pre-season friendly at Birmingham in July 1999, branded him: "Greedy, selfish, Judas". He can expect worse today.

The Chelsea striker, whose side had quietly risen to fifth with four successive wins before seeing their Champions League hopes fizzle out with a 1-0 defeat to Charlton last week, returns to Elland Road this afternoon. He is ready for a roasting reception.

"I'm looking forward very much to going back," he smiles. "Sometimes I'm too straightforward. My character is to tell the truth, but in England I sometimes have to shut my mouth and go with it. I would rather people knew where I was coming from and that I'm not going to stick a knife in their back. That's me."

Leeds fans may raise an eyebrow. Signed by George Graham from Boavista for £2m, Hasselbaink became a cult figure in West Yorkshire and scored 42 goals in 84 appearances. However, with Atletico Madrid sniffing for his £12m signature and the Dutch international threatening to strike, he left for the Vicente Calderon in August 1999.

"I offered to make him the best-paid player at the club," says the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. "I put this to his agent but it took less than three minutes for him to turn it down. His demands were outrageous."

"It wasn't about money," the 29-year-old retorts. "It was turned into that; I don't know by who. I heard talk that [David] O'Leary called me greedy and selfish; I'm not and I don't have a problem with him."

Though sixth place might be considered a reasonable dividend from a season of muddling mediocrity at Stamford Bridge, Hasselbaink has been frustrated. "I came here to win the league," he says. "When we won the Charity Shield against Manchester United it was going well. Then we had the big change with Gianluca Vialli leaving.

"You have to give Claudio Ranieri time to adapt. But a club like Chelsea has to be playing in Europe. If we win two more games we are going to be in the Uefa Cup, but that's not enough. To finish sixth would make it a shit season. Chelsea should be playing for the top three spots."

He played under Ranieri at Atletico, so one might expect his relationship with the Italian to be strong. "But he's different to work with a second time," he says. "I don't know why. It's not necessarily in a bad way, just different.

"I was unhappy to be substituted last week, but that's life. I've not spoken to Ranieri. He's not said anything. I just have to take it on the chin and try and prove him wrong. I want to stay with Chelsea and have no reason to leave." Leeds fans may have heard it all before.

fields.headline: O'Neill looks beyond bragging rights
fields.trailText: The contradictions inherent in preparing for one of the world's most famous derbies with nothing but pride at stake had the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill conceding that his main concern is that his players avoid injury.
fields.body:
The contradictions inherent in preparing for one of the world's most famous derbies with nothing but pride at stake had the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill conceding that his main concern is that his players avoid injury.

Victory in the Tennents Scottish Cup final against Hibernian on May 26 will net Celtic's third domestic treble in the 54 years of its existence, following the creation of the League Cup in 1946-47. While O'Neill may put a couple of youngsters on the bench - his relatively small squad will be without Chris Sutton who has a knee injury - it is unlikely he will use this, of all matches, to be overly experimental. The last time Celtic were at Ibrox on league business, in November, they were whipped 5-1, their only defeat in the league this season. A win for Rangers would guarantee their place in next season's Champions League.

"Naturally, I would like to win the game. But we will be going in a relaxed frame [of mind] regardless of what we say," he said. "I wouldn't want to get beat, but it is of no relevance to the season. My main focus is not getting too many injuries and keeping our minds focused, eventually, for the Scottish Cup final."

Spice comes in many guises, however. O'Neill contends that the 5-1 defeat helped emphasise his side's resolve and Celtic players took a swipe at their rivals on the afternoon the title was assured by donning T-shirts bearing the legend "No excuses" in response to the pleas of mitigation coming from an injury-plagued Ibrox.

O'Neill is clearly irritated by suggestions that Rangers' deficiencies delivered the championship. "We have won 29 out of 34 league games. It is difficult to say that it happened because somebody else has played poorly. Otherwise, I had better get my excuses in for next season when Rangers come charging back. I'll give up in October, now, because I'll say we are resting up."

fields.headline: Guardiola no to Arsenal
fields.trailText: Wenger still has Petit and Phillips on his wishlist.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger insisted yesterday that Arsenal would match Manchester United's spending - if that would make the Gunners "special" - but said that plunging into the market immediately was "dangerous".

Arsenal's manager wants to bring in at least three signings for next season and suggested that Sunderland's striker Kevin Phillips and Barcelona's unhappy midfielder Emmanuel Petit, who left Highbury only last summer, are among them.

Phillips, who together with Sunderland's manager Peter Reid yesterday dismissed reports that he had asked for a transfer, is one of a number of the English players that Wenger "has in mind". Phillips has had a disappointing season, both with his club and country-wise, and Wenger said of the striker: "I have not made up my mind yet."

The Hertfordshire-born Phillips was the Premiership's top scorer with 30 goals last season, but in this campaign he has scored only 11 times in the league. He suffered further disappointment last month when he was dropped from the England squad by Sven-Goran Eriksson.

Of Petit, who has had limited opportunities at Barcelona, Wenger said: "Although we have had no contact with him, I know he wants to come back to London. Other clubs may be interested but he loved it at Arsenal and I personally feel he is still a great player."

If Arsenal are unlikely to pay more than £5m to bring the 30-year-old French international back, Wenger insisted he would go much higher - indeed match United's British-record £19m for Ruud van Nistelrooy. "Yes," said Wenger, "I could see myself paying that kind of fee if we thought we could get somebody who would help us do something special."

But he suggested that United, by spending now rather than later, may have paid over the top for the Dutch striker. "I think prices in the overseas transfer market could drop by as much as 20% per cent this summer. It looks as if the market has not gone down yet, and everybody seems to be acting like it won't change, but I think that is a dangerous game to play."

Although Arsenal are seeking a new goalkeeper, David Seaman has extended his contract for another 12 months, keeping the England international, 37, at Highbury for a 12th season. Wenger praised Seaman's performances and physical condition after a season disrupted by shoulder and ankle injuries.

Glenn Hoddle, who has also been linked with a move for Petit, is celebrating his first "signing" as Tottenham's manager after Les Ferdinand, 34, agreed a new two-year contract with the club.

Southampton want to interview Brighton's Micky Adams for the manager's job at the Dell which was vacated with Hoddle's departure for Spurs. Talks are planned in the next few days after an official approach to Brighton, who hope to clinch the Third Division championship this afternoon. Adams has been shortlisted by Saints but Kevin Keegan is still strongly tipped for the job.

fields.headline: Julian Arguelles
fields.standfirst:
Non Political Social Club, Sheffield
***
fields.trailText:
Non Political Social Club, Sheffield
***
fields.body:
Tightly composed English jazz is alive and prospering in the hands of Julian Arguelles, whose octet features some of the UK's brightest talent. Centre stage was Django Bates on tenor horn, doing a fine job of coaxing magic from a rather unrewarding instrument. Bates is known as a musical mischief-maker, and his presence in such an apparently earnest ensemble was initially surprising. In fact, Arguelles appeared to be very serious indeed, and the first few pieces the group played sounded stately, almost classical.

The composer used careful, richly textured themes, often giving his own saxophone the tune before letting the other three horns in the front line weave respectfully around him. Most of the compositions were bewilderingly complex, featuring ambitious fugal writing and a carefully controlled lyricism. Perhaps the best example of this was Ace of Trumps, which was as neat and tidy as a Mozart piano sonata. In this piece, like several of the others, the 'hot' playing was left to the rhythm section, with the piano, electric guitar, bass and drums shuffling almost incongruously in the midst of a sophisticated chamber music ambience.

Happily, Arguelles' earnestness gave way to a playful underside. Song introductions grew funnier and, as the audience slowly latched on to the band leader's subtle brand of dead-pan humour, the warm humanity of the music started to emerge. Mind Your Head was hypnotic and all enveloping, the hornlines patiently overlapping into an enchanting, fractal complexity. But perhaps the most beautiful composition was Head-Pan, which featured trombone player Mark Bassey adding an eastern-tinged vocal line to an already intense musical backdrop.

Towards the end there were intimations of chaos and confusion. Juices was a bewildering sprawl of ideas, played at breakneck speed, but it sounded positively well-mannered compared to the closing number. Here the band abandoned all signs of restraint and ripped into an audacious splurge of noise, finally confirming that Arguelles is as much a master of cacophony as he is of cool, civilised elegance.

fields.headline: Brecht on the dangers of buying a fish
fields.standfirst:
Mann ist Mann
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
**
fields.trailText:
Mann ist Mann
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
**
fields.body:
There ain't nothing quite like a good, radical unleashing of indigenous German-language modernism. This is a howling, raggedly athletic, young-minded assault on Bertolt Brecht's 1926 folk allegory centring on a footsoldier's anonymity, from the Baracke am Deutschen Theatre, Berlin. This version sets the play in a fanciful 1920s India under British military occupation, where the soldiers ransack temples before pushing north into Tibet. A local 'porter', Galy Gay, is press-ganged into a machine-gunner's squadron. Faced with execution, he sacrifices his identity for that of killer-soldier 'Jeriah Jip aus Tipperary'.

Such pandering to the Irish crowd is part and parcel of the audience participation angle of director Thomas Ostermeier's production. Tilo Werner plays a haplessly distraught Galy Gay, who set out one morning to buy his wife a fish but somehow fell into the louche horrors of soldiery. Also Falk Rockstroh's self-appalled, raucously militaristic Sergeant 'Bloody Five' Fairchild is a horrid sweetmeat. His genocidal desires at the whore-widow's feet lead him to shoot off his manhood in a Hitler approximation that, thankfully, never plumbs the depths of a Nazi armband.

But this is really an ensemble production, the soldiers relentlessly thrashing themselves against the portmanteau railway track set in some demented version of Meyerhold's bio-mechanics.

A live band provide sound effects, while savagely refracting classic Kurt Weill numbers such as Moon of Alabama through a post-punkish, Birthday Party/ Captain Beefheart garage aesthetic. The cult of physical - if not always imagistic - expressionism will intoxicate some, while others may find it far from Brecht's notion of alienation.

Meanwhile, from a contemporary perspective, the tit-swaggering Widow Bigbeck is less offensive than the caricature of the inscrutable Oriental mandarin Mr Wang, dinging his bell and wittering like a loveable pantomime villain. The lowest-common-denominator tone of the humour sends uneven ripples of laughter through the audience. Some of the characterisations are sickening, like some Germanische stage-idiocy gone mad. But, hey, this is wild-minded stuff - bludgeoning home, in its blurred contemporary revisionism, some of Brecht's prophetic signalling of the seeds of fascism.

The production finally revels in a repeated militaristic thrust at a mountain fortress. Searchlights strafe the audience's eyeballs in darkness, while the reinvented Galy Gay rests his penile cannon between the legs of the Widow Bigbeck. Typically, Ostermeier absolutely trashes all sense-making in this latest attempt to excavate the Germanic warrior psyche.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 00-353-1-878 7222.

webTitle: Phoney prize win dropping on mats

fields.headline: Phoney prize win dropping on mats
fields.standfirst: It's nearly half a million pounds with no strings attached - it's a miracle. No, it's a highly profitable scam, warns Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Envelopes coming through the door bearing not the usual final demand but promising hundreds of thousands of pounds for doing absolutely nothing seem like manna from heaven.
fields.body:
Envelopes coming through the door bearing not the usual final demand but promising hundreds of thousands of pounds for doing absolutely nothing seem like manna from heaven.

And that's just what hard pressed south London secretary Lorraine Lauder thought when she received a letter from the grandly named Sweepstakes Reporting Network.

She was even more impressed by the superbly printed certificate which she was told to sign and return.

But what really caught her eye was the sum of £421,780 which the certificate intimated was hers - if only she complied with the rules in the small print.

"Like most people, I could do with some more money. A sum like this would pay the bills, buy a new car and loads of other goodies and still leave me enough to buy a new home without a mortgage. It sounds like a miracle," she says.

However, like all schemes that sound too good to be true, this one was bad enough to be a total loss.

When Ms Lauder, 50, checked out the Sweepstakes Reporting Network material with Jobs & Money, we had to disappoint her.

There was no prize waiting for her if she returned the form. And if she had complied with all the instructions, she would have lost the £20 "reporting fee" demanded.

Had she gone for the highly attractive bait, she would have been just the latest victim of a long-running, but highly profitable scam - the phoney lottery draw.

These give the impression that the recipient has won a huge sum of cash. But the reality is that those who bite just end up losers.

And there is nothing the UK authorities can do about this particular scam now - or in the future - despite a recent government initiative targeting the phoney draw merchants.

Earlier this month, the department of trade and industry (DTI) announced a clampdown on rogue trading schemes including false prize draws. These will be known as Stop Now Orders.

Each year millions of mailshots are sent out promising similar easy riches to the ones apparently on offer in Ms Lauder's letters, from addresses ranging from the UK to Australia via Argentina and Malaysia.

The DTI says there are various types of these mailshots. But all leave recipients with the impression they have won a guaranteed major cash prize or other award.

"Typically, the promised prize can only be claimed by returning a completed form with an "administration fee" of between £10 and £30. Sometimes there is a promised prize which acts as an inducement to purchase another product such as a low value gift or "miracle cure" or to subscribe to an overseas lottery.

"In reality, recipients are likely to end up with - at best - a low-value award."

But Stop Now Orders, when introduced, will only work in the European Union. Ms Lauder's letter has no EU origination. It was posted in the Philippines - outside the jurisdiction of the UK government, trading standards officers, and the UK post

The sender itself is apparently based either in Melville or Bethpage - both small towns in New York State and both used by the sender. All

But if Ms Lauder thinks that binning the Sweepstake letter will end the temptation, she is wrong. Just days after that letter arrived, she received two other prize scheme missives - both from UK addresses, however.

The Prize Payments Office, based on a post office box number in south London, wrote telling her she was a "confirmed cash winner". She was guaranteed "up to £5,000" if she sent £19.95. In return, PPO's Ronald Mercado promises a "beautiful, top quality, genuine leather Carlo Rossini chequebook wallet". Each wallet - "placed in our strongroom until you claim it" contains a "cash prize".

But what the letter does not say is how small most cash prizes might be. It could be as little as 1p to just scrape under the legal barrier. And, as Carlo Rossini products are not sold in shops, there is no way of knowing whether the wallet itself is worthwhile.

There is no record of a phone number for Carlo Rossini International.

The second letter - also asking for £19.95 - was sent from Swindon by Preciado Ltd, a company not currently registered in the UK according to Companies House records. Preciado does not give its own address.

A Michael J Crompton, who describes himself as the "chairman of the sponsorship committee" tells Ms Lauder: "I have been informed that you are fortunate enough to have been drawn as a cash winner and one of a select number of recipients of free genuine gemstones." Experts say the stones on offer are worth little.

To claim a cash prize of "up to £10,000", recipients must send a further £16 to Swindon-based Fortuna International whose chief executive is one James P Carrington.

This £16 apparently covers "duties, customs, notification costs, transaction charges and service fees in full". Fortuna does not appear in the BT phone book.

But, again, while the biggest prize in this international competition is flagged, no one knows how big or small the prizes handed out to others might be.

Ms Lauder asks where they got her details from. The answer is that they come from the profitable trade in mailing lists. These letters are best thrown away.

fields.headline: What it means for you
fields.trailText: We intend having children so when will the scheme begin?
fields.body:
We intend having children so when will the scheme begin?

Probably not until 2003 at the earliest. Assuming Labour is re-elected, first details will be in the Pre-Budget Report in November this year. It will require legislation (via the Finance Bill) which will then give a start date, probably the financial year beginning April 6, 2003.

How much will each child receive?

A minimum of £250 on birth plus three £50 extra donations before the age of 18, totalling £400. The maximum is £500 on birth plus three extra lots of £100, making a total of £800 from the government. At age 18, assuming 5% investment growth per year, the fund could be worth around £3,000 assuming "modest" parental contributions. Assuming moderate inflation, that will be enough to pay tuition fees for around four to five terms at university.

How much extra can be paid in?

There will be limits - not yet specified, but likely to be similar to the cash Isa rules, which currently limit you to paying in £3,000 a year. Anything more is likely to be misused as a tax dodge by the better-off.

Who can pay in?

Anybody can make extra contributions - parents, grandparents, relatives, friends - and at any time during the 18 years. Like Isas and stakeholder pensions, the plans are likely to allow people to stop and start contributions without penalty.

Who will operate them?

Banks, building societies, the post office, the new Universal Bank, unit trust companies, supermarkets; all are expected to bring out plans.

Where will it be invested?

A big question. Banks say it should be kept in deposit-style accounts - which will give returns of around 5%-6% a year, while unit trust companies say it should be in the stock market, which has in the past given returns of 10% a year - although few think those returns will be repeated over the next decade. Any product is likely to have to conform to the Cat standards on costs, access and terms, will tend to limit charges to no more than 1% annually.

Will there be financial salespeople in the birthing suite?

No - but it's the ultimate goal of banks to get you while you're young. Perhaps midwives will soon be sponsored by Lloyds or Prudential.

Will existing children gain anything?

Probably; the booster payments at age 5, 11, 16 may be paid to all existing children.

How will the means-testing work out?

It is a "universal" account open for all children, but only "low and middle income families" (there are no defini tions available yet) will obtain the full £800. Someone who qualifies for working families' tax credit is likely to be in the band of people who also qualifies for the maximum Child Trust Fund.

Will there be booster payments?

Yes. The initial payment is £250-£500, followed by top-ups of £50-£100 at age 5, 11 and 16. There is also the possibility of additional "credits" being paid into the fund to reward children who excel in civic responsibility, community service or educational achievement.

Will it replace other state benefits?

No. This government insists it will be disregarded for ben efits purposes. The caveat is that no one knows who will be in power in 18 years' time.

Will there be controls on where the money is spent?

No. The government would like to see the money spent on higher education, house-buying or setting up businesses. It is may also tie pay-outs from the fund to completing the financial education component of the National Curriculum. But it won't dictate where the money should be spent; many 18-year-olds might use it to fly off round the world.

Will there be any tax on these funds?

No - like Isas, the idea is that the money rolls up free from income and capital gains tax. But contributions from parents and families are likely to come from taxed, not gross income.

What will happen to the money if we emigrate or if the child dies?

No one has decided. Remember, this is a consultation document, with details yet to be hammered out.

What happens if there is a change of government?

The Tories have already said they will abolish it, preferring direct tax cuts. But once this scheme is established, it will be difficult to unwind altogether. That won't stop future governments tinkering with it, though. Peps, for example, were transformed into Isas.

fields.headline: The Tempest
fields.standfirst:
Mercury, Colchester
**
fields.trailText:
Mercury, Colchester
**
fields.body:
For a few moments the quality of energy in this production is tripled and the whole thing sparks into life. It happens at the very beginning, as the storm starts with a crash of thunder, and at the end, as Ariel takes his leave of Prospero, climbing a ladder to freedom and disappearing into the sky.

The in-between bits are less satisfactory, although Juno's masque is done in a refreshingly different style, concluding with a wild wedding party. There is also wit in the way that Ferdinand's travail with the logs is made so much harder by the island's spirits. And there is something rather neat about the way the supernatural characters such as Ariel are all from the future or our own time, while the human characters are located in a distant past.

Designer Tim Meacock has done excellent work at this address and initially it looks as if he has come up with a cracker: a sandy area surrounding a bare-boarded rectangle over which hangs a sea-bleached branch. Then he goes and spoils it by dropping a curtain around the back and sides of the stage. You can see what he's trying to get at - a cloak of magic around the island raised by Prospero's magic that disappears again when he renounces his powers - but the effect is about as visually interesting as watching a rehearsal in a space with drapes.

What happens on stage has to be more focused to survive this kind of austerity. Quite honestly, what happens on stage has to be much more focused altogether to convey anything much at all to row K in the auditorium. It is like watching a studio production that has been plonked down into a much larger theatre. Like a lot of the production, Gregory Floy's Prospero is subdued, but Matthew Goode's Ariel has real presence: a slight, nimble, almost ordinary figure in trainers who, nonetheless, casts a spell across the centuries.

There are some good ideas and performances here, but not enough to make a cohesive whole. It lacks the sense that those involved have a real passion for the play and something to say about it.

 Until May 12. Box office: 01206 573948.

fields.headline: Sublime Stravinsky
fields.standfirst:
Stravinsky Staged
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Stravinsky Staged
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.body:
It's almost as hard to imagine the history of 20th-century ballet without Igor Stravinsky as it is to imagine his absence from modern music. As the Royal Ballet's current unmissable tribute argues, he was the ideal composer for dance.

Ballet as an art form is dedicated to tradition but it is also constantly reinventing itself, and dozens of choreographers have heard this echoed in Stravinsky's music. History pulses throughout his scores - in the form of baroque dances or liturgical chants - yet it is endlessly being transformed through the colours and strategies of modernism. Stravinsky's radiant rhythmic invention also makes him a gift for choreographers - forcing a new accent on any step. And while those rhythms provide the securest of springboards for dance, there's always airy space in the music for the steps to fly free.

The clinching factor for dance, though, is the overwhelming variety in Stravinsky's imagination - a variety which could produce scores and ballets as different as The Firebird, Agon and Les Noces. Of these, Fokine's Firebird is most frequently seen at Covent Garden, although the luminous conducting of John Carewe (currently guesting) is producing a brightness of detail and variety of texture rare in its musical performance.

And if some of Thursday's dancers were slightly flat by comparison, Miyako Yoshida responded to the music with one of the great Firebirds of her career, her fleet brilliance given a searing edge as she raged against the violation of her capture.

Balanchine's Agon is more of a rarity on the ROH stage but the very young second cast featured assured dancing from a wilfully seductive Marianela Nunez and an engagingly cocky Johan Persson. Christina Arestis as the ballerina, however, was little more than an extravagant novelty. The extreme length of her limbs is tailormade for the predatory coils of the choreography but she lacks strength to give physical and erotic intent to her moves. She is, in an odd way, a perfect blank - the pure blank of a supermodel, which gives the role an unintentionally contemporary spin.

The highlight of the evening, though, is Les Noces - the monumental score that galvanised Bronislava Nijinska to create her awesome vision of peasant marriage ritual. Music and choreography alike are transcendent and terrifying in their portrait of marital sacrifice, and the dancers (fired by the fabulous musicianship from the pit) are superb. They give themselves up to the fierce, burdened intensity of the choreography as if whipped towards a collective fate. And when the young couple finally pass through the doors of the marriage chamber, it feels as if the flames of a crematorium are about to engulf them. This image of innocents sent to slaughter puts an unnerving frame around the fairy-tale romances of 19th-century ballet. Brilliant Stravinsky, dangerous Nijinska.

 Until May 9. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Hersh's bittersweet wailing
fields.standfirst:
Kristin Hersh
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Kristin Hersh
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
With her new album, Sunny Border Blue, Kristin Hersh has done no harm whatsoever to her image as the Sylvia Plath of pop. While Hersh claims she doesn't know what her songs are 'about' half the time, references to pain, conflict and confusion spill out, even if they are camouflaged by delicate instrumental textures.

For this performance, Hersh sat alone in a chair at the front of the stage, swapping between a pair of acoustic guitars as she worked her way through songs new and not-so-new. No accompanying musicians, no electronic effects, and just a few blobs of light scattered around the stage to provide a hint of atmosphere. The intimate, confessional tone suited both performer and audience, since Hersh's crowd treat her with a kind of chummy reverence, as if she's a slightly potty sister armed with a formidable gift of prophecy.

The striking thing about her is how the performing Hersh is only ever a hair's breadth away from the wisecracking Hersh between songs. The latter tells comical stories about playing gigs in Scotland while very drunk, which makes it even more startling when the former springs back into action with her bizarre range of wailing, cooing, slurring vocal tones.

It would take a brave performer to try to cover any of Hersh's songs, as content and delivery are so closely bound up with their author. Spain, for instance, is an acutely painful account of a confrontation with her husband, Billy ('I wanted you to sleep with her and hate yourself instead of me'), rising from gaunt simplicity to an outburst of raging guitar abuse. White Suckers is a bittersweet piece about her husband 'when he was my boyfriend', and you can only speculate about the experience that lies behind a line such as 'we were a match made in purgatory'.

By comparison, a folk ballad about the death of Rose Connolly felt like a cheerful spring morning. Kristin Hersh may be a compelling spectator sport, but you wouldn't want to go there.

 Kristin Hersh plays the HQ, Dublin (00-353-1 456 9569) tonight and the Cottier Theatre, Glasgow (0141-357 3868) on Sunday.

fields.headline: Landlords eye long-term profit
fields.trailText: With a turbulent stock market and mortgage interest rates at their lowest level in 36 years, more people might be tempted to look at renting out property as an alternative investment, writes Pamela Swinburne .
fields.body:
With a turbulent stock market and mortgage interest rates at their lowest level in 36 years, more people might be tempted to look at renting out property as an alternative investment, writes Pamela Swinburne .

Many are buying investment property to boost eventual pensions through the ever-expanding buy-to-let market. The idea is that rentals should at least cover the mortgage and other expenses, such as insurance and letting agents. Landlords hope to make their big gains from capital growth.

Buy-to-let mortgages are more affordable than they were five years ago and there is fierce competition among lenders, with rates as low as 3.75% and deposits of around 20%. Often they are the same cost as residential loans, ending the old practice of forcing buyers of investment properties to borrow at steep commercial rates.

The long-term outlook for investment properties looks good, according to the Association of Residential Letting Agents, which says it is expected to grow from 11.2% of the market to 15% in the next five years.

And new figures from the agents Savills show that the average net yield after expenses stands at 6.5% - enough to cover many current loans.

But as more people are lured into the buy-to-let market and the mortgage war hots up, where do you begin to trawl through the hundreds of packages on offer? How do you decide whether to go for a capped, fixed, discounted or variable rate? Some have penalties while others don't lock you in at all. You need to shop around carefully.

According to Nichola Pincher, from Chase De Vere Mortgage Management, the best buys for buy-to-let mortgages include Britannic Money's 5.99% fixed rate for two years with no penalties; Mortgage Express's 5.99% fixed rate for three years and Bank of Ireland's 6.39% fixed rate for five years.

When comparing schemes, it is important to weigh up costs, as lower rates may have bigger penalties, and to take into account any arrangement fee. For instance, Bank of Ireland does not charge an arrangement fee but it has steep penalties during the fixed rate term, whereas Britannic Money charges a 1% fee but does not charge any penalty.

Ms Pincher explains that there are standard mortgage products available through most intermediaries and on the high street, but larger intermediaries such as her own firm, or Charcol or Savills, may have some exclusive deals because of their big portfolios.

Karen Garner, of Charcol, says her company's best deals are Mortgage Express's rate of 6.35% fixed until June 2006, with an 80% loan and 1% fee; Scottish Widows at 6.25% fixed until June 2003, 80% loan, 3% penalty, with a £295 booking fee and a 0.5% arrangement fee. A fixed deal without penalties comes from the Royal Bank of Scotland, which offers 6.15% until July 2003.

But buying the wrong property can be an even more expensive mistake than a flutter on the stock market.

One of the key things to remember is location - convenience, safety and access to public transport are crucial. It is imperative that you factor into calculations the void periods when you have no tenant.

When buying property to rent out consider the running costs, rental return, fees, maintenance and service charges as well as rental growth and capital gains.

Deductions against tax on rents received may be claimed for the following: repairs, maintenance costs, insurance, cleaning, commission and other management expenses. A wear and tear allowance of 10% of the rent received may be deductible.

fields.headline: Here's looking at you kid
fields.standfirst: Babies will get a head start under this week's government proposal. But are cash payments the answer? Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Babies will get a head start under this week's government proposal. But are cash payments the answer? Patrick Collinson reports
fields.body:
Just weeks before a probable election, Labour has announced its big new idea; prime minister Tony Blair doesn't just want to kiss babies, he wants to give them hundreds of pounds each.

The Child Trust Fund - immediately dubbed baby bonds - will see every child awarded a government endowment of at least £250 at birth, with the children of lower-paid people picking up £500.

Topped up by regular amounts from the government and, it hopes, parents and relatives, the trust fund could be worth £3,000 or more when the child turns 18.

Tony Blair believes the money will give 18-year-olds a "springboard" for the future, helping with university costs, buying a house or set ting up a business. Parents may think otherwise, fearing a new twist to the old adage about a mis-spent youth.

But Mr Blair can draw comfort from the young adults of schools in Watford polled by Jobs & Money (see opposite); their attitude to spending is more like Saffie than Patsy or Edina in Absolutely Fabulous.

The big battalions from the financial services industry lined up by Tony Blair at the launch of the Child Trust Fund - including Halifax, Nationwide, Prudential and M&G - immediately gave their blessing to the concept. Friendly societies such as the Tunbridge Wells, which owns the rights to the name baby bond, also enthusiastically endorsed the concept.

But in private, they began squabbling over who should run the money, where it should be invested, what it will be worth, and whether the truly poor will really benefit.

Halifax and Nationwide, in rare agreement after the recent mortgage war, said the government must channel the money into deposit savings accounts, similar to cash Isas. "The first batch of anybody's money should always be in cash. People on low incomes do not want to take the risk of the stock market," said Halifax general manager Brian Duffin.

But unit trust company M&G countered: "They would say that, wouldn't they. The best place for money over an 18-year period is the stock market. To do anything else would be terrible advice," said M&G director Jeffrey Mushens.

Strict rules about projecting the future value of investments prevent fund managers from assuming that future growth will be anything more than 7% a year, even though most have achieved far more than that over the past 18 years.

M&G says that just £800 invested 18 years ago would have produced a fund worth £8,583 today, while a fund which tracked the All-Share Index would be worth £6,600.

But the Financial Services Authority warned only a fortnight ago that these sort of inflation-boosted returns are highly unlikely in the future; if so, the 7% a year that stock market schemes may earn do not have much of an edge on the 5%-6% a year that the banks and building societies are likely to offer on deposits.

The biggest problem for government and banks alike will be encouraging the very poor to make additional savings. "The challenge is making this work for the people who don't feel they have enough money to come through our doors," said Nationwide director John Sutherland.

The Child Poverty Action Group said it wanted cash now for the Social Fund rather than jam tomorrow. "The promise of a cash payment tomorrow does not feed and clothe families today," it said.

No dummy: The planned Child Trust Fund could help this youngster to start a business, buy a home or do a degree
