fields.headline: Law is just the ticket
fields.standfirst: Couple may still be able to claim £3m prize, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: Camelot's refusal to pay out £3m to a St Albans couple who lost their winning lottery ticket is the latest controversy to hit the National Lottery.
fields.body:
Camelot's refusal to pay out £3m to a St Albans couple who lost their winning lottery ticket is the latest controversy to hit the National Lottery.

The lottery organisers have accepted that on a "balance of probabilities" the couple have shown they did buy the ticket. In my opinion the evidence that they did so is overwhelming.

They, alone of the 115 claiming to have bought that ticket, were able to identify the shop where it came from and the precise time of purchase. On top of that they could show that they backed the same numbers that won on the day in question, 6 September 2000, for some weeks beforehand.

Camelot imposes a six month limit for claims where there are tickets, but also stipulates that lost tickets must be reported within 30 days. The couple's claim was not in fact made until near the expiry of the six-month limit in March.

Camelot's refusal does appear to be in accordance with its own rules and has been backed by the National Lottery Commission. However it is not certain that a court would come to the same conclusion if the couple take legal action to get their prize.

Although gambling contracts cannot normally be enforced by the courts, where money has been paid into a pool, as the sums used to buy lottery tickets would seem to be, the courts do have jurisdiction. There have already been a number of court cases arising out of lottery prizes.

The couple could point out that the details of Camelot's rules are not widely known. There is nothing on the lottery ticket or form to indicate them and they cannot even be found on the National Lottery website. Like any organisation relying on its own rules to get out of a liability, Camelot would have to show that they were part of the contract.

The Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 might assist the couple. This prevents a commercial organisation that enters into a contract with a consumer from relying on its "small print" unreasonably to enable it to perform a contract in different way to that which had been envisaged.

The couple would say they envisaged that if they picked winning numbers and could show they had done so, they would get the prize. Producing a winning ticket is obviously the best way of proving that, but when it can be shown conclusively in some other way that should be sufficient.

Such an action will not be easy, and the statutory status of the lottery may mean the courts conclude normal contractual rules do not apply. However with so much money at stake, it is unlikely that Camelot's decision will remain unchallenged.

Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Odd jobbers get the green light

fields.headline: Odd jobbers get the green light
fields.standfirst: The country's demographics are changing. We've all heard the statistics which say one in three of us will never get married. But it's not just romantic relationships that are being affected - business relationships are changing as well
fields.trailText: The number of self-employed and contract workers is rising, as is the number of people with multi-job careers - people who might have a contract for two days of the week but work as a freelance the remaining three days. Yet this can cause problems in your financial life.
fields.body:
The number of self-employed and contract workers is rising, as is the number of people with multi-job careers - people who might have a contract for two days of the week but work as a freelance the remaining three days. Yet this can cause problems in your financial life.

Unless you can show a steady job and salary, you sink down the mortgage company acceptability stakes.

According to research from Sun Bank, one in five borrowers has an initial mortgage application refused, despite having excellent credit histories, because he or she doesn't pass the lenders' credit scoring system. To add insult to injury, a no from one lender could influence others because most use the same system and will be able to see that you have already been refused.

So, what is a highly paid IT contractor or people with their own fast-growing businesses to do if they don't want to rent?

Chelsea building society and Bristol & West, the main players in the substandard or "credit-impaired" market, now have a variety of mortgage products which meet the requirements of self-employed, but otherwise financially solvent individuals.Lesser known lenders such as Sun Bank and Kensington Mortgages are also rising to the challenge.

Chelsea, for example, will lend up to 80% of a property's value to a self-employed person who can't provide three years of audited accounts, the traditional prerequisite for self-employed people going to mainstream lenders. Instead, the building society will look at the applicant's bank statements to establishincome and cashflow.

Provided all is OK, applicants will usually be offered a mortgage at the society's standard variable rate of 6.99%, with the same conditions as other applicants.

Some lenders, such as Bristol & West, may offer applicants a slightly higher rate if they are approved, but drop this to the standard rate after two or three years.

These four lenders, are also the main players in the market for credit-impaired mortgages (aimed at those with bad past records, including bankruptcies). They assess people with a bad credit history in a similar way. Applicants must be prepared to pay a higher rate to reflect their higher risk.

Chelsea's credit-impaired rates range from 7.24% APR to 8.74%, while Kensington's vary from 6.99% to 11.1%. For credit-impaired applicants, lenders will normally stagger the rates to the number of county court judgments they have against them. If they have less than three, they may be eligible for the 7.24% rate, whereas eight judgments and some missed mortgage payments over the past 12 months will nudge them up to the 8.74% bracket.

"People run into financial trouble for a whole variety of reasons," Sun Bank says. "You may have been involved in a messy, expensive divorce, or your business may have failed through no fault of your own. This doesn't mean that you don't know how to manage your finances, just that you hit a bad patch.

"Provided an applicant is coming out of their bad patch and is not still accumulating debt, we are happy to consider his or her personal circumstances."

Once clients are back on track they should be able to get loans on normal terms. Most higher risk lenders allow penalty-free switches after three to four years.

fields.headline: Remortgaging made easy
fields.trailText: • Decide what you want from the remortgage - do you want lower monthly payments, the security of a fixed rate, a capital sum for a holiday or home improvements, flexibility, or debt consolidation? An independent financial adviser or broker can help you choose the right deal
fields.body:
 Decide what you want from the remortgage - do you want lower monthly payments, the security of a fixed rate, a capital sum for a holiday or home improvements, flexibility, or debt consolidation? An independent financial adviser or broker can help you choose the right deal

 Find out any fees charged by lenders or brokers, and if they can be added to the loan

 Provide proof of ID, residence and income. You will also be asked for one year's mortgage statement, between one and three months' payslips, and between one and three months' bank statements

 If you increase the size of the mortgage you may have to increase the size of your life cover and change the terms of your investment vehicle, but you should not have to extend an endowment - you can have a part repayment loan. You may also need to check buildings insurance

 Complete your mortgage at the right time in the month - some lenders charge interest to the end of the month regardless of when you complete so you could end up paying two lenders for the same period

 Once you have completed the loan, check that your bank has acted on your new instructions

fields.headline: How would you spend £3,000?
fields.trailText: Just what would today's young adults do if a £3,000 baby bond windfall hit their bank accounts at age 18?
fields.body:
Just what would today's young adults do if a £3,000 baby bond windfall hit their bank accounts at age 18?

We went to Watford to find out from A-level students. The good news for the government is that most of them want to spend the money seriously. The bad news is that not all are impressed by the idea.

Helena Cohen would put it "straight in the bank towards university, a car and an eventual home though I would splash out £200 on clothes and nights out. But I don't think it's a good idea - what about schools and hospitals?"

Zoe Mernick has already discovered she would be means-tested out of the full amount. "It would be useful for driving lessons and maybe a car. Otherwise, I would put the money into a high interest account for when my university debts become too big. It's not enough for a mortgage deposit," she says.

Alefiyah Husseinbhai would use it to help with student debts. "Otherwise," she says, "I would either invest it in shares or fund a gap year to learn a European language."

Ben Feben intends spending half on ski equipment and the balance on winter sports in Italy "until the cash runs out".

Annette Less says: "I would probably spend it on university. But £300 would go on things I don't really need. It might be better to hand out £1,000 a year to stop you wasting it."

fields.headline: Andrew Wilde
fields.standfirst:
Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester
***
fields.body:
Andrew Wilde's piano recitals have what could almost be called a cult following in Manchester. The RNCM Concert Hall was packed for his latest concert, and a fair proportion of the audience rarely go to other classical concerts. That they keep coming back is clear evidence that he gives them what they expect: serious middle-of-the-road classics in thoroughly serious performances.

But that is absolutely not to suggest that his programmes or playing are without risks. Not content with basing the first part of his recital on the oddest of Schubert's piano sonatas, the late sonata in G major, he prefaced it with Mozart's quiet Adagio in B minor. It meant he didn't produce a loud sound on the piano until he had been playing for about 20 minutes. Until then, everything was gentle and ruminative, every texture beautifully calculated, every gradation gauged with extraordinary care and restraint. He drew the audience into this intimate world with remarkable skill. With the tone set by Mozart, he was able to make every lovingly turned detail of the Schubert sonata seem inevitable. With a very firm control of the sonata's bizarre architecture, he produced a performance of truly refined musicianship.

Things were not quite the same in the second half, devoted to Chopin. Perhaps he is less at home with Chopin's shorter, more predictable forms; perhaps they do not evoke the same challenge to his musicianship; or perhaps he has just played these works too often. But, compared with his marvellous Schubert, details went adrift, textures were often less clear, and a fair number of passages were played as though they had no real meaning. What he did show, however, was a range of dynamics and colours that he had so carefully resisted in the first half. This was a muscular Chopin that created angry Nocturnes, an intensely serious Scherzo, and a barn-storming Waltz. Whether that is the best way to play the music is open to question; but the audience will certainly be back for more.

webTitle: Straw pays tribute to animal test lab

fields.headline: Straw pays tribute to animal test lab
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday staged a symbolic visit to Huntingdon Life Sciences, the embattled animal testing laboratory in Cambridgeshire, to tell voters that the lab's staff deserved applause, not abuse.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday staged a symbolic visit to Huntingdon Life Sciences, the embattled animal testing laboratory in Cambridgeshire, to tell voters that the lab's staff deserved applause, not abuse.

The home secretary's visit came as Tony Blair announced a ministerial committee to look at further ways to protect such firms - and their staff - from attacks from animal rights militants, whose loose organisation has defied police efforts to bring them to account.

Mr Straw braved round the clock protests and took TV crews with him to flag Whitehall's support.

After touring the plant with Brian Cass, the HLS managing director who was attacked outside his home by masked men, Mr Straw assured staff that, after a slow start, ministers were keen to protect them and the wider bioscience and pharmaceutical industries, whose future was threatened by attacks by "criminal terrorists".

"What goes on here is of great importance to millions of people's lives, just as research on animals has always been important in helping to combat diseases like smallpox, polio and asthma," he told reporters at the plant in John Major's constituency.

"We need to applaud the people who work here rather than abuse them."

The criminal justice bill will strengthen police powers against intimidatory mail and email to staff, shareholders or banks - some of which have dropped HLS as clients rather than face harassment. Mr Cass said he now saw "a real commitment to making a change" to protect researchers.

The director of the Wellcome Trust medical research charity, Mike Dexter, said: "Medical research saves lives, and the government is right to get tough on animal rights extremists. Legitimate democratic debate about animal welfare is vital, but the nasty politics of the baseball bat must not be allowed to win.

"Society must get behind the government to guarantee the safety of medical researchers."

fields.headline: World Cup crisis for Brazil
fields.standfirst: Draw with Peru puts them in danger of elimination
fields.trailText: Brazil were left pondering the unthinkable yesterday after drawing 1-1 with Peru - that they may fail to qualify for the World Cup finals.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil were left pondering the unthinkable yesterday after drawing 1-1 with Peru - that they may fail to qualify for the World Cup finals.

In a game where yet again Brazil showed nothing of the creativity and skill that was once their trademark, Romario put Brazil ahead at Sao Paulo's Morumbi stadium only for the Peruvian defender Juan Pajuelo to head in a corner 12 minutes later.

Brazil are now fourth in South America's 10-team qualifying group, behind Argentina, Paraguay and Ecuador. Colombia and Uruguay are in fifth and sixth. The top four teams qualify automatically and the fifth must play off against the winners of the Oceania group.

Wednesday night's draw with Peru, in seventh place, was almost as humbling as the historic defeat a month ago by Ecuador, which was the first time Brazil had ever been beaten by the tiny Andean nation.

Emerson Leao's decision to revamp the squad by dropping all but three of the Europe-based players - including Rivaldo, Roberto Carlos and Emerson - backfired. The coach instead organised the midfield around Marcelinho, Ricardinho and Ewerthon, who all play for Corinthians of Sao Paulo. But the gamble did not pay off and the team lacked cohesion.

Brazil have used 12 different line-ups in 12 qualifying games - bringing to 68 the total number of players to have been called up to the national team since last March.

In an admission of mediocrity that stunned even a jaded press, Leao said that he chose the uncapped midfielder Leomar because he was a "seven out of 10" player - someone who was reliable but never brilliant.

Brazil played dreadfully, continually missing passes, showing little invention and managing only two shots on goal in the first half. It was left to Romario, who at 35 many consider too old and injury-prone to be relied on for the World Cup finals, to score a striker's goal early in the second half - receiving the ball on his chest and dribbling past past the Peruvian goalkeeper Miguel Miranda.

"Nothing is easy any more for Brazil," said Romario. "The mentality of the team was even quite good. Leao did everything he could. But on the pitch we have to do better." Leao put a brave face on the result. "A draw at home, under any circumstance, is a dreadful result," he admitted. "We're not in decline; it's just that at the moment we're not doing well."

Leao, who played in goal for Brazil during the 70s, has only been in charge for five games. Already his popularity is sinking to the levels attained by the former incumbent Wanderley Luxemburgo.

Luxemburgo was sacked after the Under-23 team was beaten by Cameroon, reduced to nine men, in the Sydney Olympics - although, ironically, he has subsequently been responsible for turning the Corinthians midfield plucked by Leao into perhaps the best in the Brazilian league.

Brazil have several mitigating factors - although none can excuse its dire performances. With the South America's teams contained in one qualifying group there has been a considerable increase in the number of games played, but now that more Brazilians play in Europe than ever before, there is less time for the team to train together.

The congressional investigations in the capital Brasilia point to corruption at every level of the game - from the forging of birth certificates of teenage players to tax evasion and fraud by the largest clubs. The malaise seems to have affected the players.

"We got what we deserved, thanks to the vampires who have sucked the last drops of sweat and blood from our football and left only the tears," said columnist Juca Kfouri in sports daily Lance.

Few people believe that Brazil will fail to qualify but there is a genuine worry that they could finish in fifth place.

Brazil have a run of three tough games in the next few months. First they play Uruguay in Montevideo, next come Paraguay in Rio and then Argentina in Buenos Aires. And Brazil have yet to play Bolivia in the high, thin air of La Paz. Argentina nearly lost there on Wednesday, forcing a 3-3 draw in injury-time.

fields.headline: Wednesday reward for Shreeves
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday are expected to confirm Peter Shreeves as their manager today after opening contract negotiations with the club's caretaker manager last night.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday are expected to confirm Peter Shreeves as their manager today after opening contract negotiations with the club's caretaker manager last night.

Wednesday have taken 26 points in 13 games since Shreeves took over from Paul Jewell in February. Shreeves was offered the job in talks with the board yesterday and is expected to agree to a three-year deal.

Wednesday had resolved not to appoint a manager until the end of the season, but have decided to reward Shreeves for leading the club to safety.

Everton's absentee midfielder Alex Nyarko has changed his mind about retiring but, according to his brother Kajo, will not play for the Merseyside club again.

The 27-year-old Ghanaian was confronted by an Everton fan who offered to swap shirts with the disappointing £4.5m signing during last Saturday's 4-1 defeat at Arsenal.

"He's going to come back to Ghana next week to consider his future but he is not going to give up," Kajo Nyarko added. "I don't think he would like to stay at Everton. I think he will leave."

An Everton spokesman said: "I can confirm Walter Smith has had discussions with the player. Alex has had some time to consider his future and the manager is happy to allow him this time. They will speak again next week."

fields.headline: Vieira pledges future to Arsenal
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira yesterday eased Arsenal fears when he insisted he would stay at Highbury in spite of rising interest from Italy. Plus, a full round-up of the latest news.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira yesterday eased Arsenal fears when he insisted he would stay at Highbury in spite of rising interest from Italy.

The French midfielder has attracted even greater interest from Serie A clubs, notably Juventus and Internazionale, in the last week since criticising Arsenal after the European Cup elimination in Valencia and suggesting he would leave after their "best-forgotten" season. He added tantalisingly: "Anything is possible in football."

But now the 24-year-old Vieira says: "I want to make it clear to every Arsenal fan that I have no intention of going to Italy or anywhere else.

"The people at this club know what is going to happen. It is clear to them that I want to stay at Arsenal. I have a contract until 2004; they know my respect for the club and the fans."

Vieira's comments last week could also be interpreted as a strong appeal to Arsène Wenger and the Highbury board to spend on quality players in order for Arsenal to become a heavyweight European club. He said yesterday: "From time to time players will have a moan but I don't talk without cause."

Nevertheless Wenger's buying plans for next season appear modest, with the manager suggesting his targets are limited to a new goalkeeper and defender.

Leicester's manager Peter Taylor, under fire after seven Premiership defeats in succession, has hit back after fierce criticism from the club's former captain Steve Walsh.

Walsh, who spent 15 years at Filbert Street before joining Norwich this season, claimed there was "unrest in the dressing room" and accused Taylor of "dismantling the team" built by Martin O'Neill.

But Taylor is adamant the Leicester spirit still exists and that, far from breaking up O'Neill's side, Neil Lennon had been the only regular to leave.

Taylor said: "Steve has always been welcome at Leicester since he left. He was only here a week ago and he's been up the training ground to use the gym whenever he has wanted.

"I am a little bit hurt and disappointed because Steve knows any manager or player goes through what we are going through at Leicester.

Of several signings, mainly from the lower divisions, blooded recently Taylor said that they "were for the future but I've had to play them more often and sooner than I wanted because of injuries."

Leicester's latest casualty, Gerry Taggart, is to have surgery for a knee injury and joins Muzzy Izzet and Matt Elliott in missing the rest of the season.

Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro has been cleared at a Football Association disciplinary hearing after being charged with violent conduct on the recommendation of the video advisory panel.

He was accused of stamping on Arsenal's Fredrik Ljungberg's ankle in February's FA Cup tie at Highbury. But the case against the Nigerian was found to be "not proven" after the FA accepted his defence that the incident was accidental.

webTitle: Former Gillingham manager Tony Pulis tried to 'blackmail' chairman

fields.headline: Pulis tried to 'blackmail' chairman
fields.standfirst: Court told that Gillingham manager wanted to harm the club
fields.trailText: The former Gillingham manager Tony Pulis concocted a "monstrous plot" to blackmail the club's chairman Paul Scally out of £200,000 using confidential documents stolen from the club, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The former Gillingham manager Tony Pulis concocted a "monstrous plot" to blackmail the club's chairman Paul Scally out of £200,000 using confidential documents stolen from the club, the high court heard yesterday.

Pulis confronted Scally on May 26 1999, four days before the biggest game in the club's history, the Second Division play-off final against Manchester City, and demanded that the chairman pay him the money which Pulis believed he was owed in goodwill payments, bonuses and his share of the sale of players.

During the meeting, which took place in a stand at the Priestfield stadium, Pulis produced a document from the front of his shorts which, he alleged, showed financial irregularities relating to a game against Wycombe Wanderers.

If Scally did not pay him, it was alleged, Pulis threatened to take these documents and others to the football authorities, the police and the press. Pulis, who denies the blackmail plot, also told Scally he would be leaving the club the day after the Wembley play-off, which Gillingham lost on penalties.

Giving evidence on the third day of his wrongful dismissal suit against the club, Pulis said he was "angry and frustrated" after hearing on the morning of May 26 that £62,000 he had been paid in lieu of changes to his contract had been withdrawn from his pension fund. In addition to the £62,000, Pulis said he was owed around £140,000 from the sale of Ade Akinbiyi, James Corbett and Iffy Onuora, making a rough total of £200,000.

Pulis told the court that shortly after hearing the £62,000 had been withdrawn Maurice Saffery, an accounts clerk at Gillingham, came to his office carrying a briefcase and a brown envelope containing the documents. "Maurice Saffery told me that Paul Scally was misappropriating funds through gate receipts and other ways," Pulis told the court.

Pulis said he was furious and took the document from the brown envelope and sought out Scally. "We stood in a row of spectator seats in the stand on the far side of the pitch," Pulis said under cross-examination by Nicholas Mostyn QC, representing Gillingham.

"I asked him," 'Are you not paying me the money because the club is in trouble?'" Pulis then produced a nine-page document marked Wycombe Wanderers from his shorts. He had put it there he said because he had no pockets.

The court was read part of a statement made by Scally in which he said: "He told me if I didn't pay him £200,000 he said he had a suitcase of stuff he would give to the police and inland revenue. I remember thinking, 'I need this like a hole in the head'. The biggest game in the club's history was four days away."

Later that day, Pulis said, he took the briefcase to Norman Hayward, a family friend who was chairman of AFC Bournemouth when Pulis was manager at the club. He said he did this because he did not know where else to take the documents. Hayward passed them to Roy Pack, a self-styled investigator of alleged corruption in football. Asked why he had taken them to Hayward and not the Football League, Pulis said: "I took them to people I thought could deal with it."

In fact, said Mr Mostyn, Pulis was motivated by greed and a desire to cause as much harm as possible to Scally and Gillingham. "Your story is a pack of lies," said Mr Mostyn. "There was a sordid conspiracy between you, Mr Hayward and Mr Pack, to blackmail Mr Scally, sell the story to the tabloids and to damage the club badly.

"It was naked blackmail and you set it up with the theft and concocted it with Mr Pack and Mr Hayward. That's the truth isn't it?" Pulis denied this. The court heard that the day before the meeting in the stand Pulis had spoken four times with Hayward on his mobile phone.

Mr Mostyn said that far from receiving the documents from Saffery, Pulis stole the documents. Saffery would deny any involvement, the court heard.

Pulis gave them to Hayward because he knew his former boss had a grudge against Scally. After AFC Bournemouth went into administration in January 1997 Hayward launched a bid, assisted by Pack, to win back control of the club. The Football League Commission, of which Scally was then a member, rejected their bid. "You knew, did you not, that Mr Scally was instrumental in having that bid rejected?," Mr Mostyn asked. Pulis denied this.

On receiving the documents Pack, who is acting as a consultant to Pulis in this case, took them to the publicist Max Clifford who sold them to the Daily Mail. A copy was also sent to the FA, which took no action. Clifford then tipped off the Daily Express about the documents, the court heard. "It's a monstrous situation that they [the documents] are being peddled up and down Grub Street," said Mr Mostyn.

Pulis denied accusing Scally of using club money to build an extension and swimming pool at his Kent home, and of buying cars for his wife and son and a Harley Davidson with club funds. He also denied making allegations of financial irregularities concerning the building company Dunning & Carter, which is carrying out work on a new stand and offices at the Priestfield stadium and at Scally's home. He also denied having clandestinely arranged to join Bristol City as soon as he had left Gillingham.

He agreed with Mr Mostyn's statement that, were the allegations against him true, "it would be as gross and grave a misconduct as it is possible to imagine."

Pulis also admitted he had lied about how he received the documents when he said in a statement to his solicitors that they had been passed to him anonymously. He also admitted lying when he was asked to return "all club property" at the termination of his contract. He said he had nothing other than a car and a mobile phone, when he knew his consultant, Pack, had the documents.

The case continues.

webTitle: Hendry hit by six-game Fifa ban

fields.headline: Hendry hit by six-game Fifa ban
fields.trailText: Scotland's captain Colin Hendry is facing the end of his international career after being handed a six-match ban by Fifa for his elbowing of a San Marino player last month.
fields.body:
Scotland's captain Colin Hendry was last night grimly contemplating the end of his international career after being "stunned and disappointed" by a six-match ban.

The 35-year-old defender was shocked by the punishment after Fifa had studied a video of the stoppage-time incident at Hampden Park last month in which Hendry lashed out at San Marino's Nicola Albani, catching him in the throat. Albani was carried off and spent a night in hospital.

Fifa found Hendry guilty of elbowing, and also fined him 10,000 Swiss francs (£4, 230).

Hendry hopes the Scottish FA will appeal on his behalf and the SFA, who thought his punishment severe, is considering that action.

Fifa did not specify immediately whether the ban includes friendlies. But, almost certainly, it applies only to competitive games, in which case Hendry's Scotland future looks to be over.

The Bolton defender would miss the last three World Cup qualifiers and, if Scotland reach Japan and South Korea, the first three games of next year's finals. By then he will be 36.

webTitle: Football correspondent Byron Butler dies at 66

fields.headline: Bryon Butler dies at 66
fields.trailText: English football has lost one of its best-loved voices with the death yesterday of Bryon Butler at 66.
fields.body:
English football has lost one of its best-loved voices with the death yesterday of Bryon Butler at 66.

As BBC Radio's football correspondent from 1968 to 1991 Butler commentated from around the world but will be best remembered for guiding listeners in hushed tones through the FA Cup draw on Monday lunchtimes.

With his rich voice, tinged with a West Country burr, he would welcome millions to "the antechamber" and open always with the words: "The first voice you will hear is ... "

Born in Taunton, Ewart Bryon Butler began in journalism on the Express and Echo in 1951 before moving to the Nottingham Evening News, Leicester Mercury, News Chronicle and Daily Telegraph.

He wrote the official histories of the FA Cup and the Football Association, and collaborated in the autobiographies of, among others, Billy Wright, Ron Greenwood and Alec Stock, a lifelong friend from their Somerset days.

Butler died in Guildford's Mount Alvernia hospital after fighting cancer for five years.

Peter Salmon, director of BBC Sport, said: "He was a wordsmith with a wonderfully distinctive voice which, for a broadcaster, is a magnificent combination. Our thoughts are very much with his wife Babs and family."

webTitle: You have to look up when you feel down

fields.headline: You have to look up when you feel down
fields.trailText: When you are facing the drop, the most important lesson is to remain upbeat and bright. Think positive and great things can happen at the end of a poor season.
fields.body:
I know how painful relegation can be. Going down with Sheffield Wednesday in 1990 was the worst moment I've known in football. And as the fight to avoid the drop from the Premiership goes on, there are certain rules I think troubled managers should apply.

What you have to do first and foremost is stay upbeat and bright. Obviously there will be times when you feel down, but you mustn't let the players see that you think it's past the post.

You have to be positive and make it clear that until it's mathematically impossible to stay up, everyone has to keep in there. I'm sure Joe Royle will be doing that at Manchester City.

Even when I took over at Nottingham Forest in a position that was basically beyond redemption I tried to drum into the players that we could survive.

I think we were eight points adrift but I said: "Look, forget what's happened in the first part of the season. Let's make this a 16-match season." I used to pin a league table up every week, showing the positions as if the season had just begun. As I remember, we finished about halfway.

Staying positive was crucial to keeping West Bromwich Albion in the First Division in 1979-80. In fact, I'd say that was one of my best spells as a manager.

For various reasons, we were bottom around Christmas, having finished third the season before. But I made sure everyone kept bright and breezy and nobody lost belief.

I kept reminding the lads they were good players and that if they kept plugging away it would come. I introduced a young Remi Moses into midfield to help Bryan Robson and I think we lost only one of the last 19 matches. We finished 10th.

Just as it's vital to keep bright in adversity, it's impor tant not to take your foot off the pedal and believe you are safe when you climb a few points clear of the drop zone. I know how quickly things can change from that relegation with Wednesday.

We were nine points clear of Luton going into the last week of the season. But they clawed that back and we went down on goal difference with 43 points, which was unbelievable. The irony was that in the last six games we felt we'd played better than at any other time.

We found out we were down when we got into the dressing room after losing at home to Forest and I just felt empty. I could see the players felt the same. Everyone was slumped and it was even more galling because we knew we had a good side. We felt we'd have done well the following season.

To make things worse I had to go to a supporters' club dinner about an hour or two later. That was hard, but we made the promise to the fans that we would do our utmost to get back in one and we managed it, winning the League Cup in the bargain by beating Manchester United.

But ultimately there's no set formula for avoiding the drop. You have to be in the camp to sense the mood and you need to have your finger on the pulse to judge what you think is required.

It may be that extra training will help all of a sudden. People say you shouldn't train too hard towards the end of a season but the shock treatment can kick them over the line.

On the other hand it might be a question of relaxing the players, maybe going for a game of golf or just telling them to go out and enjoy the feeling of playing football.

You have to be aware of what the situation requires. By buying John Hartson, Coventry have given themselves a chance, although I think the revival probably started half a dozen matches too late to keep them up.

When Joe Royle took over Everton at the bottom of the table in 1994 he introduced his dogs of war in midfield and survived. People like Joe Parkinson made sure opponents couldn't get through.

At Coventry in 1995-96 we had a game-plan for Liverpool that helped us avoid the drop. The pitch at Highfield Road was a hell of a mess and Liverpool had been in one of their 4-3 matches against Newcastle three days earlier. So we decided to play at a high tempo and tried to make it as awkward and horrible as we could.

We hit everything into the front as quickly as possible, stopped them getting a passing pattern going and won 1-0. What Coventry would do for a repeat at home to Liverpool tomorrow.

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.teletext.co.uk/holidays
fields.trailText: www.teletext.co.uk/holidays.
fields.body:
I can get Teletext on my TV. Why would I bother with the site?

The familiar Teletext of numbered pages will eventually become obsolete when the company has fully developed its service for digital TVs. So Teletext wants to win over web users as well as the 14 million people who consult the pages every day. It launched this site in 1994.

Seven years ago! It must be a pretty sophisticated site by now.

Oddly enough, no. While there are promises of an "interactive" site that will enable you to buy holidays and flights online rather than just searching for them, it's still a bit primitive. The holiday offers appear on the site in exactly the same format as they do on the TV. You have to scroll from page to page.

Maybe people like to find a familiar format.

Possibly, but with lavish package sites like the Virgin Travelstore snapping at its heels, Teletext should move faster if it wants to keep up. fields.headline: ITC mulls ITV news bid
fields.trailText: The news consortium comprising Sky, Bloomberg, CBS, Chrysalis and Ulster TV has formally applied to the ITC for nomination as the official ITV news provider. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The news consortium put together by Sky, Bloomberg, CBS, Chrysalis and Ulster TV has formally applied to the ITC for nomination as the official ITV news provider.

The consortium, called Channel Three News Ltd, wants to take over the contract from ITN, which has held the ITV news contract since the launch of independent television in the 1950s.

A statement from the ITC said the commission "will consider the application from Channel Three News Ltd against the requirement of the Act to ensure that a nominated news provider is, or if appointed would be, effectively equipped and adequately financed."

The ITC will comment on Thursday May 10 on whether Channel Three News is entitled to bid.

ITN has dismissed the consortium, which was announced at the end of January, as a "ragbag partnership crafted of desperation".

But the bid represents a major threat to ITN, which depends for its existence on the contract, which is worth around £50m a year.

Rupert Murdoch's Sky News has mounted a number of unsuccessful challenges to ITN's current terrestrial news monopoly, most recently with a bid for the contract to provide Channel 5 news.

But it is thought unlikely that the increasingly consolidated ITV companies, who are shareholders in ITN, would award the contract to an outsider.

Towards a single ITV

webTitle: Why Keano keeps taking a pop at his team-mates

fields.headline: Why Keano keeps taking a pop at his team-mates
fields.trailText: Roy Keane. Just days after trying to tear Alfie Haaland apart, he takes another pop at his team-mates.
fields.body:
Roy Keane. Just days after trying to tear Alfie Haaland apart, he takes another pop at his team-mates.

So what's the matter with him? Is he frustrated because he missed his chance to cripple Haaland? Or, as some United fans would believe, is he trying to upset the apple-cart to engineer a move to Celtic, the team he has supported since he was a boy?

Despite the plausibility of the Celtic conspiracy theory, the real reason for Keane's latest outburst is simple: he has no place for sentiment.

While every United fan would give both legs, one arm and their head to play in the famous shirt, Keane views it as his job and nothing more - a hard thing for the fans to accept.

A footballer's career is short and Keane wants to be as successful as possible. To help him achieve this, he needs the best players around him that money can buy. So, from his point of view, all team-mates are expendable if they can be replaced by better players.

That lack of sentimentality is also evident in the way Keane views United. He doesn't see the club through rose-tinted spectacles but merely as his employer - a stance demonstrated by his attitude during his last contract negotiations with the club.

He refused to undervalue himself and made it clear to the club that he would leave if they did not make him the right offer. United stalled, only to capitulate at the last moment. Few people doubt Keane would have left had they not.

Following this unseemly episode, Keane was also angered by the way the club intimated, in a letter to all season-ticket holders, that his salary rise was responsible for a rise in prices.

He refused to play in the next game until he received an apology. He got one, but this incident reinforced Keane's view that he is an employee, and nothing more, of Manchester United.

Much is also made by the press of Keane's social relationship, or lack of it, with the rest of the team. Gary Neville and David Beckham cook each other pasta, while Ryan Giggs and Dwight Yorke are regulars in Mancunia's finest haunts. Keane, meanwhile, goes home to his wife and young children.

What's less often pointed out is that his anti-social behaviour is not just confined to United. When Keane goes away with Ireland, he rooms alone (since Denis Irwin retired from the international scene) and spends most of his free time by himself.

But the crucial thing is that it doesn't effect the relationship between Keane and his team-mates on the pitch. It's the never-say-die attitude which has lead United to overwhelm so many teams in the final few minutes and earned the respect of his fellow players.

Keane might be a little eccentric but it doesn't mean he dislikes his team-mates. After all, if Keane dislikes you, he'll let you know.

Just ask Alfie Halaand.

fields.headline: Morning glory
fields.standfirst: After seeing Josh off at the airport, Milly returns to work, reacquaints herself with Sydney, and gets up at dawn to see the Anzac Day parade
fields.trailText: Week 21: New Zealand to Sydney After seeing Josh off at the airport, Milly returns to work, reacquaints herself with Sydney, and gets up at dawn to see the Anzac Day parade
fields.body:
Thursday saw Josh and I leave New Zealand, which was definitely a pity because I had such a lovely time there. Our flight was at the crack of dawn - which reminds me, lots of countries like to charge you for the privilege of leaving their airport, so be prepared as you pass through into the departure lounge (I never have any money left at this point).

I'd been planning to stay in a city hostel for a couple of nights when I arrived in Sydney to give me time to get myself together, but when I started phoning around I couldn't believe how expensive they were - especially since many of them were in very scummy locations. Eventually I plumped for a new hostel called Wanderers on Kent, and we fought our way through the rush hour traffic to get there. Fortunately, the hostel was worth the struggle - it was clean (including the showers!!) and new, the staff were friendly and the location was great! The only downside was that the rates were expensive, especially after New Zealand.

Josh and I ambled around Sydney and I reacquainted myself with my one-time home - although I couldn't help feeling that it had lost some of its charm after the quiet beauty of South Island. Later that afternoon I had to see Josh off at the airport - inevitably very emotional - and then I was alone again. I wasn't too worried about that as I was going to start work again on Saturday and then I had just nine short days left before I would leave Sydney forever and travel up the coast. Using the last five months as a guide, I was certain the time would fly by.

Later that night in my hostel I was desperate to go out somewhere - when I'm left alone the last thing I want to do is sit in a room. Unable to find anyone awake in the hostel, I headed to the bar next door where, after a short while, an Australian couple took me under their wing. I wound up having a very fun night that carried on into the small hours - and I got some good advice from the locals. I knew there were reasons why I loved Sydney.

The next day, in an attempt to clear my head, I walked to Circular Quay and caught a ferry to Milson's Point, the site of the North Sydney Olympic Pool. I'd promised myself I'd get back in the water, and this seemed like a good way to start. The greatest thing about this pool is that if you just turn your head while you're swimming (either indoor or outdoor) you find yourself looking across the harbour towards the city with the bridge looming large in front of it. It very nearly distracted me from the actual swimming, although I felt so relaxed in the water that there may be hope for me yet! This was also to be my last night in the city - as it happened a bed was available at my old place, and budget-wise I would have been crazy not to move back in.

My three hostel room-mates and I headed down towards the Rocks (the oldest area of Sydney) as one of them - an American girl - had yet to see the bridge and Opera House. After stopping for pizza at a small, crowded restaurant, we headed on to see Sydney's best-known sights. In the dark they are pretty spectacular and, though I didn't gawp as much as the others, I was reminded of how impressive the two structures are - especially the solid harbour bridge which dominates the skyline at so many points around the harbour. So Sydney is beautiful in its own way too.

I had to drag myself out of bed at a silly time on Saturday for the pleasure of work. My hostel has a 24-hour reception and big storage lockers which is fantastic, as I could actually check out and leave my stuff at 4.30am. My day at work was actually pretty enjoyable - as I'd been away, I spent most of it recounting details of my trip to New Zealand and catching up with everybody. I also got invited to the house-warming of a couple of work-mates, so later that evening, after dragging my bag back to Coogee and pretty much just dumping it in my new room, I headed back out to Kirribilli, an attractive area on the opposite side of the harbour bridge. It was a fun evening, although I bet the two of them were relieved that they had yet to acquire any furniture!

The disadvantage of going out with everybody you work with is that you all have to work the next day. That explains why on Sunday night there was a slightly ropy-looking group of us at the Jewish wedding reception. Actually I was quite keen to see it - I've heard they can be pretty lavish events and this turned out to be true. Such a lot of effort went into the evening: the ballroom looked like something out of a fairy tale, the guests wore some fantastic outfits and the whole thing seemed almost choreographed, especially the bride and groom's big entrance and their waltz together.

Despite it being a fun evening I was shattered, and very much relieved to be let off early - and also given a hotel room key! I had to start work at 4am the next day and luckily there was a free room, so that evening I got to stay in five-star luxury. Unfortunately it defeated the point of sending me up early - I was so excited by the comfy bed, shower and robes, big TV and tea-maker that I stayed up using everything and had less than two hours' sleep. Still, those hours were in the cosiest bed I've ever been in - which made it very hard to leave!

I made it through another long day and at the end of the shift it hit me - I've only got one more day of work after this, ever! I met this realisation with mixed emotions, but mostly with lots of anticipation for what the future holds.

That night was Sapphire and Dave's last in Sydney before they head on to Melbourne and then New Zealand - like me, they've been brought round to the idea of going there because everyone talks about it so much. They were staying in the same place as me in Coogee although none of us had really been in to see each other, so that evening we had a quiet dinner celebration - actually, we stretched to a three-course meal, but as the extent of the actual cooking was switching on an oven, I won't describe it to you!

On Tuesday I saw the two of them off for the last time until we meet England in September, and it then occurred to me that I had a day off. I was almost at a loose end - it's been such a long time since I've had a day to myself. Still, there are so many options around this city that I was really spoilt for choice. In the end I took the bus down to Bondi Junction - I hadn't been there for a while and the shops are good. I enjoyed a delicious sushi roll before purchasing the cookbook I'd been promising myself, then headed into the city simply to enjoy wandering around the ever-crowded streets. Later I cooked a beautiful vegetable stir-fry - well, OK, I cooked, which is achievement enough - and for once took it easy. Sometimes when I'm travelling I feel like I should be doing things all the time, but then I remind myself that it doesn't hurt to relax once in a while. Good for the soul.

Besides, the next morning my alarm went off at 3am - and for once it wasn't for work. Wednesday April 25 is Anzac (Australian and New Zealand Army Corps) Day, a public holiday, and I was off to the city to watch the dawn Anzac parade. I'd been advised by the locals to see this commemoration of the day in 1915 when Australians landed on the beach of Galipoli. It was the first calling of the newly-formed nation 'Australia' and although it was an unsuccessful manoeuvre, it kindled the spirit of 'mateship' and the slogan 'lest we forget'. At 4.30am a crowd of thousands stood in the dark near Martin's Place Cenotaph, listening to readings and joining in with the singing. It was a moving event, and one I was glad to be present for so I could understand the heritage of my adopted home. After the ceremony the crowd flocked to look at the Cenotaph which glowed gold in the early light and had been covered in flowers. There are just 24 veterans still living and later that morning, as taxis transported some of them at the front of a parade, the crowd cheered wildly.

Because it was a public holiday I had the rest of the day to myself, and it was sizzling hot. My house-mates and I headed to the beach for a while, then, as one of them had a birthday, we bought a big picnic and joined several other friendly family groups in the sun at a beach-side park. It was an idyllic afternoon, full of good sun, good food and good drink. I slept very soundly that night.

Until next week (end of work, end of Sydney - and no idea quite where I'm going next!), Milly.

fields.headline: TV horseracing bid imminent
fields.trailText:
Shares in Arena Leisure, part of the Go Racing consortium negotiating a £320m horseracing media rights deal, have been suspended, reports Jason Deans.

27.04.2001: GG Media launches advertising campaign
fields.body:
Shares in Arena Leisure, part of the Go Racing consortium negotiating a £320m horseracing media rights deal, have been suspended pending an announcement about the agreement.

It is thought a deal could be announced next week between Go Racing, the consortium formed by Arena Leisure, Channel 4 and BSkyB, and the Racecourse Association.

Go Racing was due to send out a revised contract to the individual racecourses with which it is negotiating exclusively by today.

The racecourses have 10 working days, or until Monday May 14, to respond.

Go Racing is negotiating a deal for all TV and online rights to UK horseracing, including interactive betting.

Arena Leisure owns six of the 59 UK racetracks.

webTitle: Pullis sacking settled out of court

fields.headline: Pullis sacking settled out of court
fields.trailText: A £400,000 High Court claim brought by former Gillingham Football Club manager Tony Pulis following his sacking two years ago was settled for £75,000 today.
fields.body:
A £400,000 High Court claim brought by former Gillingham Football Club manager Tony Pulis following his sacking two years ago was settled for £75,000 today.

Gillingham is to pay the £75,000 in respect of Mr Pulis's claim that he had not been paid bonuses due to him.

Each side is to pay its own legal costs of the case, which was suddenly settled on the fourth day of a hearing in London.

Mr Pulis, currently unemployed following stints at Bristol City and Portsmouth, had sued for loss of at least £168,000 salary, plus bonuses and expenses-paid car and telephone benefits, after his £50,000-a-year contract with Gillingham was terminated.

He said he had lost the opportunity to earn bonuses based on team performance, including possible promotion to the First Division, and had not been paid £195,000 in bonuses due to him following the sale of three players.

Gillingham's lawyers told Judge Peter Clark that the club maintained his instant dismissal was justified by "gross misconduct" which amounted to a repudiation of his service contract.

fields.headline: Scrapie gives cattle BSE-like disease
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Government scientists have infected cattle with another BSE-like disease using scrapie from sheep in an experiment that raises new questions about the origins of BSE and whether food safety measures are satisfactory.
fields.body:
Government scientists have infected cattle with another BSE-like disease using scrapie from sheep in an experiment that raises new questions about the origins of BSE and whether food safety measures are satisfactory.

Two cows developed the symptoms 18 months after injections into their brains of material from sheep brains infected with scrapie, a disease long considered harmless to humans. But it might be five years before the experiment's significance can be assessed.

If scrapie was considered a danger after all, there would shock among the political, scientific and medical establishments. British farming could be dealt another blow, since it would be far harder to remove all potentially infective parts of sheep from food.

There may, however, be no significance for human health.

The two animals put down after showing clinical signs of illness will be tested to see whether the disease behaves similarly or differently from BSE or scrapie.

The experiment is being carried out by the veterinary laboratories agency. Officials were insisting last night that the new disease might be neither scrapie nor BSE.

One official, Danny Matthews, said it was likely that the results "of this one study will not be interpretable until we have the results of other studies that are under way".

The experiment, the first in Britain, started in July 1999, 13 years after BSE was identified in cattle and three years after the admission that people were probably dying because they had eaten infected parts of cows.

Any "scrapie in cattle" would not be as worrying as BSE in sheep, which has been caused in laboratories. There is no evidence that this has happened naturally, but the government has contingency plans, including widespread sheep culls.

fields.headline: Biotechs target activists
fields.trailText: The biotechnology industry last night published an "election manifesto" calling for sweeping new restrictions on the right to protest, in an attempt to subdue violent animal rights activists.
fields.body:
The biotechnology industry last night published an "election manifesto" calling for sweeping new restrictions on the right to protest, in an attempt to subdue violent animal rights activists.

The BioIndustry Association demanded the creation of a new law making it an offence to "organise a campaign purely to attempt to cause the demise of a legitimate business".

Other suggestions include the creation of a "soft loans scheme" to aid start-up businesses and liberal patent law to avoid "discrimination" against genetic research.

Paul Drayson, chairman of the association, said: "Britain started this industry in the early 1980s. My vision for 2005 is for the UK to be the life sciences hub of Europe, and the bridge between the European and US healthcare markets."

The association's call for a further crackdown on animal rights activists is a direct response to the continuing campaign against Huntingdon Life Sciences, which has lost clients, shareholders and bankers as a result of sometimes violent protests.

But the scope of the suggested law is sure to be controversial, as it appears to rule out almost any boycott or protest against a law-abiding corporation. Greg Avery of Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, which says it opposes violence, said: "The way the Human Rights Act stands, they haven't got a chance of this. The industry is always saying they don't oppose legitimate protests - this shows that they obviously do."

The government has promised extensions to harassment legislation to target animal rights groups, which are accused of provoking violence by posting the home addresses of Huntingdon Life Science's staff and shareholders on the internet.

A spokeswoman for the BioIndustry Association said: "Companies like Huntingdon are mandated by the government to conduct animal testing work.

"The fact that a small group of people can target them, and jeopardise that work, is something that should be stopped."

fields.headline: 'Konglish' replaces good English
fields.trailText: How bad can English get? Very if it's "Konglish", reports David Cohen in his round-up of the international papers.
fields.body:
How bad can bad English get? Very bad indeed, in the view of a commentary published in the Korea Herald, in which the writer laments the state of "Konglish", the hybrid of jazzy Korean and messy English that, "like heavy traffic is an unpleasant but tolerable side of life" in the East Asian capital.

Well, maybe not quite so tolerable these days. The recent opening of a bedazzling new multi-billion dollar airport in Seoul, where as many as 49 signs were subsequently discovered to have fallen prey to writers of Konglish, spoke "volumes about the state of the translation and proofreading industry in Korea," the paper said. A few weeks previously, the vernacular newspaper Dong-a Ilbo had reported on a study conducted by Lee Ye Shik, a professor of English education at Kyungpook National University, that found hundreds of similar examples of Konglish in four first-year junior high school textbooks.

"Bad English in textbooks is particularly troubling because it helps reproduce the passivity towards good English that has permitted bad English to prosper in Korea for so long," the Herald concluded. "If students are exposed to mistakes that many teachers will teach as good English, then how can English education in Korea improve?"

Perhaps it can do this by looking to the example of continental Europe. In a colourful piece published last week, the New York Times reported from Thalwil, in Switzerland, where English has become part of the daily routine in schools. Students as young as seven are learning multiplication or discussing the weather in English, and have even bypassed learning local German tunes in favour of "Old MacDonald" and "How Are You This Morning?" Parents are delighted, the article noted, but editorial writers elsewhere have demurred, asking why on earth, in a country with German, French, Italian and Romansch as national languages, children are should be learning English as their first foreign language.

A shirty editorial published in the Geneva-based daily Le Matin attacked Zurich's education minister, Ernst Buschor, for threatening to tear the fabric of Switzerland's linguistically diverse state by extolling the example of a town like Thalwil. The newspaper said: "He who has clearly learned little from his history lessons will go down in the history books as the gravedigger of the Swiss identity."

The African press offers its younger nationals no such succour. Although news of the continent's bloodiest campus riots in nearly a decade led several of the regionÍs newspapers this week, few reports contained words of solace or explanation. An estimated 2,500 Ethiopian students were arrested following protests that started at the University of Addis Ababa, leaving at least 41 people dead and more than 250 injured. The mayhem evoked memories of the student resistance to the military regime that ruled the nation from 1974 to 1991, although the cause of the latest violence was understood to have been students demanding a greater hand in their own university's affairs.

A typical report, carried in Ethiopia's Daily Monitor, quoted an officer in charge of the crackdown saying that the arrests had occurred simply in order to allow police to sort out "the hooligans from the students". Another report quoted the police as saying that no more than 31 people had been killed -11 of them victims of stray bullets, 11 others under "unknown circumstances" and 11 more being "hooligans with criminal records who were gunned down while looting or vandalising public and private property". Elementary arithmetic, not truth, would appear to be the first casualty in any conflict in Ethiopia.

Elsewhere in the region, an editorial published in the Al-Ahram Weekly in Egypt took aim at the mistreatment of scholars in Iran. It declared that the Islamic republic's periodic crackdowns on intellectuals have become as "familiar to the public's ears as an increase in the price of milk or the vanishing of a favourite newspaper". The mass arrest earlier this month of 42 dissidents, including a number of university administrators, "was a sign to reformists that no threat to the system, however legal or mild, would be tolerated," it said.

In a separate editorial commentary, the same newspaper weighed in on Morals, the latest discipline to be added to the Egyptian curriculum, which is intended to instruct school children in what officials describe as ethical behaviour, politeness and good conduct. "This curious innovation," noted the paper, "is due to concerns about the decline in morality among young people, as evidenced in widespread bullying, cheating, complete disregard for laws and regulations and the beating up of teachers." But will it achieve the slightest good? To the contrary, said Al-Ahram, it will "be spoon-fed and memorised, regurgitated at exams then forgotten - without any gain in terms of morality, freedom or democracy."

Kids, go easy on that driver. Just a day after San Jose school bus operator Cathline Repunte was arraigned on Wednesday on charges of murder and attempted murder, the Mercury News in San Francisco speculated on a likely motive for the shootings. In addition to the usual morning-after cliches with which writers tend to adorn such pieces, the paper also noted that the assailant was a loner, as well as being "reclusive" and "angry". The suspect was also revealed to be ... a stern disciplinarian.

In the weeks before she allegedly opened fire, killing one and wounding three of her fellow school bus drivers, Ms Repunte and the students who rode the bus on her new route traded many unpleasantries. She had always been "quick to tell her young passengers to quiet down," the paper revealed, "going as far as filing a written complaint about their behaviour with her employer."

No word, of course, on the vague possibility that the easy availability of handguns in the United States might have played the remotest part in this latest American school tragedy.

webTitle: Gene hope for test tube babies

fields.headline: Gene hope for test tube babies
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists have discovered a gene which could explain some women's infertility and lead to higher success rates for IVF or test tube treatment.
fields.body:
Scientists have discovered a gene which could explain some women's infertility and lead to higher success rates for IVF or test tube treatment.

Ninety per cent of couples who undergo fertility treatment produce embryos but only 20% of those successfully implant in the lining of the womb.

Scientists at the Imperial College school of medicine and Hammersmith hospital in west London report in the Lancet that they have identified a gene which appears to play a role. El-Nasir Lalani and colleagues have found that the difference in size of the MUC1 gene, found in the lining of the womb, could influence the potential of embryos to implant.

The scientists enrolled 20 women, 10 of whom had experienced two successful pregnancies and 10 of whom had a history of unexplained fertility - although they produced eggs which were fertilised in the lab, the resulting embryos when replaced in the womb apparently failed to implant.

They extracted DNA of all the women and found that the MUC1 gene was shorter in most of those who had fertility problems. "The size of the MUC1 gene is known to vary in different geographical and ethnic populations," said El-Nasir Lalani. "We are expanding our study to include women from different parts of the world and ethnic backgrounds."

Lord Robert Winston, one of the authors of the research letter and director of research and development at Hammersmith hospital, said: "This discovery should offer a potential target for new treatment. There is no doubt that many more genes will be found which also influence the implanted embryo."

fields.headline: Warning on anti-smoking drug company
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline was criticised yesterday for failing to give doctors enough information about the anti-smoking drug Zyban, and was ordered to clarify its advice to people using the drug in combination with other medicines.
fields.body:
The pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline was criticised yesterday for failing to give doctors enough information about the anti-smoking drug Zyban, and was ordered to clarify its advice to people using the drug in combination with other medicines.

The Hertford coroner, Alan Lawson, speaking after recording a verdict of death by natural causes on Kerry Weston, 21, a British Airways flight attendant who died a fortnight after she was prescribed Zyban, said advice given when prescribing the drug should be improved. She died at a hotel in Nairobi, Kenya, in January.

Mr Lawson said he endorsed comments by Robin Ferner, a doctor, that information given to patients by GlaxoSmith-Kline should make it clear that Zyban is incompatible with the anti-malarial treatment Chloroquine, which Weston had also taken.

Thirty-seven patients in Britain have died after taking Zyban and 5,352 adverse reactions have been registered by the state monitoring scheme.

"It seems to me that it may only be now that there will be a general understanding of the dangers of taking Chloroquine and Bupropion [Zyban's trade name] in combination. It does not seem to be something of which the medical profession is generally, or has hitherto, been aware," Mr Lawson said.

GlaxoSmithKline responded in a statement: "There is no evidence of an increased risk of death associated with the use of this medicine."

webTitle: Breast implants linked to brain and lung cancer

fields.headline: Breast implants linked to brain and lung cancer
fields.trailText: Women with breast implants of any variety are statistically up to three times more likely to die from lung or brain cancer than those without, a 12-year study has shown.
fields.body:
Women with breast implants of any variety are statistically up to three times more likely to die from lung or brain cancer than those without, a 12-year study has shown.

The findings of the research are likely to alarm and confuse women who have had breast implants, because scientists responsible for the study of 13,500 women since 1989 have no explanation for them.

The results do not show that the implants cause disease - only that those women who have them are more likely to get brain or lung cancer. Scientists now intend to examine whether women who have breast implants are more likely to be smokers.

The study has been carried out in the US and is due to be published in full in two medical journals later this month, but yesterday the New York Times carried a report of its basic findings. The women involved got their implants prior to 1989, and were observed until last year. Comparisons were drawn with 4,000 other plastic surgery patients and the general population.

The researchers found no difference in the death rates between the 10% who had saline implants and the 90% who had the more controversial silicone implants, which have now been banned in the United States after large numbers of women complained of adverse health effects and sued the manufacturers.

Chief researcher, Louise Brinton, of the American National Cancer Institute, said there were no extra cancers of any other sort in the implant group and said more research was needed to establish the cause of the increased rates of lung and brain cancers.

"What the study showed is no difference for most of the cancer sites, which I think is good news," said Dr Brinton.

"For the few sites which we did find differences, we have no ready explanation. So I would not want to alarm women on the basis of one study."

Dr Brinton said research in the future would concentrate on whether women with breast implants were more likely to be smokers. It was not known if the women who died of the cancers in the study had been smokers, as information was taken from death certificates.

The women with implants were three times more likely to die of lung cancer and twice as likely to die of brain cancer as other women. Diana Zuckerman, one of the study's scientific advisers, told the New York Times: "I see this as a warning ... I think this is very alarming."

But she added that the study only showed a statistical link with cancers. "You can't draw a conclusion from these studies, even though they are very well designed, very solid," she said.

There has been continuing concern over the safety of breast implants - particularly those filled with silicone - even though independent inquiries in the UK have given them a clean bill of health.

A Commons select committee recently recommended that there should be a surveillance system to monitor the possible side-effects of breast implants.

David Hinchliffe, the Labour MP for Wakefield and the chairman of the health select committee, said women should "think very carefully" before having surgery to increase the size of their breasts.

About 8,000 women a year in Britain have breast enlargement surgery but some have had implants removed because of the controversies.

 Several soldiers have had breast enlargement operations in a military hospital at ministry of defence expense, it was revealed yesterday.

The operations were in the "public interest", the MoD insisted. "They were not just a "cosmetic or vanity thing".

The implants were only given to servicewomen who had developed a "recurring and chronic psychological difficulty" preventing them from being effective soldiers.

Breast implants were approved only when there were clinical reasons and after counselling had failed, the MoD spokesman said.

The cost of an operation, between £2,000 and £2,500, compared with the thousands of pounds training the women soldiers in the "service of the country", he said.

"We are not treating our servicewomen any differently than they would be treated as civilians by the NHS", he added.

The operations were carried out in Haslar military hospital in Portsmouth.

Up to 12 soldiers had had their breasts enlarged there since the mid 1990s. However, others may have been performed at military wards at some NHS hospitals.

"We have got no central records of them" an MoD spokesman said.

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, described the state of affairs as "ridiculous" and brought a whole new meaning to the phrase "second front".

He added: "This is happening at a time when money is short in the armed forces.

"This government seems to be squandering money on things that will have little effect on fighting capability even if they enhance morale."

Sean Ingle = £18.32

Scott Murray: Bradford to win at Everton £5 @ 7/2

Let's face it, the way things have been going, Everton are going to go down sooner rather than later. It won't happen this year - file season 2000/01 under "yet another close call" - but perhaps next time round will be a scrape too far.

They're obviously preparing for their spectacular relegation a season early. By extracting the last traces of invention from their football, the Goodison "giants" have managed to lose five of their last six. Well done lads!

Bradford, meanwhile, are in a rich vein of form. They've won their last two, were unlucky to lose at Tottenham, drew another couple and gave Ipswich a real fright for 60 minutes at Portman Road. What's more, they're scoring goals as well. With relegation inevitable and the pressure off, they haven't failed to find the net since February 10.

And Everton are odds-on to beat them?

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes): Leicester to beat Newcastle 10/3 @ £5

The Prince once met Peter Taylor at a function. It was at the residency of the Kyrgyzstani ambassador, and rather pleasant it was too. Mr Taylor engaged the Prince for more than an hour on the subject of sports socks, and the importance in the modern game of starching them thoroughly. I took his words on board and have never forgotten them. Never made any use of them either, but that's one's luck.

With such a thorough approach to the game, surely he couldn't lead his Leicester side to a club record eight league defeats on the trot? Back against weak favourites said the sage, and so I will.

So with that precious point at the so-called Theatre of Dreams last weekend, City awaken just in time to avoid the drop? Not likely. The hapless Hammers have been in one hell of a sulk since Spurs dumped them from the FA Cup, and if City could have chosen their opponents for such a vital game, Harry_s mob would certainly have been towards the top of the list.

But even so, you have to worry about a side that blows between lukewarm and frosty with shocking regularity. More worryingly still, you truly fear for a side that relies so heavily on the predatory instincts of an arthritic Goat for its survival. Even a mildly-interested West Ham will be good enough for a point. Which is, of course, of no use to City at all.

Las Palmas are huge favourites for this relegation six pointer (copyright tabloid journalists across the world), but I'm not sure why. On the surface their home record is decent (seven wins, three draws and five defeats) while Sociedad's away record is diabolical (three wins, three draws, nine losses). But pry a little deeper and different story emerges.

Las Palmas' recent record is atrocious. In their last ten games in La Liga, Vinny Samways and his mates have won once, drawn twice and lost seven. Meanwhile another Brit, John Toshack, has inspired Sociedad to a five match unbeaten run (two wins and three draws). So a small wager on John's boys has got to be worth it, hasn't it?
