webTitle: Bold No 10 idea for tax and schools

fields.headline: Bold No 10 idea for tax and schools
fields.standfirst: Think tank says middle class powers a barrier to meritocracy
fields.trailText: Think tank says middle class powers a barrier to meritocracy.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's personal think tank has told him to increase inheritance and income tax, as well as increase selection in state schools if he is achieve his vision of a genuine meritocratic society in Britain.

The report suggests wealthy parents are buying access to good state schools by being able to afford the higher house prices in the school's local catchment area.

"Significant policy interventions" would be needed to overcome the barriers to social mobility, including the barriers to downward mobility, it says.

It even suggests it might be necessary - on the basis of US studies - to spend as at least 10 times as much on the education of each black child as on each white child to equalise their future wage earnings.

The stark analysis comes from the Performance and Innovation Unit - the Cabinet Office think tank used by Mr Blair to tackle controversial political issues.

The findings, published yesterday, are bound to be attacked by the Conservatives as Labour's hidden agenda. But they are also likely to be seen as a sober warning to Mr Blair either to moderate his rhetoric about achieving a meritocracy, or think through its tough consequences for what the paper describes as "the dull middle class".

The prime minister told the Labour conference in 1999 that he wanted to create a meritocratic rather than egalitarian society.

The report is the product of a seminar involving some of Whitehall's leading thinkers, including key figures from the Downing Street policy unit and Anthony Giddens, the "third way" thinker.

It argues that earnings mobility has stalled in Britain, and suggests that deindustrialisation may have been the single biggest cause. Ethnic minorites, it says, have suffered most.

In the past 20 years income inequalities have widened significantly, Mr Blair's think tank states. "Between 1979 and 1998-99, the real incomes of the bottom decile of the income distribution rose by 6% in real terms whereas the real incomes of those in the top 10% rose by 82%. Mean income rose by 55%".

While "more room at the top" - due to economic growth - has allowed more of the poor to rise up the social ladder, the report finds no evidence that the middle class have been at any greater risk of a fall in social status.

The PIU finds that middle class people buy the best education either through private schools or by moving near to the best state schools.

The report says "the higher levels of education attainment mean that private schools nowadays offer access to good universities through academic qualifications rather than through contacts or old boy networks".

A true meritocratic society must include high rates of social mobility and the absence of any association between class origins and equality of opportunity, the report maintains.

It also shows that when the poor do move out of poverty it is not very far or for very long. Of those in the bottom two deciles in 1991, less than one in four was in top 60% of the income distribution in 1998.

Drawing on government research, the report suggests that there has also been an overall decline in earnings mobility in the two decades between 1977 and 1997, particularly among prime age men. Earnings progression for women seems to have improved.

It also shows that 40% to 50% of employees who start in the lowest quarter of earnings distribution are still there after six years in employment.

The analysis is not likely to be particularly palatable in poitical terms to the Labour leadership, which claimed yesterday that it could largely break the cycle of inequality through implementing its radical ideas for allocating incremental assets through the stages of childhood.

The report says it is a matter for politicians to decide how far they wish to push the mobilty agenda.

If the government wants mobility to be strong and widespread - downward, as well as upward mobility - it will have to chose strong options, including some quite dramatic tax measures.

The report suggests that the strongest option might have disadvantages, including the creation of more "losers, social tension and the possibility that winners could scoop all the rewards".

The findings came on the day the government faced criticism for caving into convention by appointing 15 establishment figures to the House of Lords. They had been billed in advance as " people's peers".

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed: Shopping at M&S | Overexposed: Chloë Sevigny | Overheard: "To Gabrielle it" | Pretend you know all about: Monica Magli
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: Shopping at M&S

For chi-chi accessories, who needs Colette in Paris when you've got M&S at Marble Arch? Take a deep breath, avert your eyes from the dodgy lilac cardies and head straight upstairs to Autograph for all the delectable designer what-nots a girl could want.

Philip Treacy's just-arrived hats and hairpieces are a true bargain, starting from just £70. (With only 60 of some styles produced, you'll need to be quick. And yes, there is a waiting list.) Nip over to the jewellery table to snap up a rainbow-coloured Swarovski crystal piece by designer Kate Woods (earrings start at £10). And if you just can't wait until July to get your hands on Julien Macdonald's first Givenchy couture range (or if you don't feel like robbing a bank), try this Macdonald for Autograph bikini, highlighted with flecks of gold or silver, for £27.

If your shopping lust still isn't satiated by the time you leave Autograph, check out the new "bra sensor", a hand-held gadget exclusive to M&S, which allows lingerie fitters to measure the pressure a bra applies on your skin and so ensure the perfect fit. I tried it but it didn't work properly because the fitter was shorter than me, which made the gadget go wobbly. But still, spend £25 on bras and knickers in May, and you get £3 off. How many more reasons do you need to go shopping?

Overexposed: Chloë Sevigny

Sorry, but who does the little madam think she is, frankly. Chloë Sevigny, art house It girl and creative director of much-hyped New York label Imitation of Christ, always slightly annoyed us with her too-jammy thrift-store finds and her cooler-than-thou deadpan stare. And winning a best-dressed award seems to have gone to her head.

In the latest issue of US Harper's Bazaar, Sevigny tugs our heartstrings with this poignant revelation: "For some reason the public has embraced me as a fashion icon, and I feel like it has diminished me as an actress." To make matters worse, those cruel magazine witches have ignored her pleas for anonymity and forced her to pose on the cover of the Best-Dressed issue. The meanies! Presumably the shackles are just out of shot.

Inside, Sevigny displays as much grace under pressure as a wasp in a jam jar. "Carolyn Bessette always looked so elegant - and like Gwyneth wishes," she snaps, adding: "People are saying Kate Hudson is fashionable now - boring to me." Girl, Gwyneth and Kate are clearly adorable and being nasty to them is like kicking sweet little puppies and kittens. It makes you look a right cow. Stop it now.

Overheard: "To Gabrielle it"

To sustain one's career by recycling the same piece of work once a year, every year.

Pretend you know all about: Monica Magli

If you know your shoe shops, the name probably rings a bell. Monica is the great-niece of veteran Italian shoe designer Bruno Magli. This might at first seem further evidence that a celebrated surname never goes out of fashion, but the collection from Monica by Magli, which is really very nice, will change your mind before you can say "Stella McCartney".

Known for being classic, beautifully made and pricey, Bruno Magli shoes also have the odd distinction of a walk-on role in one of the trials of last century. The shoes worn to the scene of the double murder of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ron Goldman were size 12 suede Bruno Magli lace-ups. The style, Lorenzo, has since been discontinued. (OJ Simpson called them "ugly ass" shoes and denied that he had ever worn them.)

Monica's task is to leave the Lorenzo behind. Having worked in her family's Bologna company since leaving college, Monica is well-grounded in the family art of stiletto bolognese. The Monica by Magli range is a younger, edgier look than the traditional Bruno Magli. Stand-outs from the recently unveiled autumn collection include black leather boots with panels of silver studs along the back of the calf and black satin court shoes with gold chains looped at the heel, like shiny epaulettes for your shoes. Definitely not "ugly ass" shoes, thank you very much.

webTitle: Researchers say anti-vivisection protests are misguided

fields.headline: Researchers say anti-vivisection protests are misguided
fields.trailText: Academics working to find ways of reducing animal testing in their research state that anti-vivisectionists should stop their violent protests.
fields.body:
Anti-vivisectionists have demanded that researchers reduce their use of animal testing during World Laboratory Animal Week, ending on Sunday. However, leading experts say that academics are already doing all they can and that protestors may be missing the point.

During the last year, scientists have been under unprecedented pressure over animal testing. And not all of that pressure has been peaceful or legal. Today, 26-year-old Glyn Harding from Cheshire is in court facing 15 charges of sending explosive devices to homes and businesses targetted by animal rights campaigners.

But, the National Anti-Vivisection Society - who are hosting this yearÕs World Laboratory Animal Week - say that what they are legally campaigning for would in fact reduce violent protest if it were granted. They want more information about experiments on the public record and a reduction of "pointless experiments" that use animals. The campaigners have targetted specific experiments at KingÕs College, London, the Institute of Psychiatry and the University of Edinburgh.

But Kenyon Mason, an emeritus professor of medical ethics at Edinburgh University, believes the campaigners are missing the point. "There is far more legislation in place in this country protecting animals than there is protecting humans. With humans itÕs only down to individual researchers. Animal testing is necessary in some areas, and where it is, and is conducted without pain or unusual confinement, I see no ethical problem," he said.

And other academics state they are working to find ways of reducing animal testing. For example, we are within five years of having the full mouse genome sequenced, which, combined with physiological models, could make much of current animal testing unnecessary.

Dr Duncan Davidson at the MRC Human Genetics Unit in Edinburgh is a researcher working on a digital model of mice which could be an enormously helpful teaching tool at universities and help process the information coming in from studies around the country. But he personally hopes it could reduce the number of mice used in experiments. "That's one of the reasons why I'm doing this work: the important point is to optimise the gain from each individual experiment done so less testing needs to be done," he said.

webTitle: Academics attack testing on genetic predisposition

fields.headline: Academics attack testing on genetic predisposition
fields.trailText: Two leading academics have revisisted the arguments on genetic ethics, arguing against medical testing for genetic predispositions.
fields.body:
Two leading academics have revisisted the arguments on genetic ethics, arguing against medical testing for genetic predispositions.

Tackling one of the most controversial topics in medical research, Professor James Evans from the University of North Carolina in today's British Medical Journal did admit that genetic testing of individuals could be useful in some circumstances.

But, he says that for many conditions, testing would at best be of little value and, at worst, could be actually harmful. He argues that this is true for Alzheimers, breast and ovarian cancer and colorectal cancer.

He was backed by Dr Sandy Thomas, director of the Nuffield Bioethic Committee, arguing that we know that individuals with a particular set of genes have a 12% risk of suffering from schizophrenia, which is higher than the norm.

Although this is being debated at the moment, Dr Thomas does not believe 12% is high enough to justify the concern that telling a patient about their risk could cause.

Unless there are measures a medical professional can tell their patient to take, it's not clear what benefit knowing could offer a patient, unless they simply wanted the information. And at least in the British experience of tests for Huntingdon's, many fewer people want to know about their predispositions than researchers had expected.

"The question is whether this information is going to be really useful in the clinic. A lot of people are increasingly saying no," she said.

This result is potentially disheartening for the government in the week they said they wanted to recruit significantly more specialists into hospitals and surgeries.

However, Dr Thomas main argument is that although the media has been obsessed by predictive tests, the real profit from genetic testing is not going to be directly to individual patients, but to broader society through the development of new drugs.

fields.headline: Whatever happened to protest?
fields.trailText: With the imminence of the 1 May anti capitalism demonstrations, David Triesman reflects upon the heyday of the peaceful student protest.
fields.body:
The organisers of the "May Day Monopoly" protests have deliberately set out to make violence and destruction the point of their campaign. Despite all the fine words about justice, co-operation and mutual respect, their sole aim is to create as much chaos and fear as possible in the bizarre hope that our elected representatives will cave in to their demands. There has always been an element of anarchy and chaos at the fringes of British protests as any veteran of political campaigning will tell you, but this is completely different. So, whatever happened to peaceful protest?

I was part of the student generation that became involved in politics during the heady days of the late 1960s. As young radicals we organised a sit-in at Essex University. We were idealistic and angry about injustice, especially the involvement of a British biological warfare research centre at Porton Down in the Vietnam War. There was an outpouring of support from a spectrum of leading scientists and artists because the issues were so clear. So I can't pretend never to have been involved in protest.

However, our protests were a million miles away from the organised chaos proposed by these new activists. Ideology loomed big on the horizon and we were obsessed with programmes for reform and manifestos of change. Before the environmental movement came along I fear we must have been responsible for the destruction of at least one rain forest due to the sheer number of pamphlets and leaflets we cheerily published and the responses from the other side of the debate. We were all enthusiastically left wing, concerned about the differences between the East and West, engaged in the debates about every shade of Marxism and an alphabet of other political doctrines.

Essentially, we were campaigning for a political voice. In the late 1960s and early 1970s the issues we cared about were not taken seriously by the political establishment. Anti-apartheid was a great rallying cry for young left-wingers and fighting injustice was at the core of our politics. What students' union building in the country or public authority cannot claim to have had a Nelson Mandela room, cafeteria or building? But despite our failure to give Winston Churchill a green wig, throw bottles at the police and trash the nearest burger bar we were on the winning side and all those buildings could now be called President Mandela Building.

Like all public protests, including those I was involved with, many of the organisers of the next week's events have had the benefit of a higher education. Student radicals are a traditional part of protest and British higher education has produced its fair share of political activists.I bet that a sample headcount on 1 May would produce many more A levels, degrees and higher qualifications than a similar survey in Tower Hamlets, Tottenham or Vauxhall, or any other run-down estate where the community really faces the rough edges of poverty.

Apart from the violence and destruction associated with these new protests I despise the shameless attempt by the organisers to rewrite history. Like other good dictators and autocrats of the past they are happy to airbrush out the bits of the picture that spoil their story. They positively reject any notion that protest or anger occurred before they discovered the Internet. They have "discovered" big business exploits - workers and shareholders are out to make a profit on the investment. Well now, there's a surprise. You never would have known but for some anarchist. They would have us believe they are the first explorers to stumble across the hinterlands of capitalism, that more than a century of struggle and organisation by the labour movement never existed. Perhaps it is ironic that they are staging their protests on international workersê day?

To these protesters, capitalism and western democracy are the same idea. Their selective memory has forgotten the most inspiring example of student protest against communist China in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Globalisation has created a strong belief amongst many campaigners and former student activists that they will never make progress through democratic means. Like student protestors and radicals before them they should return to rational persuasion as their guiding light and show their strength through peaceful means. Trotsky got it wrong. webTitle: Management research to get government boost

fields.headline: Management research to get government boost
fields.trailText: Embarrassment at the comparatively poor standard of management research in Britain has prompted the government to earmark £5m to improve matters.
fields.body:
Embarrassment at the comparatively poor standard of management research in Britain has prompted the government to earmark £5m to improve matters.

The Economic and Social Research Council has written to university business school heads to decide the best way these funds can be used to breathe life back into one of the UK's flailing research disciplines.

ESRC's chief executive, Dr Gordon Marshall, wonders how the schools can retain dedicated, competent management researchers and also how one might include cross-discipline research in the new initiative. One suggestion is to use the money to reinforce the few internationally-regarded UK research teams in the discipline.

Marshall said: "One major guiding principle for allocating resources will be to develop research capacity."

Business schools conduct research into wide-ranging topics from why and how consumers shop to developing methods for businesses to evaluate the effectiveness of their service processes.

Jonathan Slack, Chief Executive of the Association of Business Schools agreed there were problems with management research. He said: "Management research is a comparatively recent phenomenon in the social sciences. It has not had a separate budget from ESRC in the past and thus the £5 million earmarked is especially welcome."

Slack explained that such research is essentially multi-disciplinary, which has created problems in the past when bids have been judged against criteria that have evolved from single-base disciplines such as economics, psychology and sociology.

A major concern was whether the research being conducted was relevant to practicing managers and companies. Slack added: "This is not universal with the Social Sciences sector where articles in academically-refereed journals may be considered to be the most important output. The additional funding should be aligned to relevant, multidisciplinary research that has the potential for rigorous academically-valued outputs as well as making a contribution to businesses and practicing managers at large."

Responses to the ESRC inquiry are requested by 15 May, email David Guy

fields.headline: Remote-controlled warfare Ð using robots
fields.trailText: A robot expert is heading a project to develop remote-controlled robots that could be used by soldiers in battle.
fields.body:
A British robot expert has secured funding from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) to develop robots that could allow battles to take place hundreds of miles away from the soldiers that are using them to fight with. Dr Shaun Lawson of Napier University, Edinburgh, is heading the £60,000 project, which will start in the autumn.

Dr Lawson explains: "The basic idea is that if you want to do something in a remote environment Ð somewhere far away Ð you could put a robot there to do it for you.

"Previously, remotely-situated robots have been used to carry out simple tasks and to collate data, but that's not ideal, say, in a battle zone because decisions need to be made while the robot is there. I am suggesting that we keep a human in the loop Ð to do the intelligent thinking."

Allowing a human to interact and guide in this way involves the use of two methods. The first is tele-presence Ð this means equipping the robot with a camera that transmits what it sees back to the controller in real time.

"Generally," says Dr Lawson, "a single camera has been used. For the kind of thing that I'm talking about, this wouldn't be very useful because humans can't get enough information from that. They have two eyes, and therefore stereoscopic vision. The robots I am researching will have a camera on the left and on the right, and that information will be transmitted to the controllerÕs left and right eye accordingly."

The second method that Dr Lawson wants to apply to his robots is something called "augmented reality". This means that the information transmitted by camera will be augmented by graphics. "For example," he says, "if you wanted to control a vehicle in a remote battle zone, as well as seeing what you would see if you were actually driving the vehicle, you might see, say, a map of landmines laid over the top. It's about improving what the eye can see with extra information."

The possibilities for such technology are endless, says Dr Lawson. "When you keep the human in the equation, the possibility of a vacuum cleaner that would recognise the difference between a rug and a cat arises. On a more serious note, the American military have for some time looked at the possibility of long distance surgery, wherein the surgeon can conduct the actions of a robot through manipulating a joy stick."

Dr Lawson first became interested in augmented reality and the workings of remote robots when he took up a post as a research assistant at the University of SurreyÕs Systems and Robotics Research Group. Amongst other projects, the Surrey team has conducted work funded by the EPSRC together with the Defense Evaluation and Research Agency and North West Water, which looked at how robots could collate information and manipulate it whilst in small pipes. Professor Graham Parker from Leeds University said that there are many common misconceptions surrounding robots of this kind.

"At Leeds we've been working in this area for years, including work similar to Dr Lawson's on augmented reality. Talk of Ôintelligent robotsÕ always surfaces at some point. Robots might be very smart, but they're definitely not intelligent. They cannot ÔthinkÕ as humans do, and therefore must be controlled by humans. I even do a talk for schools on this subject, just to clarify that these things that they see in films are not plausible."

webTitle: Mathematicians and worms join the fight against slugs

fields.headline: Mathematicians and worms join the fight against slugs
fields.trailText: Academics hope to give organic farmers an environmentally-friendly method of fighting slugs, using parasitic worms.
fields.body:
Mathematicians from Surrey University's Mathematics and Statistics Department are using a mixture of parasitic worms and their own skills to aid organic farmersÕ fight against slugs. It is hoped that mathematical analysis of slug populations throughout the year, alongside a sophisticated understanding of their life cycle will result in an affordable and organic-friendly way of controlling them.

Traditionally, slugs have been dealt with through the use of chemical-based slug pellets. Not only do organic farmers reject this method, many mainstream farmers are also aware that such chemicals can have a negative environmental impact.

More recently a biological method of controlling slugs has been developed. This uses a naturally-occurring microscopic parasite worm called a nematode, which is less than a millimetre long. The method is attractive because the nematodes attack only slugs - in the absence of slugs they cannot survive, so they do not persist in the environment. A formulation of parasitic nematodes is produced commercially in the UK by a firm called MicroBio Ltd, which is collaborating with the project.

"The discovery of the benefits of nematode parasites was an important step," says Dr Martin Bees, the project's director, "but using them works out as about ten times more expensive than the more traditional chemical methods. Our research is aimed at working out a way of using the nematodes which is economically viable."

Dr Bees only embarked on the project at the suggestion of a Ph.D. student in his department. "David Schely is an organic farmer as well as a student. He was having a problem with slugs and he bought some of the nematodes. It was then that he realised that it would be a much cheaper method as he knew the most effective time of year and positioning for them. He realised that nobody really knew the answer to that. He came to me and suggested the application. He's now the research assistant on the project."

The project is funded by a £52,000 grant from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) and will run until the summer of 2001. "We are currently in the process of publishing our findings." said Dr Bees.

Dr Bees and his assistant haven't been getting their hands dirty as their engagement with the slugs has been largely of an abstract, mathematical nature. They have gone to experimental researchers at Long Ashton Research Station's department of agricultural sciences for their empirical data.

Professor David Glen at Long Ashton explains: "Our work provides the ideal kind of data for the questions they are asking. We've been investigating the dynamics of slug's spatial patterns and also their population patterns in time for quite a while now. We take large samples of soil into the lab and create the conditions in which they rise to the surface. Then we can weigh them and count them and so on."

He added, "At the moment, the simple economics of the situation mean that the use of nematodes is just not practical for most large scale agriculturists. Dr Bees and his assistant have been asking a lot of questions and we're very interested to see what conclusions they reach."

webTitle: Small step for man - giant leap for tourism

fields.headline: Small step for man - giant leap for tourism
fields.standfirst:
US financier sets off on £14m space holiday today

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Tomorrow - if an errant computer behaves itself - a 60-year-old American tourist will set off on the most expensive package holiday in history.
fields.body:
Tomorrow - if an errant computer behaves itself - a 60-year-old American tourist will set off on the most expensive package holiday in history.

The takeoff will be terrifying and the flight cramped. When he arrives, his hotel will be half-built, the small staff will be distracted, the menu limited and without wine. There will be no private bathroom.

For the entire vacation, the tourist's bones will leak calcium, his muscles will atrophy and he will probably experience intermittent nausea.

He plans to do some photography, but he can't step outside, although from the window, the view will be sensational. And when he returns next Saturday he will have strained international relations - and paid £14m for the privilege.

The trip, however, will be literally out of this world. Dennis Tito will be the first true tourist in space. He is a former Nasa engineer who became a multimillionaire financier. His journey by Soyuz rocket to the International Space Station, taking shape 250 miles above the Earth, is an accident of orbital history.

He had originally planned to visit the Russian Mir space station. When he paid the money and began his training with cosmonauts at Star City in Moscow, he was a customer of an international consortium called Mircorp, set up to exploit the space station for commercial purposes - as a free fall laboratory, as a film set, as a space vacation lodge.

The Russians decided they could no longer afford to keep their 15-year-old marvel in space, and brought it crashing down to Earth last month.

But they still owed him a holiday. And since they were partners in the new space station, and since the current crew commander is a Russian, they decided to squeeze him in. No way, said Nasa.

The Russians immediately counter-attacked, accusing the Americans of importing hazardous fungi to the space station, and installing an over weight running machine ("which breaks down all the time", said a nameless official) rather than the lightweight design the Russians used. Nasa grudgingly gave the nod.

Moscow took out insurance in case Mr Tito came to any harm. Nasa exacted a promise that he would pay for any damage. A Nasa taskforce recommended Mr Tito be barred from the US parts of the space station unless under escort. The space station's crew, however, appeared somewhat warmer.

"We will welcome anybody who shows up at our hatch," said James Voss, one of the trio aboard, "and we'll invite them inside and treat them like we would any spacefarer."

Mr Tito is not the first passenger to take a taxi-ride to the heavens. The British scientist Helen Sharman went up with the Russians as a guest, and Mir was briefly home to a Japanese journalist who spent most of his assignment complaining that he felt sick, and even a Saudi prince.

Nasa took US congressmen - including Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut - up in the shuttle. A schoolteacher perished in the Challenger shuttle tragedy in 1986.

But Mr Tito is the first spacerider to pay for his journey from his own pocket. His company, Wilshire Associates of Santa Monica, California, manages nearly £7bn in assets. He went through rigorous training for the ultimate trip.

"I had this dream over 40 years ago and at the time I didn't have a penny to my name," he once said.

"We have one life to live on this Earth, and my commitment is to fulfil all of my dreams which are healthy and legitimate. I am optimistic that I have the right stuff to make this flight."

webTitle: Analysis: the Scots have an ace up their sleeve

fields.headline: The English question
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott might be tempted to redistribute resources from north of the border to the south - but the Scots have an ace up their sleeve

Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: John Prescott might be tempted to redistribute resources from north of the border to the south - but the Scots have an ace up their sleeve.
fields.body:
In 1997, John Prescott was asked by a northern Labour MP to review the distribution of cash around the UK, and he had no hesitation in replying that it was "necessary to make sure we have a level playing field". There was little reaction from cabinet colleagues. Yet the same statement of policy sent shock waves through Labour's high command when repeated rather more robustly this week.

Four years ago even the then Treasury chief secretary, Alistair Darling, a Scottish MP, appeared to concede that the funding formula - conceived by Lord (Joel) Barnett in the mid-70s - was unsustainable, creating anything but that level playing field. Since, much has changed in the constitutional map of the UK. Scotland, with its own parliament and a spending-per-head level remaining stubbornly 23% above the English average, is going its own way. Wales (18% above), with a non-legislative assembly, is slowly flexing its muscles while Northern Ireland (39% above) is trying to make devolution stick.

But now a bigger and potentially more disruptive constitutional re-think is taking place. Ministers, even those to whom regionalism was a policy that dare not speak its name, now recognise that an answer has to be found to the English constitutional question: namely, how to govern a country of 50m when the union designed to bind the other nations with England is under increasing strain. The UK is no longer a unified state and England anything but a stable unit.

But ministers have yet to take the logical post-devolution step of addressing how government money should be distributed throughout the UK. The northern fringes of England are getting restless over a formula which seems to discriminate against them in health, education, roads and industrial support. Recognising that passions may soon be running high, Mr Prescott repeated this week that UK funding must be addressed sooner rather than later. Sensibly, he suggested it should be done alongside a forthcoming review of Whitehall's equally complex system for determining how grants are shared among town and county halls - based on a formula, known as the standard spending assessment (SSA). Some think this already discriminates against such counties as Northumberland and northern cities losing population.

The SSA distributes around £50bn and was designed to take account of the differing needs of local areas, compensating some poorer authorities through a variety of weightings. Council officials complain it is often too arbitrary and detailed. Why, for instance - even taking into account London's diverse cultural mix - should spending per pupil in Northumberland secondary schools be £2,159 annually while, in Kensington and Chelsea, it stands at £3,616?

Mr Prescott, who desperately wants to reform council finance, recognises the dilemma. "What has happened is that SSAs have been allowed to continue their disparities because no one wanted to say 'you're going to get more and you're going to get less here'... no one has done anything for years and just let (disparities) grow." His argument is that in reviewing the whole structure of council finance, it makes sense to make the exercise wider and consider funding for the wider regions, and nations of the UK. "What we are developing is the framework of a decentralised UK and the structure within that is becoming reasonably clear," Mr Prescott says. "But we haven't fixed it yet for the English regions and the financial structure, which has to be fair, is a question we haven't started on."

One idea, punted by Blairite town hall reformers, is to fund say education and social services directly from the centre, providing common standards and spending levels, give or take a tweak or two, between Northumberland at one extreme and Kensington on the other (although a centrally funded NHS is still struggling against a postcode lottery to provide national health care standards). That, of course, does not answer the wider UK funding question. On the latest figures the north-east would need an extra £1.1bn a year to catch up with Scottish spending, while Yorkshire - with a similar population to Scotland - would need £5.2bn more and the south-east £12.1bn.

While it is tempting to look north of the border and argue for a redistribution of resources from Scotland to England, the Scots can justly claim that serving a generally sparsely populated country of many diverse regions and three large island groups, with a population concentrated in the Clyde-Forth central belt, does not come cheap. Glasgow, in spite of the Barnett formula and much higher council tax levels than English cities, remains the poorest city in Britain.

Other services, like roads and transport, are clearly more expensive to provide, while water supply has never been privatised in Scotland and requires a hefty dollop from the public purse each year. And if the heat is turned on the Barnett formula, the Scottish lobby has one ace up its sleeve: the billions of pounds annually still flowing from North Sea oil fields to the exchequer. The last thing ministers want is a revival of "it's Scotland's oil" in the run-up to Scottish parliamentary elections in two years' time. So any review of Barnett may have to wait a little longer. Whether that will satisfy a restless English regional lobby is another matter.

fields.bodyText: In 1997, John Prescott was asked by a northern Labour MP to review the distribution of cash around the UK, and he had no hesitation in replying that it was "necessary to make sure we have a level playing field". There was little reaction from cabinet colleagues. Yet the same statement of policy sent shock waves through Labour's high command when repeated rather more robustly this week. Four years ago even the then Treasury chief secretary, Alistair Darling, a Scottish MP, appeared to concede that the funding formula - conceived by Lord (Joel) Barnett in the mid-70s - was unsustainable, creating anything but that level playing field. Since, much has changed in the constitutional map of the UK. Scotland, with its own parliament and a spending-per-head level remaining stubbornly 23% above the English average, is going its own way. Wales (18% above), with a non-legislative assembly, is slowly flexing its muscles while Northern Ireland (39% above) is trying to make devolution stick. But now a bigger and potentially more disruptive constitutional re-think is taking place. Ministers, even those to whom regionalism was a policy that dare not speak its name, now recognise that an answer has to be found to the English constitutional question: namely, how to govern a country of 50m when the union designed to bind the other nations with England is under increasing strain. The UK is no longer a unified state and England anything but a stable unit. But ministers have yet to take the logical post-devolution step of addressing how government money should be distributed throughout the UK. The northern fringes of England are getting restless over a formula which seems to discriminate against them in health, education, roads and industrial support. fields.headline: Great impressionist's blaze of glory
fields.standfirst: Record £7m expected at auction as 'truly exceptional' painting from Monet's famous series is seen in public for first time
fields.trailText: Record £7m expected at auction as 'truly exceptional' painting from Monet's famous series is seen in public for first time.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Monet painting of a haystack, blazing like a bonfire in the last light of the setting sun, which went on public display yesterday for the first time since the artist painted it in 1890, is expected to fetch up to £7m when it is auctioned at Sotheby's in June.

The painting has never left France before, has never been put up for public sale, and has not been seen in any of the Monet retrospectives.

Melanie Clore, Sotheby's authority on impressionist and modern art, said: "This is just a great, great painting, exceptional even among works by Monet. My guess is it will go not to a museum but to a private buyer, who will just hang it on the wall and enjoy it."

While the price of Monet paintings set international art market records, this painting has been hanging on the drawing room walls of private homes in France. It was bought from Monet by his friend Paul Gallimard, a wealthy collector who sat or hours in his studio watching him work, and regularly bought pictures.

His son, Gaston, founded a French publishing empire, and the painting remained in the family until 1953, when it was sold privately to another collector, whose heir is now selling it, daunted by the security implications of having such a masterpiece in his house. Monet's 1872 painting Impression, Soleil Levant, gave the impressionist movement its name, and its impetus for artists to take their canvases and oils into the open air. He made several "series paintings" recording the same the effects of changing light, weather and times of day on the same scene. The sunset is one of the earliest of 25 paintings of haystacks in a Normandy farmer's field between 1890 and 1901, which are regarded as a landmark in modern painting.

Most are in museums, only eight remaining in private hands. Although one was recently bought privately by the Getty foundation, for an undisclosed price, the last one sold at auction was in New York three years ago, when it made more than $10m (£7.14m).

Despite the faltering international market caused by the threat of recession in US and the Far East, Sotheby's said there were about a dozen private collectors around the world who would covet the picture. The auction house expects even greater interest than in Monet's late lily pond painting, which it sold for £5.5m in February, in four minutes of frantic telephone bidding.

Related story
Like lurid cupcakes in a slanting light

webTitle: Lions face new threat: they're rich, American and they've got guns

fields.headline: Lions face new threat: they're rich, American and they've got guns
fields.standfirst:
Schwarzkopf and Bush Snr mobilise opposition as Botswana moves to save its big cats

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Schwarzkopf and Bush Snr mobilise opposition as Botswana moves to save its big cats.
fields.body:
You might call the lions of southern Africa potential Bush meat. The former American president, George Bush senior, and his old Gulf War ally, General "Stormin' Norman" Schwarzkopf, are pleading with the government of Botswana to be allowed to revive their old alliance, this time in pursuit of Africa's endangered big cats.

Mr Bush is among prominent members of Safari Club International (SCI) who have written to the Botswanan authorities asking them to lift a ban slapped on trophy hunting of lions in February.

Arizona-based SCI describes itself as the largest hunting organisation in the world and people who do not like what it does as "animal protection extremists".

Mr Bush's former vice-president, Dan Quayle, is also among the signatories along with Gen Schwarzkopf. Both men went hunting in Botswana last year, although it is not known if they bagged lions on that occasion.

Rich Americans, Europeans and Japanese pay about £20,000 a time to kill a lion in Botswana. The government usually permits the shooting of about 50 lions a year by trophy hunters but decided to impose the ban in part because American shooters favour lions with thick manes for their walls, leading to a disproportionate killing of mature males.

The shortage of such beasts is now so great that hunters have been making use of a mane-extension service back in the US where fake hair is weaved in to give their trophies an extra flourish before they hang the heads.

Among those who campaigned for a ban on lion hunting in Botswana is Derek Joubert, the country's leading chronicler of big cats.

"I've been studying lions in northern Botswana for 20 years and watching them systematically decline in population size and health primarily, perhaps even solely, as the result of hunting," he said.

"We've also seen some bizarre situations arising. Hunters target the primary males. When they disappear the male cubs don't leave the pride, they're not chased out. So we've seen these young males breeding with their sisters and their mothers because the trophy males have been killed."

Mr Joubert estimates that the number of lions in Botswana has declined by about two-thirds in 10 years. That is average for the continent.

Exact numbers of lions are notoriously difficult to measure but there is broad consensus among conservationists and governments that the population in Africa has fallen from about 50,000 to less than 15,000 over the past decade. The surviving lions are largely confined to four viable populations in southern and east Africa.

Peasant farmers also had a hand in the Botswana ban. The government had already forbidden them to shoot lions that attack cattle. The farmers said it was unfair to permit rich hunters to go on killing lions for sport when peasants were prevented from protecting their precious livestock.

"There's no other reason to shoot a lion other than ego. As a hunter you want to feel great so you can hang it on the wall and your mates say: 'Wow, what a man'," Mr Joubert said. "I'm not particularly anti-hunting. I can't personally see the point in going out and shooting a lion. But I do have a problem with the ethics of it and the sustainability of it."

The nature of lion hunting has changed from colonial days. Faster vehicles and high powered rifles have further reduced the already bad odds against the animals. On top of that, the idea of three week hunts deep into the bush in the hope, but not necessarily the expectation, of bagging something big have given way to the concept of a sure kill.

"It's very difficult for a professional hunter to turn around to some guy who's paid $30,000 to kill a lion and say: 'Don't shoot that one he's too young, he's not ready'. The guy's going to say, I came here to kill a lion and that's what I'm going to do," said Mr Joubert.

At least there is still something of the hunt left in Botswana. South Africa offers the notorious "canned lion" service in which a trapped animal is virtually delivered to the barrel of a gun.

Many of the lions are bred in captivity solely as bait for hunters and then hardly pursued at all. They are released into what are no more than fields surrounded by fences and "hunted". They have no chance of escape.

On one occasion captured on video a lioness was separated from her cubs and shot just yards away. Last year a pride of problem lions - they had been eating livestock - in the state-owned Kruger National Park was sold to a hunting tour operator for delivery to his clients.

Tales of horrendous suffering by the animals abound. Some supposed hunters are so inexpert with guns that they take a dozen shots to kill a lion.

Sometimes the killing takes place on the same game farms that foreign tourists believe to be conservation centres. While the parks emphasise the breeding of lions to the visitors waving cameras, over the hill the hunters are shooting them with guns. The state-run South African tourist board even advertised "canned lion" hunts.

"Go for the ultimate trophy and score in South Africa," said one advert. "It is always in season in South Africa, where the world's finest hunting is in the bag."

Opponents of the ban in Botswana say it will have a big effect on the local economy. Lion hunting is estimated to be worth about £3m a year but most of the profits go to hunting operators.

The government earns just £1,500 for each lion bagged, a fraction of what the hunter pays, even though all hunting takes place on state-owned reserves and the animals are the property of the government.

Safari Club International, which calls itself a "charitable organisation of hunter conservationists" with 33,000 members across the globe, is unlikely to get its way. The tide appears to have swung against lion hunting in Botswana and conservationists are confident that when the ban comes up for review in a year it will be reimposed.

While SCI mobilises politicians, other prominent voices have spoken up in favour of the ban on lion hunting. Among those who have written to Botswana's wildlife department in support is the actor Kevin Costner, star of Dances with Wolves, about the devastating impact of hunting on America's bison population.

SCI referred questions about lions in Botswana and the prominent support for a lifting of the hunting ban to its chief executive, Rudy Rosen, who was not available.

But Gen Schwarzkopf is clearly a valued member. The organisation recently donated $10,000 in the general's name to a Grizzly bear information project.

Under threat from the gun

Rhinos

There were once hundreds of species but only five exist today and four of them are endangered. During the 1970s as many as half the world's remaining rhinos disappeared. Now fewer than 12,000 survive in Asia and Africa. The northern white rhino is reduced to only 30 individuals in the wild. In Africa poaching has been so ruthless that black rhino numbers have fallen from 60,000 to 2,500 in 22 years. Horn from African rhinos is worth£1,300 to £3,300 per kg, and horn from Asian rhinos up to £32,000 per kg.

Elephants

The demand for ivory was behind the decline of the African elephant, which fell from 2m animals in 1970 to between 286,000 and 543,000 today.

The number of Asian elephants have been reduced to between 34,000 and 51,000 animals in the wild. Hunting for meat, hides and bones has affected both breeds.

Orang Utans

Fewer than 30,000 exist in the world today, a 30% to 50% decline which has occurred in the past decade. The vast majority can be found in Borneo, where they are protected. Hunting for food and body parts has taken its toll and the trade in body parts, particularly skulls, continues despite the efforts of the authorities to eradicate it.

Tigers

A population estimate in 1996 was between 4,600 and 7,200 in the wild, and there are now no more than 4,500 Indian tigers. The Siberian tiger is the world's largest cat but only 200 remain, mostly in Russia. The demand for tiger products has increased with the bones and other body parts being used for traditional Chinese medicines and as tonics or cures for ailments.

webTitle: CD of the week: Destiny's Child: Survivor

fields.headline: Bad vibes, great grooves
fields.standfirst: They may be catty, but Destiny's Child make ground-breaking R&B, says  Alexis Petridis
fields.trailText: They may be catty, but Destiny's Child make ground-breaking R&B, says Alexis Petridis
fields.body:
Destiny's Child Survivor
(Columbia) ****
£14.99

Anyone searching for a cautionary tale about pop stardom's perils could do worse than read Mary Wilson's biography. Dreamgirl: My Life as a Supreme reveals that spending the 1960s standing behind Diana Ross, occasionally cooing a mellifluous "oooh", was not the bed of roses one might imagine. The sequins and smiles apparently hid a life of tantrums, manipulation and shady business deals, all dictated by the ruthless personal ambition of their leader. The book has two simple messages: that Diana Ross was Richard III in false eyelashes, and that being a member of the biggest girl band in the world is no fun at all.

Destiny's Child are currently the biggest girl band in the world. Their clever twist on R&B - dramatic, staccato rhythms topped with man-bashing, money-obsessed lyrics, like girl power with a working knowledge of bulls and bears - has sold 19m albums worldwide. But recently all has not been well with the Houston trio. Last January, two members of the band were summarily sacked. They are currently suing the band's manager, Martin Knowles - father of lead singer Beyonce - alleging rampant nepotism and irregular business practices. One of their teenage replacements further sullied the sisterly image by lasting only five months before bizarrely claiming she was leaving Destiny's Child owing to "dehydration".

Whatever has been going on behind the perfectly manicured facade has allowed Beyonce Knowles to emergence as the band's sole driving force. In contrast to the band's two previous albums, Knowles co-writes, produces and arranges every one of Survivor's 18 tracks. The result is indulgent in every sense. At well over an hour, Survivor is much too long. Four minutes are given over to a self-regarding spoken-word piece that essentially consists of Destiny's Child congratulating each other for completing the album and, as is the way with R&B groups, thanking God. Who in their right mind wants to listen to this? Almost as superfluous is an interminable a capella gospel medley, the sort of thing most artists would use to pad out their live set but would never consider recording for posterity.

Lyrically, much of Survivor sounds less like a rallying cry for emancipated sisterhood than a prolonged and rather vindictive attack on the band's ousted members. "Now that you're out of my life, I'm so much better," snaps Knowles on the title track. "Thought I wouldn't sell without you, I sold nine million," she adds, lest anyone think the song is about a former lover.

As mealy-mouthed and mean-minded as Survivor is, it's hard not to be frequently beguiled by the music. The lyrical tongue-poking may betray her immaturity, but at 20 years old Knowles is already remarkably assured behind the mixing desk. She has learned her tricks from former Destiny's Child collaborators Rodney Jerkins, Sheke'spere and Timbaland. They are visionary producers who have transformed R&B from a cliche-ridden, ballad-led genre - the favoured sedution soundtrack of the suburban teen lothario - into perhaps the most exciting and ground-breaking music on the planet.

Knowles has inherited their ability to deftly mix commercial hooks with avant-garde studio experimentation. Sexy Daddy bristles with discordant harmonies and thundering ragga rhythms, while Fancy is driven by pizzicato strings and unexpected, lurching key changes. A scattered and abstract re-recording of the recent number one, Independent Women, finds Destiny's Child singing over the sort of music that usually accompanies characters sneaking about in Czech cartoons.

Survivor matches its lyrical ire with tough, thrilling music. The European pop clogging up the British charts is regulated and uniform - the anaemic end result of factory-line songwriting and production techniques - but this is pop that draws in the listener by surprising them. Its selling point is its difference from its competitors, rather than its similarity.

The album loses its way when the tempo slows. A trio of identikit ballads, bafflingly placed together, hark back to an era when R&B divas existed solely on a diet of gloopy saccharine. Overwrought with showy vocal flourishes, My Heart Still Beats could be the work of Celine Dion, and it sits uncomfortably alongside tracks such as Bootylicious, which comes complete with startling, hiccuping vocals and wittily samples Fleetwood Mac's Stevie Nicks, herself no stranger to inter-band ructions and upheaval.

Those ructions, and Knowles's petulant musical response, may yet see Destiny's Child the subject of a Dreamgirls-style muck-raking. The combination of glittering success, vast wealth, disgruntled former members, a shadowy manager and the alleged megalomania of their leader is almost too salacious to resist.

But it would be a shame if Destiny's Child became better known as a kind of singing soap opera than a genuinely vital musical force. In all its flawed, arrogant pomp, Survivor has a rare individuality, and a hint of genius, hidden in its grooves.

One of their teenage replacements further sullied the sisterly image by lasting only five months before bizarrely claiming she was leaving Destiny's Child owing to "dehydration". Whatever has been going on behind the perfectly manicured facade has allowed Beyonce Knowles to emergence as the band's sole driving force. In contrast to the band's two previous albums, Knowles co-writes, produces and arranges every one of Survivor's 18 tracks. The result is indulgent in every sense. At well over an hour, Survivor is much too long. Four minutes are given over to a self-regarding spoken-word piece that essentially consists of Destiny's Child congratulating each other for completing the album and, as is the way with R&B groups, thanking God. Who in their right mind wants to listen to this? Almost as superfluous is an interminable a capella gospel medley, the sort of thing most artists would use to pad out their live set but would never consider recording for posterity. Lyrically, much of Survivor sounds less like a rallying cry for emancipated sisterhood than a prolonged and rather vindictive attack on the band's ousted members. "Now that you're out of my life, I'm so much better," snaps Knowles on the title track. "Thought I wouldn't sell without you, I sold nine million," she adds, lest anyone think the song is about a former lover. As mealy-mouthed and mean-minded as Survivor is, it's hard not to be frequently beguiled by the music. The lyrical tongue-poking may betray her immaturity, but at 20 years old Knowles is already remarkably assured behind the mixing desk. She has learned her tricks from former Destiny's Child collaborators Rodney Jerkins, Sheke'spere and Timbaland. They are visionary producers who have transformed R&B from a cliche-ridden, ballad-led genre - the favoured sedution soundtrack of the suburban teen lothario - into perhaps the most exciting and ground-breaking music on the planet. Knowles has inherited their ability to deftly mix commercial hooks with avant-garde studio experimentation. Sexy Daddy bristles with discordant harmonies and thundering ragga rhythms, while Fancy is driven by pizzicato strings and unexpected, lurching key changes. A scattered and abstract re-recording of the recent number one, Independent Women, finds Destiny's Child singing over the sort of music that usually accompanies characters sneaking about in Czech cartoons. Survivor matches its lyrical ire with tough, thrilling music. The European pop clogging up the British charts is regulated and uniform - the anaemic end result of factory-line songwriting and production techniques - but this is pop that draws in the listener by surprising them. Its selling point is its difference from its competitors, rather than its similarity. The album loses its way when the tempo slows. A trio of identikit ballads, bafflingly placed together, hark back to an era when R&B divas existed solely on a diet of gloopy saccharine. Overwrought with showy vocal flourishes, My Heart Still Beats could be the work of Celine Dion, and it sits uncomfortably alongside tracks such as Bootylicious, which comes complete with startling, hiccuping vocals and wittily samples Fleetwood Mac's Stevie Nicks, herself no stranger to inter-band ructions and upheaval. Those ructions, and Knowles's petulant musical response, may yet see Destiny's Child the subject of a Dreamgirls-style muck-raking. The combination of glittering success, vast wealth, disgruntled former members, a shadowy manager and the alleged megalomania of their leader is almost too salacious to resist. But it would be a shame if Destiny's Child became better known as a kind of singing soap opera than a genuinely vital musical force. In all its flawed, arrogant pomp, Survivor has a rare individuality, and a hint of genius, hidden in its grooves.

fields.headline: Air stuck at the poolside bar
fields.standfirst:
Air
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
**
fields.trailText:
Air
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
**
fields.body:
The prospect of a live concert by Parisian duo Air is something of a curate's egg. Like their compatriots Daft Punk, Jean-Benot Dunckel and Nicolas Godin have exerted a considerable influence on British music - record company release schedules are currently packed with Air sound-a-likes such as Zero 7, Kinobe and Bent - but they have entered the public conciousness by stealth.

Their cosseting blend of Gallic easy listening and retro electronica has proved a television producer's dream, the perfect accompaniment to fashion programmes, cookery courses and travel shows. Three years after its release, it's sadly difficult to hear their debut album, Moon Safari, without picturing Judith Chalmers at a poolside bar.

Perhaps mindful of the pale imitations Moon Safari has spawned, Air's forthcoming second album, 10,000 Hz Legend, spikes their Serge Gainsbourg-meets-Kraftwerk cocktail with noisy rock guitars and harsh synthesizer tones. On stage, however, new album tracks like How Does It Make You Feel? and People in the City are more an excursion into the past. Laden with keyboard introductions, episodic dynamic shifts and computer-affected voices, they sound like extracts from a lost 1974 rock opera called Behold the Goblin. Behind a bank of synthesizers, Dunckel sports a black cape, clearly intended as an ironic nod to the attire of prog-rock keyboard warlock Rick Wakeman. As the dry ice swirls and the music descends, regrettably, into a lengthy bass guitar solo, it seems less like knowing post modernity than straight- forward homage to the worst excesses of 1970s rock.

An encore featuring Moon Safari's La Femme d'Argent and a splendidly moody Playground Love, from Air's superb soundtrack to Sophia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides, only serves to underline how unreconstructed and weary their new material sounds live. Throughout their career, Air have drawn on the past to create music that sounded entirely of the moment. Tonight they seem lost in rock history and disappointingly oblivious to the 21st century.

webTitle: A new language of racism in politics

fields.headline: A new language of racism in politics
fields.standfirst:
Maverick Conservative MP John Townend seems to be rewriting the lexicon of xenophobia, writes Derek Brown

Special report: race in Britain
fields.trailText: Maverick Conservative MP John Townend seems to be rewriting the lexicon of xenophobia, writes Derek Brown Derek Brown.
fields.body:
In the general election of 1964, Patrick Gordon Walker was confidently expected to win the inner Birmingham seat of Smethwick and, in the event of a national Labour victory, go on to be Harold Wilson's foreign secretary.

But Gordon Walker did not win. He was sensationally defeated by a Tory nonentity, Peter Griffiths, whose campaign featured the infamous 10-word slogan: "If you want a nigger for a neighbour, vote Labour."

No candidate would dream of saying such a thing now. If they did, they'd be prosecuted.

But there are more subtle ways in which race prejudice insinuates itself into political thought and action - and no party is immune from the poison. The last important politician to blatantly play the race card was Enoch Powell, in his days as the intellectual powerhouse of the Tory front bench.

In a Birmingham speech in 1968 he spoke of a constituent - "an ordinary working man" - who was so concerned by the rising numbers of black immigrants that he was determined to see that his three children settled abroad. The splendid irony of that position was clearly lost on Powell, and on his audience, who cheered to the echo the MP's ardent plea for immigrants to be sent "home".

The phrase which stuck in the lore and language of politics was, typically for Powell, a classical allusion: "Like the Roman, I seem to see the Tiber foaming with much blood." Ted Heath sacked him more or less on the spot, but the damage was done.

For several weeks there was a surge of Powell-mania, and even talk - never by him - of the formation of a new popular nationalist party. A Gallup poll suggested that 74% of the population supported his repatriation suggestion. Smithfield meat porters joined dockers (almost certainly Labour supporters to a man) in pro-Powell marches.

Eventually the ruckus died down, and the dotty old classicist pottered off to Northern Ireland to end his political days as an eloquent, irrelevant, Ulster Unionist.

Powell was supposed to possess one of the finest analytical brains of his generation. Yet his argument was based not on logic, but on atavistic incoherence. He heard, and shared, his constituents' alarm about the new faces, languages and cultures around them, and he proposed, very seriously, that the issue be resolved by ethnic cleansing.

(Once, a colleague asked Powell how he proposed this be done. After all, immigrants had been arriving by the shipload for 20 years. He considered the matter gravely and then announced: "Now, you see, we have" - pause for effect - "wide-bodied jets.")

What Powell articulated then, and what the maverick MP John Townend is rambling about now, was a sense of national identity being eroded. With Powell, it was Britishness under attack. Townend is more concerned about Englishness, and specifically about the loopy old notion of Anglo Saxon-ness.

These are concepts that do not dare to speak their name in modern polite society, yet they are powerfully embedded still in the fabric of a society which is constantly told that its freedoms and privileges are under threat from foreigners.

Any target will do, in the new lexicon of xenophobia. Its practitioners can talk about the "flood" of asylum-seekers, never forgetting to slip in the adjective "bogus". They can talk about the asylum system being "swamped" and about Britain being a "soft touch" for immigrant "cheats". With language like that, they don't need to revert to the crudities of Smethwick 37 years ago.

fields.headline: Protesters jostle Hague
fields.trailText: The Conservative party leader, William Hague, was jostled and abused today by protesters sporting masks today on a visit to Pudsey in Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The Conservative party leader, William Hague, was jostled and abused today by protesters sporting masks today on a visit to Pudsey in Yorkshire.

Three people asked Mr Hague if he was planning to sack John Townend, the Conservative MP for Yorkshire East, for his inflammatory comments about race.

And when Mr Hague stopped at a market to buy flowers for his wife, one of the protesters, who were all wearing Hague face masks, shouted: "Are those for Mr Townend?" Mr Hague replied: "They are most definitely for my wife Ffion."

Mr Hague has come under increasing pressure form within his own party to expel Mr Townend after the Tory MP's continued attacks on asylum seekers.

Lord Taylor of Warwick, the black Conservative peer, called on Mr Hague to withdraw the whip from Mr Townend after he re-ignited the controversy by accusing ministers of wanting to turn the British into a "mongrel race".

"John Townend is clearly determined to continue spouting his racist rubbish. He is laying down the gauntlet to Mr Hague," Lord Taylor said.

"The leader of the Conservative party prides himself on his judo and 14 pints-a-day macho image. Now is Mr Hague's chance to demonstrate real macho leadership by withdrawing the whip from Mr Townend and booting him out of the party."

The row re-erupted on Thursday after the Mr Townend wrote to the Commission for Racial Equality denouncing the idea of a "multi-cultural, multi-ethnic, multi-lingual society" and accusing Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of portraying the British as a "mongrel race".

Despite the outcry his comments caused, a defiant Mr Townend insisted that he had no intention of withdrawing them.

He accused the CRE of trying to stifle debate on immigration through its compact, urging politicians to avoid racist language during the forthcoming election campaign.

"Now this is an important issue at this election and I think this pact was aimed to stop discussion, and anybody like me who puts their head above the parapet is accused of being a racist," he told the BBC radio 4's Today programme.

"Once you divide people up into groups, you have got problems, and then of course you have resentment from the indigenous population who feel that their interests are not being served."

Mr Townend said that "enormous numbers" of illegal immigrants were coming into the country.

"We are catching them at a rate of a 100,000 a year, there is probably another 100,000 a year which are getting through without being caught. "This is an important issue at this election and I think this pact was aimed to stop discussion, and anybody like me who puts their head above the parapet is accused of being a racist.

Mr Townend said he did not believe there was a big difference between his views and those of Mr Hague.

"I think William Hague wants an inclusive society and I'm sure that he would like us to have a colour-blind society."

This morning on the Today programme, Stephen Dorrell, the Tory MP for Charnwood and a former cabinet minister, also took issue with Mr Townend's approach but stopped short of calling for him to have the whip withdrawn. "He is wrong when he says it is not possible to have more than one cultural background," he said.

"He uses the example of the United States. The Americans have been extremely successful at integrating people from a wide number of different parts of the world, but the phrase Spanish-American, Polish-American, German-American, anybody who knows anything about the social background of the United States, knows that there are different communities within the United States.

"We ourselves have always been an open country and have taken people from a wide variety of different parts of the world, that is part of what it means to be English or to be British."

Asked what should be done about people like Mr Townend from the point of view of party discipline, Mr Dorrell did not, however, support his expulsion.

"This is a free country and people are entitled to express their views. But what a party is entitled to do is to distinguish its collective view from those of its members that it disagrees with. The Conservative Party does not agree with Mr Townend."

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes also strongly criticised Mr Townend's latest remarks.

Mr Hughes said: "John Townend is very wrong in principle in suggesting that it (multiculturalism) is undermining something we have always had, some pure Englishness - very few people are pure English over many generations."

Although Mr Hague has repudiated Mr Townend's remarks, he has said that he was not going to expel Mr Townend as he was standing down anyway as MP for Yorkshire East at the general election.

webTitle: Labour pays lip service to 'Cyprus problem'

fields.headline: Labour pays lip service to 'Cyprus problem'
fields.standfirst: It is time the government addressed Cypriot concerns instead of using them as part of yet more Westminster chicanery, writes Paul Hamilos
fields.trailText: It is time the government addressed Cypriot concerns instead of using them as part of yet more Westminster chicanery, writes Paul Hamilos.
fields.body:
Imagine you are a north London Labour MP with a slim majority, worried about losing the seat you have only recently won. Given the little you have achieved in the last four years, your concerns about the threat posed by the Tories must be very real.

You have scoured your campaign budgets to find some way of coming up with a clever gimmick, but there is not enough money for anything worthwhile. You have tried advertising, but your street posters have failed miserably. Your schools are failing and public transport is grinding to a halt - not much to trumpet to the electorate there.

This is the position that the likes of Andrew Dismore in Hendon, Stephen Twigg, who beat Michael Portillo to take Enfield, and Joan Ryan in Enfield North currently find themselves in.

But there may be light at the end of the tunnel. The last four years of constituency surgeries have taught you that the prominent Greek and Greek Cypriot minority in your area is politically active. They also have an issue that it is easy to pay lip service to - the reunification of Cyprus.

There is no way that you could possibly be expected to achieve anything in Cyprus, which was invaded in 1974 by Turkish forces and has remained divided ever since. Years of diplomatic talks have come to nothing, so what can you be expected to do?

Well, you can talk of the "Cyprus problem" in hushed, grave tones. You can attend the numerous gatherings of refugee associations and organise meetings at the House of Commons with Cypriot representatives. You can even, if you are lucky, take all-expenses-paid holidays (I mean working trips) to Cyprus to discuss the issue. But these do not guarantee a cross in the right box on election day.

However, help is at hand. The Labour party, in the shape of Tony's fixer, Margaret McDonagh, has just done a deal with Pasok, the Greek socialist party, in a bid to shore up the Greek Cypriot vote.

This is clever stuff - especially for Mr Dismore, whose 8,000 Greek residents outnumber his majority by 2,000. Support from this community will safeguard his seat for at least four more years, and ensure that those transport and education woes can drag on for that little bit longer.

The irony is that it was the British government (with more than a little help from their American and Turkish friends) that caused the division of the Mediterranean island for diplomatic purposes. Now, it seems, they want to exploit this split all over again.

The history of Cyprus is one of abuse and exploitation by a variety of colonial powers. Since Cyprus gained its independence from Britain in 1960, very little has gone right for its population. Indeed, there are still 1,619 missing people and more 200,000 refugees as a result of the 1974 conflict.

Surely, therefore, it is time that the British government dealt with Cypriot concerns, rather than using them as part of another tasteless piece of Westminster chicanery?

fields.headline: Workplace racism on the increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: race in the Britain
fields.trailText: The Trades Union Congress (TUC) today called for employers to be legally required to promote race relations after new figures showed that racism was getting worse in the workplace.
fields.body:
The Trades Union Congress (TUC) today called for employers to be legally required to promote race relations after new figures showed that racism was getting worse in the workplace.

Research showed that black and Asian people in Britain were now twice as likely to be unemployed as their white counterparts.

As race issues today featured prominently in the headlines, with the Tory MP John Townend controversially calling Britain a "mongrel race", figures showed black and Asian jobless rates stand at 12% - one of the highest on record - compared with 5% among white people.

In some regions the unemployment rate among black and Asian people was even higher, including 15% in Yorkshire and Humberside and the West Midlands.

Even when they found work, black and Asian people faced discrimination when they tried to get a managerial post, said the TUC.

The union organisation said the position was worse than in 1990, when black and Asian unemployment was 11%.

The government was urged to extend the Race Relations Act to give private and voluntary sector employers the same legal obligations as those imposed on public authorities.

However, the research does show that the proportion of black and Asian workers educated to degree level or above increased from 21% to 26% over the last 18 months.

webTitle: No manslaughter trial for police five

fields.headline: No manslaughter trial for police five
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Five police officers who were caught on security film chatting and joking while a black prisoner lay dying yards away will not face trial for manslaughter, the crown prosecution service has decided.
fields.body:
Five police officers who were caught on security film chatting and joking while a black prisoner lay dying yards away will not face trial for manslaughter, the crown prosecution service has decided.

Lawyers have advised that there is insufficient evidence to go beyond charges of misconduct in public office which have already been made against the five officers from Hull.

The decision was attacked yesterday by relatives of the dead man, Christopher Alder, a former paratrooper who choked on his own blood in Hull's central police station in April 1998.

His sister, Janet Alder said: "This is yet another kick in the teeth for the family. I am absolutely disgusted with the decision."

The family's lawyers said that they would be pressing for an explanation of CPS reasoning. Solicitor Ruth Bundey said: "A jury at an inquest returned an unlawful killing verdict in this case and, exceptionally, the high court has just confirmed that verdict.

"Obviously, we will look very, very carefully at the decision- making by the CPS and will be going into all their reasoning processes."

The inquest jury unanimously agreed the unlawful killing verdict last autumn, after hearing how 37-year-old Mr Alder died following an incident at a local nightclub. Jurors had watched security film taken at the police station, showing Mr Alder face down on the floor in handcuffs, with his trousers down.

The inquest heard that the officers - custody sergeant John Dunn and PCs Matthew Barr, Neil Blakey, Nigel Dawson and Mark Ellerington - thought Mr Alder was play-acting.

Their attempt to overturn the verdict failed at the high court in London last month. Mr Justice Jackson rejected their claim that a relationship between a barrister and a woman juror after the inquest had "raised a real danger of bias".

The crown prosecution service said that the five would still be facing serious charges, probably later this year. Stuart Richardson of the Police Federation in Hull said that the officers were pleased with the decision and had always denied the charge of neglect.
