webTitle: New race speech blow to Hague

fields.headline: New race speech blow to Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered a fresh blow last night when the rightwing Tory MP John Townend sparked another race row by accusing the government of turning Britain into a "mongrel race".
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a fresh blow last night when the rightwing Tory MP John Townend sparked another race row by accusing the government of turning Britain into a "mongrel race".

As the Tory leader attempted to mend fences with British Asians in Bradford, Mr Townend described the government's support for a multicultural society as a mistake which showed that ministers had "no love" for England.

Highlighting Robin Cook's "chicken tikka masala" speech, in which the foreign secretary hailed Britain's varied communities, Mr Townend said: "Presumably, he considers us a mongrel race."

Weeks after lavishing praise on Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech, Mr Townend also rounded on asylum seekers, claiming that they were a "new wave of illegal immigration".

His outburst was immediately condemned by Mr Hague, whose trip to Bradford was overshadowed by the rightwinger's remarks. "I repudiate these comments," Mr Hague said. "I believe in a multicultural Britain. Indeed multiculturalism is part of the strength of modern Britain."

However, Mr Hague again refused to remove the parliamentary whip from Mr Townend on the grounds that he is standing down as MP for Yorkshire East at the election. His failure to take action was condemned by Labour as a sign of "weakness and lack of leadership".

Mr Townend's latest outburst could not have come at a worst time for Mr Hague. The Tory leadership hoped that it had placed the controversy over race behind it after the embarrassment of last week when scores of Tory MPs, including Michael Portillo, announced that they would not sign an anti-racist pact drawn up by the commission for racial equality (CRE).

Confident that the row had died down, Mr Hague last night visited the constituency of Bradford West, where a third of voters are Asian, to highlight his anti-racist credentials. But as he arrived at the city's Hilton hotel Mr Hague found himself quizzed about Mr Townend after the rightwinger released a copy of his letter to the CRE outlining why he had refused to sign its anti-racism pact.

The MP said in a letter to the CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh: "I think the CRE causes more racial problems than it solves. I believe in individual freedom and in equality before the law. I believe that as a result of some of your activities some people are more equal than others."

In a separate statement, Mr Townend criticised the government for promoting multiculturalism, saying that Britain's ethnic minority communities should abandon their roots. "This means that certainly from the second generation all immigrants should consider themselves as natives of this island, rather than looking back to a motherland abroad," he said.

The CRE last night released Mr Singh's reply to Mr Townend in which he dismissed the MP's letter point by point. "Like yourself, I passionately believe in individual freedom in equality before the law," Mr Singh wrote in the letter dated March 26. "And it is because of that belief that I am passionately committed to the work of the commission for racial equality. I do not accept the implication in your letter that actions by the CRE have created privileges for some, quite the contrary.

"Everything I am involved in brings me up against the fact that discrimination is still a problem in our society and prevents many from enjoying an equal share in the freedoms I value."

The row ensured that little attention was paid to Mr Hague's speech in Bradford. Speaking to a 300-strong Tory audience, of whom around 100 were Asians, Mr Hague said: "All people, all communities, all races and backgrounds are welcome in the Conservative party.

"I believe the Conservative party can do more than any other party to welcome people from different communities. We were the first party to have a Jewish leader, we were the first party to have a woman leader and we will be the first party to have an Asian leader - though not quite yet."

Mr Hague also issued a blunt message that all Tory MPs were bound by the CRE pact, regardless of whether individuals had signed it. "I signed on behalf of the whole party," he said. "They are all bound by it whether they like it or not."

webTitle: Athlete tells how 'race campaign' hit gold hopes

fields.headline: Athlete tells how 'race campaign' hit gold hopes
fields.standfirst:
Olympic triple jumper Ashia Hansen describes growing suspicions about boyfriend

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The British triple jumper Ashia Hansen yesterday told a court how a "racist" campaign allegedly planned by her former boyfriend affected her hopes of winning a gold medal at the Sydney Olympics last year.
fields.body:
The British triple jumper Ashia Hansen yesterday told a court how a "racist" campaign allegedly planned by her former boyfriend affected her hopes of winning a gold medal at the Sydney Olympics last year.

Ms Hansen, who came away from the games empty-handed, described the attack, its effect on her career and her growing suspicions that her boyfriend, Christopher Cotter, might have instigated it.

"I couldn't concentrate properly," she told Birmingham crown court, as she explained how a crucial month of training in the US had been affected. "I was injured anyway, but it was very, very difficult to concentrate on what I was supposed to do because I was upset. I was trying to train in tears a lot."

Cotter, 29, is alleged to have arranged an assault on himself in the hope of reviving his relationship with the Commonwealth gold medallist and of selling his story to newspapers to help him repay debts of up to £25,000.

He is jointly accused with Surjit Clair and Craig Wynn of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice and conspiracy to obtain property by deception because of their plans to sell the story of the alleged attack. They deny both charges.

Tim Raggatt QC, for the prosecution, claimed that the trio also sent racist hate mail to Ms Hansen, leading black athletes including Denise Lewis and the Labour backbencher Jacqui Smith to lend credence to the bogus assault.

The letters were all signed "Wano", but Mr Raggatt said that police inquiries had failed to discover any other evidence of the organisation.

Cotter, a financial adviser who now lives in Plymouth, received a serious head wound and three superficial knife wounds to his back as he was attacked on his way to Hansen's house in Birmingham in March last year.

He claimed he had been assaulted by neo-Nazi thugs objecting to their inter-racial relationship, as he is white and the athlete is black.

But Ms Hansen herself was disturbed by the fact he had parked his car far from his usual spot. "I asked him whether he had anything to do with it, with the whole incident. He said no," she told the court.

Despite her anxieties the attack initially brought the couple back together and Cotter proposed to her after joining her as she trained in Florida the following month.

The couple had split up in 1997 but had continued to see each other "off and on". Ms Hansen said the relationship "would last two or three weeks at most and then we would break up again". It had become "very bad", but on the night of the attack, the couple were due to meet for dinner at Ms Hansen's house to talk about their future. "We were going to discuss getting back together," she said. "I'm not sure who had instigated it. We both talked about it and decided we were going to take it slowly."

When Cotter failed to arrive on time Ms Hansen looked out of her window for him.

"I saw Chris coming up my drive bent double and holding his head," she said. "I panicked because I knew something was wrong and I could see him bleeding."

She said the incident rekindled the relationship. "I was feeling really sorry for him and just felt so bad about what he went through. He asked me to marry him. I said no. He wouldn't talk to me and I got upset."

Ms Hansen was also disturbed when Clair suggested, two days after the attack, that they should sell the story to a newspaper, claiming the police were planning to leak it.

"Chris agreed," she said. "I couldn't believe it. I didn't want my life printed in the papers. I walked out and about 10 minutes later they came out and Chris said he was sorry."

The story appeared in the Daily Express the next day, but Cotter told police he had agreed to cooperate only after journalists pursued him through Birmingham in a "Starsky and Hutch style" car chase.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Attack on pensioner 'was not racist'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The family of a white 75-year-old beaten up by Asian youths are doubtful about speculation that the attack was racist.
fields.body:
The family of a white 75-year-old beaten up by Asian youths are doubtful about speculation that the attack was racist.

Walter Chamberlain suffered a broken nose and fractured cheekbones after he was confronted by youths in Oldham, Greater Manchester. It was alleged the gang told the D-Day veteran he was not allowed in the area because he was white.

The attack, which happened on Saturday, followed claims that parts of Oldham had become no-go areas for whites.

But Mr Chamberlain's son, Steven, said: "It was a violent assault on an elderly man. As a family we don't think it was a race issue at all."

However, Greater Manchester police said yesterday the attack would still be treated as racially motivated.

Mr Chamberlain was attacked as he walked home from a rugby match. His metal coffee flask was stolen.

His daughter, Anita Baker, said: "There were two youths behind him and one in front. He said he felt uncomfortable. As he walked down, the third youth approached him and said, 'Where do you live?'

"Walt said at that point he just wanted to get home and told the youths, 'I live a long way from here'. Walt seems to think they tried to get his bag, spun him round and after that he doesn't remember."

Ms Baker appealed for anyone with information about the attack to come forward. "My dad is a victim, not a hero, and somebody needs to be brought to justice over it. The people who have done this have to be found."

Mr Chamberlain's family made the remarks to the journalist Martin Bashir on ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald last night.

Don't be left out on May Day this year: make your protest known at work by wearing a Riot T-shirt by F.S.U. from Headstrong.co.uk at £21.50 (postage and packing is free).

So you've been there and got the T-shirt? If you're worried about getting a little too involved in the action, be prepared with a Protac combat vest (£130) from Drop Zone Supplies. It has 15 pockets (perfect for your mobile, credit cards and car keys) and quick release buckles across the chest in case you need to, erm, release your buckles in a hurry. Alternatively, the special forces vest (£145) has a handy respirator pouch for smiling through those tear gas moments.

If you're worried about becoming cold while doing a spot of urban gardening (whatever that is), stay true to the combat look and choose the Rip Stop Hood, an army surplus classic at £11.95. Otherwise, the Arctic smock hood (from £6.95), complete with warm drop-down ear flaps and peaked brim, will ensure your day out is not spoiled by the weather, just the oppressors.

Optimum footwear is essential, so get your skates on and order those must-have combat assault boots (not recommended for combat or assault, but very nice boots nonetheless) - 8in high with oil and petrol resistant soles, for £44.95.

You may be too busy to pop into Burger King so don't forget to pack this knife, fork and spoon set (£2) and plastic water bottle and mug (£4.50) from The Cadet Shop.

Finally, immortalise the experience on film with an MP3 player, digicam and webcam in one compact Jenoptik device from lastminute.com.

webTitle: Man cleared of having foot and mouth

fields.headline: Man cleared of having foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Fears that humans had caught foot and mouth diminished tonight after a farm worker feared to have fallen victim to the virus appeared to have been given the all-clear.
fields.body:
Fears that humans had caught foot and mouth diminished tonight after a farm worker feared to have fallen victim to the virus appeared to have been given the all-clear.

Paul Stamper, 33, was splashed with fluid from a slaughtered cow as he helped move carcasses at a farm near Wigton, Cumbria, earlier this month.

He later described how one of the dead animals exploded, spraying fluid into his mouth, and how he then developed symptoms of foot and mouth including painful blisters in his mouth.

But the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, indicated that Mr Stamper had been given the all-clear, saying that one of two people cleared of having the disease today was the man whose face was splashed by liquid from a carcass.

Mr Brown said: "I am delighted and really pleased he has been given the all clear. Otherwise this could have had serious implications for his future employment."

Relatives of Mr Stamper at the village of Dearham in Cumbria, where he lives with his wife and two children, said they had heard the good news but had not yet spoken to him themselves.

Officials at the Public Health Laboratory Service said that eight people had now been given the all-clear, although blood tests still had to be carried out to ensure they were not carrying foot-and-mouth viral antibodies.

Tests on saliva, blood and blister fluid samples from five other patients were continuing.

Today's revelations came as six more cases of foot and mouth among animals were recorded by 1.30pm today, taking the nationwide outbreak total to 1,492.

Growing optimism that the disease has so far failed to jump across the species during the crisis, coupled with the apparent continued slowing down of new daily cases, are likely to boost the morale of beleaguered tourism bosses.

Meanwhile, a survey of more than 500 people also revealed how the British public's perception of farmers had become more positive since the epidemic began.

National opinion poll research commissioned by supermarket chain Waitrose found that almost two-thirds of those questioned claimed to now be "very sympathetic" towards farmers.

Half of respondents also claimed the outbreak had led to a greater understanding of the countryside.

fields.bodyText: Fears that humans had caught foot and mouth diminished tonight after a farm worker feared to have fallen victim to the virus appeared to have been given the all-clear. Paul Stamper, 33, was splashed with fluid from a slaughtered cow as he helped move carcasses at a farm near Wigton, Cumbria, earlier this month. He later described how one of the dead animals exploded, spraying fluid into his mouth, and how he then developed symptoms of foot and mouth including painful blisters in his mouth. But the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, indicated that Mr Stamper had been given the all-clear, saying that one of two people cleared of having the disease today was the man whose face was splashed by liquid from a carcass. Mr Brown said: "I am delighted and really pleased he has been given the all clear. Otherwise this could have had serious implications for his future employment." Relatives of Mr Stamper at the village of Dearham in Cumbria, where he lives with his wife and two children, said they had heard the good news but had not yet spoken to him themselves. Officials at the Public Health Laboratory Service said that eight people had now been given the all-clear, although blood tests still had to be carried out to ensure they were not carrying foot-and-mouth viral antibodies. Tests on saliva, blood and blister fluid samples from five other patients were continuing. Today's revelations came as six more cases of foot and mouth among animals were recorded by 1.30pm today, taking the nationwide outbreak total to 1,492. Growing optimism that the disease has so far failed to jump across the species during the crisis, coupled with the apparent continued slowing down of new daily cases, are likely to boost the morale of beleaguered tourism bosses. Meanwhile, a survey of more than 500 people also revealed how the British public's perception of farmers had become more positive since the epidemic began. National opinion poll research commissioned by supermarket chain Waitrose found that almost two-thirds of those questioned claimed to now be "very sympathetic" towards farmers. webTitle: Israel dispatch: trapped behind Jericho's walls

fields.headline: Trapped behind Jericho's walls
fields.standfirst: Famous for its biblical ramparts, the city of Jericho is now cut off by an Israeli trench, reports Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: Israel dispatch: Famous for its biblical ramparts, the city of Jericho is now cut off by an Israeli trench, reports Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.body:
As Israelis struggled with the day-after blues following Independence Day celebrations, there was one compelling topic of conversation on Friday: the monumental traffic queues as people headed in droves for the beaches and the parks to celebrate their national holiday.

Thousands of people were halted for hours at a stretch; it took some motorists more than an hour simply to negotiate the last traffic light out of Jerusalem.

Amid the chaos, Israelis got a rare glimpse of the frustrations Palestinians encounter on a daily basis. In the desert city of Jericho, canny motorists leave at least an extra hour to clear the roadblocks that now encircle the town.

After the israeli army dug an 18-kilometre trench through the desert sands to seal off the town completely, there is only one road in or out of the city. It is guarded by an Israeli army camp that has increased steadily in size during the course of the seven-month uprising, and vehicles now pass an obstacle course of concrete barricades, presided over by an Israeli soldier who motions them forward, one car at a time, with a flick of his wrist.

"It is better not to go anywhere just to sit at home," said Wajiha, a secretary who says she has not set foot outside Jericho for more than three months.

A few days ago, there were widespread reports that the walls of Jericho were about to come tumbling down, a reward for a series of meetings by Palestinian and Israeli security officials which have seen a drop in shooting attacks on Jewish settlements and troops.

For Israeli gamblers, there was an additional frisson in the announcement on Israel Radio. There is a glitzy casino on the edges of town - banned to Palestinians to appease conservatives who frown on gambling, but a magnet for punters from all over Israel, who arrived by the busload before the intifada.

Until last September, the casino, reputedly controlled by cronies of Yasser Arafat, was the biggest money spinner for the Palestinian Authority. It remained open during the early days of the uprising, and a few die-hard gamblers broke the law on travel for Israeli citizens to Palestinian towns to get their fix. But after it was repeatedly shelled by Israeli soldiers, the casino closed down for repairs.

Alas for the gamblers - and the casino's mysterious consortium of owners - hopes that Jericho would soon be open to the public were scotched by the hardline Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who overruled the promises of his Nobel laureate foreign minister, Shimon Peres, to ease the siege on the city.

"In the Jericho area, 700 million dollars was invested in different industries... this plus the tourism. Everything has been paralysed," Mr Peres had told Israel radio. "Our position is to allow for a normal lifestyle unconditionally and without receiving anything in return. We don't want to harm innocent people."

And so the media began to report on the re-opening of Jericho as a fact. But instead, new concrete barriers arrived to fortify the Israeli checkpoint, and last week Israeli armoured bulldozers razed dozens of acres of vinyards, and destroyed a farmer's home, allegedly for security reasons.

For Palestinians, the reports were infuriating - largely because the siege of Jericho has worsened, not eased, during the last few days as Israel imposes it regular ban on entry to the Jewish state from the West Bank and Gaza as part of the security measures for Independence Day.

Palestinians argue that such announcements by Israel are meant to obscure the situation on the ground in the West Bank, and cover up the immediate hardship, and long-term damage, inflicted by the siege.

"Jericho is the only town that has a new rule now that nobody can leave without having a female sitting next to the driver, and Jericho is the only town in the West Bank that has a trench around it," said Saeb Erakat, a senior Palestinian negotiator, who lives in the town.

"Why do they do it? Simply because of the farmers. Jericho is the breadbasket of the West Bank. Farmers market their produce in Ramallah, Hebron, and Nablus, so by making the trench they ensure that not even smuggling will be done. So that means farmers will find it cheaper not to plant, not to grow, not to harvest. So that is the destruction of the agricultural sector in this region."

fields.headline: Mackems, Dutchmen, and Cockneys
fields.trailText: MACKEM STAY
fields.body:
MACKEM STAY

He's the best striker in the Premier League with an upper lip that looks like there's a moustache on it even though there isn't, so no wonder Kevin Phillips is such hot property. This morning we awoke to find Arsenal, Leeds and the ubiquitous Tottenham Hotspur locked in a race to sign the player after reports claimed he had handed in a transfer request at Sunderland because his pregnant wife wanted to bring up baby in the south of England. Why Leeds were bothering, then, we don't know.

It soon became clear, however, that Arsenal and Spurs were wasting their time as well. Peter Reid, who had obviously been worrying his pretty little head about the matter all morning, hauled Phillips into his office the moment he turned up for training, and within minutes was outside telling the world to sod off. "I've had the boy in and it's rubbish," he growled. "Kevin told me that we have such a good relationship that I would never hear anything about him first from a national newspaper," he continued, getting worryingly possessive. "Kevin rubbished the story and told me he is very happy at the club."

But with Phillips getting a hard time from the Sunderland faithful because he hasn't recently been propping up the rest of the team as usual, doubts lingered that the 27-year-old was tiring of his time on Wearside. Until, that is, Phillips emerged this afternoon to deliver the mother of all equivocal denials. "Some of the stuff I read about myself sometimes is unbelievable and that includes this nonsense about me wanting to leave," began Old Mrs Equivocal Denial. "I'm getting fed up with the tales going around that I'm unsettled, that my head's gone down, that I want to be away or whatever. It is disappointing and upsetting and I am beginning to feel that some people have got it in for me," he concluded, squinting approximately 11 miles up the A19.

WHERE'S ME VAN?

Finally - after one monumental £15m blunder from the Imperial Lord Ferg (more of that in a minute), one crocked knee, one £19m cheque and one missed flight - Ruud van Nistelrooy was unveiled by Manchester United this afternoon. Cue lots of cheesy grins and banal comments like "it's fantastic" and "it's a dream come true". Well, yes. But also, the Fiver is pleased to report, no. Because anyone who tells reporters licking their booze-coated lips at the prospect of a saccharine-sweet I've-always-loved-United-me-even-when-they-were-relegated-in-1992 anecdote "I wasn't a little boy who had United posters on the wall" is alright by us.

And he's obviously all right with Fergie too. "His pace his good, his understanding of the game is good and he scores, which is very important for a striker," explained the Imperial Lord, offering a rare but illuminating insight into why he's such a great manager. But the praise didn't end there, because Fergie then went on to pay van Nistelrooy the greatest of compliments - comparing him to Dion Dublin. "It is good when you see strikers scoring a variety of goals," he said of van the man. "A few years ago someone sent me a video of Dion Dublin, I was really surprised at the variety of goals he scored. That is why we signed him."

And the knockabout frivolities of the press conference continued, with Lord Ferg revealing that United could have signed van Nistelrooy two years ago for about £4.5m! "My son was at Heerenveen on trial for a few days. He came back and said: 'You have got to sign this lad van Nistelrooy, he's fantastic, sign him right away,'" explained Ferg. "I said: 'Hold on a minute, we have watched him already'. My son said: 'Just sign him'. That Saturday, we sent someone to the game but PSV were there and signed him the next day. Talk about slow! I shouldn't admit that, nevertheless he is here and that's what's important." Exactly. And we're sure Money Mart will feel the same way.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If you go to any office, not everyone is going to like each other. It is the same at United. Not everyone is pals. I don't think I've ever given any of them my phone number" - Roy Keane tells Ruud van Nistelrooy what life's really like in the Old Trafford dressing room.

JAMIE OLIVER'S GRANDAD, SORRY, SERVANT'S GRANDAD WRITES

Gor blimey guv'nor, I'm a right old geezer from London tahn and all that and no mistake and all that, and not only do I remember when it was all fields, I also remember when swanky boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea was just a scruffy little shop near the old Kings Rahd. But look at 'em now! Cor, me dear old dad wouldn't recognise 'em. Hats off and forelocks tugged to Kuddly Ken Bates I say. And would you believe it, they've only gorn and applied for membership of the increasingly powerful G14 group of European clubs with a view to ensuring that players who break contracts do not prosper, innit?

Lummee, what a palaver. Sitting around a table with Manchester United, Liverpool, Real Madrid, Barcelona, Juventus, AC Milan, Internazionale, Bayern Munich, Borussia Dortmund, Marseille, Paris St Germain, Ajax, PSV Eindhoven and FC Porto, innit posh? What would me dear old muvver say? "We have applied to join," confirmed old Hutchie (that's how us salt-of-the-earth supporters refer to managing director Colin Hutchinson dahn the old boozah). "It is so important that the big clubs in Europe do have dialogue, especially with the changes being made to the transfer system." Sounds as if you've only got football's best interests at heart, so good luck mister!

Blimey, who's this narky so-and-so what reckons ver Chelse are only making sure they're in on the grahnd level should the inevitable breakaway super-league happen in the next few years? Gord, no, it's Oliver Butler, editor of Soccer Investor! There's always trouble when his sort are abaht. "Membership of the G14 will be vital to clubs if there is any sort of breakaway," he said. "G14 would inevitably be at the head of any kind of attempt to set up a competition outside Uefa's jurisdiction!" Bleedin' hell, can't you just shut your meddling trap and accept that the Chelse - and each and every member of the existing G14 - are only trying their best to help? Lummee, I love London!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Brazilian international keeper Rogerio Ceni is confident of signing for Arsenal this summer. "The proposal is now with Sao Paulo and it is up to the management now," said Ceni.

Barcelona have confirmed they have received a £7m offer for Emmanuel Petit from Spurs.

Fulham are planning a £3.5m bid for Crystal Palace striker Clinton Morrison.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Kieron Dyer has escaped a road accident with cuts and bruises. The 22-year-old England international was involved in a crash outside Newcastle's Chester-le-Street training headquarters this morning. Bobby Robson has confirmed that there is no lasting damage: "As far as the club is aware, other than a few minor cuts and bruises, both drivers were unharmed and Kieron is completely unharmed."

Les Ferdinand has agreed a new two-year contract with Spurs.

Lazio defender Fernando Couto has been suspended by the Italian Football League after testing positive for nandrolone. A spokeswoman for the league said Couto's suspension had "immediate effect", meaning he will miss Sunday's Rome derby.

Greece captain Thodoris Zagorakis was cleared on Friday of using banned anabolic steroids. A sports court concluded that high levels of testosterone recorded in two separate tests were the product of natural causes.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.05am)

Doing this section on Fridays used to be so easy.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (7pm)

Just two entries to write, usually.

Live Scottish Football - Kilmarnock v Hearts (7.30pm)

Three, if you were really unlucky.

Hold The Back Page (10.15pm, 1.15am)

Now look at it!

Sky Sports 2: Non-league Football Show (5pm)

Must we be worked into the ground like an old cur?

Futbol Mundial (5pm)

That's it, you must be joking if you think we're putting up with these conditions.

British Eurosport: Live European Under-16 Football (6.15pm)

We're off. And don't try to stop us.

fields.headline: The Economist round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 28
fields.trailText: April 28: The government is big on targets to improve public services, but it looks as though it has made a mistake.
fields.body:
Targets for public services have been imposed to improve performance, but targeting is not a reliable way of extracting value, writes the Economist. Targets often cause departments to focus on certain objectives, meaning others are ignored. Targeting can also lead to ingenious and sometimes undesirable ways of meeting them. Targets assume that the centre can drive change, but individuals and teams can often find better ways of working. The government would do better to focus on transparency rather than targets, allowing users to pick the best providers of services.

About two-thirds of the government's new performance indicator targets are based on outcomes rather than outputs. For instance, whereas an output target might be the number of police officers, an outcome target is a reduction in crime. Knowing how well public services are meeting the targets is virtually "impossible to follow", according to Tony Travers of the London School of Economics. Moreover, the new targets are failing to provide incentives for workers to meet them. At present, the scrutiny of department's performance against their targets is not independent and they are held to account by the Treasury. There have been calls for an external body to set up an audit and until that time the government targets will lack credibility.

Targets assume that the centre can drive change, but individuals and teams can often find better ways of working. The government would do better to focus on transparency rather than targets, allowing users to pick the best providers of services. About two-thirds of the government's new performance indicator targets are based on outcomes rather than outputs. For instance, whereas an output target might be the number of police officers, an outcome target is a reduction in crime. Knowing how well public services are meeting the targets is virtually "impossible to follow", according to Tony Travers of the London School of Economics. Moreover, the new targets are failing to provide incentives for workers to meet them. At present, the scrutiny of department's performance against their targets is not independent and they are held to account by the Treasury. There have been calls for an external body to set up an audit and until that time the government targets will lack credibility.

webTitle: Armstrong calls for check on Whitehall's control of council cash

fields.headline: Armstrong calls for check on Whitehall's control of council cash
fields.trailText: Local government minister Hilary Armstrong has called on her colleagues to check the massive increase in Westminster's control of council spending since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
Local government minister Hilary Armstrong has called on her colleagues to check the massive increase in Westminster's control of council spending since Labour came to power.

The government has presided over a major rise in so-called "ring fencing", which forces councils to spend large parts of their budgets on ministerial priorities, such as improving school standards.

But councils argue that this process eats into their freedom to spend money on the varying needs of local people, and so erodes the importance of local democracy.

Among the options Ms Armstrong wants to use to limit the government's control of council budgets is an overall cap on the amount of money ministers can earmark in this way.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, would announce the limit as part of the next comprehensive spending review in a bid to stop departments slowly upping the amount of council spending they dictate from Whitehall.

The Local Government Association today welcomed the proposal. A spokesman said: "We've opposed the extension of ring fencing, so we'd support this stance. The amount of ring fencing has doubled in the past four years, so it's not surprising that some ministers want to rein it back in."

The Treasury is thought likely to line up with Ms Armstrong against Mr Blunkett and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, both of whom are known for jealously guarding their departmental budgets.

The value of ring-fenced money has doubled since Labour came to power - with specific grants growing from £1.6bn in 1997-98 to more than £4bn in the current financial year.

That represents almost 10% of the total amount of government funding paid out to councils every year.

Mr Milburn has already signalled a reduction in ring fencing within the NHS as part of a major package of reforms the service announced earlier this week.

Ministers are also considering changes to the massive schools standards fund, which councils pass on to head teachers in order to pay for schemes chosen by the government.

The fund is worth more than £1.5bn, but local government must add in match funding of around £754m a year if it wants the full benefit, effectively earmarking another large chunk of council budgets for central priorities.

Plans to drop this requirement may form part of the local government finance white paper, expected shortly after the next general election.

webTitle: Style: The return of the casuals

fields.headline: Football crazy
fields.standfirst: From the terraces to the catwalks:  Josh Sims on the rise and rise of casuals
fields.trailText: From the terraces to the catwalks: Josh Sims on the rise and rise of casuals.
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine how Will Smith might owe his fashion sensibility to Liverpool Football Club. Or how Liam and Robbie, Travis or Justine Frischmann might. But all have been spotted wearing a track-top last seen in the late 70s, by a brand whose name might stir the sartorial loins of many an urban male in his early 30s: Sergio Tacchini, king of Italian sportswear.

The dress sense of the terraces may now be confined to wearing the team strip, but there was a time when football fans were the epitome of style. To anyone under 25, "casual" may conjure images of sloppy Sunday sweatshirts. But to the London, Manchester and Liverpool-based football fans of the early 80s, casual recalls an obsessively-dressed time when the team colours were pastels, the fabrics traditional, and top clobber was distinguished by the details and the labels.

This was the golden 1979-81 era when travelling across the continent to away matches meant coming face to face with better-dressed opposition supporters and returning to the grey UK with a bag of chic sportswear - Fila, Ellesse, Fiorucci, Lacoste, Kappa and Diadora, names barely known at home and therefore valuable social currency. This elite clique was less interested in duffing up the opposition than out-dressing them. It was all about appropriation. Working-class kids took on traditionally upper-class sports and outdoorsy brands - from Pringle to Lyle & Scott, Barbour to Burberry - and recontextualised them in the dress codes of The Kop.

"Casuals were a huge influence on the 80s/90s label boom. It made a desire for premium brands the norm," says Robert Wade Smith, head of Liverpool's Wade Smith stores, one of the key players behind the recent resurgence of casuals. "It had an anti-establishment element and was stylistically flamboyant: baby-cord trousers with a Norfolk jacket and deerstalker hat. That sense of British and Italian style, urban crossed with country, is very prevalent now."

Casual style has reached the catwalk, informing recent shows from the likes of Raf Simons, Ralph Lauren and Prada. On the street, it overshadows the dominant look of working-class youth: razor haircuts, polo shirts with the collar up, tracksuit bottoms, white socks and Reebok Classics.

Classic casual labels have been reborn: Lacoste, Fred Perry and Pringle, in all its diamond-fronted, celebrity golf circuit glory. Burberry continues to top the fashion league, while the Urban Outfitters chain recently found a job lot of original Tacchini which sold out almost immediately. And to top it all, Will Smith is calling Sergio Tacchini direct because he can't get hold of a certain track-top once worn by its then sponsored player, John McEnroe. Good job the company is reissuing a special edition, made to the original specifications, on the original machinery.

"The casual look is set to explode," says Martin Makin, Mancunian head of design at Sergio Tacchini and part of the Makin family which fed the casual scene by importing Italian sportswear before establishing the JD Sports chain in 1980. "Casual was about individualism, which is key again now. It had a quality nobody had seen before and it was expensive, so it had rarity value."

Men's fashion has much to thank casuals for. These were some of the first young men to take an interest in labels. Their peacockery - Lois jumbo cords, for instance, were precisely split along the seams so that they sat neatly over your Diadora Bjorn Borg Golds - foresaw a generation of men's fashion and grooming magazines.

They have also clearly had an impact on modern culture. John Foley, editor of the Terrace Retro e-zine, suggests casual may have been overlooked because of its associations with football violence, just as skinhead has been overshadowed by racism, even though it was more about a specific music and look. "Casual's influence has been underestimated," Foley says. "It may have lost its edge because while once it was an underground subculture, now every kid is in a £100 tracksuit. The 80s revival has perhaps reminded people of its relevance. It's definitely still around, only now its standard-bearers aren't on the terraces but on stage - Oasis and Blur, for instance."

Those too young to remember casual the first time round are finding new icons of style in the individualistic male celebrities picking up on the casual references of their younger days. These are the new casual generation's benchmarks of cool, just as McEnroe and Borg may have been to their big brothers: Damon Albarn is the casual rocker, Jamie Oliver is the casual chef. As Neil Sellers, Tacchini's UK managing director, puts it: "There I was watching the Big Breakfast the other day and a presenter comes on in an original Slazenger V-neck. Need I say more?"

fields.headline: Davies takes reins at IoS
fields.trailText: 1.30pm update: Tristan Davies's appointment as editor has ended a fortnight of intense speculation at the paper. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The appointment of Tristan Davies as editor of the Independent on Sunday has ended a fortnight of intense speculation about the future of the paper.

Simon Kelner, the editor-in-chief of the Independent and Independent on Sunday, confirmed today that Mr Davies will take over the editorship of the paper on June 11.

Mr Kelner said he was "delighted" with the appointment, adding: "I've worked closely with Tristan for a number of years."

Mr Davies, who was one of the original launch team of the Independent, also worked with Mr Kelner on the Mail on Sunday's Night and Day magazine.

Other shortlisted candidates for the job included the former Express and Independent on Sunday deputy editor, Chris Blackhurst, and the Independent on Sunday deputy editor, Michael Williams.

Mr Kelner denied reports he had lined up Mr Davies as a replacement for Janet Street-Porter weeks before her departure was confirmed.

He said he had interviewed several candidates, both internal and external, for the position.

Ms Street-Porter, a former director at Live TV and the creator of LWT's Network Seven, resigned from the newspaper on April 11 amid reports that the paper's management felt she was not making a big enough impact on its profile or sales.

webTitle: Future closes European editions of Business 2.0

fields.headline: Future closes European editions of Business 2.0
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Future Network is to close the European editions of its new economy magazine Business 2.0, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Future Network is to close the European editions of its new economy magazine Business 2.0 after failing to secure a buyer.

The company announced today that the UK, German and Italian editions of the magazine would be closed, at a cost of around £1m.

However, Future has not ruled out a sale of the US version of the magazine.

In February, Future Network hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to explore opportunities to sell the magazine.

But the statement said: "This review is continuing, but it is now clear that, whatever the outcome of the review, the European editions will need to be closed."

Business 2.0 had been linked with a number of potential buyers including AOL/Time Warner.

Recent story

fields.headline: Julie Burchill
fields.standfirst: Does Julie Burchill really think that nine out of 10 women who enjoy sex have been abused? The Guardian columnist was online to qualify and justify a variety of caustic comments
fields.trailText: 23 April: Does Julie Burchill really think that nine out of 10 women who enjoy sex have been abused? The Guardian columnist was online to qualify and justify a variety of caustic comments.
fields.body:
spindoctor79: Please defend your assertion that nine out of 10 women who enjoy sex have been abused.

Julie: I've been thinking about THAT statement for the past 2 weeks and kicking myself. Of all the dumb things I've said, that was the dumbest. I was actually thinking of porn actresses, who always say they love sex and - nine times out of 10 - have been interfered with. However, I didn't make this at all clear, it was sloppy and lazy and I apologise unreservedly to anyone I may have offended.

However, I won't be apologising about nothing else, so you might as well sling your hook if that's what you're [after].

MotownJunk: You once said that you'd "rather have cancer than be fat." Now that you're older, wiser, and, er, wider, do you regret talking such utter rubbish when you were younger?

Julie: Ooo, yes, I said something at 18 that I don't agree with at 41! Shoot me! As Emerson said, "Consistency is the hobgoblin of small minds".

MontyCarlo: Would you say it is true that you are neither controversial or outrageous in your writing and in fact would be better described as a conservative?

Julie: Please call me what you want, because NINE TIMES OUT OF 10 it says far more about you than it does me. Because I have extremely high self esteem, I find it hard to take any of you seriously. But I have noticed that when people fling abuse it's generally to do with their own weak spots. Therefore someone who is very keen to make money and has failed will abuse me as a moneygrubber; the sex starved will call me bitter and lonely; someone who wants to be a writer and fails will abuse my talent; the hideous will say I'm ugly; and that porky pig DAWN FRENCH always says I'm fat. But insult me if it makes your own dull little lives more bearable - come on, get it all up! But don't ever mistake me for some sucker who gives a damn about your opinions, because then the laugh really is on you.

RTBYRNE300: Why exactly do you generalise so broadly about Americans in your work? It gives me the impression that you don't know many of them, or at least not the interesting ones....

Julie: A good point, very well made. I'll do my best.

rb496: Who, in your opinion, is the sexiest man or woman on earth and why?

Julie: My boyfriend Daniel without doubt. If I was gay, Famke Janssen.

niallanderson: That Tony Parsons is such a nice, inoffensive man. Discuss.

Julie: Mmm, you're so right. I've always wanted to be a short-arsed middle class cry-baby who only ever made it because of who his dad was, and who said last week that he would rather live in a savagely unjust society than a fair one because the former is better for writing! I really wish I'd said that, mmmm!

The only thing that interests me about Parsons is why he lies about his age. What's so much worse about 48 than 44?

Dionysus72: I think you were wrong about Paula Yates. I think she suffered from depression and tried every possible way to defeat it, and finally ran out of options, which was sad. Suggest you ignore the prats who cannot show common politeness.

Julie: Thank you and I think you are right. I was too harsh, but only as a reaction against all the bleeding heart sob sisters saying that she was Madame Bovary, Marilyn Monroe and Mrs Ghandi rolled into one.

krystynfinn: In one of your articles you suggested you would have been a "good" Stalinist. If you had been born in Germany in the early twentieth century do you think you would have been a "good" Nazi?

Julie: Like I'm going to say "yes" to that!

miriamkfahey : What is it, do you think, that makes women tick?

Julie: What makes women tick? What a strange question, would you ask what made Jews tick or blacks tick? I don't think so.

ozzyosiris: Which of your personal qualities would make you suitable to be a role model?

Julie: Not giving a damn about whether people, particularly men, approve of me. For some reason, this really puts the wind up them.

ptw1: You know that Tony Parsons got me the job on the NME, was the best man at my wedding and a good friend for 11 years. But when I knew him he was the sweetest, kindest man you could ever meet. It's my fault I've lost touch with him now, but I think since he's become a z-list celebrity he's turned into George 'Dubya' Bush's forgotten love child - supporting capital punishment, war-mongering, macho behaviour, USA excesses and reactionary fruitcakes who shoot 14-year-old boys in the back. What do you think Compadre?

Julie: Hello there. I think Tony's problem is what Elvis said about Priscilla; he's "mean, cos he never grew." It's no fun being 5 foot 9.

SpinningHead: I would like to know if you still have any interest in music, and if so what bands turn you on? Are you still hip or did you get square?

Julie: Like Massive Attack and St Etienne and I'm definitely a square because I'm OLD - nothing sadder than a trendy 40 year old.

Flintyboy: Was there any other reason than money to start writing for the News of the World? What do you think of the paper's readers? And the paper's "For Sarah" weekly name and shame paedophiles?

Recently there was a letter saying that Carol Vorderman deserved happiness (after finding a new man after leaving her hubby) especially as she supports the "For Sarah" campaign. What do you think goes on in these people's minds?

Julie: I like the paper, I like Rebekah and I like being on the side of the working class against the snobs. Enough for you?

I like the N.O.W and I like Rebekah Wade even more - she is a fine woman, in every way possible.

And yes, the money is unimaginable.

jsd104: Why did you make such a scurrilous attack on Tony Cliff last year? Was it malice or ignorance?

Julie: I don't understand why he changed his name from a lovely Jewish one to a silly 50's crooner one - amongst other things.

Gus69: Are you happy?

Julie: Very, but really that's not saying much as I've always been happy. I suppose I've never been so RELAXED. I think of myself as being in semi-retirement. That's why I moved to Hove.

beaky1: Was it you in that pub on the corner of St James Street and New Stein the other day? You were with some friends, drinking Guinness, and I was by myself. We exchanged glances a few times, then I winked, and you gave me a little wave with your fingertips. I wish I'd had the nerve to come up to you. I've been told I look a bit like a black version of Brad Pitt (!) except I've got short deadlocks. I was wearing a paint-splattered suit at the time. If it was you, you're a very sexy lady!

Julie: Oooo, you sound nice - but have not been to pub for five years.

PaulieWalnuts: You once said - when you were much older than 18 - that one could never be too thin or too un-American. Given that you're still making asinine remarks like this at 42 (don't lie about your age), but without the get-out clause of youthful ignorance, have you abandoned all hope of being the Dorothy Parker of your generation and instead settled for an afternoon sparring with layabouts who remember when you were good, and didn't tart up your bile in the guise of plain speaking?

Julie: Mmm, definitely.

bossreddog: Has Tony Parsons always been a closet fascist or is it a new departure for him?

Julie: Tony isn't a fascist but he's obviously got self-loathing "issues" to spit constant bile on the working class, which he comes from, the way he does.

ustadion: You got a mobile yet?

Julie: No, and I'm never going to get one. A mobile phone is a badge of servitude - not for me.

Wildboar100: I'd be interested to know what your opinion of Tracey Emin's appearance on Saturday's episode of Have I Got News For You (that's if you saw it, although no doubt you had wilder and wickeder things to do on a Saturday night)?

Julie: I didn't see it but I do like Tracey. She's got about the best chest I've ever seen.

mies56: What is it with your Martin Amis animus - was there an occurrence at the Groucho?

Julie: I only met him once and he was quite ingratiating. I just don't like Brits who put down this country in order to suck up to the Yanks. They're the lowest of the low - in Mart's case, about 2 feet off the ground.

kevcosgrove: Are you pro-pigeon?

Julie: Yes, I like them very much.

jenngriff: It worries me greatly that the UK is acting as lapdog to the US - we need to resist the Disnification of Britain. Is there anyone in UK politics gutsy enough to tell Dubya and co to piss off?

It's American tourism that's keeping the UK's own Disneyworld - aka Buckingham Palace and its contents - up and running. Monarchists never fail to invoke the tourism defence in favour of Brenda and her hangers-on.

Julie: I couldn't be happier about them staying away , and couldn't agree with you more.

EvilWillow: How do you feel now about embracing Thatcherism in the way that you did?

Julie: Thatcher - very stupid, very wrong. BUT NOT REGRETFUL.

kirstyxx: As a Communist and a Thatcherite, what are you views on the European Union? Would you support Britain joining the Euro?

Julie: I'm very much against the Euro, and the blanding out of the different European cultures in general that Europhiles are working towards. One day all cities will be like Milton Keynes.

funfur: In your article on Boris Becker, you described yourself as a married woman. You haven't got hitched again, have you? A case of hope triumphing over experience, I would say. Also, are you still carrying a torch for Tone? You mention him all the time, but your second husband barely at all. What does this mean? Or do you just think Parsons is tougher and can take the jibes about premature ejaculation?

Julie: I am still married to my second husband who won't divorce me. But I have been going steady with A.Nother for 6 years - so am very married, one way or another.

liphooker: Hello Ms Landfill - why don't you ever mention your son? Do you ever feel guilty for abandoning him?

Julie: It was SONS, not SON. And no, I don't.

puardian: About a couple of years ago, writing that Britain is less racist than America, you quoted a black musician saying that so many white women wanted to sleep with him. I think you are wrong in citing that as part proof of Britain being less racist. The myth about the hypersexual black man not only suggests that black men are virile and well-hung which is why white women fantasise about and want to sleep with black men but also feeds the 'black men are rapists' myth. - ritu

Julie: I'm sorry I didn't mean it like that, just to suggest that we are cooler about race than the US. You saw it with the black GIs and British girls too - I think its a wonderful thing.

monitor2: Isn't 'Man and Boy' awful.

Julie: Shocking. Mills & Boon with legovers.

TheMightyColin: Don't know if you've replied to this one yet (from someone else originally, but I'm curious): what's with the NOTW gig? Are you happy to have your name associated with that organ (please, no organ jokes)? Do you find it harder to write for White Van Man than for the Graun market? Don't you feel a bit grubby?

Julie: No, I genuinely like the paper. I like what it does - and I'm not a snob about tabloids, unlike lots of broadsheet readers and writers - and OH - THE MONEY!!!

Seymour2: Do you and your boyfriend agree on most of the issues you write about?

Julie: About half of them - but I don't ARGUE with him and he doesn't ARGUE with me 'cos we're too nice.

macdougal: Do you think you might be a bit less angry if you were beautiful? Genuine question.

Julie: I was far angrier when I was beautiful. I'm dead easygoing now.

macdougal: When was that?

Julie: I'm as confused as you. It's hardly Bogart and Bacall, is it? I blame therapy.

EvilWillow: You say you haven't been single since you were 15. Do you think this is a good thing or a bad thing?

Julie: I think its horrible being single. It just doesn't suit me.

Lindakay9: Where did you get the inspiration for the most memorable bits of Ambition? Was it based on any experiences that you have had? Please answer my other questions too...

Julie: You're right, I think. It's inevitable if you do it every week.

fields.bodyText: spindoctor79: Please defend your assertion that nine out of 10 women who enjoy sex have been abused. Julie: I've been thinking about THAT statement for the past 2 weeks and kicking myself. Of all the dumb things I've said, that was the dumbest. I was actually thinking of porn actresses, who always say they love sex and - nine times out of 10 - have been interfered with. However, I didn't make this at all clear, it was sloppy and lazy and I apologise unreservedly to anyone I may have offended. However, I won't be apologising about nothing else, so you might as well sling your hook if that's what you're [after]. MotownJunk: You once said that you'd "rather have cancer than be fat." Now that you're older, wiser, and, er, wider, do you regret talking such utter rubbish when you were younger? Julie: Ooo, yes, I said something at 18 that I don't agree with at 41! Shoot me! As Emerson said, "Consistency is the hobgoblin of small minds". MontyCarlo: Would you say it is true that you are neither controversial or outrageous in your writing and in fact would be better described as a conservative? Julie: Please call me what you want, because NINE TIMES OUT OF 10 it says far more about you than it does me. Because I have extremely high self esteem, I find it hard to take any of you seriously. But I have noticed that when people fling abuse it's generally to do with their own weak spots. Therefore someone who is very keen to make money and has failed will abuse me as a moneygrubber; the sex starved will call me bitter and lonely; someone who wants to be a writer and fails will abuse my talent; the hideous will say I'm ugly; and that porky pig DAWN FRENCH always says I'm fat. But insult me if it makes your own dull little lives more bearable - come on, get it all up! But don't ever mistake me for some sucker who gives a damn about your opinions, because then the laugh really is on you. I was too harsh, but only as a reaction against all the bleeding heart sob sisters saying that she was Madame Bovary, Marilyn Monroe and Mrs Ghandi rolled into one. krystynfinn: In one of your articles you suggested you would have been a "good" Stalinist. Julie: Like I'm going to say "yes" to that! miriamkfahey : What is it, do you think, that makes women tick? Julie: What makes women tick? Julie: Not giving a damn about whether people, particularly men, approve of me. fields.headline: Organised chaos?
fields.standfirst: May 1 will see one of the biggest protests in recent years descend on Oxford Street in central London at 4pm. But baring that one fact, few people know what else will happen. Matthew Tempest takes a look at how an unorganised protest is organised.
fields.trailText: It is a strange serendipity that in the week when a mass global political movement, the anti-capitalist May Day protests, utilised the internet to mobilise and organise its supporters, the UK government announced it was to close its portal, opengov.uk.
fields.body:
It is a strange serendipity that in the week when a mass global political movement, the anti-capitalist May Day protests, utilised the internet to mobilise and organise its supporters, the UK government announced it was to close its portal, opengov.uk.

The culture clash between anti-capitalists and the forces of globalisation will be fought not just on the streets of London next Tuesday but in cyberspace, for the hearts, minds and wallets of the angry, if uncommitted, young.

Government sites, by their nature, belie their huge resources and manpower with a thorough but uninspiring set of links. Anarchists are far more ingenious and witty in their use of the internet to encourage and amuse.

For all the protestations of the police and politicians, and whatever happens on May 1, the granddaddy of this year's sites, May Day Monopoly is bright and lucid.

The idea of using the monopoly boardgame as a metaphor for the corporate takeover of streets and stations of the capital - which is what the game represents - is done with a skill and an attention to detail suggesting serious techie know-how.

Slogans adorn every square of the transposed boardgame, and while only the truly corporate-at-heart could fail to grin at such idealistic calls-to-arms as: "If you can't be bought, you can't be sold", even the less epigrammatic "Tell rich bastards to fuck off" has a certain bracing camaraderie to it.

But one thing the site is lacking, to the frustration of the police (if not demonstrators) is concrete detail on what is actually planned for next Tuesday.

Two critical mass bike rides, which disrupt traffic entering central London during rush hour (activists on the rides dislike the term "holding up the traffic" as they argue that it is the cars themselves which create that jam), will leave from the Railtrack-owned stations of Marylebone and Liverpool Street at 7.30am for two separate "West End" and "City" tours.

Since the privatised utilities - rail, electricity and waterworks - are both the backbone of the boardgame and one of the prime targets for any protest - this is likely to be a heavily policed start to May Day, although the history of mass demonstrations shows violence (from either side of the police line) or damage to property is likely to come later in the day.

From there, until 4pm when protesters are asked to converge on Oxford Street - London's busiest shopping street - instructions are simply to "move off around the monopoly board". The young-at-heart will remember that the board stretches from Old Kent Road and Whitechapel, through the major rail stations and the electricity and waterworks, to Pall Mall and Mayfair. Quite a large patch for the Met to protect.

Unsurprisingly, a spokeswoman for Hasbro, who took over Monopoly manufacturers from Waddingtons, refused to comment on this subversive bastardisation of the family board game.

As far as "news you can use" goes, few consumer sites could match the confidence of the site's legal advice: "Searches: the police must have reasonable suspicion that you are carrying drugs, weapons or stolen items before they search you, so ask why you are being searched and ask for a written record afterwards. You can only have a "pat down" search unless you are arrested, and you are only required to remove outer clothing (eg a coat) in public. You have the right to be searched by a cop of the same gender."

All of which is good to know. Indeed, the site's organisers even pledge they will be sending legal observers wearing bright orange bibs into the melee.

The men and women behind the site have also played a blinder by refusing all requests to give TV and radio interviews, thus forcing all interested parties, from police, journalists, shopkeepers and even, just possibly, would-be protesters, to come through to their sites.

It would be interesting to monitor their traffic flow and hits over the past fortnight as the big day approaches - and no doubt MI5 already has. Under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which was passed last year, the security services now have the authority to intercept emails, monitor website access and decode secret or encrypted data on individual hard drives.

That power undoubtedly is the reason for the strange URL of another powerful anti-establishment site, the Network Against Terrorism Act.

Based in Tonga, to avoid UK authorities, it rails against legislation passed last year by Labour which broadened the definition of "terrorism" to include environmental protesters demonstrating against GM food or road-building programmes.

As the site itself proclaims: "A definition of terrorism that lumps together the bombing of a woman and her baby on a train and civil disobedience is morally offensive. It also devalues the term and weakens its effect on the bomber."

The site also is an exponent of media jamming, the phenomenon chronicled by Naomi Klein in her book No Logo, whereby posters from the Metropolitan police are morphed to send out a satirical message - thus instead of a discarded bag being labelled a potential terrorist, a picture of a woman dressed in taffeta and on stilts, from the last May Day protest, is daubed into the poster.

Critical Mass, the city centre bike rides which originated in San Francisco, is perhaps a tangential part of the anti-globalisation coalition, arguing as it does for car-free city centres, but its site is a model of Wittgenstian logic, if little visual stimulation, being simply a collection of collectives and their web links.

However, its introduction is a masterpiece worthy of Samuel Beckett at his driest: Critical Mass is not an organisation, it's an unorganised coincidence. Accordingly, this isn't the official Critical Mass web page, because there is no official Critical Mass web page.

But perhaps the most intellectually entertaining site of the lot is Adbusters, a click on which takes you straight to a window warning "This is TV turn off week. Please shut off your computer and go get a life." It's almost like cyber-terrorism for the "Why Don't You?" generation. And a perfect illustration of the perverse, amorphous but literate and entertaining subculture of alternative websites.

webTitle: No such thing as a free launch

fields.headline: No such thing as a free launch
fields.standfirst:
American multi-millionaire Dennis Tito is all set to become the world's first space tourist, despite Nasa's efforts to stop him, writes Neil Perry

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: American multi-millionaire Dennis Tito is all set to become the world's first space tourist, despite Nasa's efforts to stop him, writes Neil Perry.
fields.body:
This weekend, if the launch goes to plan, multi-millionaire American financier Dennis Tito will climb into a Russian Soyuz spacecraft with two cosmonauts and rocket up to the International Space Station, where he will enjoy a surreal six-day vacation as the world's first space tourist.

Nasa, the American space agency, tried to stop Mr Tito. Happily, it failed. It was 60-year-old Tito's boyhood dream to travel into space. It has cost him $18m (£12m), eagerly accepted by the cash-strapped Russian space programme, and eight months of his life holed up at Moscow's Star City, the cosmonaut training centre, to realise it.

The fledgling space tourism industry - and that includes Apollo moonwalker Buzz Aldrin, who wants to launch a lottery with a seat on the space shuttle as the prize - will be watching very carefully over the next week or so, as Russia teaches America all about capitalism in space.

Tito's giant leap for tour reps everywhere is seen by some as the first move towards the day when we will be able to pop down to the local spaceport and buy a super saver ticket for a relaxing weekend break in orbit - and Nasa doesn't like it.

"There is a concept called professional jealousy," Mr Tito has drily observed. "This exists in many, many fields. We all like to think we're experts, and if somebody comes in that doesn't have exactly the same training that we do, we don't think they're qualified."

A man with a lifelong interest in space travel - ironically he worked at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the height of the space race in the sixties - Tito's initial plan was to fly to Russia's then ageing Mir outpost. When the decrepit station was sent crashing into the Pacific earlier this year, he feared his boyhood dream had burned up with it. No worries, said the Russians. We will just fly you to the ISS instead.

Nasa was furious. In an increasingly bitter and undignified dispute with their Russian partners, the Americans repeatedly cited safety reasons as to why Mr Tito would not be allowed to set foot on the ISS. Nasa then demeaned its own safety argument somewhat by adding, rather childishly, that it "wasn't fair" to their own astronauts who had to endure years of training - Mr Tito simply had "no right" to fly. The message was clear: space is a big, scary place, so best leave it to the professionals, okay? It is definitely not meant to be fun.

"We will not budge," said Yuri Semyonov, head of the Russian space corporation Energiya. "This is an unpleasant story," he added, in a nice piece of understatement. "I think that politics are involved in it."

The issue came to a head on March 19, when the cosmonauts and Mr Tito arrived at Nasa's Johnson space centre in Houston, Texas for a week of training. He was told that he would not be allowed to train. Nasa had initially complained that Mr Tito did not have enough training. Now they were refusing to provide it. Mr Tito's fellow crew members walked out.

The Russians were ordered back by their own superiors the next day, but the gauntlet was down. "I am actually quite surprised that Nasa has opposed my flight," said a carefully diplomatic Mr Tito. "The interest that it will generate among the American public for spaceflight will be tremendous and a benefit for Nasa."

After a meeting of all the ISS partners, Nasa grudgingly relented, but continued to behave petulantly, at one point talking of barring Mr Tito from the American-built section of the station - their own miniature spaceborne Berlin Wall. The current ISS commander - a Russian, luckily for Mr Tito - countered by saying he could go where he wants. Eventually Nasa settled for the intrepid adventurer signing agreements stating that he won't sue and that he will "pay for anything he breaks".

"It's the classic beginning of real space tourism," says John Spencer, head of the Space Tourism Society in Los Angeles, California. "Tito is essentially our Neil Armstrong."

"When private individuals start to go," reckons the space tourist, "we will learn a lot more about space from a human cultural standpoint than we know now from professional astronauts that are just trained in the field of aeronautics and astronautics."

This is the heart of the matter. Since the demise of Mir, the Americans are the main players in space, and that's the way they like it. But the American public, and the world at large, stopped caring what Nasa did 30-odd years ago - about 10 minutes after Armstrong set foot on the moon, to be precise - and Nasa only has itself to blame. With many holding down day jobs in the US military, astronauts are generally brave, highly skilled and incredibly dull people - ask what it's like to fly toward the stars or float silently over the blue earth and the answer will probably have something to do with "achieving objectives" or "mission parameters".

The people we should be sending up are the writers, reporters and poets, the painters and photographers, people who can add a warm human perspective to what is still humanity's greatest achievement. If Dennis Tito's trip of a lifetime helps usher in this new space age, then more power to him.

All that can stop him now are technical gremlins and the weather.

God speed, Dennis Tito. We hope you get your money's worth.

fields.headline: DoomWatch
fields.standfirst: Talk of recession has now permeated every sector of the media. The slump is no longer the preserve of the internet and advertising industries. Each week, our new DoomWatch service will keep you up to date with the changes in the media economy, complete with expert opinions from the US and UK
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will meet this weekend to address the slowdown, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It's official - the spectre of recession is keeping bankers awake at night.

This weekend, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will meet to address the situation, which has caught them on the hop.

Growth is slowing more than they had anticipated and a soft landing seems increasingly unlikely.

The global outlook remains uncertain and media companies are feeling the pinch.

The two big media stories this week - the rebranding of ONdigital and Sir Christopher Bland quitting the BBC for BT - sent shares reeling.

BT shares fell by 7% almost immediately on the news Sir Christopher would replace Sir Iain Vallance as chairman of the troubled telecoms group.

Analysts said BT should have appointed a more dynamic troubleshooter than "the charming gentleman" Sir Christoper.

BT has lost two thirds of its value over the past 18 months.

Its share price has dropped from £15 a year ago to around £5 today and it has a £30m mountain of debt.

But some City analysts trumpeted the appointment, saying it suggested BT was turning a corner.

Benedict Evans, telecoms analyst at the investment bank, West LB Panmure, told the Guardian: "We are fans of Sir Christopher. He has a good record and has experience of companies that have been in difficulty. He could hardly be worse than Mr Vallance."

ITV's rebranding of ONdigital and plans for a harmonised ITV also failed to inspire a City disenchanted with media stocks.

Shares in Carlton fell 16.5p to 379.5p while Granada's shares closed 8p lower at 178p on the day the announcement was made.

By midday on Friday, Carlton had recovered slightly to 403p but Granada was still down at 175p.

ITV is desperate to cut costs across the board and build subscriptions to bolster declining advertising revenues.

Senior executives say ITV's revenues were down 20% in April and there are fears the downturn could last into the first quarter of next year.

However, the ITV companies are convinced the downturn is merely a blip, rather than a recession.

Recession roulette - who's winning and who's losing

 Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, which operates TalkSport and 16 independent local radio stations, bucked the trend for falling advertising revenues. On Friday, it announced it had increased its turnover by 22% in the first quarter.

 The British advertising and marketing giant, WPP, confessed to being a victim of the US economic slowdown when it reported a lower than expected rise in first quarter revenues on Thursday.

 Wanadoo, the French owner of Freeserve, disappointed the City on Wednesday by posting lower than expected first quarter revenues of £195.5m.

 Also on Wednesday, the government asked Motorola to repay the bulk of its £20m state aid after the US mobile phone giant shut down its plant at Bathgate in Scotland with the loss of more than 3,000 jobs.

 ONdigital, the Carlton/Granada pay-TV operation that will be rebranded ITV Digital in the autumn, cut its subscriber projections from 2m by early 2003 to 1.7m in 2003-4. The ONdigital chief executive, Stuart Prebble, was named head of ITV.

 LineOne, one of Britain's best known internet service providers, succumbed on Wednesday to a long-expected £62m takeover by the Italian ISP, Tiscali. LineOne was once tipped for a £1bn flotation.

 Vivendi Universal said it wanted to broaden its three-week-old music licensing agreement with Yahoo! to take in TV shows and movies and to develop a mutually beneficial partnership.

 Rupert Murdoch had a busy week. On Monday, he personally stepped in to try to rescue his flagging takeover bid for the US satellite broadcaster, Hughes Electronic. On Tuesday, he sealed a deal with Vivendi to merge its loss-making Italian pay-TV businesses, Stream and Telepiu.

 All week speculation was rife surrounding BSkyB's companywide budget review, which was anticipated to fall heavily on its internet operation and director John Swingewood.

 The Swedish mobile phone giant, Ericsson, ended months of speculation by confirming a joint venture with Sony to revitalise its loss-making mobile phone operation and develop new gadgets.

 Egg, the internet bank, silenced the critics by reducing its losses by almost £500,000 to £38m in the first three months of the year. It now claims to be on track to break even in six months.
