webTitle: Shedding light on Belgium's heart of darkness

fields.headline: Shedding light on Belgium's heart of darkness
fields.standfirst: The colonial past of Belgium still haunts the country, says Ian Black, as the ghost of Patrice Lumumba returns once more
fields.trailText: The colonial past of Belgium still haunts the country, says Ian Black, as the ghost of Patrice Lumumba returns once more.
fields.body:
Not many Belgians can tell you much about the short life and times of Patrice Lumumba. But the 40-year-old mystery of who murdered Africa's most promising post-colonial leader came back to haunt them this week - and shows no signs of going away.

On a rainy morning, police and court officials raided the homes of a former high-ranking army officer and royal aide and an ex-chief of security from Zaire, the giant central African country that used to be the Belgian Congo.

Suitcases of documents and a computer were deposited with a special parliamentary commission that began investigating the killing of Lumumba exactly a year ago.

Its findings, which are due out in the autumn, are likely to cause deep embarrassment. But at least they will finally set the record straight.

Belgium has a long and dark history in Africa. Earlier this month, four Rwandans, including two nuns, went on trial in the Brussels Palais de Justice for their part in the 1994 genocide.

That case is an uncomfortable reminder of how the hasty withdrawal of Belgium's UN troop contingent paved the way for an orgy of ethnic slaughter in a region where Belgium has played a key role since King Leopold II sought his place in the colonial sun.

But the Lumumba affair goes back much further, to the dangerous days of 1960 when the Congo, the size of western Europe, finally won its freedom after 80 rapacious years of Belgian rule - serving as the model for Joseph Conrad's novel Heart of Darkness.

The commission of enquiry was set up after the publication of a book by Lugo De Witte, an Africa expert, which claimed that there was clear evidence of Belgian state responsibility for the murder.

Lumumba, a charismatic and highly articulate nationalist, was freed from prison when the Belgians scuttled out. He was just 36 when he became independent Congo's first prime minister.

But within a month, a bloody civil war erupted, provoked by the attempted secession of the copper-rich province of Katanga led by Moise Tshombe, who recruited Belgian, French and South African mercenaries to fight the elected government.

UN forces intervened but did little more than maintain the status quo. Lumumba was deposed and an unknown colonel called Joseph-Desire Mobutu took control of the country, which he renamed Zaire, and remained a faithful friend of the west until his own overthrow.

Locked in its long cold war struggle against the Soviet Union, the US saw the militant nationalist Lumumba as a communist sympathiser. CIA involvement in plans to kill him has been long established by senate hearings and declassified documents.

New evidence that emerged last year proved that President Dwight Eisenhower directly ordered his "elimination".

Crucially however, de Witte's research showed that, by the time Lumumba was killed, Washington had little ability to operate on the ground in the Congo, and had given way to Brussels. '"Belgian officers had direct responsibility for his assassination," the author insisted.

De Witte's discoveries included a document signed by the then Belgian minister for Africa, Harold Aspremont Lynden, in October 1960, which stated baldly: "The main objective to pursue, in the interests of the Congo, Katanga and Belgium, is clearly the final elimination of Lumumba."

On January 17 1961, Lumumba, under arrest by Mobutu's forces, was transferred to Katanga on a Sabena plane on the orders of Aspremont Lynden and Belgian foreign minister Pierre Wigny.

The Congolese leader was assaulted in the presence of Belgian officers and tortured in a villa guarded by Belgian troops before being shot, along with two companions, by an execution squad supervised by a Belgian captain.

In a macabre aftermath, his body was exhumed by a Belgian police commissioner and then dismembered and dissolved in acid.

In death, Lumumba became a powerful icon of the anti-colonial struggle. A university named after him was set up in Moscow and became a magnet for students from the Third World. Ronan Bennett's novel The Catastrophist, is based on his story. Last year, a highly-praised film of his life won plaudits at the Cannes Film Festival.

In his political testament, written shortly before his murder, the young Congolese reflected: "One day, history will have its say, but it will not be the history they teach at the UN, in Washington, Paris or Brussels, but the history they teach in countries freed from colonialism and its puppets.

"Africa will write its own history, and it will be one of glory and dignity."

Africa's history is still far from glorious, but now Belgians of a different generation are doing their best to establish the truth. "A self-respecting nation should not fear the past and must have the courage to investigate possible errors," the commission's chairman, Geert Versnick, declared when work began last year.

Hearings were suspended in January after the assassination of Mobutu's successor, Laurent Kabila, with its troubling echoes of past violence. But this week's high-profile raids in Brussels were a clear signal that it is business as usual - and that there could be real embarrassment to come.

The former army officer whose documents were seized, a Colonel Weber, still works for Princess Lilian, widow of King Leopold III. Close attention will be paid to the witnesses who are scheduled to appear in open session before a final report is issued in October.

And it is widely expected that the Belgian state will then issue a solemn - if belated - official apology for its role in the killing of Patrice Lumumba.

webTitle: Comment: No 10's tax and school plans

fields.headline: Catchment if you can
fields.standfirst:
The middle classes are buying their children's education by moving to the 'right' area, according to a government think tank. But school catchment areas are still the fairer option, argues education editor Will Woodward
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Comment: The middle classes are buying their children's education by moving to the 'right' area, according to a government think tank. But school catchment areas are still the fairer option, argues education editor Will Woodward
fields.body:
Tony Blair's Performance and Innovation unit, based in the Cabinet Office, thinks school catchment areas are a bad idea. It has told the prime minister that selection in state schools will have to be increased if he is to achieve his vision of a genuine meritocratic society in Britain.

Its chief economist, Stephen Aldridge, wants to reduce their power "to counteract the scope for middle class parents to buy a good education for their children by moving to the right area".

He's right to identify the malaise. A study by Warwick University a few weeks ago showed that in Coventry parents are prepared to pay almost 20% more for their homes to ensure their children get places at good state schools. Aldridge says: "There is little evidence that educational expansion has enabled the working-class to catch up."

But the medicine could hurt even more. Popular schools have to select some way. And if they do not give priority to geographical location, it is hard to see what they can do except select on the basis of ability - or, as the government prefers these days, the closely-related notion of "aptitude".

Catchment areas are far from perfect. But they look to me like the worst system except for all the others: the best available way of ensuring that children go to schools in their local community; mixed-ability schools which don't in effect decide for them at 11 whether they will be educational successes or failures.

Downing Street was playing down the significance of this report last night; just one idea by one economist. But it will only increase the suspicion and anxiety of those who think Tony Blair has it in for comprehensive schools.

When the government launched its green paper on schools in February, Mr Blair's careful phrase was that he wanted to move to a "post-comprehensive argument". That carefully worked out line was demolished by his spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who sounded the death knell for the "bog standard comprehensive".

Mr Blair wants to rapidly increase the number of specialist schools - secondaries with a particular focus on science or technology, or other areas. Those schools have the power to select up to 10% of their pupils by aptitude; within five years he wants half of all of secondaries to be specialist.

But when the media called this a "two tier" system, ministers and officials claimed to be staggered. They did not expect that to be the line of attack at all, they say privately.

But this report adds further fuel to the fears of those who believe the post-comprehensive argument means an old-style grammar/secondary split in all but name. The comps need resourcing, not demolishing. It is to be hoped that Blair sets more store by his own declared goal of increasing spending on state schools to the level enjoyed by private schools. If that were achieved, that really would deliver life chances and social mobility to those the current system leaves behind.

A study by Warwick University a few weeks ago showed that in Coventry parents are prepared to pay almost 20% more for their homes to ensure their children get places at good state schools. Aldridge says: "There is little evidence that educational expansion has enabled the working-class to catch up." But the medicine could hurt even more. Popular schools have to select some way. And if they do not give priority to geographical location, it is hard to see what they can do except select on the basis of ability - or, as the government prefers these days, the closely-related notion of "aptitude". Catchment areas are far from perfect. But they look to me like the worst system except for all the others: the best available way of ensuring that children go to schools in their local community; mixed-ability schools which don't in effect decide for them at 11 whether they will be educational successes or failures. Downing Street was playing down the significance of this report last night; just one idea by one economist. But it will only increase the suspicion and anxiety of those who think Tony Blair has it in for comprehensive schools. When the government launched its green paper on schools in February, Mr Blair's careful phrase was that he wanted to move to a "post-comprehensive argument". That carefully worked out line was demolished by his spokesman, Alastair Campbell, who sounded the death knell for the "bog standard comprehensive". Mr Blair wants to rapidly increase the number of specialist schools - secondaries with a particular focus on science or technology, or other areas. Those schools have the power to select up to 10% of their pupils by aptitude; within five years he wants half of all of secondaries to be specialist. But when the media called this a "two tier" system, ministers and officials claimed to be staggered. They did not expect that to be the line of attack at all, they say privately. But this report adds further fuel to the fears of those who believe the post-comprehensive argument means an old-style grammar/secondary split in all but name. The comps need resourcing, not demolishing. It is to be hoped that Blair sets more store by his own declared goal of increasing spending on state schools to the level enjoyed by private schools. If that were achieved, that really would deliver life chances and social mobility to those the current system leaves behind. webTitle: West Bank sees battle, as officials meet

fields.headline: West Bank sees battle, as officials meet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops rocketed a Palestinian office building and fought a heavy battle with Palestinian gunmen today, just hours after high-ranking security officials from both sides held talks on how to work together in trying to prevent violence.
fields.body:
Israeli troops rocketed a Palestinian office building and fought a heavy battle with Palestinian gunmen today, just hours after high-ranking security officials from both sides held talks on how to work together in trying to prevent violence.

Several Israeli jeeps entered Palestinian territory, witnesses said. Three Palestinians and an Israeli soldier were wounded in the exchange of fire north of the West Bank town of Ramallah, witnesses and doctors said. But the Israeli army said that no soldiers were hurt.

Earlier in the day, Israeli and Palestinian security officials had held security talks. A senior Palestinian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that he believed that the meeting could pave the way for a resumption of security co-ordination, one of the pillars of interim peace agreements.

Israel has said such co-ordination and a complete cessation of violence are a prerequisite for renewing peace talks.

The initiative calls for a cease-fire and an Israeli freeze on settlement construction, followed by a resumption of talks on a final peace deal. Israel wants better guarantees that Palestinians will cease attacks and has said that it will not agree to stop all settlement construction.

In Jerusalem, the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, and his foreign minister, Shimon Peres, discussed Israel's response to an Egyptian-Jordanian peace proposal. Mr Sharon has said that he wants to negotiate a long-term interim agreement, not a full peace treaty.

Mr Peres is to fly to Cairo on Sunday to explain Israel's reservations about the plan, then head to Washington for talks with the US secretary of state, Colin Powell.

In an interview with army radio on Israel's independence day yesterday, Mr Sharon said that, "after examining the plan, it is clear to me that there must be changes, substantial changes in it."

Today's clashes began after Muslim noon prayers when about 2,000 Palestinians marched to an Israeli army position north of Ramallah. At one point, Palestinian gunmen opened fire at Israeli troops, and a firefight ensued.

Among those wounded was a Palestinian security official, who was hit in the chest. When the fighting intensified, Israel fired seven rockets at the Palestinian bureau of statistics, located in Palestinian territory, witnesses said. The missiles heavily damaged the facade, and three Israeli jeeps were seen in the area.

In the Gaza Strip, meanwhile, a bomb exploded near a Jewish settlement, wounding an Israeli civilian and a soldier, the army said.

fields.headline: Fergie debut boosts Tonight
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Over 5 tuned in to Tonight with Trevor McDonald to watch Sarah Ferguson's reporting debut, reports Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Over 5m people tuned in to Tonight with Trevor McDonald last night to watch Sarah Ferguson's debut as a reporter.

Her appearance boosted the show's ratings to 5.4m, around a third of the total viewership and well up on its usual audience of just 3.7m.

But when Ms Ferguson's quarter hour slot ended the show's ratings fell back to 4.4%, a 29% share.

Elsewhere, the new series of Film 2001 with Jonathan Ross kicked off with 1.2m viewers last night.

The 11.35pm movie review show pulled in 18% of the evening's audience for that time slot.

Over on Channel 4 at 11.05pm West Wing fared less well. It got just 1m viewers, 11% of the audience.

ITV's hospital drama A&E nailed 7.3m viewers, a 32% share.

Airing at 9pm, it was up against C4's Football Stories, which got 2.4m viewers giving it an 11% share.

webTitle: Gove steps down from Times home news desk

fields.headline: Gove steps down from Times home news desk
fields.trailText: 2pm: Michael Gove, assistant editor of the Times, is relinquishing responsibility for the home news desk, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Michael Gove, assistant editor of the Times, is relinquishing responsibility for the home news desk to Graham Paterson as part of an editorial restructure.

Mr Gove, who will continue to write op ed columns for the paper and will write for T2, is said to have requested the move.

The decision is bound to increase speculation that he is in line for the editorship of the Spectator.

Mr Gove has been mentioned recently as a late entrant in the race for the editor's chair at the magazine following the expected departure of the editor, Boris Johnson, who is standing as a Tory MP at the election.

But the move means Mr Gove is effectively number four on the paper and insiders say that he is pleased with the outcome.

Mr Paterson will take effective responsibility for managing home news, and will edit it in the absence of the editor, Peter Stodhart, and his deputy, Ben Preston.

Meanwhile, Tim Hames, comment writer at the Times, is promoted to comment editor and chief leader writer.

The reshuffle comes as the Times changes its US staff, with Nicholas Wapshott replacing James Bone as north American correspondent.

Mr Bone, who was not on the staff at the paper, will continue to work for the Times from northern America.

A senior insider at the Times said: "Periodically, senior staff at newspapers get shuffled about.

"It's a year or two since we've had any major changes at senior level and general elections are natural punctuation marks."

webTitle: Archer libel witness Coghlan dies in car crash

fields.headline: Archer libel witness Coghlan dies in car crash
fields.trailText: Monica Coghlan, the prostitute at the centre of the Jeffrey Archer libel trial, has been killed in a car crash, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Monica Coghlan, the prostitute at the centre of the Jeffrey Archer libel trial against the Daily Star, has been killed in a car crash.

A 32-year-old man has been arrested after the car driven by Ms Coghlan was hit by a Jaguar, allegedly driven by a fleeing armed robber, in Scammonden, near Huddersfield.

Ms Coghlan was taken by air ambulance to Leeds hospital, but died from her injuries.

Ms Coghlan was at the centre of a libel trial by the novelist and former Tory cabinet member, Lord Archer, after it was claimed that he had had sex with her.

Mr Archer won £500,000 in damages from the newspaper in 1987. But the case was reopened in 1999 after a former friend of Lord Archer came forward to claim that the peer had asked him to lie under oath during the trial.

Lord Archer resigned from the Conservative party and stepped down as a candidate for the mayor of London.

During the trial, Ms Coghlan claimed that an associate of Lord Archer had met her at a London railway station with £2,000 in cash.

Lord Archer claimed the money had been paid to help Ms Cochlan escape reporters.

Lord Archer has been charged with perjury and perverting the course of justice. His trial is due to start next month.

webTitle: Shell adds fuel to US bid

fields.headline: Shell adds fuel to US bid
fields.trailText: Royal Dutch-Shell yesterday showed its determination not to miss out on a second hostile bid by raising its cash offer for Barrett Resources in the US from $1.8bn (£1.2bn) to $2bn.
fields.body:
Royal Dutch-Shell yesterday showed its determination not to miss out on a second hostile bid by raising its cash offer for Barrett Resources in the US from $1.8bn (£1.2bn) to $2bn.

The move follows the rejection of Shell's bid for Woodside Resources in Australia and a statement from Barrett that it had increased its estimate of proven gas reserves by more than 50%.

The Canberra government ruled out the Woodside takeover on the grounds it was against the national interest. Shell retaliated yesterday by saying it might develop its Gorgon gas field separately and not in tandem with Woodside's prized North West Shelf scheme. Despite indicating previously that the offer of $55 per share for Barrett was final, the Anglo-Dutch group raised its price to $60.

This was a 36% premium over Barrett's trading levels immediately before it first expressed interest in March.

Shell, which is primarily interested in Barrett's extensive gas reserves in the Rocky Mountains, has also extended the offer date to May 9.

Barrett in the past rejected all proposals from Shell and had called on third parties to place rival offers by early May. In a letter to Barrett chief executive Peter Dea, the boss of Shell in the US, Walter van de Vijver, urged acceptance of the latest offer and regretted Barratt board's refusal to meet for talks. He said: "In the interests of maximising Barrett shareholder value we continue to urge you not to enter into a merger agreement that includes break-up fees for any bidder."

But Barrett has made things tougher for Shell by winning regulatory agreement for intensifying drilling in Colorado. This led to a rise in the Denver-based company's share price to a 52-week high of $62.90.

The improved Shell offer is not surprising given a consensus on Wall Street that it would not win control of its small but successful US target without something more.

The stakes have been raised by Shell's loss of face in failing to win the fight for Woodside. Shell shares closed in London at 585p, up 11p.

webTitle: Ex-prostitute in Archer trial killed in crash

fields.headline: Ex-prostitute in Archer trial killed in crash
fields.trailText: Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Lord Archer libel trial, died today after a car crash.
fields.body:
Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Lord Archer libel trial, died today after a car crash.

Coghlan, 50, was driving a blue Ford Fiesta car which was struck by a Jaguar car, allegedly driven by a fleeing armed robber, in Scammonden, near Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, yesterday afternoon.

She was taken by air ambulance to the Leeds General Infirmary but died from her injuries today.

A 32-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the incident, West Yorkshire police said.

Police said the accident followed an earlier incident in which a man brandishing what appeared to be a handgun raided a chemists in nearby Birkby.

He ran out of the shop carrying medical supplies and then allegedly threatened the driver of a white taxi parked outside.

The man climbed into the cab and drove off alone but was then in collision with a Land Rover on New Hey Road, police said.

Following the collision, he forced his way into a Jaguar car, which crashed into the Ford Fiesta a short time later.

A West Yorkshire Police spokesman said a 32-year-old man had been arrested and was being detained in the Huddersfield Royal Infirmary, where he was being treated for serious injuries.

Coghlan's nephew Kevin, 20, said the family was devastated by the death.

"We just can't believe what has happened. Everyone is really upset. I don't know how my cousin [Coghlan's son Robin] is coping with it because I have not seen him."

Kevin's father William, Coghlan's brother, travelled to the hospital in Leeds from his Manchester home as soon as he heard the news.

"He just rushed out," said Kevin. "It was such a shock. He didn't even remember to take his mobile phone with him."

fields.headline: Nelson Mandela
fields.standfirst: The Freedom Day concert in London this weekend will be visited by Nelson Mandela. Read our online guide to South Africa's first black president
fields.trailText: The Freedom Day concert in London this weekend will be visited by Nelson Mandela. Read our online guide to South Africa's first black president.
fields.body:
1. Nelson Mandela, the first black president of South Africa, is visiting Britain this weekend for a Freedom Day concert in Trafalgar Square.

2. He spent 28 years in jail. After his 1990 release, he worked with the then president, FW de Klerk, to end apartheid.

3. Both men were awarded the Nobel peace prize in 1993 for the peaceful transition. Mandela then won the presidency in 1994, the culmination of his life's work.

4. Born in 1918, the son of chief Henry Mandela of the Xhosa-speaking Tembu people, he renounced his inheritance to train as a lawyer.

5. He moved to Johannesburg, took up boxing and, while studying, joined the African National Congress in 1942.

6. Mandela was influenced by Gandhi - also a South African lawyer - and, as he explains in this article, tried to follow a non-violent stategy.

7. But after the 1960 Sharpeville massacre and the banning of the ANC soon after, Mandela set up Unkhonto we Sizwe, the party's military wing.

8. He was jailed in 1962. He made his last address at the infamous Rivonia trial (which you can listen to here) and was then sentenced to life imprisonment, spent mostly at Robben Island.

9. In prison (filmed here), Mandela became a focus for the international anti-apartheid campaign, though his image and words were banned at home.

10. He began his struggle again, this time trying to humanise the warders. Now retired, he welcomes visiting celebrities to South Africa and works for his children's fund.

webTitle: George Bush's favours to big business

fields.headline: All the president's businessmen
fields.standfirst:
The Republican election campaign was the most expensive in history and required big donations from big business. Since moving into the White House, George Bush has had only one concern - returning the favours. Julian Borger on how corporate America bought itself a president

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Republican election campaign was the most expensive in history and required big donations from big business. Since moving into the White House, George Bush has had only one concern - returning the favours. Julian Borger on how corporate America bought itself a president.
fields.body:
Buried in the Bush administration's first budget was a routine-looking salaries estimate for the justice department. But one particular group of government lawyers saw it immediately for what it was - a signpost to a new era. The lawyers were a specialised team, put together in the Clinton years to take on the big tobacco companies for lying about the safety of their product for five decades. They had worked out that the sprawling, groundbreaking case would cost about $57m (£41m). They were allocated less than $2m.

In desperation, the lawyers leaked a memo earlier this week, in which they pointed out that the budget would kill their prosecution. In response, the attorney general, John Ashcroft, counter-leaked his plans to replace the litigation team on the grounds that it had done a shoddy job. The message could not be clearer if it was a neon sign on the White House roof: the war on Big Tobacco is over.

The list of defendants who now appear to have escaped federal prosecution is also a list of big donors to the George Bush election campaign. At the top is Philip Morris, which gave $2.8m to the new president's war chest, his inauguration and his party. Big Tobacco as a whole gave $7m to Bush and the Republicans, 83% of the industry's total election spending. If the federal lawsuit against them is allowed to die, which now seems almost certain, the cigarette companies will have saved themselves up to $100bn in damages and compensation - an impressive rate of return by any standards. Philip Morris would argue, of course, that there is no direct connection between its donation and the apparent demise of the government lawsuit - and that its support for the president is entirely down to his policies.

In Washington, this is not some isolated, government-rocking case of support for corporate interests. In his first 100 days in office (the milestone passes on Sunday) Bush has made this straightforward form of corporate payback the defining trait of his administration. This simple fact has been obscured by the snickering over his frequent and clunky gaffes.

For Bush, the first US president with an MBA, the election was a straightforward business proposition in which American corporations acted as venture capitalists. They were invited to take a moderate risk and put the bulk of their political funds behind the Republican dauphin in the most expensive campaign in history. The returns, in the form of abandoned lawsuits, relaxed federal regulations and the scrapping of at least one major international treaty, are heavily loaded with short-term profit. Whatever the economic climate in the world outside, for big business it is truly springtime in Washington.

Naturally, the Democrats have lined up to declare that they are shocked to discover that business wields such influence in politics. The corporate world did not do too badly in the Clinton years, but it was one of many voices echoing around the Oval Office. In the Bush administration, business is the only voice.

Thus, whereas Clinton devoted much of the energy of his first 100 days to a messy fight over gays in the military, the Bush administration has briskly run through a veritable corporate shopping list of swift anti-regulatory measures.

In his first few days, Bush scrapped a raft of work-safety measures, which had been negotiated between the federal government and the unions for much of the past decade, in an attempt to address the new work injuries of the computer age, such as repetitive strain injury, affecting an estimated 1.8m employees.

The scrapping of the new rules was a triumph for the US Chamber of Commerce and a crushing defeat for the AFL-CIO union federation, which had of course overwhelmingly backed Al Gore and the Democrats. At the same time, Bush lifted regulations on federally funded works which gave preference to contractors who used union labour.

Next on the list was a bankruptcy bill, long demanded by the banks and credit card companies (who sponsored Bush and his party to the tune of over $25m). Its effect will be to strip Americans who have declared themselves bankrupt of some of the legal protection they have from their financial creditors.

The bill's proponents portrayed the targets of the bill as scam artists and irresponsible spendthrifts, but subsequent press reports and surveys suggested that the majority of the victims will be poor families who have lost jobs and fallen foul of the rapacious US health system. Clinton had vetoed a similar bill on the grounds that the poor should be allowed to pay their rent and hospital bills before their credit card charges.

The impact of the Bush era has fallen heaviest, however, on the environment, where the legal constraints on business had been the most expensive. In short order after his inauguration, Bush lifted rules which would have made mining companies (who donated $2.6m to his campaign) pay for the clean-up costs if they contaminated the public water supply, and then scrapped safety limits on arsenic levels in drinking water imposed by the outgoing Clinton White House.

Meanwhile, another Clinton-era regulation aimed at protecting 60m acres of national forests from logging and road building is also about to be scuttled, according to justice department sources quoted in yesterday's Washington Post. The ban had been one of the last acts of the outgoing administration, but it had been a consequence of more than a year of open hearings held by the Forest Service in which the views of 1.6m members of the public had been taken into account. For its part, the timber industry contributed $3.2m to the Bush campaign in the 2000 elections. The money, it seems, is talking louder.

The most important environmental victories for US industry came in March, when the new president abandoned a campaign pledge to impose legal limits on carbon dioxide emissions. The obvious consequence of that decision arrived a few days later, when the administration let it be known that it considered the Kyoto protocol on global warming dead and buried, summarily ending five years of transatlantic efforts to agree on how the accord should be implemented.

The head of the environmental protection agency, Christine Todd Whitman, has promised that the US is ready to go back to the negotiating table and start again from scratch. But meanwhile, the cost of cutting emissions has been removed for the foreseeable future from the corporate balance sheets of the coal, electricity, oil and gas industries, all of them major Bush contributors. The oil sector alone put over $25m into Republican coffers for last year's election, compared to the $7m backing it provided to Democratic candidates.

It is hardly surprising that the mood on K Street, the home of Washington's industrial lobbyists, is triumphant these days. "We have come out of the cave, blinking in the sunlight, saying to one another, 'My God, now we can actually get something done,' " Richard Hohlt, a banking lobbyist, recently told the Wall Street Journal.

Paradoxically, the only major setback the industrial lobby has suffered under Bush so far has been the old-fashioned cold war exchange of sabre-rattling with China. It has been redolent of an older, more ideological strain of Republicanism, but it cuts against the interests of corporate leaders, who view China as a vast opportunity for expansion. Consequently, there were few protests from the usual cold warriors in the party ranks when Washington sent a delicately worded apology to Beijing over this month's spy plane standoff. On every other front, the K Street army has emerged from its trenches to find that there is hardly even token resistance to its relentless advance.

In his former role as Clinton's labour secretary, Robert Reich had frequently complained that corporate America seemed to gain the upper hand more often than not in the corridors of power. Now, he says, there is not even a fight. "There's no longer any countervailing power in Washington. Business is in complete control of the machinery of government," he wrote in the New York Times. "It's payback time, and every industry and trade association is busily cashing in."

The transaction has not been so much a purchase as a corporate merger. The distinction between business and government has simply been blurred to near invisibility. The White House has made much of the fact that the new MBA-equipped president is running the administration along sleek corporate lines. Key officials, meanwhile, are being recruited straight from the nation's boardrooms.

The treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, came from the giant aluminium manufacturer Alcoa. Dick Cheney was headhunted from the oil services company Haliburton. Karl Rove, Bush's chief political strategist, performed the same function for Philip Morris from 1991 to 1996. The new "regulations czar", John Graham, charged with overseeing the further dismantling of government controls on industry, has arrived from John Hopkins University, where he once oversaw a study concluding that there were no health risks from secondhand cigarette smoke. At the same time, according to the watchdog group Public Citizen, Graham was soliciting $25,000 in funding from Philip Morris.

The list of business alunmi is endless. Mitchell Daniels, the head of the White House office of management and budget, is a former vice-president of the pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly. He represents an industry which contributed $18m to the Bush electoral effort and now expects the administration to distance itself from its predecessor's plans to impose price caps on prescription medicine.

The only risk to the mega-corporations' control over Washington appears to come from within - the danger of overreaching and provoking an electoral backlash against their greed and environmental damage. "At some point - perhaps as soon as the 2002 midterm elections, surely no later than the next presidential election - the public will be aghast at what is happening," Reich argues. "The backlash against business may be thunderous."

There are already signs that Bush and his advisors realise the danger, and there have been attempts to soften the president's image, particularly on the environment. He has signalled his readiness to sign a treaty on curbing the industrial release of particularly noxious chemicals and may think again on arsenic limits in drinking water. After all, Bush will need people's votes as well as corporate money if he is to win re-election in 2004. But all the signs from the first 100 days suggest that the moderating non-corporate influences on the administration are likely to be kept to a minimum. This is as close as it is possible to get in a democracy to a government of business, by business and for business.

fields.bodyText: Buried in the Bush administration's first budget was a routine-looking salaries estimate for the justice department. But one particular group of government lawyers saw it immediately for what it was - a signpost to a new era. The lawyers were a specialised team, put together in the Clinton years to take on the big tobacco companies for lying about the safety of their product for five decades. They had worked out that the sprawling, groundbreaking case would cost about $57m (£41m). They were allocated less than $2m. In desperation, the lawyers leaked a memo earlier this week, in which they pointed out that the budget would kill their prosecution. In response, the attorney general, John Ashcroft, counter-leaked his plans to replace the litigation team on the grounds that it had done a shoddy job. The message could not be clearer if it was a neon sign on the White House roof: the war on Big Tobacco is over. The list of defendants who now appear to have escaped federal prosecution is also a list of big donors to the George Bush election campaign. At the top is Philip Morris, which gave $2.8m to the new president's war chest, his inauguration and his party. Big Tobacco as a whole gave $7m to Bush and the Republicans, 83% of the industry's total election spending. If the federal lawsuit against them is allowed to die, which now seems almost certain, the cigarette companies will have saved themselves up to $100bn in damages and compensation - an impressive rate of return by any standards. Philip Morris would argue, of course, that there is no direct connection between its donation and the apparent demise of the government lawsuit - and that its support for the president is entirely down to his policies. In Washington, this is not some isolated, government-rocking case of support for corporate interests. In his first 100 days in office (the milestone passes on Sunday) Bush has made this straightforward form of corporate payback the defining trait of his administration. This simple fact has been obscured by the snickering over his frequent and clunky gaffes. For Bush, the first US president with an MBA, the election was a straightforward business proposition in which American corporations acted as venture capitalists. They were invited to take a moderate risk and put the bulk of their political funds behind the Republican dauphin in the most expensive campaign in history. The returns, in the form of abandoned lawsuits, relaxed federal regulations and the scrapping of at least one major international treaty, are heavily loaded with short-term profit. Whatever the economic climate in the world outside, for big business it is truly springtime in Washington. Naturally, the Democrats have lined up to declare that they are shocked to discover that business wields such influence in politics. The corporate world did not do too badly in the Clinton years, but it was one of many voices echoing around the Oval Office. In the Bush administration, business is the only voice. webTitle: Independent on Sunday names new editor

fields.headline: Independent on Sunday names new editor
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The Independent on Sunday will this afternoon name Tristan Davies its new editor to replace Janet Street-Porter. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Independent on Sunday will this afternoon name Tristan Davies as its new editor to replace Janet Street-Porter.

Mr Davies, currently executive editor (features) on the Independent, had been widely tipped to replace Ms Street-Porter, who resigned from the paper three weeks ago.

Simon Kelner, the editor-in-chief of the Independent and the Independent on Sunday, will officially confirm the appointment this afternoon.

Mr Kelner said: "I have worked closely with Tristan for a number of years and am absolutely convinced he has the skills, experience and vision to build on the progress made on our Sunday paper over recent years."

Mr Davies will start his job on June 11.

fields.headline: ITV unveils new daytime soap
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: ITV has decided on Night and Day as the name for its new daytime soap launching later this year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV has finally decided on a name for the new soap that will join the resurrected Crossroads in its daytime line-up later this year - Night and Day.

The show, which had the working title Trafalgar Square, is due to go into production next month on location in Greenwich, south London.

Night and Day revolves around the lives of six very different families.

"We're making a soap that's modern, romantic and aspirational - a programme from a different perspective and in some ways a more realistic perspective," said Peter Cregeen, the series executive producer.

"It's modern, sexy and fun with a very dark undercurrent."

Night and Day has been created by Caleb Ranson, whose credits include ITV peaktime dramas Forgotten and Daylight Robbery.

The show is being made by Granada Media subsidiary United Productions.

The producer will be Chris Le Grys, with United and LWT drama controller Michele Buck and head Damien Timmer executive producing.

webTitle: Now Porky the pig faces the slaughtermen

fields.headline: Now Porky the pig faces the slaughtermen
fields.standfirst:
Phoenix the calf may have been saved, but now attention has focused on a slightly less photogenic case
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: After Phoenix, the calf which became a national icon after escaping the clutches of the slaughtermen,  residents of a Scottish village are rallying to save Porky, a pot-bellied pet pig.
fields.body:
After Phoenix, the calf which became a national icon after escaping the clutches of the slaughtermen, residents of a Scottish village are rallying to save Porky, a pot-bellied pet pig.

Residents of Ruthwell Station in Dumfries and Galloway have rallied round owners George and Sadie Stone in their bid to prevent the slaughter of 10-year-old Porky.

The pet is due to be killed under the pre-emptive cull policy because the family bungalow falls within 3km of an infected farm. Mr and Mrs Stone, who are devastated at the prospect of losing their pet, appealed on the grounds that Porky lives indoors and has had no contact with farm animals. The animal has been checked by a vet and has no signs of foot-and-mouth disease, according to their daughter Georgie Cartner, 39, who bought the pet for her father 10 years ago.

On Wednesday, officials from the Scottish Executive's Rural Affairs Department arrived at the Stones' home on Wednesday but were refused entry by the family. Mrs Cartner, who lives next door to her parents, said: "A vet came and someone else from the Scottish Executive but we didn't let them in. They said they had the power of forcible entry but left after three hours. By that time about 20 people from the village had gathered at the gate. It's a small village and people are being very supportive."

She said her 78-year-old father has had the pet since Porky was just weeks old and has kept him inside the house since he suffered pneumonia as a piglet. She said: "He wanted a pet pig... everyone is very fond of Porky. We don't see why he should be killed, he's kept in the kitchen because he had pneumonia as a baby and the farm which is infected is two miles away and it was infected seven weeks ago."

She said the family had contacted a solicitor and planned to mount a legal challenge to stop Porky being killed.

A spokesman for the Scottish Executive said he was unable to go into detail about the Stones' case because of the possible legal action. However he confirmed that their home falls within the 3km cull zone of "susceptible animals" such as sheep, pigs and goats.

Porky is considerably less photogenic than Phoenix and the government's new policy applies only to cattle, not pigs or sheep, which are more susceptible to foot-and-mouth.

webTitle: TBWA resignations a blow to Labour

fields.headline: TBWA resignations a blow to Labour
fields.trailText: 11am: The chief executive and managing director of TBWA, Labour's advertising agency, have resigned, reports Claire Cozens.<BR Special report: election and the media
fields.body:
Labour's advertising agency has been plunged into chaos after its chief executive and managing director quit unexpectedly just weeks before the planned general election.

Simon Clemmow and Johnny Hornby, the chief executive and managing director of TBWA/London, resigned this week to set up their own agency.

It is thought they will stay on at TBWA until after the expected general election on June 7. But their departure will be a severe blow to the the agency.

While most of the media coverage of Labour's advertising agency has focused on its creative director, Trevor Beattie, Mr Hornby has played an equally important role, deciding on the strategy behind the creative work.

Mr Hornby's connections were widely credited with helping TBWA to win the account. The brother of Labour-supporting novelist Nick Hornby, he is also a close friend of Peter Mandelson.

fields.headline: GGMedia launches advertising campaign
fields.trailText: 12pm: GGMedia, the horseracing media rights company, has launched an advertising campaign to promote its five-year proposal, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
GG Media, the rival to the Go Racing consortium negotiating a horseracing media rights deal, has launched an advertising campaign to promote its offer.

Adverts in today's Daily Telegraph and Racing Post promote GG Media's five-year, £67m offer to 26 of the smaller racecourses, which includes a £100,000 guaranteed payment within seven days of signing up to its deal.

Seven of the UK's 59 racecourses - Exeter, Fakenham, Stratford, Taunton, Towcester, Leicester and Perth - have already signed up with GG Media and are due to receive their first payments next week.

GG Media initially set a deadline of last Friday for signing up to its offer, but has now extended this until midnight on May 9.

The outfit is backed by SIS, which operates a TV channel distributed to betting shops and whose shareholders include William Hill and Ladbrokes.

Go Racing, which is backed by Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure, was due to have written to the courses with which it is still negotiating exclusively by today with a revised contract for its £320m, 10-year deal.

The consortium has set a May 11 deadline for signing up to its revised offer.

The former GMTV managing director, Christopher Stoddar,t is due to join Go Racing as chief executive on May 2.

GG Media has been able to lure some of the smaller tracks away from Go Racing by promising them more money and payment in advance.

Adverts in today's Daily Telegraph and Racing Post promote GG Media's five-year, £67m offer to 26 of the smaller racecourses, which includes a £100,000 guaranteed payment within seven days of signing up to its deal. Seven of the UK's 59 racecourses - Exeter, Fakenham, Stratford, Taunton, Towcester, Leicester and Perth - have already signed up with GG Media and are due to receive their first payments next week. GG Media initially set a deadline of last Friday for signing up to its offer, but has now extended this until midnight on May 9. The outfit is backed by SIS, which operates a TV channel distributed to betting shops and whose shareholders include William Hill and Ladbrokes. Go Racing, which is backed by Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure, was due to have written to the courses with which it is still negotiating exclusively by today with a revised contract for its £320m, 10-year deal. The consortium has set a May 11 deadline for signing up to its revised offer. The former GMTV managing director, Christopher Stoddar,t is due to join Go Racing as chief executive on May 2. GG Media has been able to lure some of the smaller tracks away from Go Racing by promising them more money and payment in advance. fields.headline: Keane attacks team-mates again
fields.trailText: Roy Keane has made yet another attack on his Manchester United team-mates, calling them "complacent" and telling Sir Alex Ferguson that it's time to "move some of them on".
fields.body:
Roy Keane has made yet another attack on his Manchester United team-mates, calling them "complacent" and telling Sir Alex Ferguson that it's time to "move some of them on".

"I have seen United players getting complacent, thinking they've done it all and getting carried away by a bit of success," Keane told Four Four Two magazine.

"All you have to do is drop your standards by five or 10 per cent and it's obvious, especially in Europe. You can carry maybe one player, but no more than that. We really have to start dominating Europe as well as the Premiership."

Keane said it was up Ferguson to stem the decline. "You can see it in training when players just go through the motions. It's up to the manager to spot it ... it is up to the manager to know when to move people on, and he is strong enough to know when to do it."

"Maybe I'll help him, but ultimately the only person who can sort it out is the player himself," he added. "Real desire has to come from within."

United's success over the last decade has often been put down to the team spirit at the club. However, Keane explodes the myth that everything is sweetness and light in the Old Trafford dressing room.

"If you go to any office, not everyone is going to like each other. It is the same at United. Not everyone is pals," said the Republic of Ireland midfielder.

"You don't have to be best mates, you just have to share the same aim of winning trophies. I have made no special effort to sort it out. Look, I'm not a counsellor or anything. I'm just an ordinary human being, a footballer.

"I have had clashes with others, so I'm not one to talk," he added. "Everyone has their own lives. Anyway, I don't think I've ever given any of them my phone number."

United manager Ferguson has also always distanced himself from his players socially in order to maintain his status. And while accepting that Steve McClaren would be a popular choice to take over when Sir Alex retires at the end of next season, Keane hints that another figure-head may be needed.

He said: "Steve McClaren is a very good coach, and I know he's interested. I don't think the players would have a problem with that. They could well support it.

"However, I don't think the players should be consulted. That is up to the United board.

"The players have enough on their hands doing their own job and we don't do that properly sometimes, so I wouldn't trust us to pick a manager.

"If it were a foreign coach it would have to be a really top coach, but I would have no problems with a foreign manager. I would be open-minded."

fields.headline: Guardian writer lands multicultural award
fields.standfirst: Winners in full
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Guardian writer Gary Younge was named best print journalist at the BT ethnic multicultural media awards (Emmas), writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Guardian writer Gary Younge was named best print journalist at the BT ethnic multicultural media awards (Emmas) last night.

The awards are voted for by the public and are designed to celebrate multiculturalism in media.

Author and comedian Meera Syal was named media personality of the year and Goodness Gracious Me, which she co-wrote, won best TV entertainment production.

Kiss FM was voted best radio station and Asian Times won the best publication award.

The director of Cry Freedom, Lord Richard Attenborough, received a special lifetime achievement award in recognition of his human rights and anti-racism campaigning.

webTitle: Byers shelves plan to sue Mail

fields.headline: Byers shelves plan to sue Mail
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The trade and industry secretary has shelved plans to sue the Mail over its allegation he buried findings of a report, writes Patrick Wintour.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday shelved plans to sue the Daily Mail over its allegation that he buried findings of a critical DTI inspectors' report on the conduct of companies run by the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson.

Mr Byers is instead to refer the paper's coverage to the press complaints commission, the press industry's self regulatory body. It was suggested that he regarded the referral as the most cost effective way of seeking redress.

Government sources insisted that Mr Byers would retain his option to sue the paper if he was not satisfied by the PCC's ruling, but in practice he is unlikely to take the case further.

His decision raised questions as to why he did not refer the original story to the PCC in the first place.

There had been reports that the No 10 press secretary, Alastair Campbell, urged Mr Byers to take the Daily Mail to court in a pre-election shot across the bows of the rightwing press.

Since his announcement of an intention to sue, the Daily Mail and the author Tom Bower have refused to back down on the accusation, let alone offer an apology.

The permanent secretary at the DTI had ruled that any legal action by Mr Byers would be underwritten by the government on the basis that he had allegedly been defamed in his role as a government minister.

Government sources insisted that Mr Byers's latest decision had been his own and not forced on him by civil servants convinced that any libel action would be worthwhile.

The controversy developed after the Daily Mail alleged that Mr Byers had buried aspects of the DTI inspectors' report on Mr Robinson's companies.

Mr Byers insisted that the inquiry, set up the month after Mr Byers took over at the DTI from Peter Mandelson, was conducted at every stage by civil servants without ministerial involvement.

fields.headline: Hoon visits cull burial site
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, was today visiting a mass burial site in one of the areas worst affected by the foot and mouth outbreak, as seven people waited to learn if they had contracted the disease.
fields.body:
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, was today visiting a mass burial site in one of the areas worst affected by the foot and mouth outbreak, as seven people waited to learn if they had contracted the disease.

Mr Hoon's visit to Devon comes after a junior health minister revealed that the government had known for several weeks of potential public health risks from burning animal carcasses before an assessment was published on the Department of Health's website on Wednesday.

Lord Hunt of Kings Heath told peers last night that medical consultants had been notified by the Public Health Laboratory Service as long ago as March 1.

Yesterday, four more people were beginning tests for foot and mouth disease after visiting their doctors with health fears. Three others have already been tested for the disease, which is very rare in humans.

Mr Hoon was today joining Major General Arthur Denaro, the army commander in charge of the outbreak in the south west, on a visit to the site in Ashmoor in Devon where up to 400,000 animals will be buried.

The defence secretary was expected to underline that government policy could be "refined" in line with scientific advice only because of the decline in the number of foot and mouth cases.

Yesterday Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, defended his decision to "refine" the government's cull policy amid charges that the change was triggered by the plight of Phoenix the calf.

He announced that vets would be allowed to decide whether cattle on farms neighbouring infected sites should face slaughter or be spared because of their low risk of infection.

There have been just six new cases in Devon in the last week compared with a high of 28 in the week ending 16 April.

The average number of daily cases has fallen to 16 against a high of 43 just three weeks ago, while the total number of farms lifted out of infected area status is 15,000.

webTitle: Monks protest at Pope as Greece goes on strike

fields.headline: Monks protest at Pope as Greece goes on strike
fields.trailText: Monks at the all-male community of Mount Athos, one of the most revered places in Orthodoxy, will stage an all-night vigil tonight to pray against the Pope's historic visit to Greece next Friday.
fields.body:
Monks at the all-male community of Mount Athos, one of the most revered places in Orthodoxy, will stage an all-night vigil tonight to pray against the Pope's historic visit to Greece next Friday.

Their protest comes amid mounting anger by rank-and-file clergy at the church leadership's decision to lift long-held objections to a papal visit.

Greece is currently engulfed in a tide of strikes against the Socialist government's social security reforms.

Hundreds of thousands of workers took to the streets across the country yesterday, shutting down schools and offices, halting public transport and closing down the media. Even priests heeded the strike call.

If the papal visit goes ahead, religious conservatives have predicted widespread protests, and even violence.

The 80-year-old John Paul II will pay a 24-hour visit to Greece next Friday to retrace the footsteps of St Paul the Apostle, making him the first pope to visit the country since the "great schism" of 1054 which split Christianity into eastern and western branches.

The Pope will make a pilgrimage to the Areopagus, the hill to the west of the Acropolis where St Paul preached the Sermon of the Unknown God.

He will also celebrate mass at the Olympic indoor sports stadium. The tour then takes him to Syria and Malta.

Moderates within the Greek Orthodox church hope the trip will help heal nearly 1,000 years of deep distrust between the churches. Many Orthodox faithful blame the Vatican for what they perceive to be centuries of misdeeds against them - from the sacking of Constantinople by crusaders in 1204 to the bombing of Orthodox Serbia in 1999.

"We expect the Pope to make a humble gesture of love and apology," said Haris Konidaris, the spokesman for Archbishop Christodoulos, the head of the Greek church. "Then the fanatics here will be silenced."

The archbishop has repeatedly called for calm from Greece's ultra-Orthodox groups, including the influential Old Calendarists, who boast some 800,000 followers.

"The faithful will take to the streets; blood could be shed," warnedone black-robed monk.

"Out with the two-horned beast, the Pope of Rome 666!" read a banner. "No to the leader of heresy," read another.

Police have tightened security at Catholic churches across Greece. But fears for the Pope's safety have been raised since the weekend, too, when a home-made bomb exploded outside the offices of the Ecumenical Patriarchate in Athens. No one was hurt in the afternoon blast, which was claimed by anarchists.

Last week, Bartholomew I, head of the Eastern Orthodox church whose seat is in Istanbul, had welcomed the papal trip and he accused opponents of displaying "ecclesiastical provincialism".

Last week, Bartholomew I, head of the Eastern Orthodox church whose seat is in Istanbul, had welcomed the papal trip and he accused opponents of displaying "ecclesiastical provincialism".

fields.headline: M&S chair waives his bonus
fields.standfirst: More business news
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's chairman and chief executive, Luc Vandevelde, has waived his controversial £816,000 bonus that he had been awarded for this year, it emerged today.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's chairman and chief executive, Luc Vandevelde, has waived his controversial £816,000 bonus that he had been awarded for this year, it emerged today.

However, next year, he could still receive more than £1m in accumulated bonus payments.

A meeting of the M&S remuneration committee, headed by former spy boss Dame Stella Rimmington, accepted the decision earlier this week, and a company spokeswoman said the move was a "very significant gesture".

However, the committee has decided to increase Mr Vandevelde's bonus by £352,000 next year if he meets performance targets that have yet to be set. He is also set to receive £352,000 in shares next May.

A company spokeswoman explained that this could be on top of his normal bonus, which is worked out every year. This could potentially push his bonus payment for next year to over £1m.

Mr Vandevelde, who receives an annual salary of £650,000, had come under pressure to turn down this year's bonus payment amid plunging sales at the high street chain.

Earlier this week, there had been rumours of a damaging rift between the executives and non-executives on the board, and the company insisted that a decision on the bonus issue had not been taken by the remuneration committee.

A spokeswoman for M&S said that Mr Vandevelde had been thinking about making the decision "for some time" and had not simply reacted to recent negative press coverage.

She added he had asked for the remuneration committee meeting to be brought forward so the decision could be rubber-stamped as quickly as possible.

Mr Vandevelde was due to be paid an initial bonus of £704,000 this year, half in cash and half in shares. He would have received a further £112,000 if he kept the shares for five years.

Dame Stella said that Mr Vandevelde had met all the performance and strategical targets set by the retailer during the past year. She added that he had no obligation to give up the bonus and had "demonstrated real leadership" in doing so.

Mr Vandevelde has also reduced his notice period entitlement from twelve to nine months, which M&S said underlined his confidence in the future prospects of the company.

Dame Stella said that the committee was "more convinced than ever" that M&S had chosen the right man for the job of reviving its fortunes.

webTitle: 300,000 tourism jobs may be hit by crisis

fields.headline: 300,000 tourism jobs may be hit by crisis
fields.standfirst:
• Tourism chief issues warning
• One in four workers 'face redundancy'
• Long-term damage to industry

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
• Tourism chief issues warning
• One in four workers 'face redundancy'
• Long-term damage to industry
fields.body:
Up to 300,000 tourism jobs could be affected by the foot and mouth crisis, the chairman of the British Tourist Authority (BTA) warned today.

Between a fifth and a quarter of all jobs in the sector could be lost in some areas, with up to £5bn worth of trade sacrificed to the disease, David Quarmby said.

"We could be losing up to £2.5bn worth of inbound tourism to Britain this year, and on the domestic market there could be at least another £2bn to £3bn of lost tourism," he said. "You could be looking at £5bn worth that is not going into tourism and the rural economy.

"On a very simple calculation, that could be worth up to 300,000 jobs affected by the crisis in tourism. It is an industry that employs nearly 2m people, a lot of them in part-time jobs, and we are looking at up to 20% loss, 25% in some areas, perhaps even more."

The BTA chairman also warned it could take several years to rebuild tourists' confidence in Britain as a destination.

"Although the Gulf war was nowhere near western Europe, it took three or four years for us to rebuild Americans' confidence in Britain as a destination," he said. "Our fear is that without adequate activity it could take at least as long to rebuild confidence in foot and mouth."

The interview is published at www.ePolitix.com.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 67: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 67: Porky the pig is the new Phoenix and praise is levied on the Mirror for pressing Downing Street into saving the calf.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Times
The Times is the only paper to find a new animal on death row to test the government's will. Porky, the 10-year-old pot bellied pig from Dumfriesshire, is pictured next to the caption: "I may not be so cute, Tony, but what about me?" Pages 10 and 11 are jam-packed with foot and mouth stories such as why the cull policy is not a relaxation but a refinement and how the Mirror got Downing Street to change its mind.

Daily Mail
On pages 10 and 11, the Mail calls for humans to be put in quarantine. It also explains how a "sitcom storyline" saved Phoenix, omitting to mention the Mirror's influence.

The Mirror
Revelling in the glory of saving Phoenix, the paper prints a picture of the calf licking the front cover of yesterday's paper "to say thanks for being alive". Reporter Geoffrey Lakeman gets cosy with the bovine superstar and gets a sloppy kiss on his cheek. No doubt he is the envy of calf-lovers across the land.

The Sun
The Sun devotes half its front page to Tony Blair and Phoenix. "Vote Labour or the calf gets it", says the Sun, superimposing a picture of a target over the calf's head. The human victim, Paul Stamper, reveals he's already being treated like a "leper". Richard Littlejohn tells it like it is: "Aaahh, Tonee's saved the ickle moo-cow. Luvlee. Tonee reely cares, he does."

fields.headline: Reid denies Phillips transfer rumours
fields.trailText: Sunderland manager Peter Reid has denied that striker Kevin Phillips has submitted a transfer request.
fields.body:
Sunderland manager Peter Reid has denied that striker Kevin Phillips has submitted a transfer request.

Phillips arrived at the club's Whitburn training ground this morning and went straight to see his manager amid reports that he was ready to quit Wearside.

But after a short conversation, Reid angrily rubbished the claims.

"I've had the boy in and it's rubbish," he said. "If the boy had a problem, I would be the first to know. When Kevin arrived at the training ground this morning, he immediately came to see me after hearing the story.

"Kevin told me that we have such a good relationship that I would never hear anything about him first from a national newspaper.

"Kevin rubbished the story and told me he is very happy at the club."

The reports come at a time when Phillips is experiencing perhaps the most barren spell of his time at Sunderland.

He has scored just once in his last 12 games to leave his tally for the season at 15, just half the figure he plundered last year and five short of his annual target of 20.

Significantly, the Wearsiders have won only one of their last 12 to leave their hopes of European qualification hanging by the slightest of threads.

Phillips is understandably frustrated by his lack of goals, and was booed by a section of the Stadium of Light crowd during the 3-2 defeat by Tottenham Hotspur on April 14 when, late in the game, he allowed his emotions to boil over and hoofed the ball into the top tier of the stand after failing to prevent it from going out of play.

However, he insists that he is happy in the north-east and is confident that his touch will return soon.

Speaking last Friday just days after learning that his wife Julie is expecting the couple's second child, he said: "There's an awful lot of pressure on me because they expect me to score in every game and because I'm not scoring at the moment, people are putting two and two together and thinking 'His head's down, he wants to leave', which is nonsense.

"I've always said there's going to come a time when I'm going to have a spell and things are not going to go right. Unfortunately, it's come at this time and it's how I deal with it."

webTitle: Viduka hints at Madrid or Milan move

fields.headline: Viduka hints at Madrid or Milan move
fields.trailText: Mark Viduka has hinted he could leave Leeds in the summer, after admitting a move to Real Madrid would be a "giant step" in his career and that it would be "very difficult to decide" between the European champions and AC Milan.
fields.body:
Mark Viduka has hinted he could leave Leeds in the summer, after admitting a move to Real Madrid would be a "giant step" in his career and that it would be "very difficult to decide" between the European champions and AC Milan.

Reports in Spain claim the Primera Liga leaders have registered their interest in the 25-year-old Australian international.

When asked how he felt about being linked with the European champions, Viduka told the Spanish newspaper Marca: "It's obviously an honour.

"It's always very nice for a player when a team like Real Madrid are interested in you.

"Also, we shouldn't forget that they are the best team in the world and the most important."

To sign for Real Madrid would be "giant step in my career", Viduka is reported as saying.

"Of course it would. All players want to progress and to go to the best team in the world would be very good for me. We can't forget that it would be a giant step in my career."

He added: "I think it's an incredible team. We played against them in the Champions League and although we didn't play badly you could see that Del Bosque's team were a great outfit.

"I think that all the world knows who Real Madrid are so we don't need to say too much about that."

Viduka is also being trailed by AC Milan according to reports.

"They are truly two very strong sides and both of them are in the best leagues in the world.

"I think it would be very difficult to decide although Juric, who is my best friend and played in Spain, told me very good things about Spain and has said that it is a very competitive league."

Viduka could face the Spanish giants in the Champions League final in Milan on May 23 if Leeds beat Valencia and Real knock out Bayern Munich.

But the powerful Aussie has no preference for who Leeds might play.

"That doesn't matter. I don't think that's important. The best thing for us would be to get to the final and then we shall see."

Viduka has scored 15 league goals and hit the back of the net four times in a lethal Champions League partnership with Alan Smith.

fields.headline: Banana skin: Maff
fields.standfirst: Banana skin and top banana is a new must-read awards section courtesy of MediaGuardian.co.uk. Every week you can nominate your heroes and villains - those men or women who have impressed or distressed you most with their media performance. This week, step forward and collect your coveted banana skin trophy... Ministry of Agriculture Fisheries and Food
fields.body:
Winner: Maff
Otherwise known as: "the Siberia of Whitehall"
Company: the government
Banana skin
Phoenix the cute calf survived a Maff cull and lay beside her dead mother for five days. The story caught the nation's imagination and became a cause celebre for every national newspaper. Maff, however, failed to see the gifthorse it presented. A spokesman cruelly told the Daily Telegraph: "Phoenix has to die." Tony Blair intervened.
Result
Phoenix was spared.
Effect
Maff not only appeared to be in direct conflict with Downing Street but it ended up sounding like the grim reaper in a particularly bloodthirsty mood. But the Phoenix debacle was only the latest in long line of PR disasters for a ministry that is regarded as a backwater by the rest of the civil service. It is said no civil servants worth their salt aspire to work there. Remember BSE, salmonella and E-coli?
Action
Maff has drafted in PR people from other government departments - including the cabinet office and the department of trade and industry - to reinforce its communications operation. Staff numbers have increased from a handful to more than 30.
A Maff source says
"Maff was under the cosh, it needed some support. It needed a much bigger and more joined-up effort.
"We're trying to convey the fact the situation on the ground is improving, even though there are lots of hotspots. There are no easy choices and the government doesn't have all the answers." One slip-up too many?
 Maff may be exterminated once the foot and mouth crisis abates. There have been widespread calls for the ministry to be abolished or at least reformed.

But the Phoenix debacle was only the latest in long line of PR disasters for a ministry that is regarded as a backwater by the rest of the civil service. It is said no civil servants worth their salt aspire to work there. Remember BSE, salmonella and E-coli? Action Maff has drafted in PR people from other government departments - including the cabinet office and the department of trade and industry - to reinforce its communications operation. Staff numbers have increased from a handful to more than 30. A Maff source says "Maff was under the cosh, it needed some support. It needed a much bigger and more joined-up effort. "We're trying to convey the fact the situation on the ground is improving, even though there are lots of hotspots. There are no easy choices and the government doesn't have all the answers." One slip-up too many? Maff may be exterminated once the foot and mouth crisis abates. There have been widespread calls for the ministry to be abolished or at least reformed.  Do you know someone who deserves a banana skin or top banana? webTitle: Farmers plan to cut back their businesses

fields.headline: Farmers plan to cut back their businesses
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: More than a third of the farmers hit by foot and mouth disease plan to scale down their businesses, while some plan to quit altogether, a survey suggested today.
fields.body:
More than a third of the farmers hit by foot and mouth disease plan to scale down their businesses, while some plan to quit altogether, a survey suggested today.

A total of 128 farmers who saw infected livestock slaughtered were questioned about their expectations once the crisis is finally over.

Of these, 6% said that they planned to quit agriculture all together - three times the percentage which leave the industry in a normal year - while 36% said that they only planned to partially restock their farms.

Fewer than half expect their businesses to recover in the near future.

Almost half of those questioned thought they had been adequately compensated by the government for slaughtered livestock, while less than a fifth believed a programme of vaccination should have been introduced.

Industry magazine Farmers Weekly, which carried out the survey, said that its findings provide the first glimpse of farming in the wake of the epidemic.

The National Farmers' Union said that it would have expected even more farmers to claim they were leaving the industry.

Policy director Martin Haworth said: "The compensation they have got is fair, so it is not surprising that some will get out of farming.

"Many farmers we are talking to say this is a unique opportunity for them to re-think their businesses," he added.

"Farmers who previously opted for quantity are telling us they are now going to go for quality. That is not a bad thing."

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, also acknowledged that the foot and mouth outbreak might prompt some livestock farmers to quit the industry.

"I certainly think that the foot and mouth disease outbreak has been the last straw for some farmers," he said.

"The average age in the industry is 58 and, when farmers go through the heartbreaking process of seeing their stock slaughtered out, they get their compensation payment from the government, and they are bound to think - particularly if they are in their late fifties - as to whether they should go through all the business of re-stocking and starting again, or consider retiring.

"Frankly I don't blame them for thinking about that."

Meanwhile, the high-ranking officer who masterminded the army's battle against foot and mouth in Cumbria, was today handing over command as he retired from the forces.

Brigadier Alex Birtwistle said that he was sad to leave his dedicated team, but he felt that the battle against the disease was being won in the county.

Brig Birtwistle postponed his retirement, planned for April 2, after senior officers urged him to continue overseeing the army involvement in the country's first mass burial site, at Great Orton airfield in Cumbria.

webTitle: Leaders of starving Koreans flew in chefs

fields.headline: Leaders of starving Koreans flew in chefs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: North Korea's communist leaders imported two Italian chefs to prepare secret banquets of pizza at the height of the country's famine, it has emerged.
fields.body:
North Korea's communist leaders imported two Italian chefs to prepare secret banquets of pizza at the height of the country's famine, it has emerged.

The chefs were flown into Pyongyang with special ovens to feed its "Respected Supreme Commander", Kim Jong-il, in 1997 while millions starved on a diet of seaweed, cabbage stalks and grass. Ermanno Furlanis and Antonio Macchia were monitored by army generals as they taught selected chefs the art of rolling dough to ensure thin crusts.

"They measured every one of my moves. They even measured the distance between the olives," Mr Furlanis said.

CIA agents allegedly intercepted oven parts at Berlin airport, suspecting they had a military use. "They were very worried. Maybe they thought they were nuclear ovens or something of the sort," he said.

The revelations will appear in the geopolitical journal Heartland, which commissioned Mr Furlanis to shed light on the secretive regime,

In spring 1997, North Korean agents, posing as businessmen, asked Mr Macchia, the head chef at a Trieste hotel restaurant, to find a partner who would be willing to give a pizza training course.

He turned to Mr Furlanis, an independent financial adviser who moonlighted as a pizza chef in the nearby town of Codroipo, north-east Italy. He accepted the invitation, was paid in advance and told to spare no expense in assembling material.

The chefs, travelling with theirwives, had their passports confiscated during their three weeks in military quarters at Pyongyang and a seaside resort. "It was like being in a golden prison. We received full luxury treatment but we couldn't escape," Mr Furlanis said.

A minder, Mr Om, reported to General Pah, who appears to have masterminded the initiative. The insular state had run out of food and people were starving, but the ruling oligarchy wanted to celebrate.

Mr Furlanis explained that no two pizzas were the same, but the hosts were convinced that an ideal recipe could be discovered by analysing his technique. "After my first pizza I was told that in order to make such a dough I must be a very sophisticated person. I was extremely honoured."

He prepared 21 meals for the political and military leaders and their spouses.

Mr Furlanis's article, entitled Four Italians in the Court of the King, was a cross between Marco Polo and an unfathomable James Bond, said the newspaper Italy Daily.

His only moment of fear came when he was summoned by Gen Pah at 1am, expecting to be reprimanded for urinating in public. He fell to his knees, but the general laughed off the incident and offered a fistful of dollars as a bonus.
