fields.headline: Wireless Group boosts turnover 22%
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group has increased its turnover 22% in the first quarter this year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, which operates TalkSport and 16 independent local radio stations, has bucked the trend for falling advertising revenues by increasing its turnover 22% in the first quarter of 2001.

During the three-month period revenues at national station TalkSport rose by 41% on a like-for-like basis, while TWG's ILR turnover was up 12%. Costs - excluding digital radio - were down 12%.

"For the first quarter of 2001 TWG's total revenues are sharply up and costs are down," said Mr MacKenzie, the group's chairman and chief executive.

"This growth is supported by strong performances from both TalkSport and the ILRs," he added.

"Costs were down 12% like for like, partly as a result of the marketing expenditure to support TalkSport's launch in the first quarter of 2000 not being repeated and also thanks to effective cost controls across the group."

In 2000, TWG reported a 95% increase in turnover to £29.4m - a 12% improvement on a like for like basis.

The group's operating loss fell to £12.3m last year, compared with £13.9m in 1999; while its total loss for 2000 was £34.2m, up from £27.5m the previous year.

TalkSport's turnover for 2000 was up 15% year on year to £10.6m. But the station's operating loss increased slightly from £7.7m to £7.9m.

Revenues for TWG's 16 ILR stations increased 219% to £18.8m - an 11% rise on a like for like basis.

The ILR division posted an operating profit of £2.3m last year, following a loss of £1.2m in 1999.

TWG will save around £3.5m annually from this year after being re-awarded TalkSport's analogue licence with improved commercial terms.

The new licence runs for eight years from January 1 this year.

webTitle: NHS to release details of organ removals

fields.headline: NHS to release details of organ removals
fields.trailText: Thousands of people will learn if their children or relatives were secretly stripped of their vital organs when they died, the government was due to announce today.
fields.body:
Thousands of people will learn if their children or relatives were secretly stripped of their vital organs when they died, the government was due to announce today.

More than 100 NHS trusts in England were being given the go-ahead to start telling people whether hearts, lungs and other organs had been stripped from dead relatives without their consent.

A moratorium had been imposed on trusts giving out the information in the wake of the damning Alder Hey inquiry into organ retention.

The Alder Hey report found that children who had died at the Liverpool hospital had been systematically stripped of their organs without their parents' knowledge or consent.

During the inquiry it also emerged that more than 100,000 hearts, lungs and other organs were still being held by hospitals around the country.

An investigation by chief medical officer professor Liam Donaldson found that thousands of people may have buried their loved ones not knowing they had been stripped of many or all of their internal organs.

The findings, published earlier this year, sparked panic as people jammed hospital switchboards, trying to discover whether relatives who had died sometimes decades ago were among those whose organs had been retained.

But poor record keeping meant that many hospitals had difficulty tracing organs.

And the government was anxious to avoid a repeat of events at Alder Hey, where parents were often forced to go through multiple funerals for their dead children as more of their retained organs were discovered.

The moratorium was imposed on all hospitals as a nationwide audit of retained organs was carried out.

A retained organs commission was also set up to oversee the audit and review the whole issue.

Chairwoman of the commission, professor Margaret Brazier, was today giving selected hospitals the go-ahead to start giving information to people who have inquired about retained organs.

The move could see many more people demanding the return of vital organs and conducting second funerals for their loved ones.

webTitle: Disney plan Escape to Witch Mountain remake

fields.headline: Disney plan Escape to Witch Mountain remake
fields.trailText: Nostalgia is definitely back. Not content with remakes of the Brady Bunch and cartoon characters, Walt Disney Studios is to remake the classic children's movie Escape to Witch Mountain
fields.body:
Nostalgia is definitely back. Not content with remakes of old 70s television programmes (the Brady Bunch) and cartoon characters (anything from the Incredible Hulk to Spiderman), Walt Disney Studios is to remake the classic children's movie Escape to Witch Mountain.

The original film, released in 1975, was an adaptation of Alexander Key's sci-fi book. It featured a young, orphaned, brother and sister who have to battle against a power-hungry tycoon, Aristotle Bolt, who wants to use their magic powers.

The updated version will still feature two children with unexplained telekinetic powers. However, in an attempt to tap into the money-making teenage market, the children will be older than in the original, where they were pre-teens.

The success of the film, which starred Hollywood veterans Ray Milland and Eddie Albert, led to a 1978 sequel Return from Witch Mountain (which starred Bette Davis). The original has already been remade once, for US television in 1995.

Hollywood.com reports that, although Disney isn't the only studio in Hollywood to be dabbling in remakes, it does seem very keen. Recent attempts include Glenn Close's 101 and 102 Dalmatians, George of the Jungle, Mighty Joe Young and Inspector Gadget.

Newcomer Adam Kukalow has been commissioned to write the screenplay for the new film, which is said to remain faithful to the original but to have more of a modern bite.

 Interview with Kim Richards, child star of the original Escape to Witch Mountain

webTitle: 'Charities will lose sympathy for doing the government's work'

fields.headline: 'Charities will lose sympathy for doing the government's work'
fields.trailText: Major concerns about the growing links between the voluntary sector and government have been raised by charity leaders.
fields.body:
Major concerns about the growing links between the voluntary sector and government have been raised by charity leaders.

Speaking at a Charityfair debate on ethics, Directory of Social Change director Mike Eastwood said: "There's a sense in which the voluntary sector has lost the plot somewhat and the idea that we're different from government is being questioned."

He said there was nothing wrong with delivering good quality services in contracts with the statutory sector but that charities needed to be seen as different to the government and private sector.

"If charities are seen as simply doing the work of the government they will lose public sympathy," he said.

Andrea Kelmanson, a consultant and former director of the National Centre for Volunteering, expressed concerns that charities receiving government money were being expected to carry out the politicians' agenda.

"I understand that who pays the piper calls the tune, but funders have a responsibility that just because they've got the money doesn't meant they've got all the answers. They're missing opportunities if they don't talk to those receiving funds."

Camila Batmanghelidjh, founder of south London charity Kids Company, said she was worried that sometimes, when the charity had been consulted by the government on spending on children's services, the agenda had already been set.

"We take part in discussions but there are one or two people who have already decided what and how the money will be spent and the rest of us tag along," she said.

There was also criticism of the importation of "business speak" into the voluntary sector and claims that business practices could not necessarily be transferred to charities.

Ms Kelmanson said that since the 1980s the voluntary sector had largely adopted business sector vocabulary to define its work: "There's a need for a new language [that reflects the voluntary sector]."

Another concern raised at the debate was that, in order to win funding, an increasing number of charities promote a simplistic view about resolving problems and overstate what they can achieve.

Hilary Blume, director of the Charities Advisory Trust, said many of the social problems charities dealt with were intractable: "We can have some impact but we can't solve the problems.

"We can make things better but we can't make them right and I'm worried about the stories charities tell in order to get funds."

She criticised campaigns such as the NSPCC Full Stop campaign against child cruelty, arguing that it was misleading to suggest that child abuse could be halted.

Ms Blume said she was disappointed that the voluntary sector had not made more impact on social injustice in the last 30 years: "I'm ashamed that there is more poverty and there are more children going to bed hungry today than when I started, despite the £2bn that the lottery has given to charities."

But others were more positive about the current role of the sector. Mary Kane, executive director of Hackney-based employment project Bootstrap Enterprises, said: "I'm optimistic about what the sector can achieve."

She said the trend to adopt business concepts in measuring charitable work played an important role in fostering accountability within organisations and to funders.

"There's nothing wrong in being professional and it's possible to be professional and passionate about the cause," she said.

Mary Kane, executive director of Hackney-based employment project Bootstrap Enterprises, said: "I'm optimistic about what the sector can achieve." She said the trend to adopt business concepts in measuring charitable work played an important role in fostering accountability within organisations and to funders. "There's nothing wrong in being professional and it's possible to be professional and passionate about the cause," she said.

fields.headline: Part-time BBC chief attacked
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Labour politician Gerald Kaufman has called for the BBC to be run by a full-time executive chairman, reports Jason Deans.
16.03.01: BBC governors have outlived their usefulness, says Kaufman
fields.body:
Senior Labour politician Gerald Kaufman has called for the BBC to be run by a full-time executive chairman in the wake of row over Sir Christopher Bland.

Mr Kaufman, MP for Manchester Gorton and Commons media select committee chairman, said the BBC could no longer operate with a "two days-a-week chairman". His comments came amid fierce criticism of Sir Christopher's decision to stay on at the BBC after he was named chairman of BT.

"We have got a major broadcasting organisation, with £2.5bn in licence revenue, which ought to be a contender within the whole world communications structure," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme this morning.

"And it operates on the basis of a two days-a-week chairman, a great and the good tokenism board of governors, and a director-general who can go pretty well his own way.

"This corporation should be run by a full-time executive chairman."

Mr Kaufman said Sir Christopher's decision to join BT as chairman and maintain his BBC job until a replacement is appointed merely highlighted how the "role of the chairman as it exists today is completely out of date and anomalous".

"That Sir Christopher should feel, I'm sure very conscientiously, that he can simultaneously fulfil both roles, shows that the BBC needs completely restructuring."

webTitle: Craig David picks up best artist award

fields.headline: Craig David picks up best artist award
fields.trailText: Record breaking teenage singer Craig David put his Brits disappointment behind him last night as he picked up the award for best music act at a ceremony celebrating multiculturalism in the media.
fields.body:
Record breaking teenage singer Craig David put his Brits disappointment behind him last night as he picked up the award for best music act at a ceremony celebrating multiculturalism in the media.

David, the youngest male artist to have a debut single go in at No 1, was omitted from the Brit awards winners' list despite a record six nominations.

The 19-year-old R&B star, regarded as one of the most distinctive voices in British music, was awarded his accolade from the BT ethnic multicultural media awards (Emmas) which are supported by the Guardian and voted for by the public.

Author and comedian Meera Syal was named media personality of the year. The innovative BBC TV show Goodness Gracious Me, which she co-wrote, went on to triumph in the best TV entertainment production category. The Guardian's Gary Younge was best print journalist.

Sporting personality of the year went to Wimbledon tennis champion Venus Williams and the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, won the title of public figure of the year.

Best film production was scooped by Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, starring Michelle Yeoh, who won the accolade for best film actress. Best film actor went to Eddie Murphy for Nutty Professor II.

Lord Richard Attenborough was presented with a special lifetime achievement award in recognition of his human rights and anti-racism campaigning as well as his film career, which included Cry Freedom, about the apartheid injustices of South Africa.

The ceremony, held at the Grosvenor House hotel in Park Lane, central London, was hosted by comedians Richard Blackwood and Nina Wadia.

Music
Best British music act, Craig David (Fill Me In/Walking Away); best world music, Africando All Stars (Mandali); best international music act, Destiny's Child (Writings on the Wall).

Film
Best film production, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon; best film actress, Michelle Yeoh (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); best film actor, Eddie Murphy (Nutty Professor II).

Arts and entertainment
Best comedy/comedian, Jeff Mirza; best book/novel, Vikram Seth (An Equal Music); best play/theatre production, The Lion King.

Television
Best TV entertainment production, Goodness Gracious Me; best TV actor, Felix Dexter (The Prince of Dalston); best TV actress, Lucy Liu (Ally McBeal).

Media
Best publication, Asian Times; best radio station, Kiss FM; best cable/digital channel, Channel East.

Journalism
Best print journalist, Gary Younge (the Guardian); best radio news journalist, Zubeida Malik (BBC, Today Programme); best TV news journalist, Shulie Ghosh (ITN); best TV documentary production, Tito's Story (BBC);

Public figures
Public figure of the year, Kofi Annan; sporting personality of the year, Venus Williams; media personality of the year, Meera Syal.

Lifetime achievement award
Richard Attenborough.

fields.headline: Boss who backed Dyke
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk

Politics
fields.trailText: Sir Christopher Bland is not a man who lives up to his name, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland is not a man who lives up to his name. The Bland years have been anything but anodyne: his five-year stewardship of the BBC governors has been characterised by controversy, political spats and occasional arrogance.

Whether it was his dismissal of culture secretary Chris Smith as a mere licence fee payer during the row over the move of the Nine O'Clock News or his apparent determination to railroad the appointment of Greg Dyke as director general through a sceptical board of governors, Sir Christopher proved his light was no friend to bushels.

His patrician air made him few friends in the government, and his relationship with Mr Smith was cool. Sir Christopher was appointed to the post by John Major in 1996 to succeed Marmaduke Hussey. As a former Conservative candidate he was seen as a Tory crony, yet he described his associations with the party as "ancient".

His political past did not stop him championing the controversial cause of Greg Dyke, the former Labour supporter who emerged as the leading candidate to succeed Lord (John) Birt as director-general in 1999. Both were friends from their days at LWT. He was proved right: the Dyke regime has been welcomed by staff and observers.

Earlier, Sir Christopher and John Birt steered the BBC through a revolutionary period, in which it pioneered the drive to digital. While the vision was Birt's, Sir Christopher understood the need for change and piloted the strategy past the governors.

The BBC chairman is the buffer between government and broadcaster. Sir Christopher was the face of the corporation at media select committee meetings.

Colleagues of Sir Christopher have described him as sharp thinking, and a charming socialite. But he also has a temper, and has been described as a tough boss. He has admitted bossiness, but says he never bears grudges.

He was a Tory councillor on the GLC in the 1960s. He joined the London ITV broadcaster LWT as chairman in 1984. In 1990 he became LWT's largest shareholder after introducing a controversial "golden handcuffs" system, from which he benefited handsomely in 1994.

webTitle: New broom expected to sweep away old culture

fields.headline: New broom expected to sweep away old culture
fields.standfirst:
The former chairman was seen as an obstacle to change. Bland is more likely to 'think the unthinkable'

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The former chairman was seen as an obstacle to change. Bland is more likely to 'think the unthinkable', writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland fell back on a well worn, if slightly corrupted, aphorism yesterday. "I don't like to talk in terms of the size of BT's problems," he said. "The challenge is big. It's a very substantial challenge but not one I'd have taken on if I didn't think I could do it or if I didn't think it would be fun."

Opportunities not problems. If that is the case he has just taken on the opportunity of a lifetime.

The BBC chairman, who takes up the same post at BT on Tuesday, walks into a company with deep rooted problems. Investors had been baying for blood and got some yesterday when Sir Iain Vallance announced his decision to step down as chairman after 35 years with the company and little more than a year away from retirement. He had been on the BT board since it split from the Post Office in 1981.

The City was relieved that some action had been taken at last. But this is only the beginning of what the City hopes will be further radical steps before BT can start a process of rehabilitation.

In the past 18 months BT's share price has crumbled from a peak of almost £15 to the £5 mark. The company is now dwarfed by Vodafone, a business which began life only a decade ago but which has played its cards with better insight and a lot more chutzpah.

BT has found itself overstretched and laden with debts of £30bn. Its credit is on review and it may lose its cherished 'A' rating, which means the cost of borrowing soars. Some of the company's stategic moves, such as the merger of its international corporate business with AT&T of the US, are losing money and the company is being forced to retrench. After laying its footprint across Asia, Canada and other parts of the world, BT is being forced back to Britain with its tail between its legs.

Last year it pledged to pay back £10bn by the end of 2001. In the meantime, however, markets have turned against the company. Hopes of partial stock market flotations of BT Wireless, its mobile phone business, and its yellow pages operation have been dashed by the lack of appetite for new telecoms shares. At the same time the appetite among buyers for some of its assets has also dried up. BT is, in the words of one City analyst, "in a state of paralysis".

Sir Iain, who will remain as "president emeritus", was viewed as an important obstacle to be removed. He has been famously described as having BT running through him like a stick of rock and his removal will perhaps make previously unthinkable decisions thinkable. With a new chairman in place and a new finance director, there will be fewer sacred cows.

The finance director, Philip Hampton, oversaw the break-up of British Gas. Sir Christopher managed significant cultural change at the BBC.

"We are rather fans of Sir Christopher," said Benedict Evans, telecoms analyst at investment bank West LB Panmure. "He has a good record and has experience of companies that have been in difficulty. He could hardly be worse than Vallance.

"In general people in the City are starting to feel that BT is turning the corner. With Hampton and Sir Christopher in place, there are people in the company not associated with the failures of the past few years - the ones who have been sitting there saying nothing is wrong."

Cash call

Sir Christopher indicated that if anything he would be pushing for a quickening of pace. "One of the things BT has to do is to get on with paying down its debt. I'm not about to slow that down. If anything, I want to see it accelerated. Debt is plainly on top of the board's agenda and I wouldn't want to move it down."

Speculation is that BT will make a £5bn cash call on its shareholders through a deeply discounted rights issue. Sir Iain's head was deemed the quid pro quo. Shareholders would only pump more money in if they could see evidence of real change. The expectation of the rights issue caused the BT share price to tumble further yesterday, by 30p to 550p.

The company is in discussions to sell Yell, the yellow pages business, to a consortium of venture capital buyers led by Apax and is expected to raise £3bn. The original plan of last year had been to split BT into five trading units.

Some of the problems facing BT are not necessarily of its own making. At least £10bn of the debt has come from the bidding for next generation mobile phone licences in Britain and Germany during the dot.com mania of earlier last year when the promise of high speed wireless internet access commanded a huge premium.

BT was in an invidious position. It could not afford not to win a licence. As it turns out, neither could it afford what it did pay to win.

BT's debts and its credit rating are at similar levels to the other former state-run monopolies in Europe, such as France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom. Where they differ is that in their domestic markets, the French and German businesses have built the biggest mobile phone operator and the largest internet service provider.

BT has been slow to adapt to new technologies and has been seen as less nimble than some rivals which have come from equally bureacratic and lumbering backgrounds. Given that BT was exposed to competition some 10 years before any of its European peers, the company is regarded as having squandered an enormous advantage.

It was also viewed by many as too arrogant, assuming that because it is BT, it would wield more influence than it actually could from minority stakes in overseas telecoms companies.

Sir Christopher said he believed his experience would come in useful in changing the culture: "I oversaw a lot of change at the BBC with moves on to the internet and digital. The BBC shed a substantial number of staff, underwent radical reorganisation and developed the commercial arm. And it was very heavily regulated, so some of that experience is valuable. I also have major plc experience."

Mr Hampton has already demonstrated the waste still to be cut from BT. He has raised £2bn from a sale and leaseback of the group's property and hopes for another £1bn from a similar deal with its fleet of vans. This is, after all, a company which once owned a catering school to train its chefs.

webTitle: Chief executive faces testing time as last man standing

fields.headline: Chief executive faces testing time as last man standing
fields.standfirst:
Questions over legacy of old management

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Two down, one to go. So ran the mumblings in the City yesterday as Sir Christopher Bland was lined up to replace BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Two down, one to go. So ran the mumblings in the City yesterday as Sir Christopher Bland was lined up to replace BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance. Finance director Robert Brace was replaced by Philip Hampton in October last year. Only chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield to go.

"I'd have given you a quid on the share price for either Vallance or Bonfield or £2.50 for the pair," one telecoms analyst said.

Opinions differ widely as to where the blame should lie for BT's woeful situation. Although he was in recent years a part-time chairman, Sir Iain's personality was still said to dominate the corridors of BT's head office in the shadow of St Pauls. The alliance with AT&T, which has caused a lot of concern among investors, was heavily identified with Sir Iain.

Sir Iain and Sir Peter reportedly clashed often. Sir Christopher was in diplomatic mood: "Peter and I have met two or three times and I believe we can have an effective working relationship," he said. "He has a lot of experience at BT and I have a fresh pair of eyes and a different perspective."

Asked if he could say he fully backed his chief executive, he replied: "That would be as entirely inappropriate or useful as a football club chairman giving the vote of confidence to his manager. We are both determined to make it work. There is no probationary period on either of us."

Sir Peter, 56, joined BT five years ago from the computer group ICL. He had not run a quoted company before and was in large part hired because of his international experience - he spent a substantial amount of his career in the US and Japan, including Texas Instruments and ICL.

He has been largely responsible for the drive into other overseas markets and was for a few years a favourite among investors. His credibility was damaged by the failure of the company to cement its merger with MCI of the US in 1997.

Analysts were divided as to whether he would now quit. "Brace left of his own accord and Sir Iain's departure has been fudged. No one has really been sacked yet. But they are getting rid of the legacy of the old management and if that's the case, then Sir Peter has to go," said one analyst.

Sir Iain's departure may however have bought Sir Peter some time. He is the only one of the top three executives with any depth of telecoms knowledge and the City may be prepared to wait and see just how much influence Sir Iain had.

fields.headline: 3G phones hold $1 trillion promise
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: The mobile phone industry has predicted that internet-enabled handsets will generate revenue of £700bn globally by 2010. By Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
The mobile phone industry brushed aside fears about indebtedness yesterday with a confident prediction that internet-enabled handsets will generate revenue of $1 trillion (£700bn) globally by 2010.

The figure was calculated by the UMTS Forum, which represents phone manufacturers, operators and regulators worldwide.

Its research suggests that third-generation phones will be slow to catch on, but will accelerate sharply in popularity from 2005.

Bernd Eylert, chairman of the UMTS Forum, urged investors to be patient: "Everything that has hands and feet needs nine months to be born. Rome was not built in a day - these things take time."

Mr Eylert, a Deutsche Telekom executive, insisted that network operators' decisions to lay out billions on third-generation licences would be vindicated.

However, he hinted that the UMTS Forum was negotiating with regulators, including the European commission, for short-term help for indebted operators.

"We are in talks with our members, including regulators, about the whole issue," he said.

The forum's forecasts are based on an analysis of all the recent independent research on third-generation phones. By 2010, the organisation predicted, the average subscriber will spend $30 a month on data services and $12 a month on voice calls. Some 28% of callers will be using third-generation phones.

Paola Tonelli of Vodafone, who compiled the study, said: "This study represents the consensus view of over 200 companies in the industry. It's based on a very rigorous methodology and very conservative assumptions."

Within a decade, annual revenue from 3G phones will reach $300bn, the forum predicted. It expects cumulative revenue by 2010 to exceed $1 trillion.

The study expects Europe and Asia to be more promising markets for "infotainment" services such as video clips, online banking and ticket booking. US consumers are more likely to use their phones for surfing the internet and for local information.

The figures aroused scepticism in some quarters - telecoms shares have plunged over the last year since operators spent £22.5bn obtaining licences from the government to operate third-generation networks.

This has been a crucial factor behind BT's problems - culminating in the resignation of chairman Sir Iain Vallance yesterday.

Caroline Sceats, an analyst at Forrester Research, said: "Over the next five years to a decade, we anticipate seeing some real pain over whether operators will make the revenue they expect, particularly in European markets."

Forrester predicts that the operators' average revenue per phone user will drop 15% by 2005, forcing many companies out of business.

Ms Sceats said: "By 2008, we're only expecting about five operators to be left across Europe."

The first third-generation network is likely to be on the Isle of Man, with operations to begin by the end of May.

Manx Telecom, a subsidiary of BT, is pioneering the technology.

By 2010, the UMTS Forum expects 65% of 3G phone revenue to be from private customers, with the remainder from business users.

Handset crisis costs Siemens 3,500 jobs

The crisis in Europe's mobile phone handset business yesterday took a further toll as Siemens announced 3,500 job cuts to staunch steep losses, and issued an effective profits warning.

The new job cuts in Siemens' international communication networks division, announced by chief executive Heinrich von Pierer in Budapest, come on top of 2,600 al ready under way at its IC Mobile unit.

It is unclear how much impact the latest jobs cull will have in the UK but Siemens officials said 60% of the redundancies would be outside Germany.

Siemens' drastic action is the latest by a spate of manufacturers, including Sweden's Ericsson, which is axing up to 12,000 posts, to counteract a dramatic fall-off in demand for handsets and falling US demand for telecoms networks.

French telecoms group Alcatel underlined this trend by abandoning sales growth targets of up to 25% for just 5-15% and saying it would outsource handset production.

But, unlike Siemens whose handset division lost €147m (£92m) in the second quarter and whose chief ex ecutive abandoned a financial forecast for the full year, Alcatel said operating profit rose 4% in its first quarter and promised faster earnings growth. This optimism came despite a warning from the chief financial officer, Jean-Pierre Halbron, who said: "The mobile handset market is in crisis in Europe. This has cost us something like €150m in the first quarter."

Siemens, which reported net first-half profits up 10% at €1.36bn, expects to save €600m through its cost-cuts. The company sold 6.9m mobile handsets in the quarter, overtaking Ericsson to become the world's third largest producer.

Its research suggests that third-generation phones will be slow to catch on, but will accelerate sharply in popularity from 2005. Bernd Eylert, chairman of the UMTS Forum, urged investors to be patient: "Everything that has hands and feet needs nine months to be born. Rome was not built in a day - these things take time." However, he hinted that the UMTS Forum was negotiating with regulators, including the European commission, for short-term help for indebted operators. "We are in talks with our members, including regulators, about the whole issue," he said. webTitle: Changing the clocks could save 100 lives

fields.headline: Changing the clocks could save 100 lives
fields.standfirst: Most people, including Nigel Beard, dislike the short winter evenings. Here, the MP for Bexleyheath and Crayford explains why he's introduced a private member's bill to stop people having to tinker with the clocks.
fields.trailText: Most people, including Nigel Beard, dislike the short winter evenings. Here, the MP for Bexleyheath and Crayford explains why he's introduced a private member's bill to stop people having to tinker with the clocks.
fields.body:
Late nights in the Commons go with an MP's job so we are almost unaware at times whether it is light or dark outside. As a result we may not be the best people to determine whether or not the clocks should change in spring and autumn each year.

However, when in November I asked: "Why do we make the winter more dismal by changing the hour, why don't we just keep summertime all year round?" I was surprised by the number of my constituents who wrote to say how much they agreed with me.

Prompted by this I looked into the issues more deeply and found the case is stronger than I thought. A study by the Transport Research Laboratory in 1998 suggested that 100 lives would be saved and 500 accidents prevented each year by not turning the clock back each October.

And there studies on road accidents which suggest it is safer, even for children, to be out in dark mornings than in a dark, late afternoon.

More than 5% of people in Britain suffer from a form of depression arising from a lack of sunlight, called seasonal effective disorder. Even the most extrovert amongst us feel some gloom descend when the clocks come forward in October and feel as though a cloud has lifted when they go back in spring. There is evidence that these psychological effects could be reduced by an extra hour's daylight in winter afternoons.

The latest Home Office crime survey showed that half of all young women and two-thirds of elderly women feel very or fairly unsafe walking after dark. A quarter of our secondary school children and most primary school children are not allowed out at all after dark. For all these people an effective curfew descends on them at around 4pm in winter, which could be an hour later if summertime were prolonged.

In the past farmers and people in north Scotland have been most vocally opposed to keeping summertime in winter. But if there were no change of the clocks farmers could maintain a regular routine all year round without the present spring and autumn disruption.

On the effect on Scotland of keeping BST all year, I cannot put the answer better than that given by the Scottish journalist, Joyce McMillan, the last time the issue was raised in Westminster in 1995:

"Do what he will the secretary of state cannot turn the earth on its axis. At this time of year eight hours of daylight is all we get. The debate is about where in our working day we wish to have it."

 Nigel Beard is the Labour MP for Bexleyheath and Crayford

fields.headline: On the edge releases
fields.trailText: Zu / Eugene Chadbourne: Motorhellington | Helen Chadwick & Ashley Ramsden: Rumi | Will Menter: Celebrating Rain
fields.body:
Zu / Eugene Chadbourne Motorhellington
(Newtone Records / Distribuzione Felmay) ***
£12.99
www.felmay.it

It's getting harder to shock, so I doubt whether this confection of irreverent cover versions will offend even the most sensitive heavy-metal fan with its respectful reggae/ jazz treatment of Black Sabbath's Iron Man. Zu are an Italian trio (sax/bass/drums) who occasionally team up with trumpeter Roy Paci and guitar/banjo ace Chadbourne. They work in a vein similar to that of New York's Sex Mob, squeezing classic hit tunes such as Chain of Fools and Boogie Stop Shuffle through a semi-ironic free-jazz mill.

They're at their funniest mimicking James Brown's Sex Machine or doing Kraftwerk's The Robots in electronically octave-shifted, Chipmunk-style vocals. Whether you find this worth a second listen may depend on your sense of humour and how well you know the originals. The sleeve helpfully suggests that retailers file the CD under "improvised music, post-rock", but I suspect it will end up in the same bin as the Bonzo Dog Band, the Residents or even the Barron Knights.

Helen Chadwick & Ashley Ramsden Rumi
(Romaine Records) ***

Max Nagl & Edward Gorey The Evil Garden
(November Music) **
£13.99

These two CDs present quite different approaches to text-setting. Chadwick mixes her sung settings of the poems, songs and stories of Jelaluddin Rumi (1207-73) with Ashley Ramsden's readings, sometimes accompanied by gongs or harmonium drones. There's plenty of Rumi's cool wit and wisdom for over-stimulated urbanites to absorb at their leisure: "Your depression is connected to your insolence and refusal to praise," says Rumi in Praising Manners.

Austrian composer Max Nagl uses a chamber-jazz sextet with singer Julie Tippetts and saxophonist Lol Coxhill (who also recites and sings), with percussionist Patrice Heral and keyboardist Josef Novotny (from Nagl's own band), plus inventive French guitarist Noel Akchote. The Evil Garden is a collaboration with writer/illustrator Edward Gorey, who died before recording began. Five texts are included, whose sentiments would have been rather too misanthropic for Rumi. "She cindered toast and rotted silk / Corroded tin and curdled milk," croons Tippetts sweetly in The Disrespectful Summons, while Akchote's playing moves from Frisell territory into the Hendrix badlands.

Such "songs" are mixed with abstract instrumentals, whose bass-less melancholy plausibly parallels Gorey's creepy monochrome images, several of which come with the CD. Unfortunately, the performances lack the authority, clarity and freedom of the artist's lines and rhymes. Nagl's text settings can be careful, sneaky and unexpected, yet they often sound incomplete, like jokes without a punchline.

Will Menter Celebrating Rain
(resOnances) ***

Musician and instrument-builder Will Menter surrounds himself with beautiful sounds: water dripping on to resonant slates, "autumn rain dripping through an oak tree on to five slate marimbas", or "air bubbling up through hollowed-out bamboo stems standing in water".

In the case of the latter, a track called Ascending Air, it is the nature of Menter's bamboo sculpture that determines the "composition". Sometimes he adds voices (Sianed Jones and Chartwell Dutiro), or his own soprano-sax improvisations, but the most appealing sounds come from random permutations of water with inanimate sound-producing systems. There's also the accompaniment of birds, the occasional cow and even a self-explanatory track called The Singing Goat.

The most striking tracks are those such as Watercatch, which reproduces the sound of being inside a cavernous space with dripping water all around. It feels like being trapped on the space tanker in Alien. Slow Talker credits, in addition to snail shells, mbira and soprano sax, "sparse summer drips" - so evocative I feel as if I'm on holiday already.

fields.headline: Life's a beach, and then you dance
fields.standfirst: Frank Tope  on the albums that will bring this year's hedonist hotspots into the living room
fields.trailText: Frank Tope on the albums that will bring this year's hedonist hotspots into the living room
fields.body:
A Man Called Adam Punta del Este Sunset
(Pagan) ***

Stuart Patterson Deviant
(Heavenly) ****

Heartless Crew Ayia Napa - Return to Fantasy Island
(Telstar) **

Hypercity Mixed by Andrew Weatherall (Force Tracks)
***

Louie Vega, Tony Humphries, Tedd Patterson Magic Sessions
(Defected) ****

So where are you going on holiday this year? Napa? 'Beetha? Punta? Sorry, where was that? Ever since Ibiza gave us the concept of the clubbing holiday, it seems everyone has been keen to supplant the Balearic island's (dubious) charms. Every year dance and style magazines fall over their boarding passes to convince us that somewhere, anywhere, is the New Ibiza. It doesn't work, of course, and our little rave monkeys continue to migrate annually to Ibiza to get royally twatted - sorry, dance in the sunshine. And why not? It may be easy to mock Ibiza, but the island has clubs such as the open-air Space and DC10 that on a good night can still prove genuinely inspiring, and it has a mixture of relaxed cosmopolitan chic and the profanely hedonistic that you would be hard pressed to find anywhere else.

If last year was the turn of Cypriot resort Ayia Napa to hog the limelight and column inches, this year, all the talk is of Uruguay - but talk is all it is. Jet-set resort Punta del Este sounds idyllic, and for the elite few who have been flown over to party there, no doubt it is (Jealous? Moi? Perish the thought). Liverpool superclub Cream has opened a bar on its beach, and now comes that essential for every clubbing holiday destination: the compilation album. Chillout-room stalwarts A Man Called Adam have been inextricably linked with magical Ibiza ever since singer Sally Rogers appeared wibbling away in a charmingly off-cake "you're my best friend" manner on Channel 4's 1990 Ibiza raveumentary A Short Film About Chilling. So who better to launch the assault on South America's shores?

Sadly, these latter-day chillout conquistadors have abandoned any attempt to incorporate local rhumbas and tangos into this mix; instead the selection is a languidly laid-back one that would sound equally good in Blackpool as in Uruguay's chicest boutique. Of course, the real sound of Punta is banging house music, but why let that get in the way of a good concept? We're told that they've (somewhat pointlessly) sampled the local frogs' croaking for the mix, but the real highlight is up-and-coming London duo Zero 7's delightful remix of Radiohead's Climbing Up the Walls, which lends Thom Yorke's voice an uncharacteristically comforting edge. On the folk-edged 16 Again, meanwhile, underrated Nottingham pair Neon Heights confirm their position as the group that most needs to be handed a fat record contract right now.

Over in Ayia Napa, there's no time for relaxing tunes. Mixed by the Heartless Crew, Ayia Napa - Return to Fantasy Island is a tie-in with the terrifying fly-on-the-hotel-wall series recently shouted at by pissed students of a Friday night. There is a real and growing scene in Napa, with most heavyweight London garage clubs promoting their own nights, but the hard-drinking holidaymakers there are far more Majorca than Ibiza. As the series itself focused on last year's season, this compilation has the perfect excuse to trot out a selection of Y2K classics from garage's annus mirabilis. This is the sort of music that thumps out at you from commercial breaks and prompts kettles to go on across the country - you say "Ayia", I say "Make me a nice cup of tea."

Back in London and off to the pub. Heavenly Social was the original club in a pub, a riotous Sunday night knees-up that made superstars of the Chemical Brothers. Half a decade on and Heavenly has opened its own bars in London and Nottingham. DJ Stuart Paterson brings his record boxes to the London branch every Thursday and his Deviant compilation gives a snapshot of what he plays to drown out the noise of crunching Twiglets. It's a broad spectrum, taking in all manner of mellow, soulful grooves. There's booming hip-hop and long-deleted gems including Chicago folk-soul brother Terry Callier's euphoric 1960s Ordinary Joe and Dillinger's anti-drugs reggae shuffler Cocaine. The Blow Monkeys provide this month's bizarre pop moment - but then Dr Robert and gang's flamenco-funk B-side La Passionara has long been a staple for the more knowing DJ. The kind of variety that in more innocent times we would have cheerfully labelled Balearic.

There's been a lot of British media excitement about Miami recently: the majority of the British dance-music establishment goes there every year to cut deals at the annual Winter Music Conference, so it's thought there must be a story in it. There is, but sadly not one anyone chooses to report. Musically Miami was largely moribund this year, making remixes of Eddie Grant's old pop-reggae chestnut Electric Avenue the toast of the town's clubs. A dire thing indeed - expect it to be duly massive this summer.

One Miami night that has survived the hype and consistently championed new, exciting music is Magic Session, which is run by a trio of New York club-scene luminaries: Masters at Work's Louie Vegas, Tony Humphries and the criminally underrated producer Tedd Patterson. The Magic Sessions compilation gives a flavour of the night, mixing together classics such as Louie's ex-wife India's early 1980s club classic Love & Happiness with more modern manifestos from Tedd himself and Louie's production partner Kenny "Dope" Gonzales. It also includes former home-counties junglist turned born-again old-skool house revivalist Photek.

You'd be unlikely to choose Frankfurt as your holiday destination, but the city has given us a steady stream of house and techno over the years. Hypercity brings together 15 tracks from the redoubtable Force Tracks label mixed by one Andrew Weatherall, who, despite a lower profile than in his long-haired, leather-trousered glory days, remains a superb DJ. Once the warm-up DJ at original acid house den Shoom, elevated to producing and DJing for Screamadelica- era Primal Scream, then promoter of cheesy rave-free techno at his assault course of a club, Sabresonic, Weatherall is now a revered elder statesman of dance. He lends this collection of bleeps and minor chord minimalism somewhat more gravitas than it might otherwise have received. Buy it and earn the respect of every techno lad on your street.

fields.headline: The radiant way
fields.trailText: Bruckner | Rossini | Henze
fields.body:
Bruckner: Symphony No 5
Dresden Staatskapelle/ Sinopoli
(Deutsche Grammophon) ****
£13.99

Giuseppe Sinopoli died suddenly last weekend at the distressingly young age of 54, while conducting a performance of Verdi's Aida at the Deutsche Oper in Berlin. He was always a controversial conductor, who was vilified as much as he was admired when he was music director of the Philharmonia in London from 1983 to 1994. While some of the vitriol might have been deserved - his interpretations could be eccentric, with tempi and phrasing that went almost perversely against the grain of the music, and were apparently more concerned with analysing the music than with performing it - there were areas of the repertory where his insights were thoroughly rewarding. The Second Viennese School was a speciality to which he brought a sense of style and formal appreciation, while in its precursors, Bruckner and Mahler, his objective approach sometimes paid unlikely dividends.

This new version of Bruckner's Fifth Symphony was recorded in Dresden two years ago. Sinopoli is punctilious in observing all the gradations of dynamics, and in pointing up the web of thematic links that binds this huge structure in such a unity, though his ultra-slow adagio tends towards ponderousness at times; in the finale he synthesises all its constituents - fugue and chorale as well as references to the earlier movements - with granitic inevitability. It is a massive and ultimately impressive reading, wonderfully delivered by the Staatskapelle, and, though there are presumably more Sinopoli recordings awaiting release, a timely tribute to his distinctive ability.

Mozart: Il Sogno di Scipione
Hartelius/Larsson/Brandes/Ford/Workman/Freiburg Baroque Orchestra/Von der Goltz
(Naive Astree, 2 CDs) ***
£17.99

Scipio's Dream was Mozart's fifth opera, a serenata composed to a Metastasio libretto based on Cicero's tale about the celebrated Roman general; it was first performed at the enthronement of Archbishop Collerado in Salzburg in 1772. It is not an earth-shattering piece, especially when compared with the stage works, Lucio Silla and Mitridate, that preceded it; the ceremonial circumstances of its premiere precluded any searching characterisation or dramatic tension. Instead, there is a series of decorative arias, functional recitative and a couple of choruses, which, if not by Mozart, would hardly merit more than the occasional airing. This is a more or less stylish and generally attractive period performance, sometimes a little too ornate in its decorations; the tenor Bruce Ford as Scipio and the soprano Christine Brandes are the pick of the cast.

Rossini: Le Nozze di Teti; Il Pianto d'Armonia
Bartoli/Florez/Kelly/Scano/ Orchestra e Core Filarmonico della Scala/Chailly
(Decca) ****
£13.99

Rossini began his series of dramatic cantatas while still a student and used the form to perfect many of the theatrical devices he later employed in his operas. Il Pianto d'Armonia was the first, written for an end-of-year concert at the music school in Bologna in 1808, but of the two works in this second of Decca's series, Le Nozze di Teti is the more substantial piece. All of the singing is top class, but there are no prizes for guessing the star of the show. It's hard to believe that Decca would have embarked on these recordings were it not for the presence of Cecilia Bartoli in their stable, together with the bonus of Riccardo Chailly, whose Rossini conducting is consistently alert and energised. The mezzo-soprano is in vivacious form in Le Nozze di Teti, which includes an aria that Rossini was to recycle as one of the lollipops in La Cenerentola, and Bartoli turns it into a showstopper here, too.

Kaune/NDR Symphony/Ruzicka
Wergo ****
£13.99

Hans Werner Henze left his native Germany to settle in Italy in 1953, and his musical world changed radically. His ambivalent attitude to his homeland in the aftermath of the second world war had acquired a musical dimension, too, as Henze found himself increasingly alienated from the radicalism of his contemporaries. In his new sunlit Mediterranean surroundings, away from the polemics of the avant-garde, the expressive warmth and lyricism that were his natural musical instincts could really express themselves.

This collection of orchestral works, all first recordings, focuses upon the period in which Henze worked towards that new voice. Most revealing of all is arguably the least successful piece on the disc - the Three Symphonic Studies for large orchestra, completed in 1956 but revised eight years later, show Henze trying to reconcile his desire to make the orchestra sing with a lingering necessity to organise the music in a serial fashion. The results are rather Bergian, yet never quite in focus.

In the orchestral Quattro Poemi from 1955, however, it is Schoenberg who is the main model; there is a freewheeling chromaticism about the harmony, and the intricate, singing lines that well up among the busy counterpoints create a pithy, potently dramatic world.

But the most important piece here is undoubtedly Nachtstücke und Arien, the substantial 1957 settings of poems by Henze's then regular librettist Ingeborg Bachmann (who died in 1973). It is the work whose sense of Mediterranean warmth and lushness really put clear ground between Henze and his European contemporaries, who regarded such a frankly melodic work as unspeakably reactionary, with the result that, at the premiere in Darmstadt, Boulez, Stockhausen and Nono walked out during the performance.

All bridges had finally been burned; but now, more than 40 years on, in a much less dogmatic age, it is possible to appreciate Nachstucke und Arien for what it is: a work permeated with the threat of catastrophe (made explicit in the two Bachmann texts, imposingly delivered on the recording by the soprano Michaela Kaune), yet one that is determined to sing raptly and theatrically in the face of that impending disaster. It is one of Henze's finest achievements.

The key work from this period of his development, though, remains unrecorded. The huge opera King Stag, based upon a play by Gozzi, was the score through which Henze definitively found that new radiant voice, and enabled him to write with the freedom he found in Nachstücke und Arien. Stagings of the complete, five-hour work have been rare, too, and perhaps for that reason in 1991, Henze arranged two numbers from King Stag for the concert hall. La Selva Incantata is described as an aria and rondo for orchestra, and the music shows graphically how vivid and dramatically intense the world he created for the opera is; how it moves with such sureness, and how melodic lines burgeon and flower along the way. It is ravishing music, and though this recording is not the last word in allure, the performance by the South West German Radio Orchestra under Peter Ruzicka makes its glories plain to hear.

fields.headline: She's great with a teapot
fields.standfirst: John L Walters  hails Haco, a bona fide star from Japan
fields.trailText: John L Walters hails Haco, a bona fide star from Japan
fields.body:
After Dinner Paradise of Replica / Paradise of Remixes
(ReR AD2) *** www.megacorp.u-net.com

After Dinner was a 1980s pop vehicle for the writing and performing talents of Haco, the singer who impressed audiences for the Japanorama tour last January with her charismatic stage presence and effortless mastery of sonic devices such as the teapot. But unlike many of her experimental contemporaries, Haco comes across as a bone fide pop star: it's as if Baby Spice or Kylie had acquired a large record collection and a degree in electro-acoustic music.

The first nine tracks of this album form a re-release of After Dinner's 1989 album Paradise of Replica. The remaining four tracks are "remixes", perpetrated with varying degrees of complexity, obsessiveness and obscurity by musicians such as Terre Thaemlitz and Pascal Platinga. The original album, which owes much of its sound to keyboard player Yosuke Isshiki, is an entertaining collection of songs with eccentric and wildly changing chord progressions, put together in a clean but home-made recording that recalls every experimental production/ arrangement technique you've ever heard, from Shuggie Otis to Beck.

The lyrics may have lost something in the English translation, but they read a little like erudite versions of the baffling slogans you get on Japanese T-shirts and toys. For example: "Humankind is fine weather / According to the report, / People worship geometrical inanimate objects" (Kitchen Life).

Or how about this? "The swinging pendulum / Of some inorganic substance / The exhaust sounds / Like singing / A metaphor / That has slipped off rack" (Motorcycle). Haco's time may have come at last.

fields.headline: We will rock you
fields.standfirst: Mogwai discover grandeur, Natacha Atlas updates Arabic pop and Stevie Nicks is off with the fairies in this week's CDs
fields.trailText: Mogwai discover grandeur, Natacha Atlas updates Arabic pop and Stevie Nicks is off with the fairies in this week's CDs
fields.byline: Reviews by John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow, Richard Williams, Caroline Sullivan and Pascal Wyse
fields.body:
Mogwai Rock Action
(Southpaw) ****
£12.99

By the time a band reaches their third album, their case should be rested. Not so with Glasgow quintet Mogwai, who seemed to have missed their chance, too busy messing about with tangential, flabby doodles to compose songs. But Rock Action has shifted Mogwai's goalposts. They could still do with a rip-roaring chorus, if only to dispel the suspicion that they remain incapable of writing one. However, Mogwai are beginning to see the bigger picture. Rock Action is at its best at its bookends. The opening Sine Wave is a hypnotic instrumental, swimming in Spiritualized-esque melody, while the closer, Secret Pint, led by Barry Burns's metronomic piano, is Erik Satie as a Tortoise acolyte. In between, Super Furry Animal Gruff Rhys sings Dial: Revenge in distracted fashion and a cunningly deployed string section gives 2 Rights Make 1 Wrong a grandeur that Mogwai previously shied away from. This year's dinner-party soundtrack? Don't bet your Dido disc against it. (JA)

Brian Eno and J Peter Schwalm Drawn from Life
(Virgin Venture) ***
£14.99

These are busy times for Brian Eno, on one hand settling commercial scores with production duties for U2 and James, on the other hooking up with yet another musical partner to hitch a ride further into the ambient hinterland. J Peter Schwalm is a conservatory-trained German percussionist, but there is little percussion (and even that is played by Heiko Himmighoffen) on this gentle, sometimes sterile album. Eno prefers to utilise Schwalm's talents as a co-composer and mixer. The pair bring a serenity to Nell Catchpole's vigorous strings on Persis and subtly leaven Laurie Anderson's booming voice on Like Pictures Part £2, while children's voices bring welcome humanity to Bloom. Towards the end, some childish jiggery-pokery involving two lengthy silences rather undermines the pair's thoughtful approach, but for the most part Drawn from Life is beguiling. (JA)

Natacha Atlas Ayeshteni
(Mantra) ****
£12.99

Welcome to the queen of the new north African cool. Natacha Atlas has spent the past decade perfecting her own brand of contemporary Arabic pop, first as the belly-dancing vocalist with the multicultural Transglobal Underground and then on a series of solo albums. With Ayeshteni, she promises to extend her success beyond Egypt and France (where she is a major star) to Britain, where she once lived. The formula is simple and wildly effective. Her sensual vocals are mixed with sturdy, contemporary bass and drum rhythm tracks, and the swirling strings and wailing horns of some of the finest players in Cairo. The result is an Arabic fusion that is passionate and exhilarating. There's just one track here in English - an Egyptian update of the Jay Hawkins and Nina Simone classic, I Put a Spell on You - and a couple in French, including a breathy treatment of Jacques Brel's Ne Me Quitte Pas. The sparse remix track by Nitin Sawhney is a mistake, but can be forgiven after an album this original and impressive. (RD)

Marvin Gaye What's Going On
(Motown Deluxe, 2 CDs) *****
£16.99

While no amount of additional material could improve on the perfection of Marvin Gaye's 30-year-old masterpiece of conscious soul music, this expanded two-CD edition encourages a re-examination of his pioneering work. On the first disc, reissue producer Harry Weinger follows a remastered version of the original release - only 36 minutes long - with a complete bare-bones mix sent from the Motown studios in Detroit, where the basic tracks and lead vocals had been cut, to Hollywood, where Gaye and his engineer, Lawrence Miles, added the touches that created the mood of exotic paranoia that so transfixed listenersin the summer of 1971. But the true discovery, on the second disc, is a full 50-minute concert from the Kennedy Center in Washington on May 1, 1972. His native city was celebrating Marvin Gaye Day and the singer turned up, immaculately stoned, to perform the album's songs and a sprawling medley of his 1960s hits with a full orchestra driven by Motown's first-choice rhythm section: Robert White on guitar, James Jamerson on bass, Uriel Jones on drums, the percussionists Eddie "Bongo" Brown and Jack Ashford, and Gaye himself at the piano. Marvin rambles in his introductions, starts songs in the wrong place, and generally gives us a series of clues to the tragedy lying in wait 10 years down the road. But he also sounds utterly wonderful, reminding us of what someone once said about Miles Davis, that his mistakes were more interesting than most people's successes. When he stops the orchestra to make a minute adjustment to the groove of Inner City Blues, we hear the battle between indiscipline and precision that gave his music its special spirit. (RW)

Stevie Nicks Trouble in Shangri-La
(Reprise) ***
£15.99

Stevie Nicks decided long ago who she was and has stuck with that ever since. Her constancy elicits both admiration (where does one buy white platform boots in 2001?) and impatience - does she never tire of maintaining the hippie-witch archetype she's cultivated since the 1970s? This is her first album in seven years and, despite the modern presence of Macy Gray on the bubbling Bombay Sapphires, nothing much has changed in Nicks's hermetic world. She boasts on Candlebright of being "something of a dreamer", and her husky warble still sketches dreamscapes of sea, sky and wizards to a soft-rock backdrop co-produced by Sheryl Crow. A foray into country on Too Far from Texas counts as a daring diversion. All that's missing is the subtle something that made Rooms on Fire so luscious. (CS)

Autechre Confield
(Warp) ***
£11.99

The twitching electronica of Autechre (Sean Booth and Rob Brown) doesn't really survive in the background. It's like having spiders crawling on your brain. But the unpredictability of the music, while agitating on the horizon, becomes agile and thrilling heard on headphones - it's like being able to track individual snowflakes in a blizzard. There are no tunes or obvious grooves and few recognisable instruments. But what leaps out of every track is a frenetic storm of tiny beats, a microscopic violence of ball-bearing clicks and scrapes. The strange sampled snoring on Uviol and the squashed voices on Lentic Cathachresis show a sort of strangled humanity, but the final information overload is more like being ejected from an android's bad dream. (PW)

Orbital The Altogether
(London/ffrr) ****
£15.99

In 11 years of regular releases, Orbital haven't put a foot wrong. By their own admission, this is their happy album, running on a different fuel from the dark Insides or the politically charged Snivilisation. Less tied by thematic threads, The Altogether ranges far and wide in style and sometimes misses that earlier intensity. Pay Per View is attractive but undistinctive and Illuminate, sung by David Gray, feels slightly oversweet, as if they've stripped too much of themselves away to accompany the voice. But on Tension, Tootled and Dr Who there is still plenty of their grace under pressure. Dr Who gets a dramatic update with eerie feedback and tough beats. And oi! (sampling Hit Me with Your Rhythm Stick with a bumpy Euro beat) shows Orbital's skill at making a tune appear to move forward and stand still at the same time. Few people can make you think and dance in such equal measure. (PW)

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Rob Mackie looks at Memento, Coyote Ugly, and Going Off Big Time
fields.body:
Memento
Rental and DVD rental Fox Pathe Cert 15 *****

"Facts, not memories. That's how you investigate." Guy Pearce, in his first good part since LA Confidential's similarly dogged tec, is an insurance investigator piecing together the murder of his wife. The unique aspect to this case is that he is hampered by being unable to amass new memories since a blow on the head at the murder scene incapacitated him. Original murder plots get ever harder to invent, but this is a corker, almost as good as DOA (poisoned man tries to solve own murder). Writer-director Christopher Nolan succeeds Following - an award-winner like this - with an even more tortuous and tricky tale that demands a second viewing. Pearce's desperate hunt, put together by notes, Polaroids and tattoos leaves him uniquely open to exploitation and Nolan makes it that much more paranoid by telling the whole tale backwards. Another director would make this unbearably trendy and tricksy but Nolan keeps it comprehensible and riveting: at 31, he's clearly a talent to watch. The result is a fiendishly complicated and ambiguous twist on the noir/detective genre with a sideline meditation on memory, intuition and trust. The Polaroid, a hopeless blur turning gradually into a crisp image is the perfect metaphor for Nolan's tale but if this makes the film sound terribly abstract and intellectual, I would be doing it a disservice: it may be labyrinthine and deeply obsessive but it's also thoroughly absorbing, with shafts of dark wit leavening its gloomier aspects.

Coyote Ugly
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Buena Vista Cert 12 **

A Jerry Bruckheimer film and, as that often implies, a film that relates only to other films. "Flashdance meets Cocktail" is the pretty accurate summary on the front of the sleeve. You could also go for "Roadhouse meets Hearts of Fire". A wish-fulfilment fantasy fluffier than a poodle in an angora bodywarmer, it tells of a songwriter with stage fright who leaves a small town to pursue her dreams, meets with rejection in the big city (New York) and ends up as a sexy dancing barmaid battling with new boyfriend and tough boss. It's hyper throughout and feels like a film written by a 14-year-old and directed by his younger brother. It is saved from total redundancy by a charming lead performance by Piper Perabo - looking strikingly like Sarah Jessica Parker in LA Story - and some enthusiastic direction: the Coyote bar as sexually charged moshpit is fun to watch, in an exhausting kind of way. John Goodman looks embarrassed as Perabo's unlikely dad.

Going Off Big Time
Rental and DVD (£19.99) EV Cert 18 ***

Brit gangster film number 71, but while it won't lodge long in the memory banks, it has moments of real invention and, after all those east-end hardmen, it's a relief to have a film peopled mainly by Scousers of the lippy variety. It's constructed largely as a flashback to how our anti-hero, Neil Fitzmaurice, got involved in a life of crime. The actor, who was DJ Ray Von in Peter Kay's recent Phoenix Nights series, also wrote the screenplay, and comes up with some nice lines: "He was more Stringfellow than Goodfella." The film is far stronger in its prison scenes, where Bernard Hill is the old lag helping our youth get by in a Fletch-and-Lennie kind of way. You miss Hill in the more mundane scenes on the outside, though a fight in a bouncy castle and drug deals done from an ice-cream van are nicely original touches. But the film trips itself up with flashbacks-within-flashbacks at times, and there's some hazy plotting and rough script edges on the way to a surprise sudden ending.

fields.headline: Senior BBC man slams Prince Edward
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Wayne Garvie has launched a stinging attack on Prince Edward, describing him as 'rubbish', writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Wayne Garvie, the BBC's head of music, entertainment and features, has lashed out at Prince Edward, accusing him of "being rubbish when it's on a plate for [him]".

He compared the prince, who owns the independent production company Ardent, with Nicola Shindler of the drama producer, Red Productions, and Paula Trafford of the factual independent, Planet Wild.

In a column this week in trade magazine Broadcast, he wrote that Ms Shindler - who produced Queer as Folk - and Ms Trafford were shining examples of talented people who did not owe their success to family connections.

Mr Garvie wrote he was bemused by the fact Prince Edward had failed to create a good production company despite his wealth and royal connections.

"I've nothing against families giving you a leg up, I just feel my own family have let me down in that quarter. What I dislike is being rubbish when it's on a plate for you," Mr Garvie wrote.

He claimed launching an independent production company in the north of England was particularly difficult.

"It takes talent, drive and vision to succeed," he asserted.

"In the north there's probably an essential hunger to achieve, to prove you can do it, that the denizens of Bagshot Park would simply never understand."

He concluded by paraphrasing Caroline Aherne, aka Mrs Merton, writing: "I'd like to ask those who commissioned an Ardent programme: 'What was it that first attracted you to seventh-in-line-to-the-throne Edward Wessex?"

fields.headline: Bland's BBC salary shock
fields.trailText: 10am: Some 220 licence fees will go towards paying Sir Christopher Bland while he is chairman of both the BBC and BT, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
More than 200 licence fees will go towards paying Sir Christopher Bland's salary during the period when he is chairman of both the BBC and BT.

He is due to stay on as BBC chairman after joining BT on May 1, until a successor is appointed - which is not expected to be until September.

In the intervening four months he can expect to earn at least £24,000 - a figure equivalent to 220 licence fees.

A spokeswoman for the department of culture, media and sport confirmed that the process of finding Sir Christopher's replacement is not expected to be completed until September, allowing for an anticipated general election in June.

"We will follow the full Nolan proceedures," she added. "The job will be publicly advertised, then there will be interviews and candidates will be expected to declare any possible conflicts of interest."

Sir Christopher yesterday defended his decision to stay on as BBC chairman after he takes up the full-time post at BT.

"It would have been much simpler for me to walk out on Tuesday night, but I do not think it would have been right for the BBC," he told BBC Online.

"The government need time to recruit and put in place a successor. The BBC needs either a chairman or an acting chairman during that time.

"The election means that the recruitment of my successor will be drawn out a bit longer."

Meanwhile, this morning it was reported that Bland would be investing £1m of his own fortune into BT. It is expected that the investment will be made after the company reports its annual results next month.

fields.headline: Government in Sooty row
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The COI's census advertising campaign has used the Sooty character without permission, writes Julia Day.
26.04.2001: Labour's 172 advertising campaigns
<A HREF=""Table: top 20 government campaigns
25.04.2001: Kennedy enters row over government adspend
25.04.2001: Blair accused over advertising spend
Table: 10 highest-spending UK advertisers
fields.body:
Lawyers have become involved in a row over the use of a children's TV star in a government advertising campaign.

The "count me in" census campaign has come under fire for using the Sooty puppet character without permission.

Gullane Entertainment's joint venture company, Sooty Limited, owns the worldwide copyright to the characters Sooty, Sweep, Soo and Cousin Scampi.

But the Central Office of Information did not seek permission from Gullane to use a Sooty puppet in its campaign to encourage people to fill in their census forms.

In one poster, a woman with a baby on her lap is pictured holding a Sooty glove puppet.

Lawyers for Gullane have written to the COI demanding an immediate response about the use of Sooty in the campaign.

Helen Byrne, Gullane's group head of business affairs, wrote in the letter: "We are not aware the COI has made any approach to us to obtain our permission to use the character Sooty in this way."

fields.headline: Nick Raynsford online chat
fields.standfirst: Housing minister Nick Raynsford took part in a live online chat on SocietyGuardian.co.uk's talkboards on April 26, answering your questions on a range of housing issues
fields.trailText:
happyclappy
How will you meet demands for new affordable housing for teachers, nurses, police and social workers? The south-east is now a no-go area. Large increases in salaries would be the most sensible solution, but I don't suppose you're prepared to consider that...
fields.body:
happyclappy
How will you meet demands for new affordable housing for teachers, nurses, police and social workers? The south-east is now a no-go area. Large increases in salaries would be the most sensible solution, but I don't suppose you're prepared to consider that...

Nick Raynsford
Our starter home initiative backed by £250m will give help to teachers, nurses, police and other key workers. The scheme is designed to help the key workers buy a home in high-cost areas without adding to house price inflation. The likely impact of large salary increases would almost certainly be a runaway increase in house price inflation.

SusanJones
What about other low-paid workers? Why is support being given to just those who happen to work in the public sector rather than all people who simply can't afford to buy in the south-east?

Nick Raynsford
The Starter Homes Initiative is designed to help key workers but we have also substantially increased investment in affordable housing for other people in need. Investment through local councils has more than doubled since 1997, and over the next two years we plan to almost double investment through housing associations. Our aim is to ensure a good supply of houses available for sale and for rent to meet the full range of needs. In areas where there is very heavy pressure for housing, such as London and the south-east of England, it will inevitably take longer for our policies and increased investment to deliver the improvements that we know are needed and to which we are committed. However we are determined to continue on the lines spelt out in last years housing policy statement with no return to the disasterous policies of the previous Tory government that created boom-bust cycles, repossessions, negative equity and chronic under investment in social housing.

DCH11
It seems the government generally thinks that "public is bad, private is good" and are pursuing privatisation across the board.

Opposition is growing - have you seen the Manifesto for Council Housing jointly sponsored by Defend Council Housing, TAROE (Tenants & Residents Organisation of England), Daylight Robbery Campaign, UCATT, UNISON and GMB?

The aim is to get tenants and union reps, MPs and councillors and candidates from all the parties to 'sign up' to this Manifesto... Use it in your area in the run up to the election, speakers available on request... Details at http://www.defendcouncilhousing.org.uk/

Nick Raynsford
Council housing has an important role to play in meeting housing needs and that is why the government has more than doubled the funds available to councils to modernise and improve council housing. We do not however believe in monopolies and so we are encouraging greater diversity in social housing. This means increasing the number of homes provided by other social landlords including housing associations and tenant co-operatives. Our objective, as spelt out in last year's housing policy statement is a high-quality social housing sector with a range of providers ensuring more choice for the public.

paulmason2000
Why are you so determined to push the private finance initiative - hasn't it been proven overpriced and inefficient compared to traditional public spending?

Nick Raynsford
The PFI has a role to play in housing as in other public services. Well-planned PFI schemes can deliver better value for money than traditional procurement routes because the contractor has to maintain the property for the lifetime of the contract and so has a vested interest in ensuring that it is well built and is cost effective to run. This helps also to achieve the government's objective of getting lifetime value rather than simply thinking about the capital cost of a project at the point of time it is built. However, the PFI will only be one element in the range of options available to local councils when considering how best to improve their housing stock. There are a number of other options.

johnkw
The DETR is currently funding a pilot tenancy deposit scheme to overcome the problems of the non-return of rent deposits. If the pilot shows that the scheme works well, but that rogue landlords are not signing up on a voluntary basis, will the next Labour government legislate for a compulsory scheme?
Bowlercork
The tenancy deposit scheme pilot is working in some areas but take up and interest in others is very poor. Is it really viable to consider the introduction of a compulsory scheme, and how could it be policed.
JoshE
The government is currently running a pilot tenancy deposit scheme. How serious is it about making it compulsory if private landlords don't play along and join the trial?

Our aim is to do this on a voluntary basis, but we have not ruled out the possibility of a mandatory scheme if voluntary measures fail.
