webTitle: An opportunity to say 'enough is enough'

fields.headline: An opportunity to say 'enough is enough'
fields.standfirst: Workers' Memorial Day gives us the opportunity to remember that, with the exception of the construction industry, nowhere is the risk of serious injury more prevalent than in the NHS and social care
fields.trailText: Geoff Martin: Workers' Memorial Day gives us the opportunity to remember that, with the exception of the construction industry, nowhere is the risk of serious injury more prevalent than in the NHS and social care.
fields.body:
Saturday April 28 is Workers' Memorial Day. The idea of a day to commemorate workers who have been killed in the course of their occupation first started in Canada in 1985 and was formally adopted by the British TUC in 1999 and the health and safety executive (HSE) in 2000.

Workers' Memorial Day might not generate the tabloid interest of events such as National Cleavage Day or some of the myriad of other days that are spun with relentless monotony by the public relations industry. But Saturday is different. This is a real opportunity to remember those who have died and step up the fight for safe working conditions for the living.

There are few areas where this campaign is more important than in the NHS and social care. With the exception of the construction industry, nowhere is the risk of serious and life-threatening injury more prevalent.

A case in point is Jenny Morrison. Ms Morrison was an experienced, skilled and dedicated social worker in Wandsworth, London. In November 1998, during the course of her work, she was attacked and killed by one of her clients.

The inquiry report into Ms Morrison's death, published last December, makes horrific reading and yet the circumstances surrounding her killing could so easily be applied to over-stretched mental health services the length and breadth of the land.

The conclusion of the report will ring true with thousands of other social care staff: "the understaffing of the Thurleigh Road hostel, contrary to London borough of Wandsworth's own standards, and the lack of emergency procedures, led to an increased risk to [the client], members of the hostel staff and health and social care professionals."

But how many other services are running these same risks day in and day out because they can't recruit and retain the staff that they need? And in how many areas has the threat of assault become institutionalised and regarded as almost part of the job? In my experience as a Unison repesentative, the answer is just about everywhere and the staff and management know it.

A recent staff survey at the South London and Maudsley NHS trust found that more than 90% of staff had been subjected to one kind of assault or another and that the majority of incidents simply went unreported. This is a scandal and highlights the fact that there are many other serious incidents and perhaps deaths just waiting to happen.

Workers' Memorial Day gives us the opportunity to say "enough is enough". It's stressful enough working in health and social care without having to worry about where the next punch or blade is coming from. Politicians, particularly the New Labour breed, use the phrase "zero tolerance" as a tasty little soundbite when it comes to assaults on our staff, but there is no solid evidence they've lifted a finger to do anything about it.

The HSE recently launched a high profile campaign aimed at improving the conditions in the building industry that included a hotline where workers can shop employers who are flouting safety regulations. Perhaps we need something similar in public services?

This Workers' Memorial Day, spare a thought for those who have died working in social care. Why not also make a resolution not to put up with conditions in your job that put you and your colleagues at risk.

 Geoff Martin is the Unison London Convenor.

fields.headline: The English question
fields.trailText: Analysis: John Prescott might be tempted to redistribute resources from north of the border to the south - but the Scots have an ace up their sleeve, writes Peter Hetherington.
fields.body:
In 1997, John Prescott was asked by a northern Labour MP to review the distribution of cash around the UK, and he had no hesitation in replying that it was "necessary to make sure we have a level playing field". There was little reaction from cabinet colleagues. Yet the same statement of policy sent shock waves through Labour's high command when repeated rather more robustly this week.

Four years ago even the then Treasury chief secretary, Alistair Darling, a Scottish MP, appeared to concede that the funding formula - conceived by Lord (Joel) Barnett in the mid-70s - was unsustainable, creating anything but that level playing field. Since, much has changed in the constitutional map of the UK. Scotland, with its own parliament and a spending-per-head level remaining stubbornly 23% above the English average, is going its own way. Wales (18% above), with a non-legislative assembly, is slowly flexing its muscles while Northern Ireland (39% above) is trying to make devolution stick.

But now a bigger and potentially more disruptive constitutional re-think is taking place. Ministers, even those to whom regionalism was a policy that dare not speak its name, now recognise that an answer has to be found to the English constitutional question: namely, how to govern a country of 50m when the union designed to bind the other nations with England is under increasing strain. The UK is no longer a unified state and England anything but a stable unit.

But ministers have yet to take the logical post-devolution step of addressing how government money should be distributed throughout the UK. The northern fringes of England are getting restless over a formula which seems to discriminate against them in health, education, roads and industrial support. Recognising that passions may soon be running high, Mr Prescott repeated this week that UK funding must be addressed sooner rather than later. Sensibly, he suggested it should be done alongside a forthcoming review of Whitehall's equally complex system for determining how grants are shared among town and county halls - based on a formula, known as the standard spending assessment (SSA). Some think this already discriminates against such counties as Northumberland and northern cities losing population.

The SSA distributes around £50bn and was designed to take account of the differing needs of local areas, compensating some poorer authorities through a variety of weightings. Council officials complain it is often too arbitrary and detailed. Why, for instance - even taking into account London's diverse cultural mix - should spending per pupil in Northumberland secondary schools be £2,159 annually while, in Kensington and Chelsea, it stands at £3,616?

Mr Prescott, who desperately wants to reform council finance, recognises the dilemma. "What has happened is that SSAs have been allowed to continue their disparities because no one wanted to say 'you're going to get more and you're going to get less here'... no one has done anything for years and just let (disparities) grow." His argument is that in reviewing the whole structure of council finance, it makes sense to make the exercise wider and consider funding for the wider regions, and nations of the UK. "What we are developing is the framework of a decentralised UK and the structure within that is becoming reasonably clear," Mr Prescott says. "But we haven't fixed it yet for the English regions and the financial structure, which has to be fair, is a question we haven't started on."

One idea, punted by Blairite town hall reformers, is to fund say education and social services directly from the centre, providing common standards and spending levels, give or take a tweak or two, between Northumberland at one extreme and Kensington on the other (although a centrally funded NHS is still struggling against a postcode lottery to provide national health care standards). That, of course, does not answer the wider UK funding question. On the latest figures the north-east would need an extra £1.1bn a year to catch up with Scottish spending, while Yorkshire - with a similar population to Scotland - would need £5.2bn more and the south-east £12.1bn.

While it is tempting to look north of the border and argue for a redistribution of resources from Scotland to England, the Scots can justly claim that serving a generally sparsely populated country of many diverse regions and three large island groups, with a population concentrated in the Clyde-Forth central belt, does not come cheap. Glasgow, in spite of the Barnett formula and much higher council tax levels than English cities, remains the poorest city in Britain.

Other services, like roads and transport, are clearly more expensive to provide, while water supply has never been privatised in Scotland and requires a hefty dollop from the public purse each year. And if the heat is turned on the Barnett formula, the Scottish lobby has one ace up its sleeve: the billions of pounds annually still flowing from North Sea oil fields to the exchequer. The last thing ministers want is a revival of "it's Scotland's oil" in the run-up to Scottish parliamentary elections in two years' time. So any review of Barnett may have to wait a little longer. Whether that will satisfy a restless English regional lobby is another matter.

webTitle: Confusion rises over cull policy after Phoenix

fields.headline: Confusion rises over cull policy after Phoenix
fields.standfirst:
Agriculture minister says no change over sheep and pigs but vets can spare some cattle

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: There was confusion last night over whether the automatic cull of all animals on farms next to infected premises had been been officially "eased", "refined" or "changed" in the wake of the case of Phoenix, the two-week-old calf spared by Downing Street on Wednesday night.
fields.body:
There was confusion last night over whether the automatic cull of all animals on farms next to infected premises had been been officially "eased", "refined" or "changed" in the wake of the case of Phoenix, the two-week-old calf spared by Downing Street on Wednesday night.

In a statement, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, told parliament that, contrary to reports in yesterday's media, there would be "no change to the policy of culling sheep and pigs", but he said: "Cattle may, however, be spared, if there is adequate biosecurity."

From now on local vets would judge which cows would be excluded from the cull, and would continue to check them regularly for any signs of foot and mouth.

The new instructions were not a "relaxing" of rules but constituted "refinements" to the policy, he said. "These refinements can be expected to provide some relief from automatic slaughter of cattle.

"They will not lead to changes in the policy of culling of pigs and sheep on contiguous premises. We will continue to kill all animals which are dangerous contacts. That will include animals on a significant number of neighbouring farms and beyond."

However, David King, the government's chief scientist, said it did not necessarily mean that more animals would be saved. "It may be about the same. We will spare those animals which have not been exposed to infection." He could not say how many were likely to escape the cull.

He gave a hypothetical case: "If I have a farm where cattle have throughout the period of the disease been kept 200m from the boundary of an infected premises, that farm would be culled. But if those animals had been kept under good biosecurity and far from the boundary, then there would be no need to cull them."

He suggested that increasing opposition to the mass culling policy could prevent the disease, which is still spreading in some areas, from coming under control.

A significant number of vets and farmers are openly resisting the culling of healthy animals, but the Ministry of Agriculture has so far not gone to the courts to insist on entry to farms.

Last night angry vets, farmers and communities opposed to the culling of uninfected animals met in Gloucestershire, where a huge cull of animals between the rivers Severn and Wye is believed to be under consideration by Maff.

"People are determined," said Carol Youngs of the Forest of Dean Action group. "Feeling is running very high. We have messages of support from everywhere."

In all cases where communities or farmers have resisted strongly and worked with solicitors, the ministry has backed down.

Professor King admitted that there had been disagreements within the veterinary profession but said it was vital that vets and farmers should work together. The chief vet, Jim Scudamore, also admitted that there were some areas "where farmers do not want animals culled".

Prof King said two of the three computer models used by the government suggested outbreaks could continue through July and August, even if the culling took place in the recommended time.

In some areas the disease was still spreading, "because the culling policy was not being fully implemented". If the policy was relaxed there could be a second peak later in the year.

Mr Brown said the case for vaccinating cattle in Cumbria and possibly Devon was now accepted by the government but would take place only if the programme was supported by a "substantial majority" of the farming community, vets, the food industry and consumers - which is considered unlikely.

A further four people last night were being tested for foot and mouth disease, bringing the total to seven, including one confirmed case. The public health service laboratory said it would take several days for other results to be released. Foot and mouth is not serious in humans.

Contiguity touches a nerve

Until just the other day, contiguity was not a concept most people spent much time on. They used "near" or "close". If lawyers, they were just as likely to use a term such as adjoin or abut.

Suddenly "contiguous" is on everyone's lips. That is most of all down to Phoenix, the soft-eyed calf which melted the hearts of a nation and by all appearances the heart of the prime minister's press secretary too. Contiguous culling nearly put Phoenix to death. Therefore, contiguity matters.

But what does it mean? It comes from the Latin words which mean: to touch with.

Sometimes when a word enters popular language it lodges there; sometimes it fades away.

Will people cease to refer to "my neighbours" and say "the family that we're contiguous with"? Probably not. Will cricket pundits describe an lbw appeal as "pretty contiguous" instead of "pretty adjacent"? Perhaps. Will civil servants defend some evasive answer on the grounds that what they are saying is "contiguous with the truth"? Very likely.

David McKie

webTitle: Brown not told of reprieve for calf

fields.headline: Brown not told of reprieve for calf
fields.standfirst:
Backlash over calf

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Downing Street was last night forced to mount a damage limitation exercise after it emerged that the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, was not party to the decision to spare Phoenix, the disease-free heifer, from the foot and mouth cull.
fields.body:
Downing Street was last night forced to mount a damage limitation exercise after it emerged that the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, was not party to the decision to spare Phoenix, the disease-free heifer, from the foot and mouth cull.

Officials at No 10 and the Ministry of Agriculture were adamant that scientists rather than spin doctors were responsible for the policy shift - confirmed by Mr Brown yesterday - that eased the automatic cull of animals on neighbouring farms.

But they were unable to explain how tabloid newspapers - which had been highlighting the plight of Phoenix, sole survivor of such a cull in Devon - appeared to know that the calf would be spared.

Mr Brown was forced to concede that he had not been aware that Downing Street was going to announce that Phoenix was to be saved on Wednesday night, just in time for the main 10 o'clock news bulletins. "You say they announced it. I don't know whether it is true or not."

Godric Smith, deputy to Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's press secretary, yesterday stressed that the policy shift had been under discussion among scientists as early as last Friday; it had culminated in a chat between Mr Brown and Mr Blair on Wednesday afternoon.

That version left open the view, widely shared by MPs, that Mr Campbell's eagle eye for a tabloid story ensured that the media was encouraged to jump the gun on Phoenix before the official machine had confirmed the shift.

Downing Street's new chief scientist, Professor David King, who has taken an increasingly prominent media role, said yesterday that he and his committee of scientists and veterinarians advising Nick Brown had been discussing "refinements" of the mass cull policy for two or three weeks.

New information had been gathered which suggested that slight changes to the policy of slaughtering all animals on farms next to infected cases were possible which could spare healthy animals kept in conditions where they did not threaten others.

Professor King said: "Phoenix has nothing to do with this announcement. It was based on independent advice by scientists."

It was confirmed yesterday that four more people are being tested for suspected foot and mouth disease. Three others are already being tested.

fields.headline: Waiting for the man
fields.standfirst:
We still have not got an answer to the big question: will Tony Blair in his second term be less of a chicken?

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: We still have not got an answer to the big question: will Tony Blair in his second term be less of a chicken?
fields.body:
It so happens that the last ordinary citizen to own 10 Downing Street was a Mr Chicken. Maybe his ghost still roosts there, invading the souls of nervy prime ministers from time to time. For the question now is whether Tony Blair in his second term will be more man and less chicken. As the manifesto takes shape with daily morsels released for public delectation, we wait still for a missing clarity of purpose.

His first term saw moments of audacity, followed by rapid retreats, moments of clarity, fogged by third way obfuscation. Some remarkable good was done, but stealthily with a strange dislocation between words and actions, walking and talking in opposite directions. This chicken afraid of his own shadow leaves bemused onlookers wondering what phantoms frighten him that no one else can see. There is still time to seize the day, to be a really great prime minister.

But this week saw a classic display of chicken politics. First the Financial Times was given an exclusive: the manifesto will again pledge no income tax rise in the next parliament, on prime ministerial orders. Read his lips, no increases in the fairest tax, (sotto voce: only unfair taxes by stealth). Within New Labour, the instant response has been extraordinary. I have rarely heard such a loud spontaneous shriek of pain from all round the centre-left, from within the party and from leading left-leaning think-tanks, among all kinds of solid supporters. Even some ministers joined Labour MPs groaning loudly, "Oh no, oh God, surely not again?"

The usual compensatory zigzag came fast - very Blair, very chicken. To balance the FT story, the Guardian and Mirror get an exclusive (sort of) on the new baby bonds - the imaginative plan to give every poor child a trust fund, a slice of capital to send them on their way. It is indeed a good radical step in thinking about the nature of poverty, trying to give poor children some of the same support that middle-class children take for granted, a cushion of £5,000 to £7,000 as a stake in adult life. This idea, vigorously promoted by the Institute for Public Policy Research and the Fabians, has the added advantage of shaking off the Conservatives: Michael Portillo, who has trotted along every step of Labour's spending path, balked at this fence, dismissing it as a "gimmick" he would never implement - a cheap riposte that just leaves the Tories looking mean.

These baby bonds do flag up the government's project to eliminate child poverty. Yesterday the chancellor pledged another million children will be lifted out by 2004, reaching half way towards total abolition, a remarkable endeavour. So why is the war on poverty still not really the true battle hymn of this government? Because they slip out of anything that risks defining them too clearly. For alas, there is no comparison in the defining importance of baby bonds versus a no-income-tax pledge. It is the big figures that tell the long-term story of who and what this government really is and means to be. Baby bonds will cost under £1bn a year, while the 1p the chancellor took off income tax is costing £2.5bn a year.

One Treasury adviser protested vainly, yesterday: "Look, this is not a litmus test". How wrong he is. For many Labour voters, old and new, it is the litmus test. Bribe, cajole and flatter these dithering, non-political, half-hearted dim-wits and Labour can keep the 35 MPs it might otherwise loose. That's what this income tax pledge is designed to do. It denies that this is a disgracefully under-taxed country with multiple scars to prove it. It promises a quality of public service that will never be delivered until there is public consent for paying more. It needs strong leadership now to create enthusiasm for a long spell of social democratic government.

We need progressive government for decades, through persuading people Britain need not be the shabbiest, most despised poor relation in Europe. Minor amelioration is not enough. Clinton's third way changed no hearts and minds, left no lasting monuments. Time and again, Blair ducks the decisive moment, chooses not to choose. One of the essential ingredients for his promised progressive century has to be proportional representation, but he shies off that one too. No prime minister in living memory ever had such luck or such a chance to raise the dismal aspirations of this country permanently. If not now in this manifesto, Mr Chicken, then when?

From Millbank, the answer is deeply depressing - a gramophone record of yesteryear, fighting old elections and dead demons. "New Labour reaches parts of the electorate Labour never reached before. It may kick in at too low a level, but those on over £50,000 and again at over £100,000 should be paying more. The wealth gap widens.

Entering a downturn that might turn nasty, there is nothing prudent about ruling out the most obvious way to pay for unexpected unemployment. The pledge was a fraud last time - tax did rise. Since taxation rose 3% of GDP since 1997, it's time to come clean.

In all this, there is no red thread, no trajectory, no story and no leadership. Local government has just been denied the right to levy a 5% business tax. The tube PPP ploughs on regardless. Mothers probably won't get the right to work part time: not business friendly, but business-terrified. A lot of good had been done, but without coherent political direction, there is no imagery. Even New Labour loyalists are dispirited. They just want their leader to do the right thing for its own sake, because he believes it, even if it's not popular. They know he can - look at Kosovo, Sierra Leone, or indeed child poverty. So why not on tax? There is still time to be a great prime minister. Or will it be Mr Chicken?

webTitle: Townend renews attack on multicultural UK

fields.headline: Townend renews attack on multicultural UK
fields.trailText: William Hague faced embarrassment last night when the rightwing Tory MP John Townend launched a new attack on Britain's multicultural society while the Conservative leader attempted to mend fences with British Asians.
fields.body:
William Hague faced embarrassment last night when the rightwing Tory MP John Townend launched a new attack on Britain's multicultural society while the Conservative leader attempted to mend fences with British Asians.

As Mr Hague toured Bradford, Mr Townend described multiculturalism as a "mistake [that] will inevitably cause great problems".

Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs called on Mr Hague to take the Tory whip from Mr Townend who sparked a furore over race last month when he lavished praise on Enoch Powell's infamous "rivers of blood" speech.

Mr Hague condemned Mr Townend's remarks last night, but refused to take any action against him.

Mr Townend provoked a new row when he released a copy of his letter to the commission for racial equality which outlines the reasons for his refusal to sign an anti-racism pact. Scores of Tory MPs have refused to sign, including the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo.

In a letter to the CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, the MP for Yorkshire East wrote: "I think the CRE causes more racial problems than it solves.

"I believe in individual freedom and in equality before the law. I believe that as a result of some of your activities some people are more equal than others."

In a separate statement, Mr Townend said Britain's ethnic minority communities should abandon their roots.

"This means that certainly from the second generation all immigrants should consider themselves as natives of this island, rather than looking back to a motherland abroad," he said.

Mr Townend also rounded on Robin Cook's "chicken tikka masala" speech, in which the foreign secretary hailed Britain's varied communities. "Presumably he considers us a mongrel race," the MP said.

Mr Hague claimed there was no point in removing the whip from Mr Townend because he was not standing at the election.

The Asian Tory candidates in Bradford, Mohammed Riaz and Zahid Iqbal, were the true representatives of the modern Conservative party.

fields.headline: Thatcherite 'wreckers' accused by Irish PM
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, has accused right-wing Tories of attempting to wreck Ireland after the Thatcherite Bruges group announced plans to raise funds for Irish Eurosceptics.
fields.body:
Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, has accused right-wing Tories of attempting to wreck Ireland after the Thatcherite Bruges group announced plans to raise funds for Irish Eurosceptics.

The group called on members to support Irish Eurosceptics who will be campaigning for a no vote in a referendum next month on the Nice treaty.

"Some in the no camp appear to be willing to accept political and financial support from rightwing Tory Eurosceptics, who certainly have no love of Ireland, and would like nothing better than to wreck our political and economic standing," Mr Ahern said.

Referring to the heroes of the 1916 Easter rising who launched an unsuccessful coup against British rule, the taoiseach added: "As the heirs of Pearse and Connolly and de Valera we have, needless to say, very little in common with those who still hanker after vanished imperial glories in splendid isolation."

The Bruges group, of which Lady Thatcher is honorary president, appealed to members to send money to opponents of the Nice treaty who will be campaigning for a no vote in the referendum on June 7. The treaty lays the basis for expanding the European Union into eastern Europe.

A Bruges group leaflet says: "The Irish are the only people in the EU who are allowed to vote on the Nice treaty. That leaves eight weeks for the people of Ireland to determine the future of Europe." It then gives details of a bank account in Dublin for the National Platform, the most prominent Eurosceptic group in the Irish republic.

The intervention has embarrassed and divided "no" campaigners.

fields.headline: The people's peers: seven knights, a lord's wife and three professors
fields.standfirst:
Selection lacks the common touch

Special report: House of Lords
Special report: Whitehall
fields.trailText: The first list of 15 "people's peers" - a symbol of Tony Blair's commitment to modernise government - was published yesterday amid widespread disappointment at the lack of ordinary members of the public.
fields.body:
The first list of 15 "people's peers" - a symbol of Tony Blair's commitment to modernise government - was published yesterday amid widespread disappointment at the lack of ordinary members of the public.

Among the 11 men and four women selected in the first open contest for membership of the Lords, which attracted more than 3,000 applicants, there are seven knights, the wife of a peer, three professors and two others who had already been honoured.

All but four are in Who's Who. But Lord Stevenson, who chaired the House of Lords appointments commission - made up of four peers and two commoners and intended to replace prime ministerial patronage - said the new peers were all people of outstanding achievement, committed to the work of the Lords, who would feel "comfortable" taking part in debates.

Further questions were raised about Mr Blair's commitment to reform when it was also announced that he was not giving up all patronage. The former chief of the defence staff Sir Charles Guthrie is to become a life peer, following a direct recommendation to the Queen by the prime minister.

The new appointments include the former commissioner of the Metropolitan police Sir Paul Condon, Lady Elspeth Howe, wife of former Tory foreign secretary Lord Howe and a former chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, and Sir David Hannay, Britain's former permanent representative to the UN. Lord Stevenson - an old friend of Peter Mandelson's whose own appointment led to accusations of cronyism - said he did not know what "people's peers" were.

But he insisted all the appointees were exceptional people: "There were a number of people who applied with less obvious highfaluting achievements, some of whom we are taking forward," he said. "You haven't got your hairdresser in this list, but if you go back to our criteria one of them is that the human being will be comfortable operating in the House of Lords."

One union leader, John Edmonds of the GMB - the union which represents hairdressers - said Lord Stevenson should watch his ear lobes next time he was having a hair cut. "The club remains as exclusive as ever. If the House of Lords is going to slam its doors so arrogantly in the face of working people, then the time has come to tear the door off its hinges and bulldoze the building to the ground." Charter 88, the constitutional pressure group, dismissed the appointments as a gimmick to divert attention from proper reform of the Lords.

More than half the 15 were unavailable for comment yesterday. But one of less predictable appointees, Professor Ilora Finlay, a Cardiff-based cancer expert who blew the whistle on the case of a young remand prisoner who received treatement for terminal cancer in shackles, said last night: "I applied because my father always said if you want to change things you have got to get to the top and not lose your ideals on the way."

She said she was very surprised her application had been successful.

The commission spent six months scrutinising the detailed submissions of would-be peers in a six-stage selection process. Although all the successful applicants were self-nominated, invitations were sent to 10,000 organisations to name candidates.

Only a fifth of nominations came from women, and 15% from ethnic minorities. There was a disproportionate number of applicants from London and the south east.

Victor Adebowale, one of the four new peers from an ethnic minority and chief executive of the homelessness charity Centre Point said he had felt grilled in the interview but he would not be intimidated by the Lords.

CVs of the 15 asked to sit in the Lords

Victor Adebowale, 37

Chief executive, Centre Point, member of the New Deal trask force, and the social exclusion unit's policy action team, a board member of Homeless Network - representing all homeless agencies in London - and a member of the left-of-centre think tank Demos's advisory council. Appointed a CBE in last year's New Year's Honours.

Richard Best, 55

Director, Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the leading independent policy forum which focuses on poverty and urban regeneration. Former director of the National Federation of Housing Associations, and also an ex rural commissioner. He was the secretary to the Duke of Edinburgh's inquiry into British housing.

Amir Bhatia, 69

Businessman involved in a wide range of voluntary work. Ex-trustee of Oxfam and the Community Development Foundation, and member of the National Lotteries Charity Board. Co-founded Ethnic Minority Foundation, to promote voluntary effort in ethnic minority communities. Trustee of St Christopher's hospice.

Sir John Browne, 53

Group chief executive of BP Amoco plc, non-executive director of the Intel Corporation and Goldman Sachs. Trustee of the British Museum and vice-president and member of the board of the Prince of Wales business leaders' forum.

Michael Chan, 61

Paediatrician, visiting professor in ethnic health at the University of Liverpool, former director of the NHS ethnic health unit. Awarded MBE for services to the Chinese community. Former member of the Home secretary's standing advisory council on race relations, and former part-time commissioner with the Commission for Racial Equality.

Sir Paul Condon, 54

Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police 1993-2000, chief Constable of Kent 1989-90. Currently in Sri Lanka, he is now director of the anti-corruption unit of the International Cricket Council. Queen's Police Medal, 1989, knighted, 1994

Ilora Finlay, 52

Vice dean, school of medicine, University of Wales, world expert in palliative medicine working with the Velindre Cancer Centre, Cardiff, and Marie Curie cancer care. Alerted the public to prisoners being shackled during cancer treatment. President-elect of the Medical Women's Federation. Former member of the expert advisory group on Cancers, and of National Cancer Forum

Susan Greenfield, 50

Director of the Royal Institution of Great Britain, professor of pharmacology, Oxford. Author of The Private Life of the Brain, and of BBC2 series on the brain and the mind. Committed to "meshing science with society".

Sir David Hannay, 65

Ex diplomat and former permanent representative to the EU and UN. Previously served in the Middle East, Central Asia and North America. Said to have been the model for Sir Humphrey, the masterful permanent secretary in the TV series Yes Minister.

Valerie Howarth, 60

OBE, chief executive of Childline which she built up into a national body. Former director of social services with the London borough of Brent. Set up King's Cross homeless project and the London Homeless Forum. Member of the food standards agency, and the national care standards commission

Lady Elspeth Howe of Aberavon, 69

Deputy chair of Equal Opportunities Commission (1975-79), former president, Federation of Recruitment and Employment Services, board member of Business in the Community, and the Department of Employment's working group on women's issues. Chaired the broadcasting standards commission, 1993-99. Married to Lord Howe of Aberavon, former Tory chancellor and foreign secretary.

Sir Robert May, 65

President of the Royal Society, professor of Zoology jointly at Oxford and Imperial College London. Australian born ex-professor of theoretical physics, he was chief scientific adviser to the government and head of the government office of science and technology from 1995 - 2000. Drew up guidelines on science advice in policy making.

Sir Claus Moser, 78

CBE, chairman of the basic skills agency and the committee on adult literacy. Chancellor of Keele University, ex professor of statistics at LSE and head of government statistical service. Former director of NM Rothschild & Sons, the Economist and warden of Wadham College, Oxford. Presidential address to the British Association for the Advancement of Science led to the establishment of the national education commission in 1990.

Sir Herman Ouseley, 56

Executive chairman and chief executive of the commission for racial equality, 1993-2000. Former chief executive, Lambeth, director of education of Ilea and principal race relations adviser to GLC.

Sir Stewart Sutherland, 60

Vice chancellor of the University of Edinburgh since 1994, chairman of the Royal Institute of Philosophy. Former chancellor of the University of London, member of the higher education funding council. HM inspector of schools, founder of Ofsted 1992-1994. Chaired the royal commission on the long term care of the elderly.

Anne Perkins

Former director of NM Rothschild & Sons, the Economist and warden of Wadham College, Oxford. Presidential address to the British Association for the Advancement of Science led to the establishment of the national education commission in 1990. Sir Herman Ouseley, 56 Executive chairman and chief executive of the commission for racial equality, 1993-2000. Former chief executive, Lambeth, director of education of Ilea and principal race relations adviser to GLC. Sir Stewart Sutherland, 60 Vice chancellor of the University of Edinburgh since 1994, chairman of the Royal Institute of Philosophy. Former chancellor of the University of London, member of the higher education funding council. HM inspector of schools, founder of Ofsted 1992-1994. Chaired the royal commission on the long term care of the elderly. Anne Perkins

webTitle: Comment: Off with their silly titles

fields.headline: Off with their silly titles
fields.trailText: I was reminded of someone when a government body announced yesterday - surely tongue in cheek - that various captains of industry and chief constables are to be installed in the Lords and henceforth considered as "People's Peers".
fields.body:
I was reminded of someone when a government body announced yesterday - surely tongue in cheek - that various captains of industry and chief constables are to be installed in the Lords and henceforth considered as "People's Peers".

The person this reminded me of was a very sensible bloke down in Bristol, a pensions consultant called John Oliver, who has been running for the last few years what he calls his Commoners' Register. The idea is straightforward. He invites members of the escalatingly absurd House of Lords at Westminster to declare that they don't wish to be known any more by foolish and pretentious names. Instead, they will carry on using those they were born with.

He says: "Accepting there is only so much one person without any influence could do, I decided to take a small target, titles. The logic was that titles are symbolic of a social system which can be very offputting for people coming from the wrong side of the tracks... I think I would describe my overall aim at the beginning as helping to move things on to a position where it seems odd to use these 'social' titles in everyday life."

Since he began in the early 1990s, when Noel Annan, former provost of Kings College Cambridge, was first to sign up, Mr Oliver has done well. He now has more than 120 names of peers prepared to be normal. They include our own columnist and former Labour deputy leader Roy Hattersley, former Liberal leader David Steel and the SDP "Baroness" Shirley Williams.

Mr Oliver's initiative seems admirable. So admirable that I think the Guardian opinion pages ought to adopt it. We have already tried it in a quiet way on the comment and letters pages for the past few weeks, and it seems to have worked. Instead of the invented names used by life peers, we have used the phrase "member of the House of Lords" at the end of people's contributions. No one has complained.

After all, there is no longer any rational basis for this theme park "Lord" and "Lady" nomenclature. I really do not see how a former squatter's leader like Steve Bassam kept a straight face when asked by Garter King of Arms, on his receipt of patronage in 1997, what "territorial designation" he cared to be known by.

Bassam, or "Lord" Bassam as he is now apparently content to be referred to, solemnly stated "Brighton" as his territory. As he recalled, it was only when Garter offered to design him a Brightonian heraldic crest for a hefty £3,000, that Bassam halted these Disneyfied proceedings. They did lead to his promotion to an unelected junior ministership in the Home Office, so presumably he thought that all the nonsense was worth it.

The names used to mean something. A feudal magnate in the Middle Ages was a warlord given land by his monarch, which he controlled, along with all its tenants and serfs. Westmorland, Somerset, Northumberland - holders of such sonorously Shakespearian names may have genuinely been lords of all they surveyed.

But then, of course, titles started to be sold for cash, separated from the acres, by hard-up monarchs and corrupt prime ministers. It was when the Macmillan government invented life peers that theme park hokum finally took over. The new fancy placeholders designed themselves silly titles, based on where they were born, where their suburban houses had been erected, or simply where they liked to go on their holidays.

Harold Wilson called himself Lord Wilson of Rievaulx, after a beauty spot in Yorkshire. Ted Short transformed his low birthright of a poxy pair of prole syllables into the resounding (and idiotic) Lord Glenamara. And, to come more up to date, what can one do but laugh at the Earl and Countess of Wessex (or the right pair of counts, as the Sun coarsely describes them)? For there's no such place.

The rows of coat-hangers in the peers' entrance, just to the right of the Commons at Westminster, can keep their dotty labels for all I care - The Lord Cocks of Hartcliffe; The Lord Plummer of St Marylebone; The Lord Archer of Weston-super-Mare. The tail-coated attendants can poker-facedly say "Yes, my Lord?" when approached by, say, Baron Rees-Mogg of Hinton Blewit in the County of Avon, or even Baron Birt of Liverpool.

But there's really no reason why the rest of us should put up with these inventions. To abolish the use of them will be in keeping with the Guardian's republican spirit. And it will be a blessing no longer to have to root around Who's Who in order to distinguish between the remarks of Baroness Young (Janet Young, Tory from Oxford, a bit extreme) and Baroness Young of Old Scone (Barbara Young, health administrator from Perth, head of environment agency, perfectly sensible).

I think we should grow up and refuse to use titles. Do readers agree?

 David Leigh is comment editor of the Guardian

webTitle: Leader: New Lords' appointments not good enough

fields.headline: Lords: business as usual
fields.standfirst:
Appointment is just not good enough

Special report: House of Lords
fields.trailText: Laudable? Most certainly. Diverse? Impressively so. But the people's peers? Absolutely not. The 15 new appointees to the House of Lords are an admirable group of men and women, but tribunes of the people they are not.
fields.body:
Laudable? Most certainly. Diverse? Impressively so. But the people's peers? Absolutely not. The 15 new appointees to the House of Lords are an admirable group of men and women, but tribunes of the people they are not. This, remember, was to be a New Labour innovation for the 21st century: in the modern, meritocratic Britain of Tony Blair, the net would suddenly be cast wider than the old boy clubs of Pall Mall. Bus drivers or head teachers would be coralled into Britain's second chamber to offer their previously wasted wisdom: the body would be a true council of elders, drawing on the expertise and experience of those beyond the great and the good.

So who do we have? Seven of these "people's peers" are already knights, one already a "Lady". They include the chief executive of BP Amoco, Sir John Browne, establishment veteran Sir Claus Moser and the silky former ambassador, Sir David Hannay. Lady Elspeth Howe is among them, along with the former commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, Sir Paul Condon (Labour has apparently forgotten the debate over whether Sir Paul should have resigned for presiding over a force branded "institutionally racist" by Sir William Macpherson after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry). In other words, these are precisely the people who would have been elevated in any routine honours list. Yes, there are some welcome appointments from the ethnic communities. But even they cannot conceal the core message of this list: business as usual.

That is the first disappointment. As the Labour backbencher Gordon Prentice said yesterday - and he is to be applauded for speaking out so forthrightly - it's a "sick joke" to call this bunch "people's peers". The appointments commission which named the lucky 15 says it never used that phrase itself, and you can see why it is unhappy to be reminded of it. But that was the hype, spun by Labour at the time. Back in September, when the scheme was launched, the talk was all of retired dinner ladies and wise old coal miners who might take the place of the hereditary bluebloods exiled by the government's first stage of reform. Ten thousand people sent off for application forms, 2,000 asked to become peers - and look who made the cut. Sir Robert May, the government's former chief scientific adviser! How imaginative of the commissioners to find that unsung, unheralded talent. As Mr Prentice puts it: "There is not a lollipop lady on that list."

There is a lesson here: don't believe the hype. New Labour has a knack for selling plans as bright and shiny reforms, only for the old habits to resurface. The "independent" appointment body was meant to expunge partisanship. But its chairman, Lord Stevenson, has close Labour links and several of the new peers were said to be on previous Labour wishlists. The government has simply found another way to get them in.

Yesterday's news highlights the deep flaw in Labour's entire approach to the second chamber. It says it wants the upper house to be more representative of the wider nation (which this group is not) and to be free of the direct patronage of the prime minister. There is only one way to achieve that goal, no matter how much Labour tries to avoid it. In a democracy, members of parliament have to be elected. The upper house is one half of our legislature; it amends and passes laws of the land. Membership matters too much to be left to a committee of notables. We can argue about the precise mechanism, but the principle is clear. Not selection, but election.

fields.headline: No room for hairdressers in the realm of the peers
fields.standfirst: Special report: House of Lords
fields.trailText: More than 3,100 people applied to become a British peer, and the lucky 15 winners had been picked by the House of Lords appointments commission. It was a public relations disaster.
fields.body:
We gathered in a small room in Westminster to hear the names of the first British peers to have nominated themselves. More than 3,100 people put their names forward, and the lucky 15 winners had been picked by the House of Lords appointments commission. It was a public relations disaster.

I felt sorry for the commission and their chairman, a bouncy character called Lord Stevenson. They clearly thought they had done a spiffy job, and had selected 15 supremely wise, articulate, well-informed, thoughtful people. They seemed hurt and bewildered by the hostility of our questions.

After all, it wasn't their fault that Number 10 had called for a selection of "people's peers", leading us to expect a cross-section of society and a chance for ordinary folk to have their voices heard in parliament - and had also forgotten to tell them that this was meant to be the idea.

(Later, a Downing Street spokesman detached himself from the debacle: "They are people's peers in the sense that they are people who put themselves forward for peerages." So that's all right.)

The 15 names, far from being the kind of folk you might bump into in the bus queue, were the traditional great and the good who've been running this creaky old country for years. But they are more than that: they are the grand and the grandiloquent, the posh and the plutocratic, the nobs and the nabobs; in short, they are the people's panjandrums.

Most are festooned with honours already. Seven have knighthoods. There are MBEs and CBEs in there. They are chairs of this commission and that, professors of the other, members of taskforces, chief executives, diplomats, senior advisers, trustees of Glyndebourne, all inhabitants of that nether world of committees, boards, agencies, foundations, working parties and quangos.

Elspeth Howe, the wife of Sir Geoffrey Howe, is one. So overnight she stops being plain old plebeian Lady Howe, and emerges as the brand-new, ennobled - wait for it - Lady Howe!

I'm afraid my colleagues were rather aghast at all this. Why no ordinary people? we asked. "Um, an ordinary person is in the eye of the beholder," Lord Stevenson said elliptically. Then he started digging his hole.

"It is entirely conceivable that a retired headmaster could be a person of great achievement," he said airily.

Someone asked why he was chairing the commission. "Aren't you a friend of Peter Mandelson?" He admitted this. "But there is nothing political in my relations with Peter Mandelson," he said, as if such a concept were possible. It's like saying there is nothing alcoholic in your friendship with George Best.

I asked if they had not found an application from a thoughtful, well-informed, articulate hairdresser or bus driver. Lord Stevenson resumed digging his hole.

"That is too simpliste," he said in French of a type rarely used by hairdressers or bus drivers. "There are a number of people who applied with, um, um, less obvious, um, high-falutin' achievements. But not, no, you haven't got your hairdresser on the list."

His spade was flying. Clods of earth landed around us. "One criterion is that the human being will be comfortable in the House of Lords. We have to feel comfortable taking part in debates. I'm not ruling out the thought that such a person might be chosen at a later date..."

So that was it. Give the House of Lords to ordinary people and they'd be uncomfortable. They'd probably keep coal in it. We filed out, avoiding eye contact, the commission members apparently unaware that anything they had said was wrong.

webTitle: Leader: Re-examine the role of BBC governors

fields.headline: After Chairman Bland
fields.standfirst:
Re-examine the role of BBC governors
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: What happens to British Telecom is very important for the economy: what happens to the BBC is very important for our cultural life. That is why Sir Christopher Bland's move from one to the other is a big event.
fields.body:
What happens to British Telecom is very important for the economy: what happens to the BBC is very important for our cultural life. That is why Sir Christopher Bland's move from one to the other is a big event.

He is right to carry on with both jobs until after the election since that will help to take the decision out of the party political arena and allow more time to ponder what exactly it is that we require of the BBC's governors in the new multimedia age.

Sir Christopher leaves the BBC with a reputation for being one of the most interventionist chairman in recent memory - which raised a potential conflict of interest between his putative executive role and his constitutional duty as a governor to monitor the executive.

It is easy for cynics to say that he simply presided over the structural revolution of the Birtian era and its reversal under Greg Dyke. He has a lot to answer for, for that discontinuity - but he leaves the BBC as a still formidable player in the new multichannel, digital age and with a website that has been so successful that its commercial rivals have been crying "foul". His boldest move was to insist that Greg Dyke became the new director general against the opposition of some colleagues.

This has - so far - turned out to be an inspired move. If, and it is still an "if", Mr Dyke fulfils his potential, then media historians will look with favour on the Bland regime. Of all the responsibilities the governors have (a list so long and onerous you wonder how they can do it meeting only once a month) none is more important for the operating success of the organisation than appointing the DG.

The most urgent question after the election is who should succeed Sir Christopher. The successful candidate will be required to preserve the BBC's values first as it negotiates its future with a government wanting it to come under a wider multimedia regulatory regime and later when it renegotiates its own charter. During this period it will be competing with hundreds of digital channels, many owned by Rupert Murdoch, and also with the internet as it mutates into a medium for radio and television.

The most obviously qualified candidate is Gavyn Davies. A rich Goldman Sachs economist, he is the sitting vice- chairman of the BBC governors and chaired the government inquiry into the future funding of the BBC in 1999. The problem is that, even though a fiercely independent economist, he is too closely linked to New Labour and Gordon Brown in particular. The Conservatives are bound to complain about this. Their pathetic record in appointing Tories to the BBC when they were in power makes it hard to take their criticisms seriously. But Greg Dyke is also a Labour sympathiser and to have two Labour inclined people running the BBC would not only be rightly controversial but disastrous for the checks and balances within the BBC that the governors are suppose to uphold.

There is no shortage of other candidates including DeAnne Julius, the woman who single handedly took on the suits on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to get interest rates down, Baroness Jay, Liz Forgan, former director of network radio at the BBC, or one of a number of liberal minded Conservatives such as Michael Heseltine and Lord Cranborne.

The new appointment should be combined with a reappraisal of the role of governors. It is no longer possible or desirable that the governors have sole responsibility for regulating the BBC in a multichannel digital age. The BBC is no longer the sole national broadcaster but a major player in a fast moving and very complicated world of interacting new media in which it is important to have a level playing field. In this new world the governors must fight the case for a continuing licence fee against complaints of unfair competition from the Murdoch press (ditto for taking advertising on the BBC's overseas web activities) but they can't expect to be the sole or even the main referee. The role of the governors ought to be more that of a trust dedicated to preserving the soul of the organisation and maintaining its high standards of equity - leaving regulation to a wider body overseeing commercial television, telecommunications and the internet.

Meanwhile, Sir Christopher will need more than luck to revive BT. We welcomed his appointment to the BBC where he already had many of the media skills needed. But the problems at BT, with £30bn of debts, are of a different order of magnitude. Like other former national utilities it has failed to adjust to the new age of wireless and fierce competition. It has failed to produce an international strategy to satisfy the City while at the same time failing to bring its domestic monopoly operations into the 21st century. The first thing Sir Christopher should do is to apply the public service ethos learned at the BBC to force BT to drop its feeble excuses and roll out broadband internet connections to as many homes as possible. That would be a good first step towards restoring BT's long lost reputation as a prime mover in the digital age. But only the first step.

But the problems at BT, with £30bn of debts, are of a different order of magnitude. Like other former national utilities it has failed to adjust to the new age of wireless and fierce competition. It has failed to produce an international strategy to satisfy the City while at the same time failing to bring its domestic monopoly operations into the 21st century. The first thing Sir Christopher should do is to apply the public service ethos learned at the BBC to force BT to drop its feeble excuses and roll out broadband internet connections to as many homes as possible. That would be a good first step towards restoring BT's long lost reputation as a prime mover in the digital age. But only the first step.

webTitle: Pleas for no rush in the search for a successor

fields.headline: Pleas for no rush in the search for a successor
fields.standfirst:
Relationship with Labour seen as vital

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The announcement of Sir Christopher Bland's appointment as chairman of British Telecom met with a mixed reaction from the main political opposition parties yesterday.
fields.body:
The announcement of Sir Christopher Bland's appointment as chairman of British Telecom met with a mixed reaction from the main political opposition parties yesterday.

The Liberal Democrats demanded he resign as BBC chairman immediately while the Conservatives called for the appointment of his successor at the broadcasting corporation to be delayed until after the expected general election in June. "There is a clear conflict of interest," said Norman Baker, culture spokesman for the Liberal Democrats.

"The merging of telecommunications with traditional broadcasting will make the BBC and BT potential competitors. Sir Christopher must resign his position as chair of the board of governors."

But Peter Ainsworth, Tory media spokesman, said the chairmanship of the BBC was such an important post that the search for a replacement should not be rushed.

"It's in everybody's best interests to have an orderly search for a successor, but in any case the appointment should not be made until after the election. The timing isn't ideal, but right before a general election you can't have the BBC without a chairman."

A Downing Street spokeswoman said that the government had been informed in advance of Sir Christopher's decision to join BT and was pleased that he had agreed to stay on at the BBC until a successor had been found.

"Sir Christopher Bland has been a very fine chairman of the BBC and will no doubt make a huge contribution to BT when he takes over as chairman," the spokesman said.

David Docherty, the managing director of broadband at the cable company Telewest who worked under Sir Christopher as BBC deputy director of television until last year, said the move was good news for BT.

"He's a tough, clever, focused guy and that's exactly what BT needs at the moment".

Sir Christopher's departure after about five years as chairman would, he predicted, make a difference to the BBC's relationship with the Labour government. "Whoever comes in will be more of a natural friend of this government, with more natural understanding of what they're about."

Sir Christopher had a prickly relationship with Labour's culture secretary, Chris Smith, but Barry Cox, the deputy chairman of Channel 4 - a former colleague of Sir Christopher's at LWT - said that the BBC chairman had struck the right balance.

"I would argue that the relationship Bland has had with Labour, and the Tories before that, was the proper one. It demonstrated the necessary independence of the BBC. You might not always agree with him, but he did the job that an independent chairman should do."

Baroness Young of Old Scone, the former vice-chairman of the BBC, said Sir Christopher's biggest contribution to the corporation had been securing last year's licence fee settlement.

"He successfully steered the licence fee negotiations with the government and got a pretty good settlement, which meant the BBC could plan for the future," she said.

Good bets in race for chairman

Gavyn Davies, 50, deputy chairman of BBC. Friend of Greg Dyke and Gordon Brown. Chaired independent review panel on BBC funding. With Greg Dyke, a former Labour party member, as director general, his would be a politically sensitive appointment.

Chances: the favourite

Baroness Jay of Paddington, 61, outgoing leader of the House of Lords. As daughter of former prime minister Jim Callaghan, she is Labour aristocracy. If she got job she would join ex-husband Peter, BBC's economics editor.

Chances: good

Lord Bragg, 62, broadcaster. Excellent credentials: lifetime in broadcasting and promoting Labour, friend of Greg Dyke and close to Tony Blair. The ultimate Tony crony.

Chances: good

Liz Forgan, 56, writer and broadcaster. Strong pedigree as former head of BBC network radio and former director of programmes at Channel 4. Could be first woman to chair BBC.

Chances: fair

Lord Stevenson, 55, businessman. As chairman of media group Pearson, which owns FT and has stake in Channel 5, he has good media credentials. Also strong commercial interests - he is chairman of Halifax.

Chances: fair

Michael Heseltine, 68, Tory wet. Inside knowledge of politics and media makes him good candidate, as do Tory leanings.

Chances: worth outside bet

Lord Wakeham, 68, chairman of press complaints commission. A powerful "fixer" under Thatcher and Major and has respect of Blair.

Chances: medium

webTitle: BBC chief to head struggling BT

fields.headline: BBC chief to head struggling BT
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The chairman of the BBC, Sir Christopher Bland, was yesterday handed the task of restoring British Telecom's ailing fortunes after shareholder pressure forced out long serving boss Sir Iain Vallance.
fields.body:
The chairman of the BBC, Sir Christopher Bland, was yesterday handed the task of restoring British Telecom's ailing fortunes after shareholder pressure forced out long serving boss Sir Iain Vallance.

In a deal agreed between the corporation, Number 10 and BT, Sir Christopher will take the chairmanship of the struggling telecommunications giant on Tuesday but will remain at the BBC until a replacement is found.

The arrangement allows the government to delay the politically sensitive BBC appointment until after the general election in June.

Sir Christopher described the job at BT, which is labouring under debts of £30bn, as a "substantial challenge".

"As with other telecoms companies, BT has a languishing share price and there is clearly the debt issue," he said. "But these are addressable and soluble issues. BT has real strengths and talented people and strong technologies and we can build on that."

Senior executives at BT have been under intense pressure to quit as the company's value has fallen by two-thirds in the past 18 months. Sir Peter Bonfield will continue as chief executive.

Sir Iain, who joined BT in 1966 when it was still part of the Post Office, has been a board member since the company was separated out in 1981, and was made chairman in 1987. He has overseen its privatisation and expansion overseas as well as its more recent fall from favour. He will keep the advisory role of "president emeritus" until retiring next year.

He said he had stood down voluntarily but thought the bad publicity surrounding BT made now a good time to go. "It was always going to feel a bit sad. I have been on the board for 20 years but I'm pleased in the sense that we have finally managed to get a very good successor for BT."

Sir Christopher shrugged off criticism that his dual role would cause problems. "Of course there are conflicts of interest but there are trusted mechanisms in place for that," he said. "In my five years at the BBC, nothing involving BT has ever reached the board but if it did then I would simply declare my interest and wouldn't get involved."

Sir Christopher said he had received a phone call from headhunters three weeks ago and had consulted Downing Street and the BBC before making his decision.

"If there are any clashes, [vice chairman] Gavyn Davies has said he will step up and help. If it proves unworkable we will have to do something else. The most straightforward thing would have been to walk out of the BBC at once. But none of us, including Number 10 and William Hague, think that is the right thing."

Mr Davies, who is also deputy governor of the bank of England, is the leading contender to succeed Sir Christopher at the BBC. But his appointment would lead to charges of cronyism particularly because of the Labour credentials of the director general, Greg Dyke.

Mr Dyke said he was relaxed about the move and paid tribute to Sir Christopher, who masterminded his appointment. "The fact that he is able to continue until his successor is appointed is good news for the BBC."

The City welcomed Sir Christopher's appointment. Shares in the company fell, however, as his appointment increased the likelihood of a £5bn rights issue to help pay down BT's debts.

Before joining the BBC, Sir Christopher, 62, had built a broad mix of experience in the commercial and public sectors. He was deputy chairman of the Innner London Education Authority and held the same role at the Independent Television Authority.

He moved on to the board of London Weekend Television and became chairman in 1984 where he first worked with Mr Dyke.

fields.headline: This mollycoddling is unjustified
fields.standfirst:
Vallance glides into retirement

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: As the top brass at BT convene this morning to review the dismal response to the news that the BBC's Sir Christopher Bland is taking over from Sir Iain Vallance as chairman of the directionless telecoms conglomerate, they should start with the statement issued by the organisation yesterday morning.
fields.body:
As the top brass at BT convene this morning to review the dismal response to the news that the BBC's Sir Christopher Bland is taking over from Sir Iain Vallance as chairman of the directionless telecoms conglomerate, they should start with the statement issued by the organisation yesterday morning.

The red-hot clue is sitting there in the second sentence: "Sir Iain will step down as a board director and will remain with BT as president emeritus until July 2002."

To be sure, the man has served his term - 20 years on the BT board. But he really cannot deserve the mollycoddling that this honourary position suggests, coming as it does on top of a £600,000 "terminal bonus" agreed last year and at the end of a part-time job paying £746,000, plus perks.

Forgive the cynicism, but with Sir Iain off the board, outsiders will not automatically get a look at what the ex-chairman is being paid during his last 14 months of consultancy as he glides exquisitely into retirement.

For shareholders and customers alike, the Vallance years have been wasted years.

At home, the company's pole position in its sector was squandered as it pursed a strategy aimed purely at defending its traditional revenue base, rather than developing new areas of the telecoms business with any sort of flair or enthusiasm. It is no exaggeration to state that the latest exhibition of this insular culture - frustrating the roll-out of broadband internet access in order, we assume, to protect its high margin fixed-line voice traffic - has probably caused lasting damage to the UK economy as whole.

Meanwhile, BT's efforts at international expansion have proved chaotic and costly, and there is every expectation that the next set of figures will show Sir Iain's personal favourite venture - the Concert alliance with America's AT&T, serving international corporate customers - withering on its virtual vine.

Some 17 years on from the initial privatisation, this key British company is reduced to trying to stave off its bankers by pawning its fleet of vans.

Of course, we have all known for many months just how bad the numbers are at BT. And Sir Christopher can assure himself that the 6% drop in BT's share price yesterday did not reflect a City view that he will be 6% worse at the job than Sir Iain; the new man at the top simply brings the rescue rights issue into view, which is something that no trader could resist selling into.

But in trying to effect a soft succession, fuelling suspicions of corporate old-boyism in the process, Sir Christopher risks throwing away the one thing this company so desperately needs: a culture of change.

Shire story

If Shire Pharmaceuticals' merger with BioChem Pharma was a novel, it would be a door-stopper. The deal was delayed again yesterday, and Shire's lugubrious chief executive Rolf Stahel was even less chatty than usual about the reasons.

Shire will only say that it is still negotiating over the deal with the Canadian government. The assumption is that these talks concern pledges for jobs in Quebec, but it is hard to see how such an issue can take five months to resolve.

Arbitrage dealers suspect a hidden agenda. They are deliberately depressing Shire's shares to ensure it issues more stock for BioChem. The longer the deal takes, the more arbitrageurs will lose patience, close their positions and drift away, thus allowing the shares to creep back up. Arbitrageurs can be viewed as parasites or as wealth creators who aid liquidity. Mr Stahelis likely to take the former view.

If there is a good reason why the merger has been delayed, Shire and Canada's industry minister, Brian Tobin, should tell us. If not, it is hard to escape the view that Mr Stahel and Mr Tobin are prolonging talks as much as possible. That way, Shire's shareholders suffer less dilution and Mr Tobin looks tough when he stands for re-election.

Hard talk

Agreeing the terms of any "merger" is never easy, particularly when the talks have been leaked. But the problems facing Halifax and Bank of Scotland are more difficult than most, given national sentiment and the unusual status enjoyed by BoS. This is not just symbolic but also structural, as the Edinburgh-based firm is not a conventional plc but founded by a special charter.

None of this will ease the decision of where to locate the headquarters of any combined bank, especially as Halifax is important to the Yorkshire town.

James Crosby, the Yorkshireman running the Halifax, and his Scottish chairman, Lord Stevenson, are more aware than most of the sensitivities. They will be trying to gauge whether registered office status - good enough for Lloyds TSB - will appease the Scots.

webTitle: Britain's secrets act goes on trial with Shayler

fields.headline: Britain's secrets act goes on trial with Shayler
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Serving or former members of MI5 commit a crime if they disclose any wrongdoing by the security and intelligence agencies to the media, the chief prosecutor in the David Shayler secrets case maintained yesterday.
fields.body:
Serving or former members of MI5 commit a crime if they disclose any wrongdoing by the security and intelligence agencies to the media, the chief prosecutor in the David Shayler secrets case maintained yesterday.

The Official Secrets Act did not allow them to argue they revealed the information in the public interest, argued Nigel Sweeney QC.

He was opening a pre-trial hearing at the high court where lawyers for the former MI5 officer will mount an unprecedented challenge to the secrets act. They argue it is incompatible with Britain's new Human Rights Act which entrenches in British law the European Convention on Human Rights, and so enshrines the principle of freedom of speech.

It is the first time such a challenge has been made in the courts in Britain. Mr Sweeney acknowledged the signficance of the case, telling the judge, Alan Moses, that the court had a "vital decision" to make. Secrecy was essential to MI5 in its task in defence of the realm and "all our liberties", he insisted.

He pointed out that the secrets act imposed a blanket duty of silence. Information about the security and intelligence agencies could be disclosed only with "lawful authority" - in other words, only with "official authorisation".

If former or serving members of the security and intelligence agencies wanted to complain about the agencies' activities, they could report their concerns to their superiors, a staff counsellor, a complaints tribunal, the police, or even a minister, said Mr Sweeney.

Mr Justice Moses intervened to say agency staff might want to go to "somebody who is going to listen rather than someone who might be tainted - someone with independence of mind, a wise old bird with no ambitions".

Mr Sweeney earlier told the court that it was "preposterous" if the effect of the Human Rights Act was to make the criminal trial a "voyage of discovery" into untested realms of the law. The Official Secrets Act was "plainly compatible" with the Human Rights Act.

The defence insists it is for the jury, not the judge in these pre-trial hearings, to decide on the adequacy of the complaints procedures now in place.

It also argues it is for the jury to decide whether the criminal sanctions imposed by the secrets act meet the "proportionality" test used by the European court of human rights, as well as that court's other key criterion - whether the criminal sanctions are "necessary in a democratic society".

The defence argues that the secrets act can apply only to "lawful" activities of the security and intelligence agencies, although the statute does not include the term lawful.

The absolute offences laid down in the secrets act are a "disproportionate response" to a disclosure made in the public interest, the defence claims.

At stake in the pre-trial hearing, which continues today, is the credibility of the secrets act. If Mr Shayler cannot be prosecuted under this act, say Whitehall officials, there is little point in it.

Whoever loses as a result of Mr Moses' ruling is expected to appeal, leading to a delay in the trial almost certainly until after the general election. Before yesterday's high court hearing, Mr Shayler, 35, claimed that his case would "put the British state on trial". He added: "They have chosen who to prosecute and who not to prosecute. It is totally arbitrary rule of law."

Mr Shayler continued: "We plan to subpoena Jack Straw and Robin Cook [the home and foreign secretaries] and it is quite obvious they don't want to answer questions in open court right before an election."

Mr Shayler is charged with disclosing documents in 1997 to the Mail on Sunday newspaper, which published articles revealing that MI5 kept files on Labour ministers and rock bands, alleging incompetence within MI5, and disclosing how MI5 tapped phones and intercepted post.

He is supported by the National Union of Journalists, whose members carried placards outside the court reading "Blow that Whistle" and "Scrap the Official Secrets Act".

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Following our report on the Foreign Office co-sponsoring an anti-Cuba resolution at the UN human rights commission (to propel Mr Tony yet further through the White House tradesman's entrance), we see more evidence of absurd anti-Fidelism.
fields.body:
 Following our report on the Foreign Office co-sponsoring an anti-Cuba resolution at the UN human rights commission (to propel Mr Tony yet further through the White House tradesman's entrance), we see more evidence of absurd anti-Fidelism.

Last month, after Nick Brown appealed for international help with foot and mouth, the Cuban ambassador wrote offering a veterinary team for free. In the Commons on Wednesday, when John Redwood naughtily asked Mr T if he could define "an economic bust", Mingin' repeatedly shouted "32D! 32D!"
