fields.headline: Too clever for their own good
fields.standfirst: There's no room in boring Britain for old-fashioned polymaths
fields.trailText: There's no room in boring Britain for old-fashioned polymaths.
fields.body:
"You and this city - may fate be merciful to you both and may you remember me with pleasure when I am dead." The words of Sophocles' Oedipus came easily to Giuseppe Sinopoli when he addressed Berlin and its opera house on his return to the city earlier this year. He was a true polymath. On Monday, the day of his funeral, he was due to be in Rome to receive a degree in Egyptology. But he was also a novelist, the author of a thesis on anthropology and an expert on criminal psychiatry, as well as a composer. Like an earlier Sicilian, the ruler Frederick II in the 13th century, Sinopoli could boast of Stupor Mundi status.

A wonder, certainly, in Vienna, Bayreuth and Munich. But in London's musical world Sinopoli was a more awkward figure. He once called Britain an "arrogant and miserable place". And his habit of on-the-wing intellectualising, of mini-lectures on the psychology and history of music in mid-rehearsal, was here regarded as at best eccentric and at worst an obstacle.

But Sinopoli's challenge poses a question beyond the confines of music. Why in boring Britain is the polymath regarded with such suspicion - as a flamboyant figure whose showiness conceals fraudulence - while the European cultural tradition continues to breed the genius who has depth as well as breadth?

Britain's culture has become an affair of specialists - of people who know one thing and won't put heads above parapets for fear of offending other authorities. This is the country where that deadliest of specialists, the manager, has spread its tentacles furthest. There's a neat irony about the way in which a proudly empirical country has embraced a theory quite so unconsciously. The problem after all with being innocent of theory is that you tend not to notice when one big theory has got you in its grip.

In our literature there's an envious suspicion of figures who think that art is parasitic on experience, and that curiosity should therefore be boundless. How could Anthony Burgess, so runs the complaint, manage to be simultaneously a novelist, composer and first-rate linguist? Nicholas Moseley has written some of the best post-1945 novels - but he is consistently under-estimated since his idiom is that of European fiction drawing on ideas in science and philosophy. At the same time, to question the genius of Martin Amis, writing pyro-technically from within an enclosed and rather parochial Anglo-American literary tradition, is to question the authority of holy writ.

When it comes to remedies for specialism, complaints about school are par for the course around the dinner-table. And there is admittedly something rather bracing about the sight, by contrast, of all those French 16-year-olds mugging up on Aristotle and Descartes. Philosophy in the Bacc does make for a better class of name-dropping conversation.

But at least old style A-levels meant that you knew about more than one subject and in some depth. The suspicion about AS-levels - an attempt at imitating the Euro-baccalaureat - is that like most such British attempts at Euro-imitation the real thing will get lost in translation.

The point about the Sinopoli style was that it was genuinely expert in more than one area - something which British culture now finds impossible to accept. This is really "professionalism" as an excuse for mediocrity. It wasn't always so.

In politics we once had prime ministers who wrote literary criticism and philosophy. Gladstone on Homer was enthusiastic if daft. Balfour on scepticism was "professional" but readable. Now we just have Tony Blair, spinning for Thomism, declaring himself recently for natural law and against utilitarianism. Somehow it just isn't the same.

The lament that there's just too much of this knowledge stuff around is unconvincing. Every age persuades itself that it is experiencing a growth in knowledge different in kind from the past. The Victorians felt like that about natural science. It didn't stop them from generating an appetite for wide-spread enquiry beyond the specialisms. But Britain's knowledge merchants are so impressed by the communication revolution that they've just stopped communicating.

Universities - not schools - are at the heart of our problem. For the truth of the matter is that they are full of academics who are not particularly intellectual - who diminish a subject by being incurious about the links between the disciplines. The university of his home town should have honoured Clive James decades since - and has always been sniffy about George Steiner, our most invigorating polymath. But Cambridge's chronic empiricism is really just another version of scholasticism. That arid, dry-as-dust doctrine is a peculiar and very British disease which dumps the pretentious and the exciting in one disabling, procrustean, category: Pseuds' corner.

Beyond the self-imposed British boundaries which stifle, Sinopoli will be remembered with both sorrow and joy as the mind which defied the tyranny of the conventional. Peace be to his shade.

webTitle: It looks like bad timing for Blair

fields.headline: It looks like bad timing for Blair
fields.standfirst:
Satire on New Labour transfers to the West End, just in time for the election campaign

Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: I knew there was a reason why Tony Blair should not have postponed the general election and last night I met it. Alistair Beaton's play, Feelgood, has transferred from provincial Hampstead to the West End stage where it stands in danger of being seen by what its cast of New Labour apparatchiks would call ordinary voters.
fields.body:
I knew there was a reason why Tony Blair should not have postponed the general election and last night I met it. Alistair Beaton's play, Feelgood, has transferred from provincial Hampstead to the West End stage where it stands in danger of being seen by what its cast of New Labour apparatchiks would call ordinary voters.

This will not be good for the prime minister's ongoing project. Mr Blair will hate it. I liked it. My neighbour in the stalls, a distinguished comedienne, was distinctly cool. You just might just love it and vote Green.

But enough about you. I was dispatched to the Garrick theatre, not as some cut-price Michael Billington offering my sensitive views on the actors performances (they all seemed fine to me), but as a bit of rough trade whose daily insights allow him to judge whether Feelgood is true to life.

Of course it isn't! By sheer bad luck I saw the real prime minister and three of his senior colleagues at close quarter yesterday. Apart from jockeying for best soundbite they were all being horribly sincere. The play is much funnier.

Eddie, main protagonist and No 10 press secretary, is a monster, and, as played by Henry Goodman, more a cockney Robert di Niro than Alastair Campbell, brutal and manipulative way beyond his fellow teetotaller's range. For example, no one has yet accused Ally of murder even to supress a story. Peter Capaldi plays Paul, struggling to write the leader's conference speech. He could be one of half a dozen Downing Street thrusters except they'd have sacked him by now. Asha (Amita Dhiri) is clearly the Anji Hunter figure fretting about the PM's photo-ops. Nigel Planer's foppish George is a brilliant mickey-take on Lord Charlie Falconer, Blair's ex-flatmate. Except that they aren't a bit like them. Of course. What we are offered is a mixture of familiar farce and equally familiar political satire, jaded enough to match the spirit of the times, though some members of the audience gasped at what I felt were routine acts of cynicism.

Yet the play ends on a serious note, Jonathan Cullen's cruelly effective parody of a Blair conference speech, fake mateyness, empty phrasing, sinisterly authoritarian in intent. It left me looking forward to the real thing even less than usual.

fields.headline: Greek left offers poll help
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Labour has called in an overseas sister socialist party to galvanise support among Greek Cypriots to try to keep a string of former Tory north London seats - including that won from Michael Portillo.
fields.body:
Labour has called in an overseas sister socialist party to galvanise support among Greek Cypriots to try to keep a string of former Tory north London seats - including that won from Michael Portillo.

Pasok, the Greek ruling Socialist party, has agreed to donate staff and organise meetings in north London during the election campaign to persuade the Greek Cypriot minority to stick with Labour.

The deal was reached this week between Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, and Costas Skandalides, general secretary of Pasok, after their crucial help in Labour's last victory. Mr Skandalides came to London to organise the support.

"We are offering donations in kind rather than money," Mr Skandalides told the Guardian. "Last time we were able to organise meetings and distribute leaflets among the Greek community, particularly in north London."

The seats include Mr Portillo's old seat of Enfield, Southgate, won by Stephen Twigg with a majority of 1,433; Finchley and Golders Green, won by Rudi Vis, with a majority of 3,189; Hendon won by Andrew Dismore, with a majority of 6,155; Enfield North, won by Joan Ryan, with a majority of 6,822; and Edmonton won by Andrew Love with a majority of 13,472.

All have substantial Greek and Greek Cypriot populations in their areas. Some MPs, such as Mr Dismore, with 8,000 Greek Cypriots, have areas where the number of Cypriots is greater than the majority gained at the last election.

The MPs have taken regular trips to Cyprus in their parliamentary role, and they support the Greek Cypriot and Greek government line on the wish to reunify the island.

fields.headline: Lords: business as usual
fields.standfirst: Laudable? Most certainly. Diverse? Impressively so. But the people's peers? Absolutely not. The 15 new appointees to the House of Lords are an admirable group of men and women, but tribunes of the people they are not.
fields.trailText: Laudable? Most certainly. Diverse? Impressively so. But the people's peers? Absolutely not. The 15 new appointees to the House of Lords are an admirable group of men and women, but tribunes of the people they are not.
fields.body:
Laudable? Most certainly. Diverse? Impressively so. But the people's peers? Absolutely not. The 15 new appointees to the House of Lords are an admirable group of men and women, but tribunes of the people they are not. This, remember, was to be a New Labour innovation for the 21st century: in the modern, meritocratic Britain of Tony Blair, the net would suddenly be cast wider than the old boy clubs of Pall Mall. Bus drivers or head teachers would be coralled into Britain's second chamber to offer their previously wasted wisdom: the body would be a true council of elders, drawing on the expertise and experience of those beyond the great and the good.

So who do we have? Seven of these "people's peers" are already knights, one already a "Lady". They include the chief executive of BP Amoco, Sir John Browne, establishment veteran Sir Claus Moser and the silky former ambassador, Sir David Hannay. Lady Elspeth Howe is among them, along with the former commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, Sir Paul Condon (Labour has apparently forgotten the debate over whether Sir Paul should have resigned for presiding over a force branded "institutionally racist" by Sir William Macpherson after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry). In other words, these are precisely the people who would have been elevated in any routine honours list. Yes, there are some welcome appointments from the ethnic communities. But even they cannot conceal the core message of this list: business as usual.

That is the first disappointment. As the Labour backbencher Gordon Prentice said yesterday - and he is to be applauded for speaking out so forthrightly - it's a "sick joke" to call this bunch "people's peers". The appointments commission which named the lucky 15 says it never used that phrase itself, and you can see why it is unhappy to be reminded of it. But that was the hype, spun by Labour at the time. Back in September, when the scheme was launched, the talk was all of retired dinner ladies and wise old coal miners who might take the place of the hereditary bluebloods exiled by the government's first stage of reform. Ten thousand people sent off for application forms, 2,000 asked to become peers - and look who made the cut. Sir Robert May, the government's former chief scientific adviser! How imaginative of the commissioners to find that unsung, unheralded talent. As Mr Prentice puts it: "There is not a lollipop lady on that list."

There is a lesson here: don't believe the hype. New Labour has a knack for selling plans as bright and shiny reforms, only for the old habits to resurface. The "independent" appointment body was meant to expunge partisanship. But its chairman, Lord Stevenson, has close Labour links and several of the new peers were said to be on previous Labour wishlists. The government has simply found another way to get them in.

Yesterday's news highlights the deep flaw in Labour's entire approach to the second chamber. It says it wants the upper house to be more representative of the wider nation (which this group is not) and to be free of the direct patronage of the prime minister. There is only one way to achieve that goal, no matter how much Labour tries to avoid it. In a democracy, members of parliament have to be elected. The upper house is one half of our legislature; it amends and passes laws of the land. Membership matters too much to be left to a committee of notables. We can argue about the precise mechanism, but the principle is clear. Not selection, but election.

webTitle: Protests at birth of baby bonds

fields.headline: Protests at birth of baby bonds
fields.trailText: The government's ambitious plans to spread wealth throughout society via "baby bond" trust funds generated instant controversy yesterday as radicals protested that the scheme did not go far enough while Conservatives dismissed it as "frankly insulting" to the nation's poor.
fields.body:
The government's ambitious plans to spread wealth throughout society via "baby bond" trust funds generated instant controversy yesterday as radicals protested that the scheme did not go far enough while Conservatives dismissed it as "frankly insulting" to the nation's poor.

Tony Blair lined up three of his cabinet colleagues for a Downing Street press conference to launch what will - if implemented after the coming general election and widespread consultation - be one of Labour's most far-sighted and idealistic proposals.

It seeks to ensure that every child enjoys the benefits of savings and inheritance that middle and upper class families take for granted: by introducing both tax free bonds for newborns, which would be topped up over 18 or 21 years to maturity, and a "savings gateway" account - in which government would match individual savings pound for pound.

Mr Blair presented the scheme as the fourth strand of Labour's post-1997 welfare reforms after improving skills and job opportunities; raising living standards for the worst off; and modernising public services. He called it "more people getting the benefit of assets and savings."

Mr Blair said it was a "financial springboard" to a meritocratic society - where people had a fair chance to exercise their talents.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, who hopes to announce the full scheme in his 2002 budget, said it opened "saving and wealth ownership to all".

But the education and employment secretary, David Blunket, grabbed the day's snappiest soundbite after expressing his wish to restore the old working class habits of thrift, reliance and mutual support - embodied through friendly societies and the co-op movement.

"We are replacing 'on your bike' with 'on your tandem'," he said - with the government helping individuals from the back seat.

As reported in yesterday's Guardian the scheme would, subject to detailed discussion with interested parties, provide the New Labour equivalent of a "trust fund babe". Every child born after an agreed date, not before April 2003 at the earliest, would get £500 at birth, topped up with an extra £100 at five, 11 and 16.

The children of better-off families would get half that sum, though ministers are said to believe that making it payable universally is the safest way to protect the scheme from being abolished when the Conservatives next win power.

Yesterday the rightwing Adam Smith Institute claimed authorship of the idea, as did the Fabian Society and the IPPR think tanks on the left. But the left fears that the right will seek to gut the scheme or use it to substitute for existing welfare benefits - most obviously for student loans which many 18-year-olds would be seeking just as their funds mature.

The £800 version alone would generate £1,600 in real terms by the age of 18, though a modest family top-up of £5 a month - from parents, uncles or grandparents - plus interest could more than double it. Mr Blair sees it as a down payment on a mortgage, a business or training.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, later stressed that - as with pensions and Isa savings rules - the system would be policed to prevent abuse of tax-free benefits, though policy-makers admit it will be hard to enforce once the money becomes payable.

The savings gateway would allow parents who put aside a modest amount - say £25 a month - to have their funds matched by the government up to a time limit of 3-4 years and a capped total.

The idea is that the scheme dovetails with Isas and stakeholder pensions - which ministers are also keen to encourage among the lower-paid as part of a "savings" culture.

Poverty lobbyists welcomed the plan as a bold first step, though some would like the £1bn it will cost - Mr Brown refused to provide a figure - spent on more urgent poverty via the social fund.

Ministers say it is establishing a principle. But the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said it was giving back to poor people a portion of the extra taxes they have paid - and it was "frankly insulting" to expect them to be grateful.

fields.headline: Bulger killer 'mollycoddled'
fields.trailText: The mother of murdered toddler James Bulger has accused social workers of mollycoddling her son's killers after it emerged that one of them had been allowed to watch Manchester United play as part of his rehabilitation into the community.
fields.body:
The mother of murdered toddler James Bulger has accused social workers of mollycoddling her son's killers after it emerged that one of them had been allowed to watch Manchester United play as part of his rehabilitation into the community.

Jon Venables, 18, has reportedly travelled to Old Trafford several times with his father in preparation for his release from secure accommodation. They were accompanied by two members of staff from the unit.

He also allegedly plays five-a-side football once a week against schoolboys who do not know his true identity. A carer from the secure unit where he is detained claimed that he had been treated with favouritism.

"It made me sick to see how many privileges he was given, like he was some kind of VIP," he said. "Venables had a PlayStation 2 for Christmas, when millions of kids went without."

No one at Manchester United would comment about claims that Venables had attended its matches. A club spokesman said nobody knew of his visits and they did not give tickets to social services.

Venables's solicitor, John Dickinson, said: "In any child who is detained for a lengthy period of time then, subject to risk assessment, rehabilitation includes leaving the unit." He said he could not comment on whether his client had been taken to watch football games.

James Bulger's mother Denise Fergus, who lives in Kirkby, Merseyside, said she felt Venables was being mollycoddled: "I am not surprised that social workers are prepared to do almost anything Venables wants. Both [Robert] Thompson and Venables have always been mollycoddled and given special privileges ever since they were put in care.

"It makes me very angry because it shows that they have never been punished - all they had is rewards for murdering my son."

She claimed Venables had some kind of hold over most of the staff there.

Her two-year-old son was abducted by Venables and Thompson from a shopping centre in Bootle in 1993 and murdered.

This year it emerged that Thompson had made supervised visits to the Trafford Centre in Manchester. It is understood that Venables has also visited the shopping mall and the Meadowhall centre in Sheffield.

Sean Sexton, the solicitor representing Ms Fergus, said the problem about Venables and Thompson's new identities was that no one else knew who they were dealing with. "If they are released he could be playing football or drinking next to you in a pub," he said.

webTitle: Ex-LWT chief who landed the goods

fields.headline: Ex-LWT chief who landed the goods
fields.standfirst:
Handling of hostile takeover impressed City

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Comment: Paul Murphy on the payoff Sir Christopher Bland received when, as chief executive of LWT, he agreed to sell the London Weekend franchise to Granada.
fields.body:
He referred to it at the time as "go-to-hell money" - the payoff Sir Christopher Bland received seven years ago when, as chief executive of LWT he agreed to sell the London Weekend Television franchise to its bigger rival, Granada.

His shareholding amounted to a cool £14m. But while the LWT windfall, which extended to a number of Sir Christopher's boardroom colleagues at the time, including the BBC's director general Greg Dyke, provoked squeals of jealousy elsewhere in the world of media, the reaction in the City was altogether more supportive.

Sir Christopher was judged to have landed the goods. In the space of three months, as the LWT board embarked on a fierce resistance to Granada's hostile takeover plan, only to capitulate once the money on offer became irresistible, shares in the television company rocketed 40%, dragging other media stocks higher in their wake.

Sir Christopher, who aborted an early political career as a GLC councillor and made his first fortune turning round a near-bankrupt firm of printers with £20,000 of his own savings, had come of age in the eyes of the Square Mile's pension and insurance fund managers.

At LWT Sir Christopher was seen to have led a dynamic business, packed with talent, albeit a relatively small company focused on one core product. But it was his handling of the Granada attack and the grace with which he finally conceded defeat that convinced many in the City that he would move on to a bigger stage in the world of business.

At the time, Sir Christopher had a small collection of outside directorships, such as the chairmanship of a laboratory equipment group, Life Sciences International, and there was surprise in the City when, in 1996, he decided to set all this aside and accept the chairmanship of the BBC, paying £82,000 at the last count.

The big unknown now is whether five years at the helm of a public sector institution - undeniably complex, but still buffered from the harsh forces of true commercialism - will prove an adequate stepping stone between the hothouse of LWT and the international hi-tech conglomerate BT.

"It is difficult to avoid scepticism," one fund manager with a large shareholding in BT said. "BT needs a visionary rather than a corporation man. The assumption, the hope, is that the visionary bit comes in the form of Bland finding a new chief executive [to replace the current incumbent, Sir Peter Bonfield]. Either that, or he may have to fall back on his old skills of mounting a defence against a hostile takeover."

Others were more charitable. One investment banker said: "This is a first step, overdue, but welcome nevertheless. Reform of the BBC required tact as much as toughness and quite a bit of political nous. Those qualities will not go amiss at BT."

webTitle: UK viewers to see US Weakest Link

fields.headline: UK viewers to see US Weakest Link
fields.trailText:
8.30am: British audiences are to get the chance to watch Anne Robinson humiliate her US contestants, writes Ashley Davies.
26.04.2001: NBC orders more Weakest Link
24.04.2001: Robinson's racism cranks up BBC complaints
10.03.2001: Welsh say Robinson is weakest link
fields.body:
British audiences are to get a chance to watch Anne Robinson humiliate her American Weakest Link contestants.

From next Friday, BBC1 will start showing the whole of the US series in an afternoon slot.

A BBC spokesman said: "The show's been phenomenally successful in the US. This is a good opportunity to show it to the audience here."

Meanwhile, the BBC has decided to go ahead with a second home-made series of the Weakest Link.

More than 100 new episodes will be made for the daytime and peaktime versions.

They will be screened in the autumn.

fields.headline: Hyland drops showbiz column
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Sunday Mirror's showbusiness writer is to concentrate on TV reviews and celebrity interviews, writes Jessica Hodgson.
26.04.2001: Buckley joins Sunday Mirror
25.04.2001: PCC backs complaint against Sunday Mirror
18.04.2001: Kelly expected to replace Weaver
12.04.2001: Tina weaves her way to the top
12.04.2001: Myler quits as Sunday Mirror editor
fields.body:
The Sunday Mirror's showbusiness writer, Ian Hyland, is to drop his weekly column to concentrate on TV reviews and celebrity interviews.

The move is the second major change to be made by Tina Weaver, the former deputy of the Mirror, who last week replaced Colin Myler as editor of the Sunday paper.

Ms Weaver is keen to stamp her personality on the Sunday Mirror.

However, she will be working closely with the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, to introduce a more co-ordinated editorial strategy.

Mr Hyland picked up a Princess Margaret award earlier this week for Best Showbusiness Vendetta, honouring his long-running campaign against Victoria Beckham.

In his Sunday Mirror column - which he has written for three years - he claimed Ms Beckham wore a wig on stage and that she had agreed to pose nude in Playboy with her husband.

But Mr Hyland is believed to have grown tired of the column and is looking forward to writing more celebrity interviews.

Last week he interviewed the acid-tongued Anne Robinson.

fields.headline: WPP moves into contract publishing
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Advertising giant WPP and Forbes are to form a global contract publishing venture, reports Claire Cozens.
26.04.2001: WPP results spark slowdown fears
fields.body:
WPP, the advertising and marketing group, is linking up with the US publishing giant, Forbes, to set up a contract publishing venture.

The new operation, called Custom Media Group, will produce magazines, newsletters, annual reports and websites for companies seeking an alternative to traditional advertising.

Sir Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP, described contract publishing as "a half-way house between editorial content and advertising," adding: "The point is to build a relationship over time with the consumer and this is just one of the weapons in the arsenal."

Custom Media Group will target existing WPP clients and the company says it hopes to have news of new projects within the next few months.

fields.headline: Channel 4 invests in breasts
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A woman is to be given large, fake breasts as part of an experimental documentary series, writes Ashley Davies.
25.04.2001: Channel 4 unleashes the Estate Agents
23.04.2001: Channel 4's sitcom pledge
fields.body:
A woman is to be given large, fake breasts, courtesy of Channel 4, as part of an experimental documentary series.

The programme aims to find out whether the "grass is greener" for people who yearn to change something in their lives.

The woman will be fitted with a prosthesis to make her new chest look as realistic as possible.

Other people who feel their lives could be improved in different ways will be given the chance to find out whether the reality lives up to their expectations.

Some will be allowed to live in the countryside, some will get to run a bed and breakfast and one will get a dog.

Other ideas are being considered.

The series, So you Think you Want..., is being made by the Liverpool-based production company, Planet Wild.

It will air in the autumn.

fields.headline: Elstein lambasts Channel 4
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The former Channel 5 chief accused C4's non-executive directors of 'losing the plot', writes Jason Deans.
23.04.2001: Viewers lose their right to reply
18.04.2001: C4 has moved on, says Jackson
17.04.2001: Elstein leads digital initiative
fields.body:
Former TV luminary David Elstein has slated Channel 4, describing it as a "runaway train" in which the non-executive directors "have lost the plot".

The recently dispatched chief executive of Channel 5 laid into Channel 4 at the Royal Television Society's monthly dinner, saying the broadcaster had "far more money than it needs".

"Its revenues exceed its programme budget by £250m a year," he said.

"Last year, it increased its overhead cost by 30% and its staff numbers by 20%.

"It pays spectacular wages and offers state-of-the-art perks. Basically it's a runaway train where the non-executive directors seem to have lost the plot."

According to the last published accounts chief executive Michael Jackson takes home £494,000 a year - the figure is expected to rise significantly next week when its latest accounts are published.

Viewers could no longer access Right to Reply to "protest at the scale of waste and self indulgence at this publicly owned corporation" because the show had been axed, Mr Elstein noted.

"So much for accountability," he added.

Channel 4 executives "piously tell us privatisation would cut off innovation and risk investment", Mr Elstein said.

"Some might say shareholder discipline is just what is lacking at Channel 4 - and every privately owned company in the creative business spends its entire time taking risks."

But Channel 4 would not have to be privatised to cut out the waste, according to Mr Elstein.

"Just charge it £140m a year for its frequencies. That way, the intentions of the 1990 Broadcasting Act - whereby part of Channel 4's surplus would revert to the Treasury - would at last be achieved.

"And the vast sums spent on dodgy propositions like FilmFour, E4 and the Horseracing Channel - not much connection there with public service broadcasting - could be diverted to schools, hospitals and the arts," he concluded.

webTitle: Straw braves animal militants in lab visit

fields.headline: Straw braves animal militants in lab visit
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday staged a symbolic visit to Huntingdon Life Sciences, the embattled animal testing laboratory in Cambridgeshire, to tell voters that the lab's staff deserved applause, not abuse.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday staged a symbolic visit to Huntingdon Life Sciences, the embattled animal testing laboratory in Cambridgeshire, to tell voters that the lab's staff deserved applause, not abuse.

The home secretary's visit came as Tony Blair announced a ministerial committee to look at further ways to protect such firms - and their staff - from attacks from animal rights militants, whose loose organisation has defied police efforts to bring them to account.

Mr Straw braved round the clock protests and took TV crews with him to flag Whitehall's support. After touring the plant with Brian Cass, the HLS managing director who was attacked outside his home by masked men, Mr Straw assured staff that, after a slow start, ministers were keen to protect them and the wider bioscience and pharmaceuti cal industries, whose future was threatened by attacks by "criminal terrorists".

"What goes on here is of great importance to millions of people's lives, just as research on animals has always been important in helping to combat diseases like smallpox, polio and asthma," he told reporters at the plant in John Major's constituency. "We need to applaud the people who work here rather than abuse them."

The criminal justice bill will strengthen police powers against intimidatory mail and email to staff, shareholders or banks - some of which have dropped HLS as clients rather than face harassment. Mr Cass said he now saw "a real commitment to making a change" to protect researchers.

The director of the Wellcome Trust medical research charity, Mike Dexter, said: "Medical research saves lives, and the government is right to get tough on animal rights extremists."

webTitle: Romance embraces new breed of novelist

fields.headline: Romance embraces new breed of novelist
fields.trailText: Cathy Kelly, Belfast born and Dublin reared, swearing like a trooper with a hangover, yesterday became the Parker romantic novelist of the year.
fields.byline: Maev Kenned, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Cathy Kelly, Belfast born and Dublin reared, swearing like a trooper with a hangover, yesterday became the Parker romantic novelist of the year.

Ms Kelly has achieved the romantic dream of every red blooded journalist.

"I was always saying I was going to write a book, and then I finally did, and then it went to number one on the bestseller list so I thought 'Jaysus, I'd better write another'," she said.

Her fifth novel, Someone Like You, yesterday took the £5,000 prize, beating a shortlist of six, which included four previous winners and the grande dame of the trade, Rosamunde Pilcher.

Ms Pilcher, with 60 years writing, 30 novels and a shelf of disowned Mills and Boon titles behind her, said Someone Like You was one of a handful among the hundreds of novels she is sent every year which she could bear to read beyond the first three pages.

Alan Titchmarsh, celebrity gardener reborn as a romantic novelist, presented the prizes at the Savoy hotel in London.

When Ms Pilcher started writing at 18, not only was sex unmentionable for her heroines, so were divorce, alcohol and even going to the races. "Now one tries to hold the line between writing about more challenging subjects in a more modern way, and driving away a whole generation of older readers," she said.

Ms Kelly's heroines are usually tottering under the influence of excesses of one kind or another - although her book ends with a kiss in a car. She knows that "romantic novel" is still a term of abuse in literary circles.

But Norma Curtis, novelist and chairwoman of the Romantic Novelists' Association, said: "You only have to sell about 2,000 books to get on the Booker shortlist. Our books start with a print run of 30,000."

Sales of romantic novels are only beaten by crime fiction, and a survey in 1996 found that 182m copies had been sold world wide that year. "Bridget Jones has really changed the market, with all the 20 and 30-year-olds coming in for the first time as readers and writers," Ms Curtis said.

"The younger writers' books are much more earthy - bollocks is a very popular word now - and the older readers won't go near them, although the younger readers will read the older books."

Cathy Kelly's latest manuscript is due in on Monday, for publication in October: "I knew I wasn't going to win, so I didn't bring my laptop, I didn't expect to be hanging around for long," she said guiltily. HarperCollins, her publishers, will probably forgive her.

Three years ago Ms Kelly was a hack in a Dublin newsroom. She now lives in a pretty and very expensive Wicklow village, contributes a weekly column to her paper, has a new three-book contract, and has sold almost 500,000 copies between the first four. Who says there are no happy endings?
Winning words

An extract from Cathy Kelly's prize-winning novel Someone Like You

Moving quietly so she wouldn't wake him, Hannah padded naked and barefoot into the kitchen, and swallowed two headache tablets with a glass of water. After another glass to slake her hangover thirst, she crept into the bathroom. Her hair was a wild bush around her head. Her make-up was in patchy scales under her eyes. Her mouth was bruised from a combination of fierce kissing and from Felix's late-night stubble. All in all, the sort of face to normally make Hannah groan. Only, today, something shone out from behind the tiredness and the panda eyes: something delirious and fulfilled. Her eyes sparkled and her mouth refused to stop smiling. She was happy, in love! She beamed at her reflection.

After brushing her teeth until her gums hurt in case she had bad breath, Hannah slid back under the duvet and wriggled over until she was half lying on top of him. He didn't appear to wake up, yet one hand moved gently to cup her breast, idly caressing the nipple expertly until Hannah sighed loudly. Felix opened one eye. 'Are you a morning sex person?'

fields.headline: Bernard Venables
fields.standfirst: Gifted writer and artist who shared his love of angling with millions through books and a celebrated cartoon character
fields.trailText: Gifted writer and artist who shared his love of angling with millions through books and a celebrated cartoon character.
fields.body:
Bernard Venables, who has died aged 94, was the best-known name in angling journalism since the second world war. He emerged quite suddenly, like a fully-hatched mayfly, on to the angling scene in 1947 as the creator of Mr Crabtree, a character in a cartoon strip about fishing in the Daily Mirror. A number of books followed, illustrated by the author, and the founding of two journals, so that his name has been before the angling public for the last half century.

There had been a slowly-maturing preparation for this unusual career. Born in Catford, south London, Bernard's first fishing was in the mysterious dykes of Romney Marsh at the age of six. The other great loves of his life - painting and drawing - were encouraged by his training at Croydon School of Art in the 1920s. This was followed by work in commercial studios, and on the staff of the Daily Express. In 1939, he was drawn into a variety of war-work commissions, including writing and illustrating a book on battle tanks. He returned to the Express in 1945, but was then poached by the Daily Mirror.

Soon afterwards, the most celebrated cartoon character in angling history made his public debut. Today, the Crabtree strip has a certain period charm; here is a father seeking refuge from postwar austerity on the river bank, and playing instructor and sage to his son Peter. Excellent drawings made all points clear, and Peter, eager and respectful in collar-and-tie and short trousers, is taken through a variety of angling situations.

The series had such a runaway success that the Mirror persuaded Bernard to turn it into a book. Thus, in 1949, with the addition of commentary and coloured illustrations, Mr Crabtree Goes Fishing appeared - and at once began to sell in staggering numbers. A happy combination of the practical and the philosophical had created a work of irresistible charm. Eventually, more than 2m copies were sold, surpassing all angling titles since Izaak Walton. An edition was produced last year, and rapidly sold out.

In 1953, Bernard was lured away from the Mirror by the broadcaster Howard Marshall. Marshall was ambitious to found a national angling paper in tabloid form, and had fixed on Bernard as his editorial director. Again, a real need had been identified; the circulation of Angling Times climbed from 30,000 in the first year to 170,000 in 1962. But Bernard was restless and slightly bored by its success, and was anxious to move on to some new creative challenge. In 1963, he got backing from Purnell for the launch of a new journal called Creel.

Carrying articles from many leading angling writers of the day, it was distinguished by good design and the quality of the colour pictures reproduced by the new web offset process. But the issue of this venture was much less happy: Purnell became impatient with the high production costs and insisted on a drastic scaling-down of the paper, causing Bernard to leave in disgust.

In the years that followed, Bernard was busily involved with appearances on radio and television, and with writing, punctuated by some larger-than-life experiences in the wider world.

Already, in 1959, he had set up a one-man expedition to Madeira, which resulted in the landing of a 1700lb shark. In 1966, during a trip for the Zambian government to explore tourism possibilities, he trekked to the source of the Zambezi, and added to his growing fist of book titles with Coming Down The Zambezi. In 1967, he joined a group of men in the Azores still whaling in small, open boats, in the same primitive and dangerous way described in Moby Dick. From this he derived another book, Balela! (1967), a strangely moving account of the risky lives of desperately poor men lacking the security of the factory ship, and of the pitiful deaths of the great whales.

Bernard was one of those people who refused to notice the onset of old age. He was well over 80 when he fished for tiger fish on Lake Kariba, and for Nile perch in Uganda, and was still writing, painting and broadcasting in the 1990s. Failing sight slowed him a little, but fishing expeditions were still possible - with friends in attendance to stop him from walking into the water.

His philosophy was a little out of step with the signs and developments of the modern angling scene, which he observed with some disquiet. For him, fishing was not just an absorbing and delightful sport, but also an escape from the cares of modern life and a calm to the soul. He was not much in sympathy with the commercialisation, competitiveness and obsession with technical gadgetry that have become such a part of fishing today.

He was also unusual in that he loved all forms of fishing - something he shared with the great angling writers of the past, such as Francis Francis, RB Marston and William Senior - and was not tied to one area of the pursuit.

In 1995, he was pleased at the award of an MBE, regarding it as a sign of recognition for anglers in general. He leaves his wife Eileen, and two sons.

 Bernard Venables, angler, artist and writer, born February 14 1907; died April 21 2001

fields.headline: Wizard yarn tops readers' poll
fields.trailText: The Naked Chef last night joined forces with Harry Potter and Archie Jones, the nowhere man of Zadie Smith's version of Cricklewood Broadway, by taking three of the first WH Smith book prizes to be chosen by popular vote.
fields.body:
The Naked Chef last night joined forces with Harry Potter and Archie Jones, the nowhere man of Zadie Smith's version of Cricklewood Broadway, by taking three of the first WH Smith book prizes to be chosen by popular vote.

The books won awards worth £5,000 for their authors - Jamie Oliver, JK Rowling and Ms Smith - after coming top in a poll which attracted 65,000 votes in high streets and on the internet.

Another best-selling writer, Maeve Binchy won the fiction prize in a contest which, while advertised as unprecedentedly democratic, confirmed what the book trade has known for a century: that the public tends to go for titles which are being most heavily promoted in bookshops and the media.

Ms Rowling won the children's book of the year award for Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire; Ms Smith took the new talent prize for White Teeth and Jamie Oliver the home and leisure prize for The Return of the Naked Chef. Ms Binchy won the fiction prize for her novel, Scarlet Feather.

Simon Schama's A History of Britain came top in the general knowledge section and David Starkey's Elizabeth was first in biography and autobiography. Cynthia Crossen's The Rich And How They Got that Way took the business prize and Bill Bryson's Down Under, the travel award.

The WH Smith literary prize, which has been running for 43 years, was considered too complex to be left to open vote. This award was given by a judging panel to Philip Roth's novel, The Human Stain.

Smith's chief executive, Richard Handover, was delighted by the results at last night's award ceremony. "People have welcomed the opportunity to participate in the voting, and it has been extremely interesting to see their perspective on which books they believe to be the best.

"Because they were offered a choice of voting methods, adults and children could find a process to suit them," he said.

However, voters were not given the chance to nominate their own choice of books. They were asked to pick from shortlists of five titles chosen by judges. A third of voters used the internet.

Voters showed a degree of independence by rejecting Joanna Trollope's novel Marrying the Mistress, the bookies' evens favourite for the fiction prize. William Hill had rated Ms Binchy's novel as second favourite.

The new voting opportunity was taken up by only a small fraction of WH Smith's 7m weekly shoppers. It was introduced because the company considered traditional judging methods "elitist". But the results leave it open to the criticism that it merely produces a mirror of the best-seller charts.

fields.headline: Carnegie medal shortlist announced
fields.trailText: The shortlist for prestigious children's book award the Carnegie medal has been announced with a strong selection which includes three former winners and covers a wide range of issues.
fields.body:
The shortlist for prestigious children's book award the Carnegie medal has been announced with a strong selection which includes three former winners and covers a wide range of issues.

David Almond returns, two years after River Boy took the award, with Heaven Eyes, his tale of a group of friends who run away from a children's home. He is joined by another previous winner, Melvin Burgess, whose The Ghost Behind the Wall describes a child's reaction to an old man's deterioration through Alzheimer's disease. Burgess won the award in 1996 for his controversial drug-addiction story, Junk. After winning with Northern Lights in 1995, Philip Pullman returns with his ambitious conclusion to his Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass.

Also on the shortlist and a strong contender for the medal is this year's winner of the Whitbread children's book award, Coram Boy by Jamila Gavin, a disturbing tale of 18th-century child slavery.

The other four shortlisted books are Sharon Creech's yachting adventure, The Wanderer; Alan Gibbons's computer game story, Shadow of the Minotaur; Beverley Naidoo's tale of a Nigerian brother and sister fleeing their country, The Other Side of Truth; and Adele Geras's reworking of a Greek myth, Troy.

The oldest of the children's book awards, the inaugural Carnegie medal was given in 1937 and is now awarded annually by the Library Association for "outstanding writing in a children's book". It was won last year by Aiden Chambers for his second world war thriller Postcards from No Man's Land.

The shortlist for the Carnegie's sister award, the Greenaway medal, which is given to "outstanding illustration in a children's book", has also been announced. Acclaimed illustrator Lauren Child has been nominated twice, once for Beware of the Storybook Wolves and again for I Will Not Ever Never Eat a Tomato. She is joined by Ron Brooks for Fox, Anthony Browne for Willy's Pictures, Ruth Brown for Snail Trail, Ted Dewan for Crispin: The Pig Who Had It All and Jane Ray for Fairy Tales.

For the fifth year running, children in libraries across the UK will be 'shadowing' the judging process across both medals, discussing the books in groups and picking their choice of winner.

The winners of both medals will be announced on July 13.

The shortlist

Heaven Eyes by David Almond
An atmospheric and moving story about a group of friends who run away from their children's home, embarking on an adventure that pushes their ability to survive to the limits.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

The Ghost behind the Wall by Melvin Burgess
Never one to shy away from controversial subject matter, Burgess tells the story of a young boy's friendship with an old man suffering from Alzheimer's disease.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

The Wanderer, by Sharon Creech
A young girl embarks on an adventure, crossing the Atlantic from Connecticut to Ireland in her uncle's yacht, The Wanderer.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Coram Boy by Jamila Gavin
A gripping tale, set in 18th-century London, about a young orphan boy trying to escape being sold into slavery.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Troy by Adele Geras
Reworking of the ancient legends of Troy, seen through the eyes of two young Trojan sisters.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Shadow of the Minotaur by Alan Gibbons
A plot which cleverly weaves strands of modern computer games with Greek myths to tell a story of family, friendship and growth.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

The Other Side of Truth by Beverley Naidoo
A topical story about a Nigerian brother and sister fleeing oppression and seeking asylum in the UK.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

The Amber Spyglass by Philip Pullman
The conclusion of the Dark Materials trilogy.
Buy it at a discount from BOL

fields.headline: Guglielmo Biraghi
fields.standfirst: Film festival director famed for collecting seashells
fields.trailText: Film festival director famed for collecting seashells.
fields.body:
The Italian Guglielmo Biraghi, who has died of cancer aged 73, was a playwright and one of the world's best-known malacologists, or seashell collectors. He was also a distinguished film critic, and an internationally-appreciated director of film festivals, first in Taormina, Sicily, in the 1970s and early 1980s, and then, from 1987 for five years, at Venice.

His gracious manners, knowledge of languages and general good taste in film made him popular with film professionals worldwide, many of whom owed him their critical and market attention. Several seashells he discovered are also named after him.

Though he had a degree in chemistry, Biraghi preferred art to science as a career, and soon found an entry into journalism, joining the staff of the leading Rome newspaper Il Messaggero, for which, from 1953 to 1987, he was film critic and cultural contributor. His first play, a two-character conversation piece, The Sun And The Moon (1965), premiered in Rome, with Alida Valli returning to the stage after a 10-year exile in Mexico.

As a critic, Biraghi distanced himself from the political prejudices that so often influenced many of his colleagues. His knowledge of languages helped his judgment of foreign films. I remember that when Bernardo Bertolucci showed Last Tango In Paris to the press in Rome, he gave us the choice of seeing it in the original English and French, or the version he had been obliged to dub into Italian. Biraghi was the only major Italian critic who joined the English-speakers in the smaller screening room.

In 1970, he was called in to help out at the summer film event at Taormina, then less a festival than a promotional junket for movie people on holiday. Overcoming most of the local protests, Biraghi gradually gave it prestige. In the end, he managed to separate the first and second features competition from the more razzmatazz festival, leaving an imbecilic TV show on the last night, which he reluctantly had to bear with.

He could, nonetheless, take credit for helping to give a wider European launch to several films that got only sidebar attention at Cannes, among them Peter Weir's Picnic At Hanging Rock in 1975, and Michael Radford's Another Time, Another Place in 1983, the latter being the only competition entry at Taormina to win the top award and both actor and actress prizes.

In the mid-1980s, when Venice was suffering from continual political and bureaucratic mishaps, Taormina was winning its own role as Italy's most intelligent and enjoyable festival. Not surprisingly, Venice beckoned to Biraghi, who, in 1987, was asked to be curator of the world's oldest film festival. By not being a political appointee, he was able to bully his gentlemanly way into favour.

His first year's selection was put together in a hurry, but even so, the Golden Lion went to Louis Malle's Au Revoir Les Enfants. Before accepting a four-year term as director, he got his way in bringing in a private sponsor to pay the cost of covering the open-air arena.

Biraghi was often accused of mistaken choices. He preferred one of Lina Wertmuller's worst films, On A Moonlit Night, about Aids, with Faye Dunaway and Peter O' Toole, to Peter Greenaway's The Cook, The Thief, His Wife And Her Lover, and he turned down Nanni Moretti's witty parable anticipating the fall of Italian communism, Palombella Rossa.

In 1988, his stubborn decision to show Martin Scorsese's Last Temptation Of Christ stirred up a hornet's nest in the Catholic establishment. He continued to defend his right to show the films he personally liked, and to put quality before nationality.

To his credit, Biraghi was a good talent scout. He helped to launch directors like Pedro Almodovar (Women On The Verge Of A Nervous Breakdown), Jane Campion (An Angel At My Table), and many Asian directors, including Hou Xiaoxian (City Of Sadness, Golden Lion 1989). He put no pressure on his juries, and did not flinch when jury president Gore Vidal upset almost everybody by persuading his colleagues, divided between Campion and Scorsese (Goodfellas), to give the Golden Lion to fellow writer and part-time director Tom Stoppard for Rosencrantz And Guildenstern Are Dead.

Perhaps relieved to free himself from this too involving commitment, Biraghi dedicated his subsequent years to his seashells and travel, sitting on film juries - from Cannes, Berlin and Montreal, to Chicago, in which he had a special role. He loved going to India and Thailand. Until recent months, he enjoyed being a consultant script reader for Istituto Luce, the state-funded film finance agency.

He was discreet about his private life, but it was generally known that he was bisexual. His name was often associated with actresses, one of whom, Annabella Incontrera, he married in the 1960s, although it did not last. In later years, he adopted an Albanian refugee, whom he helped to study and get a job in Rome, and who, with his wife, is Guglielmo's heir. His valuable seashell collection is to be made available for public viewing.

fields.bodyText: The Italian Guglielmo Biraghi, who has died of cancer aged 73, was a playwright and one of the world's best-known malacologists, or seashell collectors. He was also a distinguished film critic, and an internationally-appreciated director of film festivals, first in Taormina, Sicily, in the 1970s and early 1980s, and then, from 1987 for five years, at Venice. His gracious manners, knowledge of languages and general good taste in film made him popular with film professionals worldwide, many of whom owed him their critical and market attention. Several seashells he discovered are also named after him. Though he had a degree in chemistry, Biraghi preferred art to science as a career, and soon found an entry into journalism, joining the staff of the leading Rome newspaper Il Messaggero, for which, from 1953 to 1987, he was film critic and cultural contributor. His first play, a two-character conversation piece, The Sun And The Moon (1965), premiered in Rome, with Alida Valli returning to the stage after a 10-year exile in Mexico. As a critic, Biraghi distanced himself from the political prejudices that so often influenced many of his colleagues. His knowledge of languages helped his judgment of foreign films. I remember that when Bernardo Bertolucci showed Last Tango In Paris to the press in Rome, he gave us the choice of seeing it in the original English and French, or the version he had been obliged to dub into Italian. Biraghi was the only major Italian critic who joined the English-speakers in the smaller screening room. In 1970, he was called in to help out at the summer film event at Taormina, then less a festival than a promotional junket for movie people on holiday. Overcoming most of the local protests, Biraghi gradually gave it prestige. In the end, he managed to separate the first and second features competition from the more razzmatazz festival, leaving an imbecilic TV show on the last night, which he reluctantly had to bear with. webTitle: Terry Gilliam picks the 10 best animated films of all time

fields.headline: The 10 best animated films of all time
fields.standfirst: From Pinocchio to Cartman via disintegrating heads . . . sometime Monty Python animator  Terry Gilliam  picks his favourite cartoons
fields.trailText: From Pinocchio to Cartman via disintegrating heads . . . sometime Monty Python animator Terry Gilliam picks his favourite cartoons
fields.body:
The Mascot

(Władysław Starewicz, France 1934)

It was at the Sitges film festival that I first saw an exhibition of work by the pioneering Russian animator Władysław Starewicz, and the puppets were so enrapturing that when I got home I ordered up all the tapes I could find of his work. His work is absolutely breathtaking, surreal,inventive and extraordinary, encompassing everything that Jan Švankmajer, Walerian Borowczyk and the Quay Brothers would do subsequently. This is his last film, after The Tale of the Fox from 1930; it is all right there in this cosmic animation soup. It is important, before you journey through all these mind-bending worlds, to remember that it was all done years ago, by someone most of us have forgotten about now. This is where it all began.

Pinocchio

(Hamilton Luske and Ben Sharpsteen, US, 1940)

For me, as an American growing up in Minnesota, Walt Disney was animation. But the joy of Disney’s films always came from watching the baddies. Pinocchio is visually the richest of his features and it is also the darkest. The Bad Boys’ World is a truly immortal nightmare, full of eerie images of kids turning into donkeys and all manner of strangeness. Then there is that stuff with cages, and I notice now that every film I have made features a scene with somebody in a cage - a trait I attribute to watching Pinocchio. Great songs in that film too; Disney was essentially a musical film-maker. Plus there is something intriguing about a character who desperately wants to be a real person, but who we all think is actually more interesting as a piece of wood.

Red Hot Riding Hood

(Tex Avery, US, 1943)

The magic of Tex Avery’s animation is the sheer extremity of it all. The classic Avery image is of someone’s mouth falling open down to their feet, wham, their eyes whooping out and their tongue unrolling for about half a mile: that is the most wonderfully liberating spectacle. Avery would just stretch the human body and face however he liked, and the result was unbelievably funny. There is no hesitation in his work, no sense that you can go too far. I think that nowadays they should put on Tex Avery festivals as an antidote to political correctness. There is also a childlike sense of immortality and indestructibility in his work; people get squashed, mashed, bashed, bent out of shape, whatever, and they bounce back. In essence, it is like the myth of eternal life.

Out of the Inkwell

(Dave Fleischer, US, 1938)

I first saw this when I was a teenager and, in retrospect, it was a career leap for me. This was when I first discovered surrealism. You have a scenario in which you see an animator creating something which suddenly develops a life outside of the cartoon. The character starts communicating with the animator, and then it is Frankenstein all over again, the creation of a monster over which you have no control. Until I saw Out of the Inkwell, I had always thought of animation as existing on one plane, but here were the Fleischer brothers taking you right through the looking glass and into the picture. Of course, when I saw it I loved it - not because I wanted to be the animator whose ink comes to life, but because I wanted to be the animation, the clown wreaking havoc upon the world.

Death Breath

(Stan van der Beek, US, 1964)

After college, I lived in New York with some people who would watch experimental avant-garde films. We embraced them because they annoyed everybody else, even though they were mostly awful. One night we were enduring some of this stuff when on to the screen came a cut-up image of Richard Nixon trying to talk with his foot in his mouth. It was the simplest animation pun imaginable. Years later, when I had come to England and we were working on a TV programme that was meant to make people laugh, there was a problem with dramatising one of the ideas. So I got a picture of Jimmy Young, cut it in half, moved his mouth around a bit and everybody laughed. That subsequently became a trademark, for which I think van der Beek should take credit.

Les Jeux des Anges

(Walerian Borowczyk, France, 1964)

Walerian Borowczyk was a twisted man whose films were infused with a unique cruelty and weirdness. He started out making extraordinary animations, graduated to directing classics such as Goto, Island of Love and La B te, and then ended up directing Emmanuelle 5, which I think is a perversely fitting end. Les Jeux des Anges was my first experience of animation that was utterly impressionistic. It didn’t show me anything specific, just sound and movement from which you create a world of your own.

Dimensions of Dialogue

(Jan Švankmajer, Czechoslovakia, 1982)

Jan Švankmajer’s stop-motion work uses familiar, unremarkable objects in a way which is deeply disturbing. The first film of his that I saw was Alice, and I was extremely unsettled by the image of an animated rabbit which had real fur and real eyes. His films always leave me with mixed feelings, but they all have moments that really get to me; moments that evoke the nightmarish spectre of seeing commonplace things coming unexpectedly to life.

Street of Crocodiles

(The Quay Brothers, UK, 1986)

There is something peculiar about falling for Jan Svankmajer and then discovering the Quay brothers - Americans who came to Europe and somehow wound up working in a style that felt like Polish animation. As an American, I always wanted to be seduced into this strange decadent, rotting idea of Europe, and the Quays have created that world in a manner which hypnotises me, but which I don’t fully understand. Maybe I like them because they ended up going further east than I did.

Knickknack

(John Lasseter, US, 1989)

John Lasseter’s work was the first digital animation that had genuine life in the characters. To be able to mix that level of characterisation with the smooth, crisp, clean quality of computer animation, to give it a real sense of three-dimensional existence, of touchiness and tactility, was like discovering a whole new texture of animation. The quality has endured from Lasseter’s short films such as Knickknack through to Toy Story 1 and 2, both of which are touching, funny, intelligent and brilliant.

South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut

(Trey Parker, US, 1999)

Parker and Stone are the only guys who were ever inspired by me, who took the crudeness of my animation to even lower depths. Their stuff is so shoddy that it is miraculous that it works at all. I assured them that while it may be great for TV, there was no way to sustain it for 90 minutes. And, of course, their movie worked just brilliantly.

Terry Gilliam’s Desert Island Flicks is tonight at Animated Encounters 2001 at the Watershed, Bristol (0117-925 3845). The festival continues until Sunday.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Memento | Coyote Ugly | Going Off Big Time
fields.trailText: Memento | Coyote Ugly | Going Off Big Time
fields.body:
Memento
Rental and DVD rental Fox Pathe Cert 15

"Facts, not memories. That's how you investigate." Guy Pearce, in his first good part since LA Confidential's similarly dogged tec, is an insurance investigator piecing together the murder of his wife. The unique aspect to this case is that he is hampered by being unable to amass new memories since a blow on the head at the murder scene incapacitated him. Original murder plots get ever harder to invent, but this is a corker, almost as good as DOA (poisoned man tries to solve own murder). Writer-director Christopher Nolan succeeds Following - an award-winner like this - with an even more tortuous and tricky tale that demands a second viewing. Pearce's desperate hunt, put together by notes, Polaroids and tattoos leaves him uniquely open to exploitation and Nolan makes it that much more paranoid by telling the whole tale backwards. Another director would make this unbearably trendy and tricksy but Nolan keeps it comprehensible and riveting: at 31, he's clearly a talent to watch. The result is a fiendishly complicated and ambiguous twist on the noir/detective genre with a sideline meditation on memory, intuition and trust. The Polaroid, a hopeless blur turning gradually into a crisp image is the perfect metaphor for Nolan's tale but if this makes the film sound terribly abstract and intellectual, I would be doing it a disservice: it may be labyrinthine and deeply obsessive but it's also thoroughly absorbing, with shafts of dark wit leavening its gloomier aspects.

Coyote Ugly
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Buena Vista Cert 12

A Jerry Bruckheimer film and, as that often implies, a film that relates only to other films. "Flashdance meets Cocktail" is the pretty accurate summary on the front of the sleeve. You could also go for "Roadhouse meets Hearts of Fire". A wish-fulfilment fantasy fluffier than a poodle in an angora bodywarmer, it tells of a songwriter with stage fright who leaves a small town to pursue her dreams, meets with rejection in the big city (New York) and ends up as a sexy dancing barmaid battling with new boyfriend and tough boss. It's hyper throughout and feels like a film written by a 14-year-old and directed by his younger brother. It is saved from total redundancy by a charming lead performance by Piper Perabo - looking strikingly like Sarah Jessica Parker in LA Story - and some enthusiastic direction: the Coyote bar as sexually charged moshpit is fun to watch, in an exhausting kind of way. John Goodman looks embarrassed as Perabo's unlikely dad.

Going Off Big Time
Rental and DVD (£19.99) EV Cert 18

Brit gangster film number 71, but while it won't lodge long in the memory banks, it has moments of real invention and, after all those east-end hardmen, it's a relief to have a film peopled mainly by Scousers of the lippy variety. It's constructed largely as a flashback to how our anti-hero, Neil Fitzmaurice, got involved in a life of crime. The actor, who was DJ Ray Von in Peter Kay's recent Phoenix Nights series, also wrote the screenplay, and comes up with some nice lines: "He was more Stringfellow than Goodfella." The film is far stronger in its prison scenes, where Bernard Hill is the old lag helping our youth get by in a Fletch-and-Lennie kind of way. You miss Hill in the more mundane scenes on the outside, though a fight in a bouncy castle and drug deals done from an ice-cream van are nicely original touches. But the film trips itself up with flashbacks-within-flashbacks at times, and there's some hazy plotting and rough script edges on the way to a surprise sudden ending.

fields.headline: The strike: a film-goer's guide
fields.standfirst: On Tuesday, Hollywood's writers are due to down word processors and walk out. How will that affect the films we get to see?  Gary Susman  reports
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, Hollywood's writers are due to down word processors and walk out. How will that affect the films we get to see? Gary Susman reports
fields.body:
Having endured fires, floods, riots, mudslides, and earthquakes, Los Angeles is bracing itself for its next potential disaster: simultaneous strikes by Hollywood's writers and actors. If, as expected, the Writers Guild of America strikes when its contract expires on May 1, and if the actors' unions (the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists) follow suit when their contracts expire on June 30, Hollywood could see several months in which virtually all film and television production is shut down. As a result, the industry could face nearly $7bn in lost income and more than 81,000 lost jobs, according to a study commissioned by the Mayor of Los Angeles, Richard J Riordan, who announced its findings last week.

The writers and the actors are demanding more in "residuals", payments for replays of films and TV programmes, in markets that barely existed or generated little revenue when contracts were last renegotiated a few years ago, such as video/DVD, basic cable, the Fox TV network and overseas TV. Since few of the 11,000 writers and 135,000 actors are actually working at any given time, and since fewer still earn the eight-figure salaries of Tom Hanks or Mel Gibson, residuals from past work may constitute most of an actor's or writer's earnings.

Members of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) argue, however, that these payments could cost them hundreds of millions of dollars at a time when their revenues are shrink ing because of increased production costs - due, in no small part, to the ballooning salaries of top actors and writers.

The last time the writers picketed, in the summer of 1988, the walkout lasted five months, delaying the start of the network TV season by about three months and sending millions of defecting viewers to cable. Last year's actors' strike, against the producers of TV commercials, lasted a record six months. If the actors strike this summer, no one expects work to resume before September or October.

To lessen the impact of the walkouts, which no one claims to want but everyone thinks are inevitable, studios have been speeding up production schedules to cram as many movies into the pre-strike window as possible.

Stars such as Gwyneth Paltrow (who has shot four movies in recent months) and Julia Roberts (who cut short her Oscar partying so she could film America's Sweethearts and Ocean's Eleven back-to-back) have been working overtime, as if to aid the very producers whom the strikes are supposed to cripple.

Many movie shoots, however, are in limbo until the strikes are averted or settled, and threats of a labour stoppage may have shut down some productions altogether (see accompanying chart). Since a big-budget Hollywood movie can take 75 days to shoot, any film that did not start shooting before last week is effectively shut down already.

Whether or not the impact of the strikes is as deep as Mayor Riordan fears, it will certainly be wide. The following shows how the highest-profile projects will be - and are already being - affected.

Basic Instinct 2 Intermedia/MGM

Storyline: Sharon Stone returns as everyone's favourite icepick-wielding, panties-eschewing, bisexual serial killer. John McTiernan (Die Hard, The Thomas Crown Affair) will direct.

Impact of the strike: Producers haven't been able to find a suitable leading man in time for a pre-strike shoot: Pierce Brosnan said no, and Stone dragged her feet so long on approving Benjamin Bratt that he signed on for another pre-strike production, Abandon. However, since the distributor MGM has no financial stake in BI2, the film is eligible for a union waiver, so shooting could start as soon as a lead is cast, strike or no strike.

Release: 2002

Butterfly Revolution Sony/Revolution

Storyline: Thriller that would reteam Julia Roberts with The Mexican director Gore Verbinski.

Impact of the strike: With Roberts working back-to-back on Ocean's Eleven and America's Sweethearts, she had only a 50-day window before the strike deadline to shoot a 70-day movie.

Release: Mothballed

The Cat in the Hat Universal/Imagine

Storyline: From the folks who brought you Jim Carrey as the Grinch comes another Dr Seuss adaptation, this time with Tim Allen as the homewrecking feline.

Impact of the strike: Producers didn't even commission a screenplay until late February, so there's no way this will be ready to shoot before the deadline. But after the strike, Allen is also committed to shooting Disney's The Santa Clause 2, which was also delayed because Allen wanted a script rewrite.

Release: 2003

Confessions of a Dangerous Mind Warner Bros/ Renaissance

Storyline: The autobiography of Chuck Barris, creator of TV's talent-free talent contest The Gong Show, and self-styled CIA spy to boot.

Impact of the strike: With Johnny Depp as the star and Bryan Singer (X-Men) as the director, this was to be Renaissance's tentpole, for which it had set aside small British projects such as Dr Sleep and Personal Shopping. But financial details weren't finalised in time for a pre-strike shoot. Two of the executives who helped relaunch the UK production company two years ago have lost their jobs.

Release: Gonggggg!

Enchanted Disney

Storyline: Live-action/animation mix about a fairytale princess who is banished to modern-day New York City.

Impact of the strike: Toons can't strike, and the voice actors may be able to record their parts before June 30, but the live portion, with possible stars John Travolta and Susan Sarandon, will have to wait until the strikes end happily ever after.

Release: Christmas 2002

The Green Hornet Universal

Storyline: Based on the old radio/television/comics action serial, less famous today for its hero than for his sidekick, the karate-chopping Kato, who was played on TV in the 1960s by a young Bruce Lee.

Impact of the strike: Universal has been trying to get this off the ground for five years and seemed to be on its way with the Hong Kong action legend Jet Li as Kato. But Li dropped out late last year and the studio failed to find a replacement (much less a lead actor) in time to shoot before a strike.

Release: KO'd

Indiana Jones 4 Paramount

Storyline: Who knows? But Premiere magazine reports that Harrison Ford is still interested and that both M Night Shyamalan (The Sixth Sense) and Stephen Gaghan (Traffic) have been approached to write it.

Impact of the strike: Still very much in the just-talking stage, but the potential strikes are sure to delay production even further.

Release: Not before 2003

Kill Bill Miramax

Storyline: Quentin Tarantino's long-awaited follow-up to 1997's Jackie Brown would be a revenge/martial arts thriller starring Uma Thurman.

Impact of the strike: Having decided that he can't teach Uma to fly and wield a sword like Michelle Yeoh in time for a pre-strike shoot, Tarantino has put this one on the back burner, favouring instead the second world war drama Glorious Bastards or else the prequel The Vega Brothers, which would unite John Travolta's Pulp Fiction gangster with Michael Madsen's Reservoir Dogs ear-slicer.

Release: Killed

The Matrix 2 Warner Bros

Storyline: What is The Matrix 2? Plots for this cyberpunk/kung fu sequel and Matrix 3 remain top secret. But Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss and Laurence Fishburne are rebooting.

Release: July 2002

Release: Possibly extinct

Release: 2002

Release: Out of work

How the industry will be affected

Actors

Many of them probably want a vacation after the extra work they have done over the past few months. Several film and TV stars plan to spend their summer on the New York stage, including Meryl Streep, Kevin Kline, Nathan Lane, Matthew Broderick, Eric McCormack, Don Cheadle, Billy Crudup, Natalie Portman, John Goodman, Christopher Walken, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Allison Janney.

Writers

Traditionally the least esteemed group in Hollywood, the writers are fighting not just for money but also for respect. They want more creative control over their screenplays once shooting starts, and they want to end the "possessory credit", the "a film by..." citation that names the director and not the writer as the sole creator of a movie. The Directors Guild of America, however, remains unwilling to give up its favoured status.

Studios

Thanks to the extra work of writers and actors in recent months, most of the releases for the next year have already been shot. Independent producers who are not members of AMPTP may be eligible for union waivers, so they may continue to shoot. However, many of this summer's releases depend heavily on expensive publicity campaigns centred around the stars, and if the guilds bar the stars from promoting their work, many completed films could get pushed back until after the strike, ruining Hollywood's most lucrative season of the year.

Cinema owners

Naturally, they are panicking about a lack of product, especially with the current summer slate, which is low on the big names (Jim, Mel, Tom, Harrison) that draw ticket buyers.

Print media

A publicity embargo could hurt weekly magazines, newspapers, TV shows and other outlets that depend heavily on celebrities to draw viewers and readers. Monthly magazines that conduct interviews well in advance may have to shuffle stories at the last minute to accommodate changes in film release dates.

Agents

Ten percent of nothing is nothing. The big talent agencies have already laid off assistants and slashed expense accounts.

Support workers

No production means no work for the camera operators, caterers, pool cleaners, personal trainers, hairdressers, dog walkers and the like. The Teamsters union, which does much of the driving and heavy lifting for Hollywood, has already threatened to withhold its support of striking writers and actors.
fields.bodyText: Having endured fires, floods, riots, mudslides, and earthquakes, Los Angeles is bracing itself for its next potential disaster: simultaneous strikes by Hollywood's writers and actors. If, as expected, the Writers Guild of America strikes when its contract expires on May 1, and if the actors' unions (the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists) follow suit when their contracts expire on June 30, Hollywood could see several months in which virtually all film and television production is shut down. As a result, the industry could face nearly $7bn in lost income and more than 81,000 lost jobs, according to a study commissioned by the Mayor of Los Angeles, Richard J Riordan, who announced its findings last week. The writers and the actors are demanding more in "residuals", payments for replays of films and TV programmes, in markets that barely existed or generated little revenue when contracts were last renegotiated a few years ago, such as video/DVD, basic cable, the Fox TV network and overseas TV. Since few of the 11,000 writers and 135,000 actors are actually working at any given time, and since fewer still earn the eight-figure salaries of Tom Hanks or Mel Gibson, residuals from past work may constitute most of an actor's or writer's earnings. Members of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) argue, however, that these payments could cost them hundreds of millions of dollars at a time when their revenues are shrink ing because of increased production costs - due, in no small part, to the ballooning salaries of top actors and writers. The last time the writers picketed, in the summer of 1988, the walkout lasted five months, delaying the start of the network TV season by about three months and sending millions of defecting viewers to cable.
