Stars such as Gwyneth Paltrow (who has shot four movies in recent months) and Julia Roberts (who cut short her Oscar partying so she could film America's Sweethearts and Ocean's Eleven back-to-back) have been working overtime, as if to aid the very producers whom the strikes are supposed to cripple. Many movie shoots, however, are in limbo until the strikes are averted or settled, and threats of a labour stoppage may have shut down some productions altogether (see accompanying chart). Since a big-budget Hollywood movie can take 75 days to shoot, any film that did not start shooting before last week is effectively shut down already. fields.headline: La Captive
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is really a very opaque movie, evidently premised on a vividly perceived emotional situation, but in which the emotional lives of the main characters are a mystery
fields.body:
Recently, Raoul Ruiz scored a bullseye with his exquisitely observed period adaptation of Proust's Time Regained - now Chantal Akerman attempts something dissimilar with the La Prisonnière volume, updated to contemporary Paris with a strange kind of frigid languor, heavily furnished with a slightly ponderous score, using Rachmaninov, Schubert, and Mozart.

This is a chamber piece in which the larger panorama of society is mostly absent. Stanislas Merhar is Simon, the wealthy, obsessive lover of Ariane (Sylvie Testud), a beautiful young woman who submits to virtual incarceration in his apartment, indulging his behaviour impassively, with neither complaint nor the fierce submissive passion that might in other circumstances explain the situation.

Simon is creepy, morose and obsessed with discovering precisely what is going on in Ariane's head. He wears expensively and unfashionably tailored suits and topcoats that gesture forward to a gloomy and reticent middle age. Ariane is slight and simply dressed, almost like a child. The combination is disquieting, especially when it comes to their sexual life, which consists in Ariane's sleepy tolerance of his frottage.

As with Leon Carax's Pola X, his recent updating of Herman Melville, the transposition of a bygone age to modern life brings with it uncertainties of tone: all the fastidiousness and seclusion in which Simon lives looks in a modern context more dysfunctional and sinister than it need do.

This is really a very opaque movie, evidently premised on a vividly perceived emotional situation, but in which the emotional lives of Simon and Ariane are a mystery. The whole thing is muted, and a very great deal of the movie's intellectual content is invested in their inconclusive discussions taking place in various expensive cars in long, continuous takes. Even their final showdown is conducted on the level of a murmuring demurral.

As a study of jealousy it is neither as candid or generous as Cedric Kahn's recent L'Ennui, and certainly not Claude Chabrol's inflamed L'Enfer, and neither does it have the richly suggestive enigma of, say, Bunuel. There are felicitous moments, however, such as Ariane and Simon bathing on opposite sides of an intricate glass screen, elegantly suggesting both eroticism and estrangement.

fields.headline: Exit Wounds
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Any conceivable nuance in the storyline or the dialogue... is drowned utterly by the cacophonous roar of the action sequences
fields.body:
Roughly defined as the wounds you suffer in the frantic stampede for the exit. You will sustain these after five minutes of this by-the-numbers action thriller co-produced by Joel Silver and starring Steven Seagal as Orin Boyd, the rogue cop with balls of steel and a face like that big cross dog in Tom and Jerry. He's got a smoulderingly flirtatious thing going with his gorgeous female precinct commander, whose natural air of authority compares favourably with Cherie Lunghi's Kenco boss lady.

Seagal is on the trail of some heavy drugs larceny, apparently masterminded by the fantastically cool Latrell Walker, played by the rapper DMX. I'm not giving much away in revealing that Latrell is actually not merely a good guy, but a crusader against police corruption and his massive wealth derives from being an internet millionaire! Naturally!

There are scrupulously equal numbers of blacks and whites in the ranks of Good Cops, Bad Cops and Villains, and any conceivable nuance in the storyline or the dialogue - which has the regulation number of self-mocking quirks and broad comedy - is drowned utterly by the cacophonous roar of the action se quences, the continuous impact of fist on face, bumper on fender, helicopter rotor blade on tarmac.

Most prominently of all, there's the repeated use of people getting thrown through plate glass, always the dullest and laziest trick in fight choreography, especially as we all know it's that safe, easy-breaking pseudo-glass substance (most famously demonstrated in the 1980s news photo of Princess Diana breaking a trick bottle over Prince Charles's head). Through it all, Seagal maintains a face that appears to have had a gallon of Botox injected into it, if not reinforced cement.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Who will be the sixth 007?

fields.headline: Who will be the sixth 007?
fields.standfirst: James Purefoy can't be the next James Bond - he stole my girlfriend
fields.trailText: James Purefoy can't be the next James Bond - he stole my girlfriend
fields.body:
All of a sudden it seems like everyone wants to be James Bond. Apparently the venerable franchise still manages to cast a bewitching spell over male actors in their mid-30s. How long have they fantasised about strolling into that fabled gun-barrel iris, swivelling and firing and causing that curtain of crimson to cascade down the screen just before the traditional pre-credit action sequence and the mudbath-in-a-tittie-bar credits? How many thousands of hours did they spend in front of mirrors in their teenage bedrooms growling, "Good God, an ejector seat!" or "Dom Perignon above 39 degrees Fahrenheit is like listening to the Beatles without earmuffs" - or perhaps the most lascivious line in the series, repeated several times in Goldfinger: "Soooo, Puuussy . . ."? How is it that this endearingly preposterous, bizarrely anachronistic hero figure - whose original contexts, the cold war of the novels, the whizz-bang, gadget-gorged parallel-1960s of the Connery movies, have evaporated into dust - still manages to exert such a strong hold on actors?

The list of pretenders to Pierce Brosnan's soon-to-elapse licence to kill shows that actorly enthusiasm is extensive and undimmed. Brosnan's 007 contract with the Broccoli family expires after his next mission, and his recent movies, like The Thomas Crown Affair and particularly The Tailor of Panama, suggest that he's already in training for a post-Bond career. He hasn't definitively ruled out the possibility of re-enlisting for another stint, but whether he does one or two more Bonds, the replacement killers are circling already. And an odd bunch they are.

The most prominent and, I think, least likely candidate at the moment seems to be the Down Under Wonder, Russell Crowe. Unfortunately, Crowe is already a superstar on his own terms after the success of Gladiator, and he did a pretty useful quasi-Bond turn in the recent thriller Proof of Life, the film that is making people consider him for 007. There he was tough, utterly commanding, ruthless, babesome and forceful - which ticks every box on the Bond application form. Trouble is, he's also a very fine and subtle actor (witness his pudgy Jeffrey Wiegand in The Insider) and the character of Bond is little more than a chalk outline surrounding some timeworn quirks and a quiverful of smartass quips.

The last thing you need for this is a great actor; look at the way the series atrophied during the reign of the highly intelligent Timothy Dalton. Expecting Crowe - who would probably resent the franchise's constraints - to take on the role is as futile as Ian Fleming's oft-expressed desire to see Cary Grant playing Bond. Fleming was said to have been deeply uneasy about the Etonian superspy of his novels being played by Connery, a mere ex-milkman from Edinburgh - which proves that it's sometimes worth offloading the author once the movie rights have been secured.

No, what you need is someone like the medium-subtle Brosnan (my second favourite Bond after the magisterial Connery. Oh, sue me), a man who hungered after the role even before Dalton was recruited, and who was vocally narked at being passed over. Brosnan has been devoted to the franchise, which was in a confused post-cold war slump when he took over. He realised that his name was now on the door and after all his intensive lobbying for the part, he needed to deliver on his claims. And deliver he did. Even though his movies don't soar to the heights of Goldfinger or On Her Majesty's Secret Service, Brosnan himself has always been worth watching. This puts his replacement in a similar position to that confronting poor George Lazenby when he replaced Connery in 1969.

One odds-against candidate's ambitions seem to parallel those of Lazenby - whose previous experience included a chocolate commercial and little else. Colin Wells has been Brosnan's stand-in for the last couple of movies and his name seems to be in the running. This option suggests that the actor is merely an insertable/removable aspect of the Bond movies' design - as characterless as the gadgets, and every bit as replaceable. Although that approach worked with On Her Majesty's Secret Service - my favourite Bond these days, perhaps because it features such un-Bond elements as love, marriage, real emotion and actual tragedy - there was only a shadow 007 at the film"s centre.

The rise of Gerard Butler - "the Scottish unknown", as the tabloids are calling him - seems meanwhile to parallel the ascent of Connery in 1961: also Scottish, also little-known. A good but unfamiliar actor is what the series needs now, one who can grow in the role and make it his own (Broccolis permitting). I'm unfamiliar with Butler's work, but the profile seems to fit. Unlike that of Robbie Williams, who was patronised by casting director Debbie McWilliams: "Robbie, bless him, I don't think is quite what we are looking for." Oof.

Colin Firth's name has also surfaced here and there, probably because he currently turning heads in Bridget Jones, though perhaps his intelligence and coolness disqualify him for the role (which I don't think he's even seeking). I also have a sneaking suspicion that Fleming would have been delighted with him, and that clinches it for me: no Colin.

Better perhaps, if looking among the ranks of intelligent, posh actors, to examine the claims of James Purefoy from A Dance to the Music of Time. His name surfaced as a Bond candidate about a year ago in, of all places, the alumni newsletter of the school we both attended. fields.bodyText: All of a sudden it seems like everyone wants to be James Bond. Apparently the venerable franchise still manages to cast a bewitching spell over male actors in their mid-30s. How long have they fantasised about strolling into that fabled gun-barrel iris, swivelling and firing and causing that curtain of crimson to cascade down the screen just before the traditional pre-credit action sequence and the mudbath-in-a-tittie-bar credits? How many thousands of hours did they spend in front of mirrors in their teenage bedrooms growling, "Good God, an ejector seat!" or "Dom Perignon above 39 degrees Fahrenheit is like listening to the Beatles without earmuffs" - or perhaps the most lascivious line in the series, repeated several times in Goldfinger: "Soooo, Puuussy . . ."? How is it that this endearingly preposterous, bizarrely anachronistic hero figure - whose original contexts, the cold war of the novels, the whizz-bang, gadget-gorged parallel-1960s of the Connery movies, have evaporated into dust - still manages to exert such a strong hold on actors? The list of pretenders to Pierce Brosnan's soon-to-elapse licence to kill shows that actorly enthusiasm is extensive and undimmed. Brosnan's 007 contract with the Broccoli family expires after his next mission, and his recent movies, like The Thomas Crown Affair and particularly The Tailor of Panama, suggest that he's already in training for a post-Bond career. fields.headline: Bread and Roses
fields.standfirst: Ken Loach's latest film is a thrilling tale of love and politics among the LA underclass
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Ken Loach's latest film is a thrilling tale of love and politics among the LA underclass
fields.body:
At its premiere at Cannes last summer, Ken Loach's first American-set movie looked to me like megaphone cinema: a blazing rhetorical assault on the iniquities of white corporate America and its urban peasant class of blacks and Latinos - powerful, but without some of the nuances of humour he was able to contrive in cultures and locations in which he was more at home. I can only say that on a second viewing, Bread and Roses has bloomed into an intensely watchable, deeply felt, terrifically actedÉ and very exciting story of love and politics.

Some may find this last element a little black and white - but from the point of view of the exploited underclass in LA, that teeming capital of the third world, that's probably exactly how politics looks. And Bread and Roses is a virile rebuke to those modernisers and progressivists under the impression that trade unionism is an irrelevance in the new century.

Pilar Padilla plays Maya, a young Mexican woman who is smuggled over the border with a bus full of cowering "wetbacks", her passage paid for by her older sister Rosa (Elpidia Carrillo), who she joins working for a contract cleaning firm in a gleaming office-block in downtown LA. Terrified of being reported to immigration, they and the other illegals submit to exploitation and sexual harassment until they are galvanised by Sam (Adrien Brody), a middle-class Anglo union organiser who co-opts them all into his "Justice for Janitors" campaign. Gradually, Maya falls for the cute, dishevelled Sam.

Loach's movie shows a Los Angeles utterly absent from mainstream Hollywood movie-making: a Los Angeles that does not show up on the conventional cinema radar. It is neither the glamorous world of fictional sex and money, nor the obviously exoticised "criminal" world of the wrong side of the tracks: it is the quotidian world of corporate LA, and Loach shows us how this universe looks if you are part of the service economy.

Loach, and his long-time colleagues, cinematographer Barry Ackroyd, and production designer Martin Johnson, brilliantly show how unsexy the corporate environment is for those without money. The iridescent marble forecourts, the dazzling glass architecture, the burnished steel of the handrails: they are all deeply alienating when you are being paid very little to clean them, or if, as a supplicant hoping for just this sort of job, you are being curtly told to move off the property by a uniformed security guard one millimetre further up this food chain.

As one says to Maya, their uniforms announce them as the Untouchables of whitecollar America, they are the Invisibles. As they hunch by the lifts, gouging irritants and bits of grit out of the elevator door tracks, all the lawyers and accountants simply step over them and look through them, schooled in the taboos of the unacknowledged caste system.

Below stairs, the story is very different. The cleaners are only too visible, terrorised by their watchful supervisor, Perez, a horribly convincing study in bullying from George Lopez, a stand-up comic making a superb debut in a serious role. Writer Paul Laverty gives him a scene of almost unwatchable nastiness in which Perez fires an elderly cleaning woman for being two minutes late for her shift, and refuses to listen to her tearful pleas for mercy - while all the other cleaners look away, ashamed of their failure to intervene. It is a moment of towering, almost Dickensian cruelty. Loach is not afraid to pull the throttle out all the way for moments like these, and the scene works.

Contrary to first impressions, there are subtle moments in Loach's film, genial moments of wit, and tenderness: some looks and smiles. But this is a film with a mission, and its emotional and political register often gets turned up awfully high. Maya rages that the USA is the richest country in the world, and yet won't pay its humblest workers a decent wage. It reminded me of the smug plutocrat in a late 60s New Yorker cartoon: "I feel very proud to live in a country rich enough to have war and peace at the same time." Now in 2001, there's a new spin. It's a corporate culture belligerent enough to have wealth and poverty at the same time.

And could there be a more pertinent, contemporary subject than this? Globalisation is an issue that now exercises the political classes of both left and right: there is hand-wringing across the board at the prospect of a decreasing number of inexorably growing, merging corporations effortlessly pricing local firms out of each and every market and using the mendicant populations from developing nations for a lower wage bill. But if something is seriously to be done about it, is there an alternative to the unsophisticated, démodé business of trade union organisation?

Whatever the answer, Loach has made an engaging, enjoyable and provocative movie about the human injustices of race, sex and class accumulating in the new 21st century order. It's a film with red blood in its veins.

fields.headline: The Mexican
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Nothing in this implausible marriage of thrills and whimsy works, least of all the supposed chemistry between Brad and Julia
fields.body:
It should have been dream casting: the babelicious Brad Pitt (though here for once not showing his abs) and Julia Roberts, whose career just now is hotter than Georgia asphalt. They team up for a comedy-thriller-road-movie, in a relationship pertly triangulated by no less a person than James Gandolfini, famed for his mob boss in The Sopranos, a screen event more admirable than anything Julia or Brad have ever been involved in.

But nothing in this implausible marriage of thrills and whimsy works, least of all the supposed chemistry between Brad and Julia, a relationship the film scuppers from the outset by having them spend most of the film's interminable 124 minutes apart. And when they are together, shouting, wheedling, murmuring and smirking lines of dialogue at each other, we are always uncomfortably aware that these people are actors who just don't know each other very well. They do not click; neither do they gel - like Ming-Ming and Bao-Bao, the resolutely celibate pandas of London Zoo. Julia can just about crank up some screen energy with her great split watermelon grin, but Brad is very poor, and his entrance riding a donkey in Mexico is a virtual masterclass in how not to do funny.

The motions they go through are these: Brad plays Jerry, a lovably incompetent non-violent hoodlum, who promises his feisty girlfriend Sam (Roberts) that he will quit dirty work for the Mob - but gets bullied into accepting one last job, picking up a valuable antique pistol south of the border known as The Mexican, which everyone is after. Sam storms off and is kidnapped by the burly-yet-cuddly hit-man Gandolfini. The plot has a lot of holes, and as a "McGuffin" to drive the plot, the Mexican pistol is irritatingly unconvincing. Why would any tough US mafioso want it so much? The answer is sentimental reasons, but these are very improbable and in any case left unclear until the end.

The most disappointing thing, maybe inevitably, is Gandolfini, whose tough guy turns out to be gay, sensitive, emotionally literate and unafraid to cry in front of a woman who deftly analyses him. It is an obvious and hamfisted attempt to deconstruct and reassemble the Tony Soprano package for a different audience. The cinema career of that other HBO star Garry Shandling has not taken off, and, sadly, there is no guarantee Gandolfini's won't be similarly earthbound.

webTitle: Japan's PM puts outsiders on inside track of reform

fields.headline: Japan's PM puts outsiders on inside track of reform
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Junichiro Koizumi set his reformist stamp on a new cabinet yesterday with the appointment of several political outsiders and more women than in any ministerial line-up in Japan's history.
fields.body:
Junichiro Koizumi set his reformist stamp on a new cabinet yesterday with the appointment of several political outsiders and more women than in any ministerial line-up in Japan's history.

In a break from Japan's decades-long, male-dominated faction politics, Mr Koizumi appointed women to five of the 17 posts. No previous administration has had more than two.

"I want to appoint those who are zealous about reform," Mr Koizumi said.

The most striking figure in the cabinet is Makiko Tanaka, 57, an outspoken and popular lawmaker who becomes Japan's first female foreign minister.

The new administration's first priority will be to restructure the world's second- biggest economy, which is teetering on the verge of recession.

The task will be led by the new economic minister, Heizo Takenaka, a professor at Keio University and a leading advocate of fiscal reform, and Hukuo Yanagisawa, the current minister for financial services.

By appointing a cabinet regardless of the LDP's factional ties, Mr Koizumi is embarking on a high-risk strategy dependent on using public support for his administration to offset his weak power base in the ruling party.

"To maintain momentum, he has to do something new every day of the week," said Gerald Curtis of the National Graduate Institute of Policy Studies. "It will be a huge challenge: like trying to sprint a marathon."

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
When a neighbour's sheep falls sick our diarist fears the worst - but it's a false alarm

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: When a neighbour's sheep falls sick our diarist fears the worst - but it's a false alarm.
fields.body:
A telephone call on Wednesday from a farm neighbouring ours raised the stakes around here once more. One of their sheep had blisters on its mouth and appeared very unwell. The Maff office had been informed.

So the waiting began for all of us, again. I'm not sure which is worse, the knowing or the waiting. Both are exceedingly unpleasant and exhausting to go through day in, day out, especially after so many weeks of uncertainty and worry. It took two phone calls from the farm to Maff before a vet was sent out: the ministry said it had no record of the first call. Communication glitches like this help nobody.

The ewe in question was running a temperature of 104 degrees and the farm was cleared just before bedtime. After a thorough check by the Maff vet, all was pronounced well. The highly restrictive A notice (nothing or no one goes in or out except under licence), put on as soon as the vet was sent for, was cancelled, the children were finally allowed back in and there was an enormous sigh of relief from both their farmhouse and ours. They had telephoned us, and again we'd decided to keep quiet about it, as the rural rumour machine is already overworked.

What helped clinch the all-clear verdict was the fact that there had been no sudden deaths among their new lambs. When foot and mouth is present, the sudden death of lambs aged eight to 10 days is common, as the virus brings about an instantaneous and fatal heart attack.

The ewe under suspicion was diagnosed as having orf, a disease which also goes by the more scientific name of contagious pustular dermatitis. It is a highly infectious virus which causes painful lesions around the mouth and sometimes on the feet. A vaccine is routinely given in many flocks.

We had a few lambs with serious orf about 10 years ago, but they presented with unusual symptoms. Their heads swelled and it was difficult for them to eat or drink. Eventually, despite veterinary treatment, a couple of the affected animals died. It was only after I had taken the carcasses down to the veterinary investigation centre in Newcastle that we learned what was going on. The rest of the affected lambs were vaccinated and they eventually recovered.

Orf can be carried from one batch of animals to another via contamination of the shepherd's hands or clothes. It can affect humans painfully. I can't help wondering if some of the flocks recently diagnosed as having foot and mouth were, in fact, suffering from orf, and were culled mistakenly.

Archie, our stalwart lambing shepherd, finishes tonight. He has worked tirelessly for four and a half weeks with no days off, and we are very grateful for both his help and his good company - he has the knack of cracking jokes to lighten the atmosphere during even the darkest days. Peter says that without the extra lambing help and the first-class help from Graham, our full-time employee, he would not want to continue with farming: the workload is too heavy. I owe Archie too, as yesterday he set on the lonely pet lamb to a ewe. Let's hope it works.

We hope to be able to turn the cattle out - a procedure that resembles a wild-west rodeo - in about three weeks. Until then there is no chance of a break from the slog of twice-daily feeding and straw bedding.

Yesterday, the news reports said that contiguous culling would cease, but as I suspected, the facts were being misconstrued. Culling on contiguous premises will still occur, but it will not necessarily be a blanket cull of every single animal on every contiguous holding, which we feel is how it should have been all along. Although all dangerous contacts will still be taken out, cattle on contiguous premises may be spared if there is adequate bio-security. But sheep and pigs will not. Complacency remains our biggest danger.

Tigger, the terrier, has been up to no good again. She has had to have three baths in the back kitchen sink in the past 10 days. She has taken to running away from the garden when she thinks we are preoccupied, and she always rolls in the very worst thing she can find. Last time James got her back she was covered in muck. Of course, once she was clean and dry, with a noticeable whiff of designer shampoo, she was forgiven and allowed to watch the telly. But as dog washer-in-chief, I am hoping these smelly escapades don't become a habit.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland. Her diary appears again next Wednesday.

He has worked tirelessly for four and a half weeks with no days off, and we are very grateful for both his help and his good company - he has the knack of cracking jokes to lighten the atmosphere during even the darkest days. Peter says that without the extra lambing help and the first-class help from Graham, our full-time employee, he would not want to continue with farming: the workload is too heavy. I owe Archie too, as yesterday he set on the lonely pet lamb to a ewe. Let's hope it works. We hope to be able to turn the cattle out - a procedure that resembles a wild-west rodeo - in about three weeks. Until then there is no chance of a break from the slog of twice-daily feeding and straw bedding. Yesterday, the news reports said that contiguous culling would cease, but as I suspected, the facts were being misconstrued. Culling on contiguous premises will still occur, but it will not necessarily be a blanket cull of every single animal on every contiguous holding, which we feel is how it should have been all along. Although all dangerous contacts will still be taken out, cattle on contiguous premises may be spared if there is adequate bio-security. But sheep and pigs will not. Complacency remains our biggest danger. Tigger, the terrier, has been up to no good again. She has had to have three baths in the back kitchen sink in the past 10 days. She has taken to running away from the garden when she thinks we are preoccupied, and she always rolls in the very worst thing she can find. Last time James got her back she was covered in muck. Of course, once she was clean and dry, with a noticeable whiff of designer shampoo, she was forgiven and allowed to watch the telly. But as dog washer-in-chief, I am hoping these smelly escapades don't become a habit.  The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland. webTitle: UN calls for £7bn a year Aids fund

fields.headline: UN calls for £7bn a year Aids fund
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, told the world yesterday that it was now an "ethical imperative" that everyone infected with HIV/Aids should get medical treatment.
fields.body:
The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, told the world yesterday that it was now an "ethical imperative" that everyone infected with HIV/Aids should get medical treatment.

His tough new stance cuts more ground from under the feet of those in the west who have argued that developing countries cannot afford Aids drugs and do not have the doctors, nurses and clinics to administer them.

He called for the creation of a "war chest" of $7bn-$10bn a year (£4.8bn-£7bn) to prevent and treat HIV/Aids in the developing world, and gave unequivocal backing to the use of generic drugs: a declaration that will appal the big pharmaceutical companies, who fear the growing use of these cheap copies of their patented medicines.

"This crisis is so grave that developing countries must face it by exploiting all options to the full - including the production and importation of 'generic' drugs under licence, within the terms of international trade agreements," he told an African summit on Aids in the Nigerian capital Abuja.

Last week 39 pharmaceutical companies dropped their legal challenge to South Africa's right to import or make generic drugs when their court action became the focus of international campaigning for access to affordable drugs.

Just a year ago, Mr Annan said, few people thought treatment could be brought within the reach of the poor. "Those already infected with HIV were condemned to be treated like lepers in earlier times - as people from whom the healthy had to be protected, but for whom nothing could be done.

"[Now] there has been a worldwide revolt of public opinion. People no longer accept that the sick and dying, simply because they are poor, should be denied drugs which have transformed the lives of others who are better off."

Everybody infected with HIV had to be be able to get the anti-retroviral drugs that kept Aids at bay in the west.

This was not just ethically right, but essential to any kind of prevention strategy, he said, "because, so long as testing positive is a death sentence without hope, many people will not even want to know their HIV status". Such people are more likely to infect others.

An estimated 25.3m Africans are HIV positive and 2.4m are believed to have died last year of HIV-related causes.

Aids is expected to kill a third of today's 15-year-olds in Africa unless they get treatment. It has already reduced life expectancy by more than 20 years in Botswana, from 69 to 44; in Zimbabwe it has fallen from 65 to 43. There are 4.2m people infected in South Africa, more than any country in the world.

Options for a global Aids fund were discussed by delegates from the G7 industrialised countries, Scandinavian governments, the UN and big donors at a meeting in London on Monday.

But Mr Annan said: "The war on Aids will not be won without a war chest of a size far beyond what is available so far."

The money was needed for HIV tests, condoms, drugs, scientific research, the care of orphans, and improved healthcare systems, he added.

webTitle: A new excuse to walk the dog

fields.headline: A new excuse to walk the dog
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: The promise of collecting goods ordered online at your local pub yesterday joined the increasingly off the wall attempts to lure shoppers to the internet.
fields.body:
The promise of collecting goods ordered online at your local pub yesterday joined the increasingly off the wall attempts to lure shoppers to the internet.

Same-day delivery to homes has failed to stimulate growth in online shopping to the extent many retailers hoped but the pub could be a much more attractive alternative, according to Bass Leisure Retail and Delivery Networks, an online delivery booking service.

The companies have joined forces to launch pickup@pub and went live yesterday with initial trials at nearly 100 pubs in London.

Success would bring a roll-out of the service to the 2,000 Bass pubs across the country.

"Anyone who has had to take time off work to wait in for a delivery, or wasted a weekend tracking down parcels by post, is sure to appreciate this new service," said Adam Martin, marketing director of the hospitality group.

Mr Martin admitted Bass hopes to convert people who pick up their parcels at the pub into customers, but insisted that the service was intended to be attractive to all web shoppers and not just those people who like to prop up the bar.

Goods can be ordered from some 20 companies including Freeserve, eBay UK and Clearly Business, the Barclays bank and Freeserve business portal.

Parcel size is restricted: they have to be small enough to be stored at the pub.

Customers will be charged £1 for delivery to the bar but be given a voucher offering 50p off the price of a drink.

"Ordering over the internet is often the easy bit while waiting in for your parcel is time consuming, frustrating and defeats the original objective," said Sarah Hemstedt, the marketing director of Delivery Networks. "The flexibility of this new service will have great appeal."

fields.headline: City diary
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: • Internet portal Yahoo! finds itself embroiled in yet another heated debate on its favourite subject, freedom of speech.
fields.body:
 Internet portal Yahoo! finds itself embroiled in yet another heated debate on its favourite subject, freedom of speech.

You will recall how tenaciously the Yahoos fought (and lost) a French court battle to preserve internet access to a Nazi memorabilia website last year. More recently, they have been quietly selling porn products through their shopping and auction sites - though this practice was also curtailed earlier this month after Bible belt America got wind of the offerings.

Today, however, as the Yahoos hold their most crucial annual shareholder meeting to date, it emerges that the company's commitment to free speech stops short of allowing journalists to attend the AGM. One Yahoo told reporters that this was to ensure enough space in the meeting room for investors.

Meanwhile, journalists eager to hear the Yahoos explain away an 85% drop in share value in 12 months, as well as plunging profits and the first job cuts in the company's history, have been instructed to watch proceedings over the internet - thus guaranteeing sanitised reports and inhibiting access to disgruntled shareholders.

 Setting a better example of corporate transparency is Patrick Ricard, chairman and chief executive of French spirits firm Pernod-Ricard, who has elected to conduct a question and answer session with employees on Pernod's acquisition of fellow drinks group Seagram. The full transcript of the session is available to all on the Pernod website, www.pernod-ricard.com.

Scrolling through the text, it is not hard to imagine the sweat breaking on Mr Ricard's brow as he faced a barrage of Paxman-like questioning. "Pernod's acquisition is going to involve the integration of some very fine brands and related staff," begins one. "What is your take on this aspect?" Making prime minister's question time look like the Spanish inquisition, another questioner ventures: "Today Pernod is a leading group in France and the eurozone. Are you planning to increase your activity in other parts of the world?"

 Thanks to all who responded to yesterday's request for a review of ludicrous job titles. Perhaps the most extraordinary email claims there is a man by the name of Andrew Mark Smith working at Rolls-Royce's Derby plant under the improbable title Supplier Quality Renaissance Leader. Suspecting our leg is being pulled, we call Rolls-Royce who, to our amazement, confirm these details (though asked what he does, the woman on the switchboard says: "I've no idea."). According to our emailer, Mr Smith's previous posts include Commitment Acceptance Engineer and Cell Leader.

 They once taught a generation of internet folk to sip champagne with venture capitalists - deftly fanning the flames of outsized ambition - and now they are back. First Tuesday, the dot.com networking club sold for £33m last summer and bought back by its original members for £1m earlier this year, is to hold its first London event since the buyback on Thursday of next week. The cast is likely to be much as before, though the focus of chat, we are told, will be on "the importance of the merger and acquisition exit in today's climate". Know these people no shame?

Simon.bowers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Bulger killer 'mollycoddled'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The mother of murdered toddler James Bulger has accused social workers of mollycoddling her son's killers after it emerged that one of them had been allowed to watch Manchester United play as part of his rehabilitation into the community.
fields.body:
The mother of murdered toddler James Bulger has accused social workers of mollycoddling her son's killers after it emerged that one of them had been allowed to watch Manchester United play as part of his rehabilitation into the community.

Jon Venables, 18, has reportedly travelled to Old Trafford several times with his father in preparation for his release from secure accommodation. They were accompanied by two members of staff from the unit.

He also allegedly plays five-a-side football once a week against schoolboys who do not know his true identity. A carer from the secure unit where he is detained claimed that he had been treated with favouritism.

"It made me sick to see how many privileges he was given, like he was some kind of VIP," he said. "Venables had a PlayStation 2 for Christmas, when millions of kids went without."

No one at Manchester United would comment about claims that Venables had attended its matches. A club spokesman said nobody knew of his visits and they did not give tickets to social services.

Venables's solicitor, John Dickinson, said: "In any child who is detained for a lengthy period of time then, subject to risk assessment, rehabilitation includes leaving the unit." He said he could not comment on whether his client had been taken to watch football games.

James Bulger's mother Denise Fergus, who lives in Kirkby, Merseyside, said she felt Venables was being mollycoddled: "I am not surprised that social workers are prepared to do almost anything Venables wants. Both [Robert] Thompson and Venables have always been mollycoddled and given special privileges ever since they were put in care.

"It makes me very angry because it shows that they have never been punished - all they had is rewards for murdering my son."

She claimed Venables had some kind of hold over most of the staff there.

Her two-year-old son was abducted by Venables and Thompson from a shopping centre in Bootle in 1993 and murdered.

This year it emerged that Thompson had made supervised visits to the Trafford Centre in Manchester. It is understood that Venables has also visited the shopping mall and the Meadowhall centre in Sheffield.

Sean Sexton, the solicitor representing Ms Fergus, said the problem about Venables and Thompson's new identities was that no one else knew who they were dealing with. "If they are released he could be playing football or drinking next to you in a pub," he said.

webTitle: Harare judge overturns violent election victories

fields.headline: Harare judge overturns violent election victories
fields.standfirst:
Court ruling gives the Zimbabwe opposition some hope of eventually beating Mugabe at the polls

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Court ruling gives the Zimbabwe opposition some hope of eventually beating Mugabe at the polls.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and agencies
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean opposition won a crucial legal victory yesterday when the high court overturned last summer's general election results in two constituencies on the grounds that the candidates for the government party, Zanu-PF, secured their victory by violence and intimidation.

If the ruling is upheld on appeal, there will be byelections in Buhera north, where the Movement of Democratic Change (MDC) president Morgan Tsvangirai was defeated, and another rural constituency.

During the violence-racked election campaign two of Mr Tsvangirai's aides died in a firebomb attack by men identified as state agents.

Jubilant MDC supporters mobbed him outside the court after Judge James DeVittie gave his ruling.

"We are delighted with this ruling. It vindicates our position to contest the elections in the courts," Mr Tsvangirai said.

"It puts in focus what we have said all along, that the elections were not free and fair. It also shows the judiciary has not succumbed to intimidation from the government. We are expecting more victories in other key constituencies."

The MDC has challenged 37 other Zanu-PF victories.

"The people in my constituency are itching for a re-run," Mr Tsvangirai said.

Kenneth Manyonda, a senior Zanu-PF official and former provincial governor, and Reuben Marumahoko, whose victories were overturned, remain in parliament until their appeals are heard. If the verdict is upheld, they will be barred from holding public office or seeking election for five years.

Despite widespread violence, the MDC won 57 of the 120 elected seats in the parliamentary elections last June. Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF has a comfortable majority because the president appoints another 30 members.

Nevertheless, the MDC could gain an absolute majority if it wins 19 of its legal challenges and goes on to win the byelections.

Shortly after the court ruling, the police raided Mr Tsvangirai's offices and arrested four of his security staff and an office worker.

"These arrests are sour grapes after our win in the courts," Mr Tsvangirai said.

"It is part of the continuing intimidation that all of Zimbabwe is experiencing."

Harare remains in the grip of a wave of violent intimidation of factories and businesses by Mr Mugabe's "war veteran" supporters.

Scores of factories and companies have been invaded and their managers, both black and white, have been beaten up. The veterans have demanded large payments, on the pretext that they were settling old labour disputes.

Their leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, said yesterday that his followers would soon invade embassies and international aid organisations to prevent them providing assistance to the MDC.

webTitle: The dictator is behind bars, but the unravelling goes on

fields.headline: The dictator is behind bars, but the unravelling goes on
fields.standfirst:
The breakdown Milosevic started is slower now but still irrevocable

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The breakdown Milosevic started is slower now but still irrevocable
fields.body:
Trapped in his Belgrade prison cell, Slobodan Milosevic can only watch in impotence as Yugoslavia continues to unravel. The process which he bears more responsibility than any other Balkan leader for starting is not moving with as much blood or speed as when he was in power. But it is just as irrevocable. In parliamentary elections last Sunday roughly 56% of Montenegro's voters (on a high turn-out of 80%) supported parties which campaigned to break with Serbia and go for independence. In Kosovo the drafting of an interim constitution which will give the one-time Serbian province a parliament and president was moving towards its climax this week.

In this new period of slow-motion change in the Balkans, western policy is more coherent than it was when images of war and human catastrophe dominated the front pages, demanding action. But there is still a surprising amount of confusion. If the tendency then was to respond late and feebly when emergency measures to stop the killing were needed, now the first reflex is to go against the flow even when it is peaceful and democratic.

It took only a few hours after Vojislav Kostunica's election to the Yugoslav presidency last autumn for it to become clear that the Montenegrin government was not going to give up its drive for independence. During the Milosevic era western leaders had assumed it was his manipulation and bullying which alienated most Montenegrins. Once democracy revived in Serbia, the expectation was that they would return to the fold. The opposite happened. Milosevic's threats to use the Yugoslav army against the pro-independence movement had acted as a deterrent but they were also a goad. When the new Yugoslav president wisely lifted the threat of force, the Montenegrins were emboldened to escape while they could. After all, for several years they had been tempted with the charms of independence by the west itself, which wanted them to assert as much autonomy from Milosevic's Belgrade as possible. The west helped Montenegro to break from the Serbian economy by introducing the Deutschmark as its official currency. During the Kosovo crisis Montenegro's leaders were offered constant trips to foreign summits with all the trappings of independent status.

The elections last weekend were the first test of support for independence in the post-Milosevic era. They did not produce as big a victory for President Milo Djukanovic as he hoped. Over-confidence let his campaign organisers down, as did heavy funding from Belgrade for the opposition. But western diplomats are wrong to focus on the narrow margin of 2% by which Djukanovic's coalition emerged as the largest force in parliament.

The pro-independence Liberals and three Albanian parties also did well, amounting to a de facto vote for secession of 56.5% . Such totals are often called landslides, and Robin Cook and other western officials, who rushed to Podgorica this week to claim stalemate, urge delay, and threaten the government with aid cuts, would have done better to analyse things coolly.

Djukanovic will certainly have difficulties with a fully-fledged referendum on independence. The opposition may call for a boycott, leaving it hard to get the required 50% turn-out. In parliament he does not have the two-thirds majority needed to change the constitution. But a Yes vote will give him a moral case which will be hard to resist if his side gets as big a margin as it did in Sunday's general election.

Some western opponents of Montenegrin independence argue that one must be nice to Kostunica. Without Montenegro, Yugoslavia disappears and the president loses his job. But Kostunica already has his eye on the Serbian presidency and he is still popular enough to win it if elections are held soon. Others fear the final dissolution of Yugoslavia would make Kosovo independent by default. If there is a good argument for being careful about Montenegrin independence, it is neither of these. The risk is of violence within Montenegro itself which could be provoked from ei ther side, by a pro-independence majority which feels unfairly denied just as much as by a pro-Yugoslav minority which wants to hang on to the status quo. The danger of bloodshed is small but western policy would do better to concentrate on this rather than the false strategic problems for the region which it claims to see. The west should be neutral about independence but make it clear it will put enough observers in place to monitor the referendum's fairness and ensure its results are implemented non-violently and through negotiation, both inside Montenegro and between Podgorica and Belgrade.

On Kosovo, by contrast, western policy appears to be getting back in line with the democratic aspirations of the majority. The draft has not yet been made public but reports suggest the new "legal framework" for the territory which is being worked out by the UN administrator, Hans Haekkerup, and local Albanian leaders will give the Albanians most of what they have been asking. After first taking the minimalist approach, it now seems that western governments are willing to let Kosovo have a president rather than a chief executive, a parliament rather than an assembly, and even an interim constitution. Haekkerup or his UN successor will have the final say in the most sensitive areas of policy just as his internationally-appointed counterpart does in Bosnia, even though Bosnia is a nominally independent state. These two Balkan protectorates are doomed to last for a long time.

But Kosovo will get the symbols of sovereignty and these matter as an incentive to responsible self-government. They also imply that the territory can never be part of Serbia again - a de facto guarantee of what every Kosovo Albanian wants. The main obstacle to signing the new document is the Albanian leaders' demand for it to include a promise of a referendum on independence in the foreseeable future. That is not something which Haekkerup has a mandate to give, or the security council over Russian, Chinese, and some western governments' objections will currently accept.

The Albanians were being given this tough message on their visit to Brussels yesterday. fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a piece on climate change (Bushwacked, Society page 11 April 25) we presented possible world temperature increases as being "between 1.4C (34F) and 5.8C (42F)".
fields.body:
In a piece on climate change (Bushwacked, Society page 11 April 25) we presented possible world temperature increases as being "between 1.4C (34F) and 5.8C (42F)". The Fahrenheit equivalents were wrongly given as converted temperatures rather than increases - those figures should have read 2.5F and 10.4F

The phone number given for the Manchester Environmental Resource Centre Initiative (Merci) was incorrect (Space of waste, Society, page 10). Merci can be contacted on 0161 273 1736.

Our explanation of nuclear fission (Hot house, G2 page 2, April 25), contained the statement that natural uranium consisted of U-233 and U-235, which is radioactive. Natural uranium is very largely U-238, not 233, and U-238 is also radioactive, but not nearly as much as U-235. The process, as described by Cesare Emiliani in The Scientific Companion (1995), page 29, is as follows: "This is how the atom bomb works: neutrons produced by the spontaneous fission of U-238 mixed in with U-235 cause the fission of U-235 nucleii; this produces more neutrons which go to fission more U-235, and so on. So much energy is produced so fast that the whole thing blows up."

Yesterday's statement from the human rights lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, QC (Saddam inquiry sparks debate on immunity, page 15), referred to the traditional view that heads of state are "immune from policies" in English courts. This should have read "immune from prosecution".

Marie Colvin was reported to be the only journalist to stay behind in the besieged UN compound in the East Timor capital of Dili last year (Time to call the editors to account, G2, page 7, April 18). Two Dutch journalists, Irene Slegt and Minka Nijhuis, were also there, as we reported in September 1999.

fields.headline: Watching his back
fields.standfirst: If Thabo Mbeki is indeed paranoid, there is probably some justification for it
fields.trailText: If Thabo Mbeki is indeed paranoid, there is probably some justification for it
fields.body:
Thirty thousand people will crowd into Trafalgar Square on Sunday to celebrate the new South Africa. Presiding over it will be former president Nelson Mandela, basking in universal love and approval.

Meanwhile, encumbent president Thabo Mbeki is at home, allegedly glancing fearfully over his shoulder for potential rivals lining up to bump him off. It is in the gap between the relative popularity of these two men that the new South Africa really lies.

It was Mandela who wove the seductive narrative that South Africans could transcend their bitter past and emerge as the rainbow nation, working in harmony for a mutually prosperous future. It fell to Mbeki to manage the reality: that, if resources were to be spread equally, they would have to be spread pretty thinly.

Sources close to Mbeki yesterday denied he is paranoid and say the controversial police investigation into plotting against Mbeki by Cyril Ramaphosa and/or Mathews Phosa and Tokio Sexwale is to dispel persistent damaging rumours. While Mbeki may not be paranoid (mental disorder with delusions of persecution; Oxford Dictionary), he is right to feel threatened. First, he probably acquired the habit when working for the ANC in exile in London and Lusaka: the apartheid government not only infiltrated spies into every level of the organisation but also made several attempts on his life.

Those close to him admit there is very little possibility his life is now in danger; but he is entirely justified in thinking that his job is. And why not? The post-Mandela era has thrown up other strong potential leaders. Cyril Ramaphosa - whose unionisation of the gold mines in the 80s and leading role in democracy negotiations still give him hero status - is indeed a powerful contender. So is Jacob Zuma, the current deputy president, who is credited with stopping the seemingly intractable Kwazulu/Natal wars between the IFP and the ANC.

Cosatu, which is to the ANC what the TUC was to Labour, have been consistently critical of Mbeki's Aids policy and have now warned against his use of the police to investigate his rivals. Mandela's support for them is also damaging for his successor.

Nor have the press been particularly kind, although their motivation is quite different. Newspapers in South Africa are largely a white affair: mostly run and read by white people. Some 38% of the English daily press and 14 % of the weekly press is owned by a foreigner - Tony O'Reilly's Independent Group. In the main, they pander to white prejudice which, increasingly, is informed by a sense of dwindling privilege. The generous, reconciliatory glow cast over the white community by Mandela has long faded.

Many are taking hard the loss of political power and monopoly of state resources they enjoyed under the apartheid government, and this niggling sense of being robbed is expressed in an obsession with crime and government corruption - even though some figures show that 70% of the victims of violent crime know the perpetrator and the majority of victims are African women and children.

Many whites expect the worst of the government and the press reflects that. These negative images beamed abroad discourage the tourism and foreign investment needed to boost the economy, increase employment and thereby fight both crime and poverty.

Take last week's story in which newspapers worldwide echoed horrified reports that Gauteng, the largest province, had banned Nadine Gordimer's July's People. As it turned out, it was merely some lowly committee of misguided teachers who had recommended the ban. But it was a week before the government got round to letting the world know that they had never had any intention of following their advice. By then the damage had been done.

The vision thing so powerfully employed by Mandela seems to escape Mbeki altogether. Not only has he failed to create a national narrative that would inspire all South Africans, he has allowed his enemies to magnify his errors, while all but burying his successes.

Mbeki's mistakes are well rehearsed: the Aids fiasco was one; this involvement of state forces in what appears to be internal party politics is clearly another. But, quietly, he has also done a great deal of good. The economy is much better managed than it has ever been, growing by 3% last year; millions more people have houses and access to running water, electricity, education and health care. Public institutions which were wastefully and inefficiently run, essentially as sheltered employment for whites, have been slimmed down and their racial and gender profiles transformed.

And, notwithstanding the complaints about Mbeki's repressiveness, there is an energy and vitality to political and cultural life that South Africans could only have dreamed of under apartheid.

That is what is supposed to be being celebrated on Sunday - and in the subsequent six-week fest of dance, song, film and theatre in venues throughout London. In June, Mbeki comes for a state visit. It would be well for him if it is the magic cast by Madiba on Sunday night that is remembered here, not this fiasco.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Pump primer Human resources software company Job Partners yesterday secured £11m in funding. The firm, whose investors include Cisco and ING Barings, will use the money for acquisitions and to expand in Europe.
fields.body:
 Pump primer Human resources software company Job Partners yesterday secured £11m in funding. The firm, whose investors include Cisco and ING Barings, will use the money for acquisitions and to expand in Europe. The company, which received £4m last May, hopes to be profitable by the end of this year.

 Brand switch IT services company FI Group yesterday announced that it was rebranding itself as Xansa. The rebranding of the company, which has taken about nine months and involved four consultancies, cost the company about £1.5m.

 Strong growth British software company Logica said yesterday that its strong revenue growth in the first half of the financial year had continued into the third quarter. "Our confidence in the future ... remains undiminished," said finance director Andrew Given. Shares in Logica rose more than 5% on the news to 795p.

 Narrowed losses American ISP Prodigy Communications said yesterday that its first-quarter losses narrowed and revenues rose as its subscriber base grew, but warned that full-year revenues would be flat or lower than a year earlier.

fields.headline: Autonomy senses a thaw
fields.trailText: Software firm Autonomy yesterday warned that it could not predict when the trading conditions that forced it to issue a profits warning earlier this month would improve. But it seemed confident that contracts currently on ice would get signed.
fields.body:
Software firm Autonomy yesterday warned that it could not predict when the trading conditions that forced it to issue a profits warning earlier this month would improve. But it seemed confident that contracts currently on ice would get signed.

Shares in the Cambridge-based company, which halved when the first warning was made, rallied 24% to 430p at relief that first-quarter results announced yesterday were no worse than expected and following news of an important licence win.

Revenues of $14.7m (£10.2m) for the three months to March 31 and a pre-tax profit of $8.8m were in line with analysts' expectations, which were revised after the company warned of a slowdown in UK and European orders.

Mike Lynch, Autonomy's chief executive, said: "You can't bank on anything anymore but we're confident that the contracts some customers have put on hold will get signed. Seven of the 15 that were put on ice have already come through and we're optimistic about the other eight."

Darren Curtis, analyst at Autonomy's stockbroker Deutsche Bank, said the announcement that the major software firm BEA would incorporate Autonomy's product into its own was one of the key drivers behind the jump in the share price. "The disappointing top-line numbers have already been dis counted and today's new information was all better than expected," he said.

Mr Lynch remained confident about Autonomy's long-term prospects, saying that it still had $144m cash in the bank.

Although analysts took heart from the results they warned that a repeat of the last minute deferrals, that hit the first-quarter results, could not be discounted given the instability of the market.

Technology and software firms are complaining about a lack of "visibility" - the ability to forecast future sales patterns. They blame it on the reluctance of big customers to spend on new products while the full extent of the economic downturn is unknown.

fields.headline: At this price? Cookson
fields.trailText: Cookson Group is having a torrid time with the two main planks of its business, with electronics and ceramics being hurt in the US economic downturn.
fields.body:
Cookson Group is having a torrid time with the two main planks of its business, with electronics and ceramics being hurt in the US economic downturn.

The last time Cookson was hit in both areas simultaneously was during the Asia crisis and the company admitted at its annual shareholder meeting yesterday that the outlook looked grim.

The stock has already underperformed its sector by 12% and the FTSE all share index by 7%. Yesterday they fell a further 5% yesterday to end the day at 145p.

Shareholders were told that "the outlook is that the difficult trading conditions we are currently experiencing are likely to persist, at least through the second quarter.

"The electronics industry experienced an exceptionally sharp fall in demand in the first quarter, particularly in the US where printed circuit board manufacturing volumes are well down and order intake has fallen by an unprecedented rate, by 40%."

Reduced US demand also hit the ceramics unit with sales down by 12% in the first quarter. Ceramics are used for heat insulation with materials such as steel and make up one third of Cookson sales. But Cookson also showed itself to be no slouch in taking remedial action. It cut 1,550 jobs in the US over the first quarter - six times greater than anticipated.

Ian Rennardson, electronics analyst at Merrill Lynch, notes that while Cookson is heavily exposed to the economic slowdown it is just as strongly geared for the upside.

"During the Asian crunch of 1998, Cookson shares came back very strongly from something like 90p to 270p within a year of [economic market] recovery," he said.

Last week Merrill Lynch significantly downgraded pre-tax profit forecasts for Cookson to £145m and 14.3p earnings per share but still rates the stock as a long- term buy.

fields.headline: Private word on Merant
fields.trailText: When Merant, the Anglo-American software group, announced it had ended discussions about a possible takeover in February it attempted to sugar the pill.
fields.body:
When Merant, the Anglo-American software group, announced it had ended discussions about a possible takeover in February it attempted to sugar the pill by telling the market it was intent on delivering shareholder value and was reviewing a broad range of strategic alternatives.

Since then there has been nothing apart from a rather gloomy third-quarter trading statement in late February.

Yesterday the shares moved higher for the first time in a long while on rumours that Merant's management are considering a buyout.

fields.headline: Defence firms join forces
fields.trailText: Consolidation in the European defence sector will quicken today with a brace of mergers in missiles and radar systems.
fields.body:
Consolidation in the European defence sector will quicken today with a brace of mergers in missiles and radar systems.

A complex series of joint ventures and stand-alone subsidiaries among big defence contractors in Britain, France and Italy will be simplified with the aim of providing stronger, more integrated businesses.

The two new entities, both involving BAE Systems, the UK's premier contractor, will have combined sales of around €3.5bn (£2.2bn) and employ 18,000 people across the three countries.

They could significantly boost BAE's fortunes since the group took a hammering earlier this year when it issued a profits warning in January and reported a sharp downturn in earnings last month.

The new combinations break the logjam in European consolidation since BAE took over former GEC's defence electronic business and France's Aérospatiale Matra teamed up with Germany's Dasa, BAE's jilted partner, and Spain's Dasa to forge EADS.

A critical factor behind the mergers, to be announced today, is to create the financial firepower and economies of scale that will enable the new joint ventures to compete with companies such as America's Raytheon and Northrop Grumman.

In missiles the Italian group Finmeccanica has agreed to fold that activity of Alenia Marconi Systems - itself a 50:50 joint venture with BAE Systems - into Matra BAE Dynamics.

MBD is in turn a 50:50 joint venture between BAE Systems and EADS. It will also take over the remaining missiles business of what was Aérospatiale Matra, with the enlarged company to be known as MBDA.

This grouping, which has annual sales of more than €2bn and an order book of €13bn, will be second only to Raytheon in global scale.

The hope is that it will eventually encompass all the partners, including separate German and Swedish firms, which successfully outbid Raytheon to supply its Meteor missiles for the UK's fleet of Eurofighters.

webTitle: Market forces: Billiton is sold short

fields.headline: Billiton is sold short
fields.trailText: The tangle of cross holdings which link the world's mining companies unravelled further yesterday as Anglo American placed its 7% stake in rival Billiton with City institutions.
fields.body:
The tangle of cross holdings which link the world's mining companies unravelled further yesterday as Anglo American placed its 7% stake in rival Billiton with City institutions.

The sale forced Billiton down 24.5p to 321p - the worst performer in the FTSE 100 - as hedge funds sold the shares short in anticipation of buying them back at a lower price in the placing.

But market sources played down rumours that Anglo, off 50p to £44.35, was selling the shares to help pay for the increased $18bn (£12.5bn) offer it and a consortium of investors made for diamond company De Beers yesterday.

Apparently, Anglo decided to sell in order to take advantage of the recent strength of Billiton's share price, which is expected to come under pressure as it completes its merger with Australian firm BHP.

Investment bank Goldman Sachs was given the task of placing the 165m shares with institutions. Market sources said demand had been strong with Goldman closing the book-building exercise ahead of schedule. Goldman is said to have placed the shares at 317p, raising £524m, before expenses, for Anglo.

Meanwhile, BT slipped 30p to 550p as the resignation of the chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, sparked speculation that the company was preparing a radical solution to solve its crippling debt problem. According to the market gossip, BT is just days away from revealing a £5bn rights issue.

But the prospect of mammoth rights issue made little impact on the FTSE 100 index, which closed 40.8 points higher at 5,868.3, due to a strong showing from oil companies Shell , up 11p to 585p, and BP, 22p stronger at 638.5p. Turnover was modest, with 1.9bn shares changing hands.

The tech sector also had a good day with the FTSE Techmark 100 index climbing 53.46 points to 1,958.96 after a comforting trading statement from IT services firm Logica, 84p higher at 844p.

The update lifted rivals CMG, 18.5p better at 341.5p, and Misys, 20p stronger at 585p.

Optical component maker Bookham Technology, recovered from Wednesday's drubbing, rising 60p to 331p on talk that US chip company Cypress Semiconductor is mulling a £8 a share bid. On a rather sounder footing, International Power advanced 7.5p to 298.5p with traders salivating over the prospect of a £20m cash windfall for the group.

The government of Pakistan has just dropped corruption proceedings against Hub Power Company, which is 26% owned by International Power. The ending of the legal case is, say traders, a prerequisite for Hubco paying its first dividend to shareholders for several years. Analysts estimate that International Power could receive a dividend of £20m this year and up to £25m thereafter.

Elsewhere, British Airways dipped 9p to 328p as investors began to fret about a slowdown in revenues on its lucrative transatlantic routes after a downgrade from Merrill Lynch. Citing a "softer than expected revenue backdrop" Merrill lowered its 2002 pre-tax profits to £256m from £424m previously.

Vague talk of a bid from a private equity house helped Invensys , the controls and automation group, end 5.5p higher at 143p.

The FTSE 250 index edged up 0.6 point at 6,309.2, with transport company Arriva, up 16p at 301p, among the top performers after ABN Amro upgraded its rating to "buy". The Dutch broker feels the company is significantly undervalued.

In the smaller companies' universe, Scoot.com rose 2.25p to 11.25p on rumours that it is close to selling Loot, the classified advertising business it bought last year for £178m, to an overseas bidder. Scoot is under pressure to sell the business to boost its dwindling cash reserves.

Elsewhere, video-phone specialist Motion Media finished unchanged at 94.5p despite talk that an important announcement, possibly concerning BT, is on the way.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BG wins back 2m clients
fields.body:
BG wins back 2m clients

British Gas, the energy supply arm of Centrica, said it had regained 2m gas customers who switched to new suppliers after market liberalisation. Since the market opened to full competition in 1998, 6m of the country's 20m gas customers had switched supplier to make savings, leaving British Gas with 70% of the UK residential market.

The company said it had also won 4m new electricity customers.

Drug push for AstraZeneca

A strong US launch of ulcer drug Nexium helped AstraZeneca, Britain's second biggest pharmaceuticals company, increase its first-quarter profits by 12% to $1.11bn (£770m).

Nexium snatched 3% of the multi-billion dollar US market for acid disorders in just three weeks.

The product is crucial for AstraZeneca, because it replaces off-patent ulcer drug Losec, which accounts for more than a third of group sales.

The company warned its profits would decline in the second quarter as sales of Losec drop.

Boeing plane may fly early

Boeing said its £6bn project to develop a "sonic cruiser", which would cut four hours of the 22-hour journey from London to Sydney, could be launched as early as next year.

But the airline industry has yet to be convinced that Boeing can commercially outsmart its main rival, Airbus.

The European consortium will launch its 550-seater A380, the world's largest airliner, in the next four years. It is more advanced than its American rival and has more than 600 positive orders from some of the biggest airlines.

Trader loses court challenge

A former JP Morgan trader found guilty of two charges of manipulating the stock market for profit yesterday lost a high court challenge of importance to all the City's major regulatory bodies.

In the first case of its kind, Frenchman Bertrand Fleurose alleged that he was denied a fair hearing by the securities and futures authority, in breach of the European convention on human rights.

The former vice-president of American investment bank JP Morgan received a two-year suspension from trading and was ordered to pay £175,000 in legal costs.

Another new man at M&S

Marks & Spencer has hired Barry Stevenson from Kingfisher to become its new retail director. He was hired by managing director Roger Holmes, who joined M&S from Kingfisher himself in January.

Mr Stevenson, 41, who was managing director of B&Q Supercentres, will join M&S immediately. He will not have a seat on the main board.

webTitle: Pay boost for workers as Mini rolls off production line

fields.headline: Pay boost for workers as Mini rolls off production line
fields.trailText: The first 50 of the new generation Mini, replacing the model first launched in 1959, rolled along BMW's new £230m body and assembly lines yesterday in time for the car's official arrival in British salesrooms on July 7.
fields.body:
The first 50 of the new generation Mini, replacing the model first launched in 1959, rolled along BMW's new £230m body and assembly lines yesterday in time for the car's official arrival in British salesrooms on July 7.

Under a ground-breaking, two-year agreement with unions, BMW is allowed to ramp up shop-floor hours to the EU maximum when it wants to match output to demand. It has already increased the basic working week from 35 to 37 hours.

Up to 2,500 employees at the German car group's Oxford plant are working a 46-hour week, the maximum permitted under EU laws, to produce the Mini.

In return, according to Herbert Diess, the Oxford plant's managing director, the workforce is receiving pay increases of up to 17% - including 4% last year, 3% this year and a further 3% to compensate for the rise in the basic working week. In addition, there are personal and quality bonuses.

Average weekly pay for a production worker is between £343 and £360 - or £20 more than when Rover, sold by BMW last year, owned the plant.

The flexible working conditions are designed to enable BMW to raise output of the new Mini from 30,000 this year to 100,000 next year and, ultimately, 120,000 if demand is high. The basic Mini will cost £10,300 on the road in Britain.

Already, labour and skills shortages in the Oxford area, where unemployment is effectively 1% or less, have forced BMW to begin recruiting 1,800 temporary staff as volume out put rises. According to Mr Diess, about 5,000 people have applied for these posts via three recruitment agencies. The temporary staff, some of whom may be offered permanent posts, are paid at agency rates.

Mr Diess admitted that the group was struggling to attract skilled labour on a par with its German staff but insisted that BMW employees were among the most highly paid in the British car industry, earning twice as much as service sector staff in Oxford.

BMW's two-year union deal, designed to ensure an uninterrupted production-run for the Mini and approved by 82% in a ballot last November, means the Oxford plant is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

Under a "working time account" staff can now put in 46 hours because they got full rates of pay for doing fewer hours while training. They can work up to 200 hours a year more or less than the basic amount, with extra hours taken - at management discretion - as increased leisure.

Employees work a 9.5 hour shift, with the total break time reduced from 55 to 45 minutes. The extra 10 minutes is compensated for by cash. The normal working day is from 5am to 6pm, with work outside these hours counted as overtime.

According to Ernst Baumann, BMW's group human resources director: "The staff voted to generate more cash, we wanted more output and the result was a win-win situation."

Mr Diess said the Mini should be profitable next year, with industry estimates that it could be generating £700m a year on full production.

fields.headline: The German model
fields.trailText: BMW's three British plants have been set demanding targets of surpassing the 10% annual productivity growth in its German factories, according to Ernst Baumann, the car group's human resources director.
fields.body:
BMW's three British plants have been set demanding targets of surpassing the 10% annual productivity growth in its German factories, according to Ernst Baumann, the car group's human resources director.

Noted for the rigidity of its economy, Germany in recent years has become a model of flexible industrial relations and working patterns - based on what Mr Baumann calls "state of the art equipment and training, training, training".

"We have not decided to stay in Britain with the old levels of productivity," he said in an acid comment on BMW's disastrous experience with Rover.

BMW is investing £960m in Britain and will not tolerate failure this time.

Even the award-winning Rover 75, now built by MG Rover at Longbridge, achieved productivity levels of just 70-75% of the German plants. Oxford, Hams Hall, the engine plant near Coventry employing 500, and Goodwood, home of the new Rolls-Royce, due to employ 350, have to match and then go beyond Regensburg and Dingolfingen.

The crucial shift is "moving from the rules of mass production [as in Britain until now] to those of building premium cars to customer specification in Germany," Mr Baumann said. Up to 85% of the German plant's output is produced under the latter model.

Preparing for the new Mini has meant trawling Britain for highly skilled labour - in short supply - and paying for 20,000 training days, with 200 of the top shop-floor personnel sent to Germany and BMW's US plant.

Skill shortages, according to Mr Baumann, can be overcome because "we don't have problems in recruiting highly qualified, young staff; we don't have a loser image".
