fields.headline: Swedes win CHG for £237m
fields.standfirst: Capio to expand cosmetic surgery group
fields.trailText: Swedish doctors could soon carry out many of Britain's breast reductions, tummy tucks and nose jobs, following a £237m agreed bid for Community Hospitals Group by Stockholm-based Capio.
fields.body:
Swedish doctors could soon carry out many of Britain's breast reductions, tummy tucks and nose jobs, following a £237m agreed bid for Community Hospitals Group by Stockholm-based Capio.

Capio intends to bring Swedish medical staff to Britain to work in CHG's 21 hospitals, which are leading providers of cosmetic surgery.

Capio's chief executive Per Batelson said: "Physicians employed in Scandinavia are very keen to develop contact with their counterparts in the UK. We will be sending people over for education and for ordinary work." The Swedish firm's 665p a share cash bid is likely to end a year of uncertainty over CHG's ownership.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers blocked a takeover by private insurance network Bupa, then referred an offer by rival hospital operator General Healthcare to the competition commission. Capio is unlikely to face regulatory problems because its only existing business in Britain is a chain of Florence Nightingale psychiatric institutions. Mr Batelson said: "We are confident that our offer will succeed."

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which bought a 27% stake in CHG on behalf of Bupa, has been pressing for an alternative takeover. The deal will mean a £2.1m windfall for CHG's chairman, Alan Dexter.

Capio intends to forge closer links with the public sector. Mr Batelson said he hoped to carry out more NHS opera tions in CHG's hospitals: "We have very good experience from Sweden in how to work with the public sector."

Less than 10% of CHG's turnover at present is from NHS work. Mr Batelson wants to increase this by offering radiology, pathology and more sophisticated surgery, including heart bypasses and cancer treatment. Capio is one of Sweden's biggest private healthcare providers, with revenue last year of £228m. It is listed in Stockholm.

Analysts gave a thumbs-up to the deal. Paul Saper of LCS International said: "It's a decent price and it means a big sigh of relief for the management of CHG, who've been worried about their jobs. We can expect Capio to build on the occupational health side."

CHG is the fourth largest operator of private hospitals behind General Healthcare, Bupa and Nuffield.

The government was concerned that a combination with Bupa, the biggest private purchaser, would be anti-competitive. CHG's shares jumped 12.5p to 657.5p.

webTitle: All aboard P&O takes delivery of the 2,600-passenger Golden Princess

fields.headline: All aboard P&O takes delivery of the 2,600-passenger Golden Princess
fields.trailText: P&O Princess takes delivery today of its latest vessel in Italy, the 2,600-passenger Golden Princess, above, - the largest cruise ship to ever dock in Britain when it sails into Southampton next week.
fields.body:
P&O Princess takes delivery today of its latest vessel in Italy, the 2,600-passenger Golden Princess, above, - the largest cruise ship to ever dock in Britain when it sails into Southampton next week.

The ship- the size of three football pitches - is one of nine new vessels contracted by P&O Princess, the third largest cruise operator in the world.

The company yesterday reported a 64% slump in first-quarter profits and predicted that revenue margins would be lower by 3% over the year.

Shares in the company, demerged from the P&O group last November, climbed from 297.5p to 304p after it showed better trading conditions in the first quarter than at the end of 2000.

The company's pre-tax profits for the first quarter of this year were $18.9m (£13.1m), while its earnings per share slumped to 2.6 cents from 6.6 cents. The stock has outperformed the FTSE all share index by 9% since January after a torrid end to last year.

The US economic slowdown coupled with fears about overcapacity have forced P&O Princess and its major competitors, Carnival and Royal Caribbean Cruises to cut their fares.

All three companies have seen their profits tumble.

P&O Princess has been forced to cut overheads, for example by moving its main booking offices from London and Los Angeles to cheaper locations.

The ship- the size of three football pitches - is one of nine new vessels contracted by P&O Princess, the third largest cruise operator in the world. The company yesterday reported a 64% slump in first-quarter profits and predicted that revenue margins would be lower by 3% over the year. webTitle: Mayflower warns of tight bus market

fields.headline: Mayflower warns of tight bus market
fields.trailText: Mayflower Corporation, the engineering group, yesterday warned that markets for coaches in Britain and heavy trucks in the US were slowing faster than anticipated and said further job cuts might be needed.
fields.body:
Mayflower Corporation, the engineering group, yesterday warned that markets for coaches in Britain and heavy trucks in the US were slowing faster than anticipated and said further job cuts might be needed.

Growing fears about trading conditions were revealed at the company's annual general shareholder meeting.

Shares in the company fell - closing at 76.5p, down 4p - as it blamed foot and mouth for a one fifth reduction in the number of buses and coaches being sold in Britain. Tour operators were shy about ordering new vehicles because of falling tourist bookings and Mayflower did not expect to make up the shortfall.

Chief executive John Simpson also said the truck market in the US, which had been expected to dip by around 25%, now looked like falling by something closer to 30%.

Mr Simpson said he was not issuing a profits warning because "we can offset this by taking out costs". Further redundancies in the US were possible.

The US market, for which its MVS subsidiary produces truck and bus body parts, was continuing to suffer from manufacturers shutting down production at short notice.

Thomas Dennis, the joint venture company in which Mayflower has a 49% stake and which manufactures and markets buses in the US, is now thought unlikely to move into profit this year.

webTitle: US politician and Vietnam war hero admits killing civilians

fields.headline: US politician and Vietnam war hero admits killing civilians
fields.trailText: One of America's most widely admired and highly decorated politicians of modern times has admitted to leading a combat mission during the Vietnam war which shot dead more than a dozen unarmed women and children.
fields.body:
One of America's most widely admired and highly decorated politicians of modern times has admitted to leading a combat mission during the Vietnam war which shot dead more than a dozen unarmed women and children.

Bob Kerrey, who retired as a Democratic senator for Nebraska this year and who has not yet given up his very plausible presidential ambitions, has now confessed to being "haunted" by the incident for the past 32 years.

This week, Mr Kerrey, 57, went public about the incident in a series of interviews and has cooperated with a detailed article which is due to be published in the New York Times magazine on Sunday.

"I was so ashamed I wanted to die," he told the Wall Street Journal yesterday. "This is killing me. I'm tired of people describing me as a hero, and holding this inside."

Mr Kerrey is the most highly decorated Vietnam era politician in American public life. As a 25-year-old US navy lieutenant, he received the prestigious Bronze Star for his part in the 1969 mission. Later he was awarded the Medal of Honour, the highest US military honour, for his role in another engagement, in March 1969, during which he lost his right leg below the knee.

The killings occurred when the then Lt Kerrey led a seven-man team on a raid against what they believed was a Vietcong meeting in the Mekong Delta village of Thanh Phong on the night of February 25, 1969.

"We expected it to be a very difficult mission and we met some people we believed were the outpost and we killed them," Mr Kerrey said in a CNN interview. "And then we went on and took fire where we expected this meeting to occur and we returned fire, and when the firing was over, all we had was women and children that are dead."

"I have been haunted by it for 32 years," Mr Kerrey confessed in an unreported speech last week to cadets at the Virginia Military Institute. "It was not a military victory. It was a tragedy and I had ordered it."

But his claim that the incident was a tragic accident is challenged by a member of his commando team. Gerhard Klann says the unit herded the villagers together before killing them in cold blood.

A Vietnamese woman who claims to be a survivor says the same."They lined them up and shot all of them from behind," Pham Tri Lanh told CBS.

Mr Kerrey ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic presidential nomination against Bill Clinton in 1992, and considered running against Al Gore in 2000. He is actively considering a White House bid in 2004 - which may partly explain his sudden candour about the events at Thanh Phong.

webTitle: Judge has to drop 'convincing' case against Chirac

fields.headline: Judge has to drop 'convincing' case against Chirac
fields.trailText: France was plunged into constitutional confusion yesterday after a judge probing Jacques Chirac's alleged role in a vast kickback scam at Paris town hall was forced to drop his case despite having uncovered "serious and consistent evidence" implicating the president.
fields.body:
France was plunged into constitutional confusion yesterday after a judge probing Jacques Chirac's alleged role in a vast kickback scam at Paris town hall was forced to drop his case despite having uncovered "serious and consistent evidence" implicating the president.

Judge Eric Halphen, who caused uproar last month by summoning Mr Chirac for questioning as a witness in the scandal, concluded he was not competent to proceed against Mr Chirac because the head of state enjoys immunity from prosecution as long as he remains in office.

In a formal memorandum to the justice ministry, he said he was shelving his inquiry into Mr Chirac's alleged part in the scam although "there now exists evidence making it probable that Jacques Chirac could have participated, as author or accomplice, in offences under the law".

The judge said only the high court of justice could now examine the accusations against Mr Chirac. Arnaud Montebourg, a Socialist deputy, has been trying for some months to bring the president before the high court.

He has so far made little headway since, despite the large leftwing majority in the National Assembly, the Socialist prime minister Lionel Jospin - Mr Chirac's likely rival in next year's presidential elections - does not want to appear to be making political capital out of what is essentially a judicial problem.

"But what force do our words carry if we fail to react to the probability that a person who has broken the law is now our head of state?" asked Mr Montebourg yesterday.

"We have to confront this situation as the American people had to confront Richard Nixon's involvement in Watergate."

Judge Halphen is leading an inquiry into allegations that during Mr Chirac's 18-year tenure as mayor in the 1980s and early 1990s, Paris city hall creamed £60m off public building contracts, most of it being used to fund the president's party, the RPR.

The judge's main evidence against Mr Chirac - who has refused to appear as a witness, and repeatedly denied his involvement in any of the six Paris sleaze scandals currently under investigation - comes from testimony by a former RPR fundraiser, Jean-Claude Méry, and a former senior official of the city's public housing department, François Ciolina.

Mr Méry, who died in 1999, said in a video confession taped in 1996 but released last year that the covert fundraising system was run "exclusively on Mr Chirac's orders" and that the then mayor of Paris had been present when a contractor handed over £500,000 to another RPR official.

Mr Ciolina said the sums mentioned were "credible" and that several building contractors had told him that "to win contracts, you had to deposit cash in the mayor's office". He described Mr Chirac as both the inspiration for the scam and its main beneficiary.

Under normal circumstances, such specific accusations would lead automatically to a suspect being placed under formal investigation. The president's immunity "for the duration of his office" was, however, confirmed in a controversial ruling by France's constitutional council in January 1999.

Mr Halphen is now the second judge to abandon proceedings against Mr Chirac. In 1999, judge Patrick Desmure, who is investigating allegations that Paris town hall gave well-paid but non-existent jobs to dozens of RPR party activists, dropped his case "in view of the office of president currently occupied by Jacques Chirac".

webTitle: Children play with death in toxic wasteland

fields.headline: Children play with death in toxic wasteland
fields.standfirst: First ever study of Albania's environment shocks UN staff experts
fields.trailText: First ever study of Albania's environment shocks UN staff experts
fields.body:
Children are playing in the ruins of the old factory while the family cow grazes on the weeds growing out of a pile of rubble. The water runs yellow in the ditch between the factory and the family's makeshift home, in what used to be the pesticide store. It is a tell tale sign of the 20,000 tonnes of chemicals under the thin layer of soil.

The site - the former chemical plant at Albania's biggest port, Durres - is one of the five most contaminated "hot spots" in the country, according to a UN Environment Programme report published yesterday. This first ever assessment of Albania's environment has shocked even some of the experts involved in the study.

They concluded that all 80 families living on the site are risking their lives every day. None more so than the family of Flutorime Jani, 51, whose two grandchildren, six and two, are playing in the factory puddles. They live in the former lindane store, and on hot days they have to leave their home because the vapour from the banned pesticide threatens to overwhelm them.

Vegetable plot

In the ground where the family has a makeshift vegetable plot, the concentrations of lindane are up to 500 times the level which would require it to be declared hazardous waste in Britain. The milk from the cow has lindane levels 100 times above the EU safety limit, according to the report. The water from the well the family use for cooking is also contaminated.

Mrs Jani shrugs when she is told that living at the site is illegal. "I know that. I know it smells terribly, but where can I go? We have no choice," she says. "Living here is free. Sometimes we can get casual work in Durres in the building trade."

She says the family left their home village of Dibra, on the Macedonian border, because they were starving. They eventually found the empty factory and moved in. "At least we have more money to buy food than at home, where we had nothing," she says.

She concedes that all four families living in the former lindane store suffer unexplained illnesses, especially the children. She says they would like to move. but they have nowhere to go.

Lindane and chromium VI, another dangerous chemical on the site, cause liver and kidney failure and cancer.

Raw sewage

The chemicals that were once stored in Mrs Jani's new home have been moved to another store near the sea shore, but the roof leaks and the chemicals are dissolving in the rain. The smell scorches the lungs. Breathing in the fumes there could be instantly fatal, but there are no homes nearby.

The pesticides from the contaminated area, along with the raw sewage from the city, are pumped into the sea, but there is no ban on local lobsters and crabs being sold.

The mayor of Durres, Miri Hoti, is not sympathetic to the refugees. "The building is not licensed; they are not permitted to live there," he says. "People build all over the banned area. Most of them are refugees; how can we stop them? We have public land in clean areas to build houses, but no money. What are we to do?"

It is a common theme among officials. Albania has only just begun to recover from 50 years of a repressive communist regime, followed by 10 years of virtual anarchy, the collapse of the economy in a pyramid-selling scandal in 1997 and a war in neighbouring Kosovo which brought half a million refugees into the country.

Ilir Qesja, one of three people who comprise the Durres region environment agency, says: "You can see we have had other problems, but now with international support we can start on this one. First we had to find out the extent of the problems, and the UN has helped us do that. Now no one can claim in Albania they do not know it is dangerous. We must get the people moved, the areas fenced off. Then we must find the £150,000 it would cost to move the chemicals to a safe place. At least that would be a start."

In another hot spot at Vlore, a holiday resort in the south, where 15 tonnes of PVC were made a day until 1993, there is 1,000 times the permitted level of mercury in the soil and on the beach. The vapour damages the brain, kidneys and lungs.As at Durres, more than 100 refugee families have moved on to the site and take advantage of the former factory's services by stealing its electricity and water supply.

Dioxin rain

After a visit by journalists and a UN team yesterday, the mayor, Niko Veiza, has promised to stop local builders stealing highly contaminated sand from the site to build local homes and hotels, after scientists warned him that these people would unwittingly be poisoned too.

The other three hot spots mentioned in the UN report are the capital Tirana's main rubbish dump at Sharra, which is constantly on fire and rains dioxins on the city; the Marize oilfield, where there are lakes of oil from leaks; and the badly maintained oil refinery at nearby Balsh. All need millions of pounds spent on remedial work - money which Albania has not got.

fields.headline: Ukraine's popular PM forced out
fields.standfirst: Communists and business combine to push ex-Soviet state back towards Moscow's orbit
fields.trailText: Communists and business combine to push ex-Soviet state back towards Moscow's orbit
fields.body:
The Ukrainian prime minister, Viktor Yushchenko, was forced out of office yesterday by communist MPs backed by big business, throwing the country into confusion.

The resignation of the country's most trusted politician cut short his attempts to end corruption and pursue pro-western policies, and consolidated the power of the widely discredited president, Leonid Kuchma.

It also boosted the Russian strategy of drawing former Soviet states back into Moscow's orbit and polarising Ukraine between the pro-Russian east and the nationalist west.

But, out of office, Mr Yushchenko is expected to exploit the crisis and his enhanced popularity to lead the opposition to President Kuchma.

"I am not abandoning politics; I am leaving in order to return," he said

Yuliya Tymoshenko, the opposition leader whom Mr Kuchma sacked as deputy prime minister in January, immediately invited Mr Yushchenko to lead her campaign against the president.

Ukraine's polarisation was evident in the heart of the capital Kiev yesterday.

As MPs gathered in parliament to pass the vote of no confidence in the prime minister, thousands of Mr Yushchenko's supporters were outside demanding Mr Kuchma's impeachment.

The president has been under attack since the publication of details from a tape recording purportedly revealing him ordering the rigging of elections in 1999 and authorising the murder of a journalist last year.

The no-confidence vote was carried by a 263 to 69.

Mr Yushchenko's opponents accused him of leading the country into economic ruin, even though last year he gave Ukraine its first economic growth in the 10 years since its independence from the former Soviet Union.

"Democracy in Ukraine has suffered a serious defeat," he said.

"The political elite ... showed itself unable to accept a legal economy and public politics."

Although the communists have long been opposed to Mr Yushchenko's government, the no-confidence vote would have failed without the backing of the centrist parties, which are beholden to the millionaire clan leaders who dominate Ukraine's notoriously corrupt public life, and the tacit assent of Mr Kuchma, who appointed Mr Yushchenko prime minister at the end of 1999.

It came after months of demonstrations, sackings, and occasional violence triggered by the secret tape revelations, allegedly from Mr Kuchma's office, but it was seen not merely as another government tussle but as a signpost to the future direction of the biggest country in eastern Europe.

One of Mr Yushchenko's supporters in parliament, Vasili Chervony, said the choice facing the parliament was not for or against the prime minister, but "for Russia or for Europe".

"The KGB men in the Kremlin are re-assembling their empire."

Given the threats to his position, Mr Kuchma appears to be battening down the hatches and making concessions to the industrial oligarchs who run Ukraine and feared that Mr Yushchenko's economic reforms would imperil their control of key national assets.

He sought to distance himself from the row, refusing to support Mr Yushchenko before the vote, and after it blaming him for being unwilling to make compromises.

Mr Yushchenko was under strong pressure to give cabinet seats to several oligarchs' supporters, but he refused to make changes which would have neutered his policies.

If western diplomats in Kiev were hugely dismayed by yesterday's events, Moscow was quietly satisfied. Following the recent election triumph of pro-Moscow communists in neighbouring Moldova, the downfall of Mr Yushchenko helps to surround President Vladimir Putin with broadly supportive regimes.

Privately, Russian diplomats are even suggesting that Ukraine may yet ask to join the Russia-Belarus union, although this seems far-fetched, since the union is a feeble con struct and membership would polarise Ukraine even more completely.

Dmitry Rogozin, head of the Russian parliament's foreign affairs committee, summed up Moscow's view of the crisis by claiming that Mr Yushchenko was supported only by "extreme nationalists" and his government was at the mercy of "western arm-twisting".

Ukrainian opinion polls show Mr Yushchenko to be easily the most popular and most trusted politician in the country, and 4m signatures were collected supporting him and opposing yesterday's no-confidence vote.

fields.headline: Israeli minister in diplomatic U-turn
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, departs for Cairo and Washington this weekend in the most intense burst of diplomatic activity since the hardliner Ariel Sharon became prime minister.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem  and Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, departs for Cairo and Washington this weekend in the most intense burst of diplomatic activity since the hardliner Ariel Sharon became prime minister.

Mr Peres's mission - confirmed by Israel Radio yesterday - focuses on a Jordanian-Egyptian plan for bringing Israel and the Palestinians back to negotiations. Israel rejected it outright last week.

The diplomatic move has won Mr Sharon some gains from the US and European Union countries. Palestinian officials, however, accuse Israel of seeking to dilute the brief Jordanian-Egyptian proposals and thus render them unworkable.

"When the Jordanian-Egyptian proposal was introduced about a month ago, the Israelis dismissed it out of hand," Saeb Erakat, a senior Palestinian negotiator, told the Guardian.

"Then they decided why say no, why can't we say introduce some amendments. It is actually torpedoing the Egyptian-Jordanian ideas."

Israel Radio reported yesterday that Mr Peres will tell Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian president, that Israel will not freeze settlements in the West Bank, or contemplate negotiations for a final peace deal with the Palestinians.

Despite Mr Erakat's gloom, European Union countries are encouraged by the prospects of renewed diplomacy

"No one wants to introduce a new element into the current situation given that the diplomatic traffic has become much more intense in the last few days," said one source after a meeting of foreign ministry political directors.

Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, was flying to New York last night for the final meeting of the Mitchell Commission, set up to examine the causes of last September's fateful outbreak of violence in Jerusalem. The report is due out this weekend.

News of Mr Peres's trip - he leaves for Cairo on Sunday - came as Israelis celebrated their independence day yesterday, struggling with anxieties about the possibilities of an attack inside the Jewish state by Palestinian militants.

Instead, the holiday brought fresh violence in Palestinian-ruled Gaza, with a farmer shot dead east of Gaza's main city, and to Beit Jalla south of Jerusalem, which was pounded by Israeli tank fire overnight.

Palestinian and Israeli brigade commanders are expected to meet again today. The continued talks, under CIA sponsorship, have fuelled speculation that Mr Sharon may be prepared to carry out another election promise: to ease the suffering of ordinary Palestinians.

Instead, this week saw the fortification of concrete barriers around Jericho, intensifying a siege that has severed the desert town from its hinterland. Earlier this week, Israeli bulldozers destroyed a home on the edges of the town, and razed a vineyard.

webTitle: Mandela scorns claims of plot against president

fields.headline: Mandela scorns claims of plot against president
fields.trailText: The crisis in South Africa's government deepened yesterday as Nelson Mandela threw his support behind three leading anti-apartheid politicians under investigation for allegedly plotting to harm and oust President Thabo Mbeki.
fields.body:
The crisis in South Africa's government deepened yesterday as Nelson Mandela threw his support behind three leading anti-apartheid politicians under investigation for allegedly plotting to harm and oust President Thabo Mbeki.

Mr Mandela was joined by other powerful voices, including the ruling African National Congress's influential trade union allies, in pouring scorn on the supposed conspiracy and warning the government not to abuse its power.

Mr Mbeki tried to wash his hands of responsibility for the controversial and vague allegations by his security minister. But the row refused to die as one of the accused men struck back by saying that the accusations were "101% political", and implicitly warning that Mr Mbeki might pay a high price if the claims persist.

On Tuesday, the security minister, Steve Tshwete, said a special police unit had been appointed to investigate claims that Cyril Ramaphosa, the ANC's former secretary general, and two former provincial premiers, Tokyo Sexwale and Mathews Phosa, were plotting against the president. All three are now businessmen and Mr Ramaphosa is an international monitor of the IRA's weapons dumps.

Among the allegations were claims that the men were spreading a rumour that Mr Mbeki had a hand in the murder of Chris Hani, the popular Communist party leader who was assassinated in 1993.

But Mr Mandela was unequivocal in his support.

"The three comrades that have been mentioned ... until there is evidence to substantiate the allegations, I will always regard them in high esteem," he said. "Cyril Ramaphosa led our negotiating team [in talks with the apartheid regime]. It is him who is really responsible for the settlement that led to a democratic South Africa."

"Tokyo Sexwale was with me on Robben Island and he is a comrade I respect very highly, as well as Mathews Phosa."

The trade union confederation, Cosatu, a key ally of the ANC, criticised the naming of the men by Mr Tshwete as "highly irresponsible".

As support for the accused men rallied, Mr Mbeki tried to distance himself from his minister's accusations. He denied that his government was in trouble, saying: "There is no crisis either for government or for the ANC."

But more troubles may lie ahead. In an interview with a local radio station, Mr Phosa said the accusations against the three were being circulated in documents within the ANC by a female journalist whose name has been frequently mentioned in connection with claims that Mr Mbeki is a "womaniser".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Students hijack Ethiopian plane
Nine students armed with hand grenades and pistols seized an Ethiopian plane with at least 50 people on board soon after takeoff from Addis Ababa yesterday and ordered it to Khartoum.
fields.body:
Students hijack Ethiopian plane
Nine students armed with hand grenades and pistols seized an Ethiopian plane with at least 50 people on board soon after takeoff from Addis Ababa yesterday and ordered it to Khartoum.

Reports claimed the Ethiopian hijackers wanted talks with western diplomats in Sudan. It was not clear which airline was involved. Student clashes with police last week in Addis Ababa over greater academic freedom left 41 dead. AP, Khartoum

Activists pass US abortion law
Anti-abortionists pushed their first bill of the year through the House of Representatives yesterday, which would make it a federal crime to harm a foetus. Fifty-three Democrat congressmen joined with Republicans in voting for the bill. AP, Washington

UN holds bishop for genocide
A Rwandan Anglican bishop wanted by a UN tribunal trying leaders of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda was arrested yesterday in Nairobi, his lawyer said.

Samuel Musabyimana was bishop of Shyogwe diocese at the time of the genocide. AFP, Nairobi

Doctor rescued from Antarctica
A twin-engined propeller plane carried a sick American doctor out of Antarctica yesterday, flying him to safety in Chile from the icy South Pole research station where he was stricken with a gall bladder ailment.

The Twin Otter aircraft picked up Dr Ronald Shemenski, 59, from the Amundsen-Scott station where temperatures were -65C. AP, Antarctica

Strike shuts down Greece
A general strike shut down much of Greece yesterday, crippling schools, hospitals, banks, public transport and state agencies, despite a government climbdown on pension reforms.

Thousands marched through Athens against plans to raise the retirement age and reform pension funds. Reuters, Athens

Judge allows US navy bombs
A federal judge has allowed the US navy to resume exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, saying she found no proof that shelling from training this weekend would cause irreparable harm to residents. AP, Washington

webTitle: Story of an Australian submarine during WWI

fields.headline: The hunt for the AE2
fields.standfirst: In 1915, an Australian sub slipped into the enemy waters of the Dardanelles. Though short of air and dogged by mechanical problems, the crew caused havoc among Turkish warships - and changed the course of the war.  Phillip Knightley on an untold story of heroism
fields.trailText: In 1915, an Australian sub slipped into the enemy waters of the Dardanelles. Though short of air and dogged by mechanical problems, the crew caused havoc among Turkish warships - and changed the course of the war. Phillip Knightley on an untold story of heroism.
fields.body:
Eighty-six years ago tomorrow, in the middle of one of the great disasters of the first world war, an Australian submarine under the command of some colourful British officers achieved one of the finest feats in submarine history. AE2, captained by an Irishman, Henry "Dacre" Stoker, an eccentric more interested in polo than naval matters, became the first vessel to breach the Dardanelles - that turbulent stretch of water leading from the Aegean into the Sea of Marmara and on to Constantinople - to attack Turkey, Germany's ally.

The AE2, an unreliable submarine from the infant navy of a new country, with a crew regarded as amateurs by the more experienced British and French submariners, had succeeded where all others had failed.

Then, for reasons unexplained until now, the AE2's triumph slipped into the dustbin of history. Few Australians and Britons even know that there was an Australian submarine fighting against Turkey, much less its mission. AE2 was, it now appears, a victim of first world war "spin".

In 1915, with the fight against Germany bogged down on the Western Front, Winston Churchill, then First Lord of the Admiralty, came up with a bold plan. Allied warships would breach the Dardanelles, land Allied troops at Gallipoli and knock Turkey out of the war. The Allies could then attack Germany through the Balkans and take the pressure off Russia, struggling to hold Germany on the Eastern Front. The plan aroused great expectations - a popular poem of the time read: Cease your preaching! Load your guns!/Their roar our mission tells,/The day is come from Britain's sons/To seize the Dardanelles.

But it all went terribly wrong. Mines and Turkish guns in the Dardanelles accounted for three Allied battleships and several hundred men. Submarines from Britain and France tried to sneak through but did not make it. Then AE2 found a way through the mines and past the forts, surprising everyone, Stoker included.

He had applied for a transfer from the Royal Navy to the Australian Navy because he had heard a rumour that in Sydney there was a rich Australian who sponsored impecunious polo players like him. This turned out to be untrue but by then Stoker and his fellow officers were enjoying life in Australia and the challenge of mastering the unreliable submarine technology of the time - the Royal Navy had launched its first submarine only in 1901.

They must have been one of the most literary bunch ever to grace a submarine's mess. Stoker was a cousin of Bram Stoker, author of Dracula. Lieutenant Geoffrey Haggard was a nephew of Rider Haggard, author of King Solomon's Mines, and Lieutenant John Cary's brother was Joyce Cary, author of The Horse's Mouth.

In the early hours of April 25 1915, just as Allied troops were being shuffled from ships to landing barges for the assault on Gallipoli, AE2 entered the Dardanelles for a last-ditch attempt. Its orders: "Generally run amuk [sic] at the Narrows - if you get there." It did. For the next five days, although short of air, dogged by mechanical failure and forced to lie silent on the bottom while Turkish warships steamed back and forth overhead, it created havoc in the Turkish high command.

It torpedoed only one Turkish ship - thus revealing its presence to the enemy - but it was the threat it represented that worried the Turks. How did it get past the minefields? How many torpedoes did it carry? Was it the only Allied submarine behind Turkish lines? Was it safe to continue to supply the Turkish forces at Gallipoli by sea? Stoker hastened to signal his success.

On land everything had gone sour for the Allies from the very beginning. The Royal Navy had got the troops on to the beaches - the Australians were led ashore in many cases by teenage British midshipmen, one of whom was still only 13. But some of the landings had been on the wrong beaches, the terrain was hostile, the Turks had rushed up reinforcements and within hours the Allies were in danger of being pushed back into the sea.

The commander, General Sir Ian Hamilton, was seriously considering a withdrawal when the signal arrived from the AE2. A British naval officer told Hamilton: "This is an omen. An Australian submarine has done the finest feat in submarine history and is going to torpedo all the ships bringing reinforcements, supplies and ammunition into Gallipoli."

There is disagreement whether this swung Hamilton's decision, but he then issued his famous "dig yourselves in and stick it out" order to his troops. The next day there was a notice nailed to a tree stump on shore reading: "Australian sub AE2 just through the Dardanelles. Advance Australia!" So the Allied troops were not evacuated until eight months later, by which time casualties on both sides had reached more than 250,000. A feeling then grew that the timing of AE2's signal was a tragedy. Stoker himself said: "The receipt of our signal stopped the Anzacs being withdrawn that night ... Maybe an immediate evacuation would have saved those terrible casualties."

As for the AE2, its luck ran out on April 30. It had to keep popping to the surface to get fresh air and to see where it was - once, she surfaced so close to a Turkish fort that the Turks could not depress their guns sufficiently to fire on her. It had run aground several times and been rammed by a Turkish gunboat one-tenth of her size. Now the submarine found herself on the surface holed in three places and therefore unable to dive again. So Stoker scuttled her. The crew took to the water, where they were quickly picked up by the Turks, and they spent the rest of the war in captivity.

The Gallipoli campaign had been a disaster. To tell the story of the AE2's achievement would have involved assessing the importance of her signal on Hamilton's decision to fight on, rather than save lives and evacuate that first day. Far better to concentrate on the bravery and fortitude of the troops. So the authorities pushed the story of the gallant Anzacs and this soon obliterated the navy and the AE2.

Then, in 1994, two Australian authors, Fred and Elizabeth Brenchley, learned that the Turks were searching the Sea of Marmara for the AE2. While the search went on, the Brenchleys looked into the submarine's history. When the wreck was located in July 1998, their book, Stoker's Submarine, was already well under way - it was published in Australia by HarperCollins this week.

Stoker, they learned, had gone on to a successful postwar career on the West End and Broadway stage as an actor and a playwright, and later wrote scripts for radio, TV and films. He served in the RN in the second world war, became croquet champion of Ireland aged 77 and died in London in 1966, aged 81.

Now there are moves in Australia and Turkey to raise AE2 and put it on display in Istanbul, perhaps alongside the Australian war memorial. The Brenchleys say it could become a magnet for the thousands who go to Turkey each April to visit the Gallipoli landing site, "a symbol of the permanent co-operation between former enemies".

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I don't want to retire alone. Should I have another go at meeting 'Mr Right'?
fields.trailText: I don't want to retire alone. Should I have another go at meeting 'Mr Right'?
fields.body:
"I bought my own flat nine years ago and live alone with two cats. At 46 I'm getting used to the idea that I will probably never meet a man who wants to settle down. The relationships I've had in the past have always been stormy, with no likelihood of becoming long term. I have a few good friends, plenty of interests, a responsible job and wonderful nephews and nieces, so I don't feel my life is empty without a partner. What really makes me unhappy is living on my own. The idea of spending my retirement years living alone fills me with dread. Should I have another try at meeting "Mr Right", or is there another way of sharing my life and my home?"

Lose the cats, find a man

I, too, am 46 and living on my own. I, too, have some good friends, plenty of great nieces and nephews and a wide range of interests. I do not, however, have any cats and I have no intention of getting any. Perhaps that is the problem. Get rid of the cats and find a man. Cats do not care about humans, but men are always interested in women.

I often despair about never meeting the right woman and I can offer no advice on how to meet the right man as I also need advice on how to meet the right woman. Perhaps you should contact me!
Peter Jenkins, Surrey

Get a student lodger

I also gave up the idea of settling down with a partner and bought a property eight years ago. I am 49, have a cat and a two-bedroomed house. My peace and quiet was disturbed only after a reunion with friends in Cornwall I had not seen in 20 years. Their 21-year-old daughter needed to resit some exams - would I have her to stay for a few months?

Of course I worried about the loud music, about strangers coming and going and many other things. In fact, what she really wanted to do was study and my fears were quite unfounded. We don't agree about everything but the discussions are usually quite interesting. Additionally, she is very good at making tea, occasionally vacuums the carpet and looks after the cat when I'm away. When she goes, I may now decide to have another student to stay - perhaps a possibility for you?
Name and address withheld

Join a dating agency

You simply must not give up finding Mr Right. Forty six is not old but just slightly more difficult to find a partner than at 26. Join dating agencies that specialise in group trips, dinner parties and singles holidays, and place ads yourself. Go all out to find someone proactively, as if you were looking for a new job or buying a new car. Having more fun and meeting lots more new people will give you a lot more confidence and ensure you don't appear desperate or lonely. Take a lodger in for a year, aiming for another female of a similar age - there are lots about with divorce rates soaring. Then you can hunt out suitable men together and have a fun at home getting ready to go out and flirt. All these things worked for me two years ago when I met a fantastic man through a dating agency - and I was a twice-divorced woman aged 49 facing a sad and lonely retirement too.
Sheila O'Donovan, Surrey

Look beyond a man

I can empathise with your dread of living alone in retirement years - I'm at that stage myself. But a man is not the only option.

You could consider having lodgers - your own age, or students; this would bring fresh ideas and outlooks, as well as a little supplementary income. You could seek people willing to share a house - pooling resources to ensure adequate personal and communal space.

You could become live-in companion/nanny/etc to a family - which would allow you privacy while ensuring company, companionship and shared experience. Or invite someone to share your home; arrange a trial period of maybe three months before confirming any of these.

However, you seem to be happy and content with your current lifestyle. There's a lot to be said for having good friends, family, and social activity which you can call on at times of need or celebration, and yet can politely leave when you require your own space.

Sharing space and time with any other person can be a drastic change after living alone: you might not be able to eat spaghetti bolognese while reading a book and listening to music at 3am.

Concentrate on building positive and constructive relationships, and activities which are satisfying to you. This, I hope, will fill your life, and perhaps you will be very pleased to have your own private space in which to regenerate and promote your self-esteem.
J Whittaker, Sussex

Next week

I was shocked to discover that my husband of 30 years had been having an affair with a work colleague for six months. Most hurtful of all was that he fell in love with her. He also says he loves me and wants to stay with me. We have had lengthy discussions and I realise I had neglected him and taken him for granted. We went away for a weekend and our sexual relationship has been fantastic, returning to a mature honeymoon state. We have agreed to try again and my husband has promised not to see this other woman. But I am a mess inside. I can't even confide in my best friend and certainly not my three adult children. I don't want to visit Relate but desperately want advice. Can our marriage work? Can I trust him again? Am I mad to let him stay?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.bodyText: "I bought my own flat nine years ago and live alone with two cats. At 46 I'm getting used to the idea that I will probably never meet a man who wants to settle down. The relationships I've had in the past have always been stormy, with no likelihood of becoming long term. I have a few good friends, plenty of interests, a responsible job and wonderful nephews and nieces, so I don't feel my life is empty without a partner. What really makes me unhappy is living on my own. The idea of spending my retirement years living alone fills me with dread. Should I have another try at meeting "Mr Right", or is there another way of sharing my life and my home?" Lose the cats, find a man I, too, am 46 and living on my own. I, too, have some good friends, plenty of great nieces and nephews and a wide range of interests. I do not, however, have any cats and I have no intention of getting any. Perhaps that is the problem. Get rid of the cats and find a man. Cats do not care about humans, but men are always interested in women. I often despair about never meeting the right woman and I can offer no advice on how to meet the right man as I also need advice on how to meet the right woman. Perhaps you should contact me! Peter Jenkins, Surrey Get a student lodger I also gave up the idea of settling down with a partner and bought a property eight years ago. I am 49, have a cat and a two-bedroomed house. My peace and quiet was disturbed only after a reunion with friends in Cornwall I had not seen in 20 years. Their 21-year-old daughter needed to resit some exams - would I have her to stay for a few months? Of course I worried about the loud music, about strangers coming and going and many other things. In fact, what she really wanted to do was study and my fears were quite unfounded. We don't agree about everything but the discussions are usually quite interesting. Additionally, she is very good at making tea, occasionally vacuums the carpet and looks after the cat when I'm away. When she goes, I may now decide to have another student to stay - perhaps a possibility for you? Name and address withheld Join a dating agency You simply must not give up finding Mr Right. Forty six is not old but just slightly more difficult to find a partner than at 26. Join dating agencies that specialise in group trips, dinner parties and singles holidays, and place ads yourself. Go all out to find someone proactively, as if you were looking for a new job or buying a new car. Having more fun and meeting lots more new people will give you a lot more confidence and ensure you don't appear desperate or lonely. Take a lodger in for a year, aiming for another female of a similar age - there are lots about with divorce rates soaring. Then you can hunt out suitable men together and have a fun at home getting ready to go out and flirt. All these things worked for me two years ago when I met a fantastic man through a dating agency - and I was a twice-divorced woman aged 49 facing a sad and lonely retirement too. Sheila O'Donovan, Surrey Look beyond a man I can empathise with your dread of living alone in retirement years - I'm at that stage myself. But a man is not the only option. You could consider having lodgers - your own age, or students; this would bring fresh ideas and outlooks, as well as a little supplementary income. You could seek people willing to share a house - pooling resources to ensure adequate personal and communal space. You could become live-in companion/nanny/etc to a family - which would allow you privacy while ensuring company, companionship and shared experience. Or invite someone to share your home; arrange a trial period of maybe three months before confirming any of these. However, you seem to be happy and content with your current lifestyle. There's a lot to be said for having good friends, family, and social activity which you can call on at times of need or celebration, and yet can politely leave when you require your own space. Sharing space and time with any other person can be a drastic change after living alone: you might not be able to eat spaghetti bolognese while reading a book and listening to music at 3am. Concentrate on building positive and constructive relationships, and activities which are satisfying to you. This, I hope, will fill your life, and perhaps you will be very pleased to have your own private space in which to regenerate and promote your self-esteem. J Whittaker, Sussex Next week I was shocked to discover that my husband of 30 years had been having an affair with a work colleague for six months. Most hurtful of all was that he fell in love with her. He also says he loves me and wants to stay with me. We have had lengthy discussions and I realise I had neglected him and taken him for granted. We went away for a weekend and our sexual relationship has been fantastic, returning to a mature honeymoon state. We have agreed to try again and my husband has promised not to see this other woman. But I am a mess inside. I can't even confide in my best friend and certainly not my three adult children. I don't want to visit Relate but desperately want advice. Can our marriage work? Can I trust him again? Am I mad to let him stay?  Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies should reach us by Thursday. webTitle: Food: What are the latest cocktails?

fields.headline: Mix it up
fields.standfirst: First it was cranberry, then it was raspberry - now rhubarb is  the mixer du jour.  Victoria Moore trawls London's snootiest bars to try the very latest cocktails
fields.trailText: First it was cranberry, then it was raspberry - now rhubarb is the mixer du jour. Victoria Moore trawls London's snootiest bars to try the very latest cocktails.
fields.body:
Friday night, 1am. Chris Calarco, wearing a light grey suit, open-necked white shirt and a thin line of hair above his upper lip, is standing in a Soho doorway deciding who is cool enough to come into his bar and drink his cocktails. Down the road, a young woman is telling her friend: "Last time I was here, Jordan was sitting in a car sobbing into her mobile, 'Why won't they let me in?'"

Chris, who is the manager of this bar, Attica, tells me: "We are snobbish; we are pretentious. People ring me up and ask what the dress code is. Well, if you need to ask you won't get in." Irritating, certainly, but in bars such as this, trends are set.

Cocktails have stayed in vogue, since their resurgence a few years ago, partly because of the prestigious bartending competitions organised by spirit companies, partly because big drinks companies regularly produce tempting new recipes that, they claim, will work properly only with their brands, and partly because the most expensive style bars keep serving them. They do so because cocktails are the ultimate in added value - hedonism in a glass.

But then the fashion set are fickle creatures ("We opened six months ago; if we're still this busy in three months, then we're here to stay," says Chris) and their interest has to be sustained somehow.

This is not necessarily a bad thing: it means that barmen are always inventing new cocktails and resurrecting old favourites. First, the sea breeze (equal measures of cranberry, and grapefruit, and lots of vodka) was the only thing to swallow between inhalations of Marlboro Lights. Then the raspberry martini (only ever accept one made with real fruit purée, as opposed to raspberry liqueur) swept the board. After that the espresso martini - with the dual caffeine-alcohol hit - was considered terribly chic.

I have been wary of cocktails since the night I sampled a flaming ferrari (as drunk by James Archer and his city chums) and woke up under a hedge. But in the hands of a bartender who knows how to make them properly, there is nothing better. And it is a well-honed talent. Get the measures wrong, or allow the ice to melt too much when you shake, and the drink becomes flabby and loses its edge.

Sometimes the simplest drink - the martini, for example, which must be perfectly dry - requires the most care. Italian Gilberto Preti, at Dukes Hotel, has carved out a reputation for himself as London's best martini mixer. His drinks cost £12.50 each, are poured with a flourish into ice-cold glasses and require one fifth of a bottle of spirit (gin or vodka straight from the freezer) and the tiniest sniff of vermouth. They are utterly deadly.

Over the past two years, vodka martinis, flavoured with ever more outlandish ingredients, have been incredibly popular. "Martinis will never go out of fashion," says Rikke May-Olsen, head bartender at the Long Bar in Ian Schrager's Sanderson Hotel. "At the moment we are serving a very fresh one that uses apple, grape, cucumber vodka and lemon vodka. The elderflower martini is also doing very well and we have a lavender martini on the list, too."

At other bars the caipirinha (made with lime and cachaca) and mojito (flavoured with bundles of fresh mint leaves) have established themselves as firm favourites.

Indeed, clean vibrant tastes are very in. The ingredient du moment is rhubarb, which is so tangy and clear-flavoured it makes palate-tingling drinks. The 10 Room is using rhubarb in bellinis and daiquiris. "We're kind of into rhubarb at the moment," says Paul Barns, the general manager. "We make what I call a kind of a soup with it, using lemon zest, fresh vanilla pods and Mexican honey. We strain that, and chill it and then use it in classic mixers."

It is into this culture that Coca-Cola has decided to launch its latest product, an energy drink called Burn. The idea is that Burn, and cocktails made using it, will become the new Red Bull and vodka, but with the cachet of the espresso martini. It is well positioned. Red Bull is fast falling out of fashion and energy drinks are greatly prized by those trying to stay up until 3am (without drugs) and who aren't too bothered about the taste of the drink.

Add to that the fact that the Burn can is a neat little black thing branded with a single flame (and no mention of the parent Coca-Cola company) and a clever marketing strategy that includes eschewing advertising and, instead, providing lots of free Burn at celebrity parties so that the names of those celebrities can be bandied around to create an air of exclusivity, and it looks even more likely to take off.

Further, Burn is currently available in London bars where you have to be cool enough to get past bouncers to drink it. (If you're not cool enough the nice man on the door will say: "I'm really sorry. Private function." If you're not cool enough but the bar is having a bad night, he will make you pay £20 to get in.) And there are no plans to sell Burn in shops, ever. Exclusive, you see.

Funnily enough, though, the people who really are in the know drink none of these things. When bartenders go out drinking they ask for the granddaddy of all cocktails, the old fashioned - a layered drink made with bourbon. Why? Because it's very, very, good and "they want to see if you can get it right", says one barman. A top tip if ever I heard one.

fields.headline: No 1,868
fields.standfirst: Auntie Beeb
fields.trailText: Auntie Beeb.
fields.body:
Age: 74.

Appearance: Careworn, seen-it-all.

Maiden? Says she is, at any rate. Claims never to have surrendered her virtue to politicians, although the Tory press peddles vile rumours of secret liaisons with grinning gigolo Tony Blair, with Greg Dyke as pimp.

Ah yes, the BBC's dyspeptic DG. What has he got a bee in his bonnet about now? Croissants, wasn't it? That, and he wants to kill off the Auntie tag because it conveys an outdated, "staid" and "cosy" image.

His chairman has just quit, and he's fussing about bloody patisserie and words he doesn't like - sounds pretty auntie-ish to me. What's at the root of all this? Imagine young Gregory in London suburbia in the 1950s, being forced to listen to Sing Something Simple. He was eight when commercial TV arrived in 1955, but his parents' set only received BBC, so he had to visit friends with ITV to watch fun stuff such as westerns. When ITV fat cats sneered at prim, snooty, fuddy-duddy "Auntie", they were talking his language - and 46 years on, he's still seething.

So dumping the name makes sense? Au contraire, the whole idea is arsy-versy - when he ought to be turning his back on the Beeb's hideously patriarchal past, here he is objecting to a nickname that handily feminises it. BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey had the right idea when she compared her channel to a big sister.

What should Greg be doing, then? Concentrating on subtly rebranding aunts rather than rebranding the BBC. Films portraying them as sexy (Les Amants, Travels with my Aunt). Documentaries about the maiden aunt as reinterpreted by feminism: creative and nonconformist because she is sexually free. Bertie Wooster stories with Aunt Agatha at her most assertive. Cool aunts introduced into The Royle Family, Buffy, EastEnders.

Don't think: Patricia Routledge, Thora Hird, Pauline Fowler.

Do think: Janet Jackson, Monica in Friends, the Appleton sister who's sensibly not having Liam's baby.

fields.headline: Pipe dreams
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland.
fields.body:
Traditionally held in late April, the Morpeth Northumbrian Gathering is a glorious annual celebration of customs, local skills, buildings and civic treasures. Morpeth, although built on the fringes of extensive coalfields, still remains an old-fashioned country market town lying low on a peninsula in the Wansbeck river valley. The Clock Tower bells will be pealing, reminding visitors of this ancient building's original purpose, as a prison for miscreants.

When I was a child, I remember my father taking me in to see the stocks that are still kept there. The Border cavalcade and pageant at the Gathering depicts the return of troops from the battle of Otterburn in 1388, always a stirring sight, although this year foot and mouth has put paid to the cavalry so it is foot soldiers only.

Dancers, children and pipers join in the parade. Some Northumbrian pipers were shepherds who used to while away long hours watching their flocks by playing their small pipes. Others were employed as professional pipers travelling around the countryside keeping soldiers in step, road menders digging and farm workers harvesting. Our pipes produce a lighter, sweeter tone than the more strident Highland bagpipes. Pipers of either ilk put a swagger back into the weariest marcher's step, they bring tears to the driest eye and - as an instrument for dancing - the pipes suit all levels of society.

Story telling and dialect recitals at our Gathering will be worth listening to, if I can spare time away from the proggy mat-making, the clog dancing and the stick dressing. With another case of foot and mouth confirmed on a neighbouring farm this morning, we need cheering up.

webTitle: Peter Lennon on rebuilding South Africa's culture

fields.headline: Culture clash
fields.standfirst: On Sunday Nelson Mandela will join a host of stars in London for a concert to celebrate the anniversary of South Africa's liberation. But where do the arts fit into the rebuilding of a nation? By  Peter Lennon
fields.trailText: On Sunday Nelson Mandela will join a host of stars in London for a concert to celebrate the anniversary of South Africa's liberation. But where do the arts fit into the rebuilding of a nation? By Peter Lennon.
fields.body:
"Because we voted," Hugh Masekela says, "the world thinks we are now OK. But we are not. That is the great secret". It's lunchtime in a sunny suburban Johannesburg restaurant and the famous trumpeter swaps ideas with vocalist Sibongile Khumalo about life, culture and politics in that alternatively humorous and passionate way one often encounters in people from South Africa's townships.

On Sunday, Masekela will be in Trafalgar Square, helping to lead a raucous celebration of South Africa's liberation struggle, but today he does not appear to be in celebratory mood. When I ask him what cultural line the ANC has adopted since coming to power, he replies: "TV and casinos." Then, in mock terror, he shouts: "I'm going to jail. I'm going to jail." He goes on: "With every revolution there is always an element of amnesia and the people who lead are the most amnesiac!"

High on Masekela's list of dismaying developments are the four grotesque Las Vegas-style casinos that have sprung up around Johannesburg - with creches for babies so mother can more easily hand over the housekeeping money. But he is equally exasperated by South African TV, which, with rare exceptions, conforms to a homogenised western formula. "It is not that black people working in TV don't want to show who they are," he says. "They don't know who they are."

Masekela's gloomy assessment of the cultural climate provides a discordant note to the six-week Celebrate South Africa festival, which will see a host of the country's brightest talents performing in London. "The black intelligentsia need to tell [the government] what they are doing wrong," he says. "When we had the most draconian rulers we were prepared to speak out, go to jail. But people don't want to speak out."

What is there to speak out about? Well, apart from Masekela's complaint that "in other countries people dress up to go out, but we dress up to stay at home" - a reference to the perceived lawlessness of some areas - the arguments are, predictably, about whose culture is being neglected and which unfavourably favoured. Many black South Africans feel that their long-suppressed cultures should now be a prime concern of the government. "But every year," Masekela says, "when the budget comes up the dispensation for the arts decreases."

Masekela's artistic anguish and doubt is not typical of black South Africans; the overwhelming impression you bring away from the townships and settlements is one of astounding confidence and hope and pride in the success of their uniquely civilised revolution.

Meanwhile a white minority is incensed by the government's refusal to continue bailing out national classical orchestras or maintain a level of support for ballet and opera. (One white South African has a brisk solution for the white culture dilemma: "Have your classical concerts and ballet," says Eve Gray, a publishing consultant, "but make them work. I saw a performance of Wagner with a black township chorus. It added a new dimension to the work.")

Some white South Africans are convinced that the ANC is actually intent on stifling white art, a belief reinforced by events such as last week's Nadine Gordimer incident. A committee of teachers appointed by the education department of Gauteng province were accused of "political correctness gone mad" when they accused Gordimer's July's People of being "deeply racist, superior and patronising". Although the education minister immediately accused the teachers of being "ill informed and pedagogically unsound" and sent his apologies to Gordimer, the apprehension still smoulders.

The ANC government goes to some lengths to present itself as a patron of the arts, remembering the central role of the world's artistic community in persuading foreign governments to take a stand against apartheid. Indigenous art adorns the country's constitutional court building.

Albie Sachs, the former ANC activist who lost an arm in a car bomb planted by agents of the South African security forces, is now one of the country's constitutional judges. He took on the job of what he calls "decorator" for the court, filling the vestibule and corridors with South African artworks."We were engaged in turning our country from the polecat of the world into a distinctive democracy," he says. "We rented this office block. We had little money so had to rely on people's generosity and passion, energy and madness - all kinds of emotions not normally associated with a court of law."

The result is that the blind lady with the scales is replaced by a high panel of a solemn figure, flattened hands upraised in a gesture suggesting both the lifting of a burden and a restrained gesture of jubilation. Corridor after corridor reflects the tumultuous experiences, griefs and hopes of the country. Madness is represented by a kind of quixotic, generously hung witchdoctor apparently gibbering before solemn Justice. "This is the latest addition," Sachs explains. "If we had put it in first you can imagine how the good judges would have freaked."

Brigitte Mabandla, deputy minister responsible for the arts, insisted the ANC had merely diverted funds from costly buildings and bureaucracy to on-the-ground performances, as well as redirecting more money to the townships. In the townships, though, few are convinced that they are likely to be properly supported. Many in the arts world also point out that the ministry now responsible for the arts is also responsible for science and technology - it isn't difficult, they say, to see where the spending priorities will be in a developing nation.

Even with far greater sums of money than the South African government has at its disposal, one or more of the country's numerous ethnic groups (and 11 official languages) would undoubtedly feel neglected. Khumalo and Masekela, who have now devoted themselves to promoting indigenous music, fear that they are very vulnerable to being swallowed up by western cultures. "One problem," Masekela says, "is that the whites can't think of themselves as African."

But artists such as Masekela and Khumalo face a further obstacle: black opposition to indigenous culture. "If you want to appreciate these cultures," Khumalo says, "it is seen as tribalism or promoting ethnicity."

This does not discourage all entrepreneurial spirit. Lopang Manyama had to leave school when she became pregnant. To care for her child she got a job with a music promoter. Now she manages exclusively Zulu groups, singing in their own language. They have already had success in Scandinavia.

When it comes to literature, meanwhile, the South African public seems to be suffering from "battle fatigue" which means "struggle" literature no longer has a following. When Athol Fugard brought out a book of poetic memoirs, it had little to do with politics. But the public saw the name Fugard, equated it with struggle literature, and did not buy. Some say that the literature was not very democratic anyway; it was intellectuals telling people what they should think. Guidance now comes from another source: while the sale of books has halved, the sale of magazines which tell people how they should look, dress, act - the new revolutionary guides - has doubled.

Over the next two nights at the North Sea Jazz festival in Cape Town it was difficult to detect any trace of Masekela's scepticism. Khumalo and he were back in business. Khumalo driving the crowd wild with her fantastic duels with a violinist, with back-up from some of the most talented young singers in South Africa. Next night, Masekela had the huge standing audience literally jumping. A thousand arms and feet rose in the air to his command: 95% black; 5% white. No tension, no aggro. This was pure triumph and joy.

fields.bodyText: "Because we voted," Hugh Masekela says, "the world thinks we are now OK. But we are not. That is the great secret". It's lunchtime in a sunny suburban Johannesburg restaurant and the famous trumpeter swaps ideas with vocalist Sibongile Khumalo about life, culture and politics in that alternatively humorous and passionate way one often encounters in people from South Africa's townships. On Sunday, Masekela will be in Trafalgar Square, helping to lead a raucous celebration of South Africa's liberation struggle, but today he does not appear to be in celebratory mood. When I ask him what cultural line the ANC has adopted since coming to power, he replies: "TV and casinos." Then, in mock terror, he shouts: "I'm going to jail. I'm going to jail." He goes on: "With every revolution there is always an element of amnesia and the people who lead are the most amnesiac!" High on Masekela's list of dismaying developments are the four grotesque Las Vegas-style casinos that have sprung up around Johannesburg - with creches for babies so mother can more easily hand over the housekeeping money. But he is equally exasperated by South African TV, which, with rare exceptions, conforms to a homogenised western formula. "It is not that black people working in TV don't want to show who they are," he says. "They don't know who they are." Masekela's gloomy assessment of the cultural climate provides a discordant note to the six-week Celebrate South Africa festival, which will see a host of the country's brightest talents performing in London. "The black intelligentsia need to tell [the government] what they are doing wrong," he says. "When we had the most draconian rulers we were prepared to speak out, go to jail. But people don't want to speak out." What is there to speak out about? fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Life's Little Luxuries | Census ... 915 Years And Still Counting | Andy Kershaw
fields.body:
John Singer Sargent recognised one of the hazards facing artists. "Every time I paint a portrait", he commented wryly, "I lose a friend". Yet, as Simon Parkes notes, having one's image painted still ranks as one of Life's Little Luxuries (11.0am, Radio 4). For the Queen, of course, it's just another chore. But portraits can arouse considerable passion. When Parliament commissioned a picture of Winston Churchill from Graham Sutherland, Lady Churchill hated it so much that she had it burned.

With the nation undergoing its decennial survey on Sunday, the Afternoon Play offers Census ... 915 Years And Still Counting (2.15pm, Radio 4), a light-hearted reflection on the process. What happened in 1086, of course, was the completion of William the Conqueror's Domesday Book, ensuring that he knew about every taxable person and property. Donald Sinden guides us through official nosey-parkering after that.

There's a rare chance to hear the multi-talented Senegalese instrumentalist and singer Baaba Maal. Andy Kershaw (10.15pm, Radio 3) plays highlights from the concert Maal gave in Cambridge last weekend. The singer originally intended to be a lawyer but was increasingly drawn to the music he heard as a child from his mother. The switch was not an easy one, not least because Maal's family was not of the region's traditional musical caste.

fields.headline: I want to break free
fields.trailText: British Home Stories: A Place In The Country
fields.body:
British Home Stories: A Place In The Country (Channel 4) reminded me of the French and Saunders sketch, West Country. In it, two village women sit in a cottage belonging to "her fart-ass majesty" who only comes down from London to live in the place at the weekend (when she's not nipping to Bangladesh to buy rugs). The BBC, it seems, want to use the place as a location for Miss Marple.

"They want this place here. A typical cottage they thought it were, right. I offered them my place but they weren't happy with the double glazing and the satellite dish."

According to British Home Stories, two-thirds of people who don't live in the country would like to. I imagine this survey - most likely done in the office of the production company making the documentary - was carried out before the big livestock bonfires filled the air with the stench of burning cow and carcinogenics. But even if it wasn't, the countryside that this two-thirds dream of isn't the same countryside that people who already live there recognise. The outsiders dream of a rural idyll - first imagined by the Victorians. Like the BBC, they imagine a typical cottage to be one without double glazing and a satellite dish. They are the kind of people who pay 40 quid for a T-shirt.

And so they were. Rachel and Richard had just bought a converted barn in Sussex for £380,000. Rachel, a solicitor, was quite happy spending three hours a day and £4,000 a year commuting to and from London. (It made you wonder for whom Rachel was a solicitor - General Pinochet? The Sunday Mirror? Huw Edwards?) They were typical residents in the village of Harting, where those who have lived there all their lives now feel like outsiders.

Cardrona, Britain's newest village which is 20 miles outside Edinburgh, is effectively a suburb without the urb. The houses are horribly new with corner baths, mirrored wardrobes and breakfast bars. Evangelical residents spoke of their decoration plans. "That wall is going to be gold and the dining room will be chocolate with crocodile-print wallpaper," said one woman who has clearly taken Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen way too seriously.

While the narrator may have been overstating it somewhat with "We're witnessing an urban exodus" - so when, exactly, will London become a ghost town? - British Home Stories was nonetheless engaging and persuasive both in sociological terms and as an excuse to nosey round people's houses. The middle classes' gentrification of the countryside was obvious and wholesale. Like the women who find their ideal man and set about changing him, the townies who upped sticks to the sticks set about transforming it into what they imagined it should be.

Not that you can blame them. Just as the city is remade by television, so the country has been idyllically remodelled but to a much larger degree. From Heartbeat and Where The Heart Is through Monarch Of The Glen, Two Thousand Acres Of Skye and Ballykissangel (the last of which has the added bonus of being in Oireland) and even the slightly grubbier Down To Earth, the countryside is a green, pleasant and almost mythical land. Recently, only The Lakes has really exposed the dark underbelly of village life. Unless you count The League Of Gentlemen, of course.

If there was a disincentive for moving to the country, bumping into Michael Watson-Smith down Asda could be it. He was selling Buckland Park for some £6m, six times what he paid for it in 1993. Retired from his window box business and living alone, he made his money from property and was convinced of the virtues of old country houses (as you would be if you had made buckets of money from them). "I love old things", he said. "Except for wives. They're better younger." Quite.

Watson-Smith was planning on selling his Toad Hall to some Americans who were "quite shrewd". To demonstrate this, Mrs American said of the country pile, "It's nicer to have bigger closets." You can't really argue with that but £6m is an awful lot to pay for big closets, unless you're Liberace.

Of course, having a place in the country isn't really about having a place in the country at all. It's about having money and getting whatever you want.

Paving paradise, converting barns, driving up prices and driving out locals is just incidental.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: My Beautiful Laundrette | Superfly | Live Tennis
fields.body:
Films

My Beautiful Laundrette
(Stephen Frears, 1985)
8pm, FilmFour

Incisive portrait of Thatcher's Britain as seen through the eyes of a gay Asian entrepreneur. Gordon Warnecke plays the young lad who, with the help of chum-turned-lover (and ex-National Front member) Daniel Day-Lewis, turns a dreary south London launderette into the hippest top-loader in town.

Superfly
(Gordon Parks Jr, 1972)
9pm, TCM

This ranks right up there with Shaft and Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song as a classic of the blaxploitation genre. Hip martial arts expert Ron O'Neal stars as Harlem drug dealer Youngblood Priest, who's planning one last big score. Chock full of sex, coke and kung fu kicks, all set to a terrific Curtis Mayfield soundtrack, it was a box office hit - despite the (entirely valid) protests against its glorification of drug pushers.

The Astronaut's Wife
(Rand Ravich, 1999)
10pm, Sky Premier

Astronaut Johnny Depp returns from a space mission apparently unharmed by a mysterious accident during a two-minute communications black-out; but his wife (Charlize Theron) begins to notice changes. Soon she becomes pregnant, but is she carrying human twins, or alien creatures? It is basically a sci-fi Rosemary's Baby, and Theron - in a performance containing many shades of fear, anxiety, and gutsy strength - sports Mia Farrow-style cropped blonde hair. But this is a quieter, slower movie than Polanski's, glimmering with Allen Daviau's stylish camera work.

Full Metal Jacket
(Stanley Kubrick, 1987)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Kubrick's cool and clinical vision of the hell that was Vietnam. The first half is a bright and gleaming study of the dehumanisation of American recruits through foul-mouthed abuse and ritual humiliation, led by real-life army sergeant R Lee Ermey; the second is a graphic illustration of the inhumanity of war. Each part ends with a cathartic shooting, pointing up an overly schematic structure which distances us from Matthew Modine's Private Joker and his suffering comrades: nevertheless, it's superb film-making.

Wild At Heart
(David Lynch, 1990)
11.45pm, FilmFour

The horrible opening in which Nicolas Cage's petty crook Sailor Ripley smashes in the skull of a would-be killer sets the bizarre, dark tone of Lynch's sub-Blue Velvet tale. Cage and Laura Dern's Lula are lovers on the run through a weird American south, stalked by a hitman hired by mother-in-law-from-hell Marietta (Diane Ladd). A road movie with a vengeance, it's full of Lynch's demonic humour, energy and disturbed violence.

Others

Live tennis
2pm, British Eurosport

Clay court tennis, so much slower than the grass the British are used to, is not everyone's cup of tea. It does, however, promote rallies that last longer than three shots. The Spanish are the true masters on this surface but must be annoyed that the major events on clay are in Italy and France. This, though, is their week to shine in Barcelona.
