fields.headline: Trial and error
fields.trailText: Today Programme | In A Green Shade
fields.body:
On Wednesday morning, as the nation arose and brushed its teeth, something very strange was happening behind the closed doors of a London court of law. A mock trial of Slobodan Milosevic was taking place, complete with an expert panel of judges and key witnesses. That, in itself, isn't the strange bit. What was odd about this early morning courtroom drama was that it was held at the behest of a radio show, the Today Programme (Radio 4).

Thoroughly muddying the line between reporting the news and making the news, the show featured live reports from outside the court as if a real trial were taking place. Online you could watch the "action" unfold, listen to testimonies and vote on whether Milosevic could ever receive a fair trial in the Hague (it didn't actually say "especially after the broadcast of this mock trial", but that is an issue).

At the end of it all, the judges were unable to come to any kind of verdict because of "insufficient evidence" - hardly surprising given the two-and-a-half-hour slot they'd been allotted. Excusing their inability to make any judgement, they reminded us that this was a limited radio event. All we learned was that, if the trial ever happens, it will take longer than one breakfast show, and that it's all mighty messy and complicated.

Sensational and unnecessary, The Milosevic Hearing, as it was dubbed, made me wonder if a Brookside editor had sneaked in to the Today planning meeting ("yeah, let's have a hostage crisis. You're not keen? Foxy lesbians? Nope. OK then, how about a big trial?"). One listener emailed to question the use of his license fee for the event. He has a point.

I hope the same listener tuned into In A Green Shade (Radio 3) later that day, a whole evening of programmes on the changing face of the countryside. This did what the Today trial failed to: commented intelligently on an already existing news story - the foot and mouth crisis - stretching you to think in other ways about familiar concepts.

Short programmes covered topics as diverse as utopian rural communities, literary representations of the countryside, birdsong and rural architecture. Between them a lively studio panel tussled with the pleasures and problems of life in the country today. Artists and writers contributed in letter form and listeners' emails were read out at regular intervals.

Serious points were made about the future of farming, but the diversity of rural life was what the evening celebrated. People think, emailed one country-dweller, "that you just sit making daisy chains and being quaint". Nobody who tuned in to this passionate evening of radio will think that now.

fields.headline: Habes al-Majali
fields.standfirst: As Jordan's military chief, he defeated Israelis, Palestinians and Syrians
fields.trailText: As Jordan's military chief, he defeated Israelis, Palestinians and Syrians.
fields.body:
The Jordanian Field Marshal Habes al-Majali, who has died aged 87, was the only Arab commander to administer military defeats on Israelis, Palestinians and Syrians alike. His baptism of fire came during the first Arab-Israeli war, when he successfully defended the town of Latrun, 17 miles west of Jerusalem.

The Jewish state had declared independence on May 14 1948. The next day, the armies of five Arab nations invaded, among them the Bedouin of Transjordan's crack Arab Legion, under the supreme command of Britain's [Sir John] Glubb Pasha. They immediately secured the West Bank, then rushed to fill the vacuum created by British troops leaving Jerusalem.

Meanwhile, the Zionist Haganah forces were desperate to keep open their lines of communication with the 85,000 besieged Jews of Latrun, the epicentre of the only route linking Tel Aviv with Jerusalem. Lieutenant Colonel Majali, the first Arab to head a legion regiment, occupied a strategic hill straddling the nearby Bab al Wad (Gate to the Valley). His spies fanned the countryside, while he held a deserted British police fort, built near a Trappist monastery in 1936.

When the Haganah attacked on May 25, Majali's Fourth Regiment was ready. Nonetheless, it was a Pyrrhic victory. Despite their losses at Latrun, the Haganah pinned down Jordanian troops who might have been fighting in Jerusalem. The Israelis also managed to build a makeshift bypass round Latrun and siphoned through vital arms, water and supplies. Majali's brigade commander, Colonel Ashton, forbade him from shelling their bulldozers. Ultimately, Jordanian troops, assisted by local Arabs, did capture the Old City and East Jerusalem, but lost West Jerusalem to Israel.

It was in the Old City, three years later, that Habes al- Majali experienced tragedy at first-hand. For two years, he had been the private escort to King Abdullah of Jordan. Then, on July 20 1951, as he was ushering the king to prayers at the Al Aqsa mosque, Abdullah was shot dead by anti-Hashemite Palestinians.

Matters only improved after King Hussein (Obituary, February 8 1999) replaced his father, Talal, in 1953. Three years later, Glubb was dismissed, and, in 1957, Majali became chief-of-staff of the Jordanian armed forces, a post he held until June 1967.

Majalis have long dominated Karak, an Arabian province that joined the Emirate of Transjordan in 1921. Though they originally hailed from Hebron, on the West Bank, they had integrated comfortably into Bedouin society, and resented Palestinian political agitation after 1948. Earlier, and more crucially, they had welcomed Hashemite rule in Jordan.

Thus, as a reward for unswerving loyalty, Majalis have been prime ministers, police chiefs and speakers of the Jordanian national assembly; Habes himself served some 20 years as a senator, including a period on the foreign affairs committee. Nonetheless, he preferred martial matters to diplomatic niceties, and, as his brother-in-law, Hazza, once told the British ambassador in Amman: "We Majalis are used to killing and being killed."

Habes joined the Arab Legion in 1932, and soon impressed Glubb Pasha. Despite acquiring modern skills, he never lost his Bedouin elan. King Hussein's biographer, James Lunt, dubbed him the "grand seigneur" of Karak and "beau sabreur" of the army.

Certainly, King Hussein found him indispensable. He ruthlessly tracked down the Hashemite ruler's Nasserite enemies during the uprising of 1958. In 1960, he restored order after pro-Syrian agents had murdered his cousin, the Jordanian prime minister, Hazaa'. Forced to relinquish overall command to Cairo on the eve of the six-day war in June 1967, and bemused by conflicting orders, he lost the West Bank to Israel. He resigned, but served as defence minister for another year.

Majali's return to active duty was sudden and dramatic. Jordanian-based Palestinian fedayeen (guerrillas) were growing more autonomous and audacious. After terrorists destroyed four international aircraft near army headquarters at al-Zarqa, in September 1970, Hussein declared martial law, re-appointed Majali as commander-in-chief, and ordered him to crush the revolt.

Habes did so with relish. Over 10 days, his troops routed the fedayeen; some 3,500 fighters died on both sides. He also repulsed a pro-PLO Syrian invasion - destroying half the enemy's armour in the process, and inadvertently setting off the coup that brought President al-Assad (Obituary, June 12 2000) to power in Damascus. In July 1971, the remaining PLO units in Jordan were expelled to Lebanon.

Despite these victories, the old warhorse found it hard to forgive old enemies; in 1994, for instance, he boycotted the official ceremonies marking Jordan's peace deal with Israel. fields.headline: The Ven Wallis Thomas
fields.trailText: A man of enormous intellect and charm he continued to preach, and care for, his north Wales flock well into his 90s.
fields.body:
The Venerable Wallis Thomas, who has died at his home in Dolgellau, Gwynedd, aged 93, continued to preach, and care for, his north Wales flock well into his 90s. He was a man of enormous intellect and charm, and while his work rarely took him outside Wales, he travelled extensively in Europe and drew about him a devoted circle of friends from around the world.

Surprisingly, he never climbed the church ladder beyond being Archdeacon of Merioneth, a post he held from 1959-76. So to everyone who knew him, Thomas was "the Arch".

Born to working-class parents in Llanrwst, he was educated at Pwllheli grammar school and University College, Bangor, where he studied French before going to Jesus College, Oxford, to read theology. At Oxford, he considered himself an outsider; he always felt that, as a Welshman, he was not welcome. Yet later, at Barmouth and Dolgellau, he found himself very much the centre of a circle of English incomers. And, despite the prevailing leaning towards the Welsh language, his mother tongue, he chose for the most part to preach in English.

Throughout a long ministry, which began at St David's church, Bangor, in 1931, Wallis Thomas was renowned for his fine sermons and enormous fund of stories. In the early years, he was secretary and chaplain to the Archbishop of Wales, and was responsible for organising a number of bishops' consecrations. He was rector of Barmouth from 1946-66, moving to the tiny hamlet of Llanelltyd, where he was vicar until he officially retired in 1976, when the parish was absorbed into the Dolgellau benefice.

But until a few years ago, he continued to preach regularly, not only in the tiny Llanelltyd church but also in St Mary's, Dolgellau. Even after his 90th birthday, it was not unknown for him to conduct the service, preach and play the organ in Llanelltyd.

To the end, his mind was sharp, although failing hearing frustrated him greatly. Reminiscing on his 90th birthday, he described himself as an inveterate visitor. "I will always believe that a house-going parson makes a church-going people," he said.

Earlier, he had played cricket for north Wales in 1954, and been a reserve for the Welsh hockey team as well as a keen tennis player.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ecstasy death of steward
fields.body:
Ecstasy death of steward

An air steward died after taking 12 ecstasy tablets, four times the fatal level, an inquest in Woking, Surrey, heard yesterday. A verdict of accidental death was recorded on Laela Playford, 22, of Lightwater, Surrey.

Gameshow humiliation

Almost half the population would not go on a gameshow for fear of being humiliated, according to a survey. Most thought they lacked enough general knowledge.

British Gas 'kills off' politician

A shadow foreign affairs minister has been declared "dead" by British Gas, which sent a letter referring to the late Cheryl Gillan, 49.

Immigrants cling to ferry

Four immigrants in a dinghy who clung to the side of a ferry for 20 miles were spotted just before Dover and sent back to Calais. A spokeswoman for Seafrance said: "This shows the lengths people are going to."

Leeson banned from driving

Nick Leeson, the trader who brought down Barings Bank, was yesterday banned from driving for 30 months after admitting drink-driving.

Police seize £5m drug haul

Police in Greater Manchester have seized cocaine, esctasy, amphetamines and skunk cannabis worth £5m on the street.

fields.headline: Judge attacks QC fees as hijack trial bill hits £12m
fields.standfirst:
Pressure grows for court reform after 27 barristers work on one case

Special report: the Stansted hijack
fields.trailText: A high court judge's outspoken attack on the cost to the taxpayer of the 27 barristers in the Afghan plane hijack trial has given the lord chancellor ammunition in his battle with the bar over fees and overmanning.
fields.body:
A high court judge's outspoken attack on the cost to the taxpayer of the 27 barristers in the Afghan plane hijack trial has given the lord chancellor ammunition in his battle with the bar over fees and overmanning.

On Tuesday Mr Justice Butterfield ordered a retrial of the 11 Afghan asylum seekers accused of the Stansted airport hijack after the first trial ended last week with a hung jury at an estimated cost of £12m. But the judge questioned why the taxpayer had funded a separate QC and junior counsel for each of the 12 defendants in the original Old Bailey trial, when some had called no witnesses or evidence and confined themselves to a few questions and a closing speech.

He said he had no power to change the legal aid order for the new trial, but he reminded the barristers that they had a professional duty to keep un der review whether the case merited a QC at all, or whether a QC could do the case alone without a junior.

The judge said Ben Emmerson QC, who represented the first defendant, Ali Safi, could "fully justify doing the case and the assistance of a junior." But he added: "I have grave doubts whether those observations could properly be applied to many others in this case."

Some did little more than take notes. For a four month trial, QCs will probably be paid brief fees of around £50,000 for preparation, with "refreshers" - the fee for each day in court - of around £500. Behind the scenes, judges have been expressing concern for years about overmanning and the high level of QCs' fees in long criminal trials and child care cases.

Occasionally they express their exasperation in court or in a written judgment. In a judgment given in private in 1992, a high court judge, Sir Alan Ward (now an appeal court judge) described the £1m cost of a case with 11 barristers as a scandal, adding: "It cannot be allowed to happen again, the public purse cannot stand it."

In 1998 the House of Lords called four QCs and five junior barristers to account over fee claims of up to £416 an hour. Last January the courts ordered four criminal QCs to hand back £90,000 in legal aid fees. The lord chancellor has also passed on to the Bar Council the names of more than 100 barristers reported by the courts for overcharging.

All have had their legal aid bills cut by at least 50% in the last two years. For cases lasting more than five weeks, barristers submit bills after the trial, which are assessed by costs judges.

The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, plans to abolish these after-the-event assessments, and put barristers on contracts with set fees. He plans to reduce QCs' refreshers - which can be £1,000 a day or more for fraud trials - to £455 for fraud cases and £415 for other cases, and hourly rates for work outside court - now around £300 - to £125 for fraud and £105 for other cases.

But the bar is fighting back and its chairman, Roy Amlot QC, told Lord Irvine in a letter last month: "The rates that are proposed to be paid to advocates remain far too severe a reduction from what has previously been regarded as reasonable remuneration for these cases.

"I regret that so little regard appears to have been taken of our repeated representations."

The lord chancellor has also introduced regulations aimed at limiting the number of cases in which legal aid will pay for two defence barristers or for a QC.

The rules are intended to ensure that more QCs work alone without a junior, and that more cases are handled by junior barristers alone.

fields.headline: MoD defends operations
fields.trailText: Several soldiers have had breast enlargement operations in a military hospital but the Ministry of Defence insisted yesterday that they were in the "public interest", and not just a "cosmetic or vanity thing".
fields.body:
Several soldiers have had breast enlargement operations in a military hospital but the Ministry of Defence insisted yesterday that they were in the "public interest", and not just a "cosmetic or vanity thing".

The implants were only given to servicewomen who had developed a "recurring and chronic psychological difficulty" preventing them from being effective soldiers and after counselling had failed, the MoD spokesman said.

The cost of an operation, between £2,000 and £2,500, compared with the thousands of pounds training the soldiers in the "service of the country", he said. "We are not treating our servicewomen any differently than they would be treated as civilians by the NHS," he added.

The operations were carried out in Haslar military hospital in Portsmouth. Up to 12 soldiers had had their breasts enlarged since the mid 1990s. Some may have been operated on in military wards at NHS hospitals.

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said the state of affairs brought a new meaning to the phrase "second front". He added: "This is happening at a time when money is short in the armed forces."

fields.headline: Prescription for protest
fields.trailText: You rightly write that GPs' enthusiasm with the NHS reforms has evaporated and identify the unrealistic pace of change as one reason (Leader, April 24).
fields.body:
You rightly write that GPs' enthusiasm with the NHS reforms has evaporated and identify the unrealistic pace of change as one reason (Leader, April 24). But your attempt to put protests planned for May 1 down to a "readership war" between the medical weeklies suggests you have fallen for some classic spin doctoring from the Department of Health.

Contrary to your assertion that the GP press is "each trying to outbid the other in criticism of the BMA's leadership", Doctor magazine's priority is reporting on the concerns of grassroots GPs.

The idea for a May 1 protest came from Oxfordshire GP Dr Dick Mann, who believed doctors needed to set a day aside in order to catch up on the mountain of target-related paperwork they have no time to address during an average hectic day treating patients. He came forward after results of our morale survey were published, revealing more than eight in 10 GPs would quit the NHS if they could.

Since then more than 1,000 practices have pledged their support for a May 1 day of protest. Many plan to take action, closing surgeries, telling patients why they can't deliver government targets overnight, and writing to local MPs.

Doctor makes no apologies for gaining national attention for the plight of GPs, nor for capturing the militant mood of the profession ahead of the British Medical Association, which has now decided to ballot all 36,000 GPs over mass resignation.
Phil Johnson
Editor, Doctor

 Your argument was brought down by your comment on the NHS staff - "They need to have a sense of ownership". Stuff that. Sense of ownership is a con trick borrowed from pop psychology and used frequently by NHS managers to hide the unpalatable truth that both they and the "managed" have no real ownership at all of the system or process.

As an ex-GP forced out by work-induced depression and limiting my comments to the GP system, I say look at Canadian Medicare which has no management structure at all for GPs. My impression is that it works at least as well, it is certainly much cheaper to administer, there are fewer GPs seriously ill with work-induced mental problems and the results are as good, if not better, than our NHS. I'm packing for my next trip to Canada where I can happily work hard as a locum GP but get the heebie-jeebies when I contemplate same in the NHS.
Declan Fox
Newtownstewart, Co Tyrone declan@boksone.freeserve.co.uk

As one who was recently discharged, after emergency admission, from Addenbrooke's NHS Trust, still with a not fully diagnosed condition, to wait six weeks for an outpatient appointment, I think lists of "top" hospitals (Best in NHS is doing well says hospital survey team, April 25) may serve the needs of health professionals for a pat on the back, but are meaningless to patients. Far from feeling that my needs for a clear diagnosis were "focused on" or that I was in a place "well managed", I had the impression that here was a hospital at the very limits of its capacity, throwing me out into an equally overstretched outpatient system.
Annemarie Snodgrass
Cambridge

Liam Fox's pre-election pledge to fund a single dose measles vaccine "to increase the inoculation rate" is misguided (MMR policy risks children's lives, claim Tories, April 25). Splitting up the MMR vaccine into three would mean three injection visits for each child, resulting most likely in lower, not higher, rates of protection against these diseases.
Prof Adam Finn
University of Bristol

Annemarie Snodgrass Cambridge Liam Fox's pre-election pledge to fund a single dose measles vaccine "to increase the inoculation rate" is misguided (MMR policy risks children's lives, claim Tories, April 25). Splitting up the MMR vaccine into three would mean three injection visits for each child, resulting most likely in lower, not higher, rates of protection against these diseases. Prof Adam Finn University of Bristol

fields.headline: Defending the police
fields.trailText: I am writing to express my anger about the way in which Superintendent Dick Crawshaw was portrayed in an article about racial tension in the Oldham area ('No go for whites' in race hotspot, April 20).
fields.body:
I am writing to express my anger about the way in which Superintendent Dick Crawshaw was portrayed in an article about racial tension in the Oldham area ('No go for whites' in race hotspot, April 20).

We believe that his personal reputation and standing has been both undermined and damaged as a result of the article.

Supt Crawshaw agreed to be interviewed by Matt Keating and Abigail Etim on April 19, in response to the Today programme on Radio 4 that morning. He had done a number of other interviews on the same subject that day.

Among other things, Supt Crawshaw talked at length about his community involvement in and around Oldham and in particular Glodwick, where he is a school governor. He also told the reporters of his long-standing association with the town and his dismay that the media are never interested in reporting "the good news about the town".

We were extremely angry to read that - according to your reporters - Supt Crawshaw "reciprocated the ill-feeling" expressed by one local youth.

Let me be clear about this. Supt Crawshaw has lived in Oldham since 1960 and is a very well respected and valued member of the community. He has never had any ill-feelings towards the community and indeed has a great deal of affection for the people of the town.

Like most other community members, however, he does abhor the actions of a minority element who seek to create areas where others are "not welcome" or feel threatened.
Sarah Dean Forrester
Head of press office, Greater Manchester Police

webTitle: Letters: Hard hearts softened by the thought of calves' liver

fields.headline: Hard hearts softened by the thought of calves' liver
fields.trailText: The lives of many thousands of animals have possibly been saved by Phoenix the calf, whose story has apparently aroused the passions of a hitherto indifferent nation (Policy change after public outcry, April 26).
fields.body:
The lives of many thousands of animals have possibly been saved by Phoenix the calf, whose story has apparently aroused the passions of a hitherto indifferent nation (Policy change after public outcry, April 26).

Six years ago, angry protests by animal welfare campaigners trying to stop the export of thousands of similar calves to European veal-crates received scant support from the general public, while dairy farmers contemptuously dismissed the protesters as "bunny-huggers" who have no idea of what farming is all about.

Since the end of the calf processing aid scheme, under which farmers received compensation for the slaughter and incineration of their unwanted (ie unprofitable) male calves, farmers have been shooting or otherwise killing some 600,000 newly-born male calves every year, as these animals are considered nothing more than an unsaleable and embarrassing waste product of the milk production industry.

Perhaps more consumers in this animal-loving country will now realise some of the horrors which lie behind the production of meat and the milk on their cornflakes?
Peter Allen
Worthing, West Sussex

 Touched as I am by the coy photo of Phoenix, and inspired by the integrity of all those tofu-munching, animal rights campaigning Sun readers, I cannot for the life of me stop thinking about Antonio Carluccio's splendid recipe for calves' liver with balsamic sauce. Or the suggested accompaniment of sauté potatoes with rosemary and garlic.
Bill Hawkes
Whitstable, Kent

 The decision to save Phoenix from slaughter has to be one of the most blatant examples of cynical electioneering ever. It goes without saying that at any other time the calf would be veal by now.
Mark Walker
London
mwalker2@dircon.co.uk

 Now I understand what is meant by the phrase "making policy on the hoof".
Graham Maughan
Henley-on-Thames, Oxon
gm@cyrusmedia.co.uk

 Contrary to your claims (Campaigners warn of lasting dangers, April 23) there is no verified evidence that foot and mouth disease has spread to wild deer. All tests from suspect cases have been negative. The Elisa test is not the only one used and there are no doubts about accuracy.

The Pirbright Animal Health Institute tests on deer in the 70s showed that although they can contract the disease none of the species tested became carriers. Wild deer present little risk of spreading the disease. There is no current reason for a deer cull. While there is a perfectly sound scientific case for selective vaccination, this particular issue is irrelevant to it.
Elliot Morley MP
Ministry of Agriculture

fields.headline: Contracts made clear
fields.trailText: The article (Dirty deeds on the high seas, April 25) reports in relation to the Type 45 destroyer programme that: "the Vosper board rejected an agreed structure, process and price for the contract and put in a higher take-it-or-leave-it price". This comes as something of a surprise to the VT board! We have issued no such rejection.
fields.body:
The article (Dirty deeds on the high seas, April 25) reports in relation to the Type 45 destroyer programme that: "the Vosper board rejected an agreed structure, process and price for the contract and put in a higher take-it-or-leave-it price". This comes as something of a surprise to the VT board! We have issued no such rejection.

Vosper Thornycroft (VT) has only ever submitted prices to build the ship platform for the first batch of three Type 45s, as part of a joint alliance bid with BAE Marine. The alliance itself embodied a structure and process agreed between BAE Systems as prime contractor, BAE Marine and VT, to give effect to the competitive procurement strategy announced by government ministers last July. This requires BAE Marine and VT to share the work on the first batch to ensure that there is fair and effective competition for the remaining ships.

VT has never issued take-it-or-leave it ultimatums.
John Wakeham
Chairman, Vosper Thornycroft UK

webTitle: Letters: Coins of a magic realm

fields.headline: Coins of a magic realm
fields.trailText: Talk about jam tomorrow (Children to share in £1bn Labour giveaway, April 26)! To reach even the lower level of the projected benefit in 18 years (£5,000) implies a compound interest rate of 13%. I've got a pocket full of hot zlotys ready to lump on any investment showing this sort of return - show me the way.
fields.body:
Talk about jam tomorrow (Children to share in £1bn Labour giveaway, April 26)! To reach even the lower level of the projected benefit in 18 years (£5,000) implies a compound interest rate of 13%. I've got a pocket full of hot zlotys ready to lump on any investment showing this sort of return - show me the way.

They'll be lucky to get £3,000 if the money is invested in that great betting shop colloquially known as the Stock Exchange. Assuming general inflation remains at a modest 2%, then in 18 years £3,000 will be worth just over £2,000 at today's prices. A nice birthday piss-up but as a contribution to income redistribution - I don't think so. Bill Willoughby
Croydon, Surrey
bill_willoughby@lineone.net

 If the government's foremost priority is supposedly "education, education, education", can someone explain why David Blunkett's "widely expected" move to the home secretaryship (After the election, April 26) is a promotion?
Paul Clein
Liverpool

 I completed my census form in less than 10 minutes, yet hundreds of thousands are phoning the census hotline with problems and queries. I am worried. Do they not know something that I do?
T Hall
Manchester

fields.headline: Corelli under fire again
fields.trailText: I enjoyed the critique by Seumas Milne (Corelli's curiosity, April 25) of the many historical inaccuracies contained in Captain Corelli's Mandolin. Louis de Bernieres is not the only one to regret that he has written the book in the first place.
fields.body:
I enjoyed the critique by Seumas Milne (Corelli's curiosity, April 25) of the many historical inaccuracies contained in Captain Corelli's Mandolin. Louis de Bernieres is not the only one to regret that he has written the book in the first place. I am sure that the book makes for a wonderful film (how could it not, given the location?), but what I have found puzzling, in all its broadsheet coverage, is that nobody seems to have commented on what a truly awful novel de Bernieres has produced.

Sure, it has a cracking plot (almost incredible, had it not been lifted from the real-life story of Amos Pampaloni), but what a delivery: pedes trian, hectoring, cumbersome, painstakingly (and of course inaccurately) didactic, the book is at least a third too long. Other recently written war-time romances such as, say, Moon Tiger or The English Patient, are models of economy and inventiveness by comparison, and yet de Bernieres escapes scot-free over the quality of his writing.

I've bored friends for several years now on how Captain Corelli's Mandolin is quite the worst novel I have ever read; however, a colleague recently lent me something by Jeffrey Archer...
Alasdair MacDonald
Malmesbury, Wiltshire

webTitle: Comment: Monet's grainstack series -  an enduring masterpiece

fields.headline: Like lurid cupcakes in a slanting light
fields.trailText: The grainstacks are lurid cupcakes in slanting light. The stacks themselves were particularly suited to Monet's late impressionist approach, in that the surfaces of these great, rounded forms, and the way their surfaces trap and scatter light and shadow, was undoubtedly of as much interest to him as the splendid shapes themselves.
fields.body:
The grainstacks are lurid cupcakes in slanting light. The stacks themselves were particularly suited to Monet's late impressionist approach, in that the surfaces of these great, rounded forms, and the way their surfaces trap and scatter light and shadow, was undoubtedly of as much interest to him as the splendid shapes themselves.

The lumpy silhouettes of the stacks, mussed up by stray stalks, become indeterminate, glowing penumbras. Monet painted these shaggy, robust forms with a wonderful sense of the stuff that composed them, using an extraordinary variety of brushstrokes.

Everything about these paintings - the stubbly, churned earth, even the sky - appears granular, turned and forked-over. Rhythms come and go in the paintwork, recalling the repetitive labour that built the stacks, as well as the painter's own efforts to record them. The texture of the world, and of the light, are as one. And as much as light reveals his subjects, it destroys them.

More than this, the haystacks, sometimes seen singly, sometimes in groups, are fantastic sculptural presences. They lower and glow, they stand alone in a winter sunset, they march across the painting, casting long autumnal shadows. It would be a mistake, however, to imagine that Monet painted these works entirely on the spot. Their apparent spontaneity, their freshness, was manufactured in the studio, the work of months. It is as if he had to reinvent the haunting presence of the grainstacks, the particular light, out of what critics at the time called "the chaos of palette-scrapings".

Monet found it hard to let go of them. He began this series in 1888, and by February 1891, there were 25 canvases.

It would be marvellous to see them all together, as Monet must have done in his studio. This is where their meaning lies. The importance of the grainstacks and the series of paintings of the facade of Rouen cathedral which followed them, lies in the fact that they are sequential views and variations, however singular the individual paintings are.

The very idea of series and of repetition has had far-reaching consequences over the past 100 years. However much the stacks recall pre-mechanised farm labour, they prefigure industrial forms and mass production.

Think of the repetition in Mondrian, in minimal sculpture, in Andy Warhol's Brillo boxes and multiple silk-screens. The example of Monet's great series, which for me are fugues on the passing of time, stands before them.

Related story
Great impressionist's blaze of glory
